title: Introduction
body_one:
Talking with a local expert is a great way to learn about a place! A local guide can take you places that other people might not go. A local can share their favorite things. A local can introduce you to their friends and family. A local can give you a unique look into the daily life of a community.



Over the next six weeks, you and your PenPals will become World Explorers! You will learn about communities all over the world.


You will share your experiences and learn from others. You will discover different cultures and lifestyles. You may even be surprised by how much we all have in common.


Week 1: Daily Life


First you will learn and talk about daily life. You will learn about the things people do for fun. You will discuss family, work, and education around the world.



Week 2: Food


Next, you and your PenPals will talk about food. You will discuss the foods you, your friends, and your family like to eat.



Week 3: History


Third, you and your PenPals will talk about history. You will learn about famous explorers, inventors, and ancient civilizations.



Week 4: Art & Literature


In Week 4, you and your PenPals will learn about art and literature. You will discuss paintings and learn about famous buildings. Then, you will learn about musicians and authors.



Week 5: Popular Culture


This week you and your PenPals will study popular culture. You will learn about famous athletes, movie stars, and musicians. You will discuss the videos games, mobile apps, and fashion trends that are popular in your communities.



Week 6: Reflection


In the final week, you and your PenPals will reflect on the previous weeks. You will think about your PenPals’ communities and reflect on what you learned during the course.



How to be a Great PenPal


Being a great PenPal starts with respect. Your PenPals are students just like you. Sometimes, you and your PenPals might agree. Sometimes, you and your PenPals might disagree.


Show respect by writing every week. Also show respect by using appropriate language. If your PenPal has a question, make sure to help.



If your PenPals say something that you don’t agree with, ask your PenPals a question about what they said. If your PenPal writes something inappropriate, report the message and our team will reviewed it.



Write to Your Future PenPals


Soon you will be matched with PenPals! So let’s get ready by answering this week’s discussion question! Scroll to the top of the page. There you will find the discussion question on the right.



Each week, answer the weekly discussion question.


After you answer this week’s discussion question, use the chat section underneath to tell your future PenPals about yourself. Then ask your PenPals some questions about their communities.
body_two:
There is no better way to learn about a place than by talking with a local expert! When traveling the world, a local guide can take you places that others might not think to go. A local can share their tastes and preferences, introduce you to friends and family, and give you a unique look into daily life in a different community.



Over the next six weeks, you and your PenPals will take part in the World Explorer course on PenPal Schools. You will learn about communities all over the world and share perspectives unique to life in your own community. You’ll discover a variety of different cultures and lifestyles, but you may also be surprised by how much we all have in common.


Week 1: Daily Life


You will begin your PenPal exchange by learning and talking about daily life. You and your PenPals will learn about the the growth of cities and the lifestyles unique to urban and rural communities. You will learn about recreational activities, family structure, and the types of jobs that people have all over the world.


Week 2: Food


Be sure to save your appetite for Week 2 when you and your PenPals will talk about food. You will study how food can tell us the history of a place. You will learn about favorite dishes and compare restaurant culture around the world. Prepare for this week by paying close attention to what foods you, your friends, and your family like to eat.


Week 3: History


Next, you and your PenPals will take a step back in time to talk about the history of your communities. During Week 3, you will learn about famous explorers, inventors, and the leaders who have shaped the world we live in today.


Week 4: Art & Literature


In Week 4 you will explore art and literature. Don’t worry, you won’t just discuss famous paintings and sculptures. This week’s lesson will help you discover the architects who design famous buildings, the musicians who perform your favorite songs, and the authors whose books have take you on adventures. Perhaps your PenPal will help you discover a new and interesting artist during Week 4!


Week 5: Popular Culture


As you study popular culture, you and your PenPals will discuss what exactly it takes to become famous. You’ll learn about famous athletes, movie stars, and musicians. You will compare and contrast videos games, mobile apps, social media, and fashion trends that are popular in each of your communities.


Week 6: Reflection


During the last week of your PenPal exchange, you and your PenPals will reflect on the previous five weeks. You’ll have the chance to think about your PenPals’ communities and reflect on what you learned during the course. You just might realize that you and your PenPals live in communities that are more similar than you previously thought!


How to be a Great PenPal


You are about to join thousands of students from more than one hundred different countries who are learning and sharing perspectives with PenPals from around the world!


Being a great PenPal starts with respect. Your PenPals are students just like you, so remember to always be respectful of them and their opinions! Write to your PenPals every week, use appropriate language, and help your PenPals when they have questions.



It's ok to disagree with your PenPals as long as you are polite. If your PenPals say something that you don’t agree with, ask your PenPals to explain their thinking. Remember, if your PenPal writes something inappropriate, flag the message and it will be reviewed by your teacher and the PenPal Schools team.



Write to Your Future PenPals


So let’s get ready for your PenPal exchange by answering this week’s discussion question! Scroll to the top of the page and find the discussion question on the right side. Make sure to refer to the text and video when answering the question.



Each week, answer the weekly discussion question.


After you answer this week’s discussion question, use the chat section underneath to tell your future PenPals about yourself. Then ask your PenPals some questions about their communities.


Once matched, your PenPals can read and reply to your answers so you’ll already have something to talk about!

title: The Great Barrier Reef Is Under Attack
body_one:
Warm water temperatures have bleached coral off the Australian coast.


By Justin Worland for TIME, adapted by TFK editors

April 25, 2016


The Great Barrier Reef is more than worthy of its name. It covers more than 130,000 square miles off the coast of Australia. The reef is home to corals of all shapes, sizes, and colors. It is the world’s largest reef system. It supports an astounding variety of marine life.


DANIELA DIRSCHERL—GETTY IMAGES


Scientists say countries around the world will have to work together to reduce threats to the Great Barrier Reef.


But today the Great Barrier Reef is dying. A major El Niño event has caused temporary warming. That has combined with ongoing climate change. Together, they have heated the waters around the reef to nearly unprecedented levels. That warming has driven a mass bleaching. It has sucked the color—and the life—out of the coral. And the Great Barrier Reef isn’t alone. “This is the longest bleaching event ever recorded,” says David Kline. He is a Scripps Institution of Oceanography scientist. “It’s truly global. And it’s … very severe.”


Bleaching occurs because of ocean disruptions. They include warm water, pollution, and algae overgrowth. These disruptions drive away the symbiotic organisms that live on the coral. Such organisms give coral its color. Within weeks, the reef could die. Left behind would be a forest of lifeless, bone-white coral. Scientists believe the bleaching now under way may kill more than 15% of the world’s coral.


A Great Loss

It’s not just a matter of beauty. Reefs act as natural barriers. They protect coastal communities from storms and flooding. Marine life depends on coral reefs as habitats. Coastal towns depend on them as tourist attractions.


But a bigger worry may be what the bleaching suggests about future climate change. The rapid death of a coral reef is evidence that climate change is irreversibly affecting the world right now. Meanwhile, many policy makers are treating warming as something to be dealt with in the future. “Climate change may be slow-creeping sometimes. But other times, it takes great leaps forward,” says Steve Palumbi, an ocean scientist at Stanford University. “This is one of those leaps.”


ANDREW WATSON—GETTY IMAGES


Coastal towns, like Airlie Beach in Australia, depend on coral reefs to attract tourists.


Local solutions can slow reef loss. Examples include reducing fishing and cleaning up pollution. But scientists say a global problem requires a global solution. Nearly 200 countries agreed last year to work to keep global temperatures from rising more than 3.6°F by 2100. That goal will be tough to achieve. And if governments fail, coral reefs will be only the first victims.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

astounding

adjective: causing a feeling of great surprise or wonder

El Niño

a naturally occurring weather event in which a warming of the central Pacific Ocean interacts with the atmosphere, causing a change in weather across the globe. This year’s El Niño has tied with the one in 1997–1998 as the strongest on record, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

unprecedented

adjective: never done or experienced before

symbiotic

adjective: living together and depending on each other

title: Poverty in the United States
body_one:
7 Kids, 1 Apartment: What Poverty Means To This Teen


Seventeen-year-old Jairo Gomez lives in a one-bedroom apartment with eight other family members. Emily Kwong/WNYC


Jairo Gomez is 17 years old and lives in a tiny apartment in New York City with eight other family members. He has grown up in poverty, like one-third of all kids in the city. This is the story of how poverty has held him back, and how he's trying to overcome it.


There are nine of us in my family, and we live in a one-bedroom apartment. I share a bunk bed with my sister Judy.


"It's just so stuffed," Judy says. "We don't have enough space for seven kids."


On the floor we have two mattresses side by side, where three of my other sisters sleep. You have to step toe to heel to get out of the room.


"All we actually need is like a big closet," Judy laughs.  “My mom, step-dad and the two youngest ones sleep in the living room.”


My mom cleans other people's houses. When she gets home, she keeps on cleaning and takes care of my sisters and brother.  I used to think of my family as middle class, but after my parents split up, my mom had four more kids.


"The truth is I haven't looked it up in the dictionary, the word 'poor,' " says my mom, who speaks only Spanish. "To me, poor is when you don't have enough for soup or a roll of toilet paper."


During my freshman year in high school, I wore ripped jeans, and my sneakers had holes in them. It was kind of embarrassing, but I still didn't think I was poor.  


I asked my mom to do the math, and she said right now, my family makes $30,000 a year. According to the federal government, we're $15,000 below the poverty line.  That kind of scares me. I've seen articles posted on Facebook about how unlikely it is to get out of poverty, how poor people usually stay poor. If I don't get an education, I'll be stuck like my parents.


But I haven't always been able to make school my priority. When I was younger, I felt like a robot. All I did was go home and help baby-sit and clean. I never had that freedom before — to be able to hang out and skate with my friends. So in ninth grade, I started cutting school every day.


Then, when I was in the 10th grade, for the second time my mom started asking me if I could stay home from school to watch the kids. If I said no, most of the money she would make would go to a baby sitter.


I failed every class that year. That made me finally realize that if I ever wanted to graduate, I needed to be in school. I switched to a transfer school, and my first trimester, I got perfect attendance. I told my mom I wasn't going to take care of the little ones anymore.


Sometimes I feel like I blame my mom too much for having more kids than she could afford.  She's always telling us we're lucky because we'll have each other to go to. But when we still had two of our sisters in diapers, and the pregnancy tests came out positive again and again, Judy, Sarahi and I were like, "I'm not washing the bottles this time."


i

Because he's often babysitting his younger siblings and trying to keep his grades up, Jairo hardly has any time to do what he loves — skateboarding. Emily Kwong/WNYC


It gets me mad that my mom works so hard. And there are people out there who are just born into it. They make money like nothing. They don't have to clean houses, wake up early, drain themselves.


I know I should be thinking about going to college when I graduate if I don't want that life, but I'd have to stay at home to afford it. Nine of us in a one-bedroom apartment, no privacy, one bathroom and toys everywhere. I don't know if I can make myself do it.


Now I'm working 13-hour shifts, making food deliveries on a bike. Honestly, I'd rather do that and earn money for my own place. We're told, "If you work hard, you'll get results." But for my family, there haven't been any results — just survival.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

Attendance

(noun) the action or state of going regularly to or being present at a place or event

Poverty

(noun) the state of being extremely poor

Priority

(noun) a thing that is regarded as more important than another

Trimester

(noun) in North America, each of the three terms in an academic year split into three parts

View the Original Article from NPR
body_two:
7 Kids, 1 Apartment: What Poverty Means To This Teen


Seventeen-year-old Jairo Gomez lives in a one-bedroom apartment with eight other family members. His school attendance has suffered because he often has to stay home to babysit his younger siblings. Emily Kwong/WNYC


Jairo Gomez is 17 years old and lives in a tiny apartment in New York City with eight other family members. He has grown up in poverty, like one-third of all kids in the city. This is the story of how poverty has held him back, and how he's trying to overcome it.


There are nine of us in my family, and we live in a one-bedroom apartment. I share a bunk bed with my sister Judy.


"It's just so stuffed," Judy says. "We don't have enough space for seven kids."


On the floor we have two mattresses side by side, where three of my other sisters sleep. You have to step toe to heel to get out of the room.


"All we actually need is like a big closet," Judy laughs.  “My mom, step-dad and the two youngest ones sleep in the living room.”


My mom cleans other people's houses. When she gets home, she keeps on cleaning and takes care of my sisters and brother.  I used to think of my family as middle class, but after my parents split up, my mom had four more kids.


"The truth is I haven't looked it up in the dictionary, the word 'poor,' " says my mom, who speaks only Spanish. "To me, poor is when you don't have enough for soup or a roll of toilet paper."


During my freshman year in high school, I wore ripped jeans, and my sneakers had holes in them. It was kind of embarrassing, but I still didn't think I was poor.  I asked my mom to do the math, and she said right now, my family makes $30,000 a year. According to the federal government, we're $15,000 below the poverty line.  That kind of scares me. I've seen articles posted on Facebook about how unlikely it is to get out of poverty, how poor people usually stay poor. If I don't get an education, I'll be stuck like my parents.


But I haven't always been able to make school my priority. When I was younger, I felt like a robot. All I did was go home and help baby-sit and clean. I never had that freedom before — to be able to hang out and skate with my friends. So in ninth grade, I started cutting every day.


Then, when I was in the 10th grade, for the second time my mom started asking me if I could stay home from school to watch the kids. If I said no, most of the money she would make would go to a baby sitter.


I failed every class that year. That made me finally realize that if I ever wanted to graduate, I needed to be in school. I switched to a transfer school, and my first trimester, I got perfect attendance. I told my mom I wasn't going to take care of the little ones anymore.


"At first I felt annoyed, like, 'How could this kid dare to say that to me?' " my mom says, "when I feel that I try my best to give what's necessary. But then I thought about it, and I thought, 'Maybe I'm not doing my job right. I'm not providing enough.' "


Hearing her say that makes me feel selfish, especially since now my sisters are stuck at home every day.


"Sometimes I wish, like, yeah, you would stay home and, like, help," Judy says.


Judy is 14. She and my older sister, Sarahi, who is in college, are always home baby-sitting, cleaning up after my little sisters and helping feed them.


"I don't want to put this all on Mom," Judy says.


Sometimes I feel like I blame my mom too much for having more kids than she could afford.  She's always telling us we're lucky because we'll have each other to go to. But when we still had two of our sisters in diapers, and the pregnancy tests came out positive again and again, Judy, Sarahi and I were like, "I'm not washing the bottles this time."


i

Because he's often babysitting his younger siblings and trying to keep his grades up, Jairo hardly has any time to do what he loves — skateboarding. Emily Kwong/WNYC


I asked my mom why she had so many of us.


"With each pregnancy, I accepted it and let it happen," she says. "And I felt happy, but I never thought, 'This son I'm gonna have, I'm gonna educate and motivate to become a doctor, or this daughter I'm going to have I'm gonna motivate to become a lawyer.'


"The job of the mother is to feed and clothe them, to give them love, when maybe I didn't have time to give them each enough love," she adds.


It gets me mad that my mom works so hard. And there are people out there who are just born into it. They make money like nothing. They don't have to clean houses, wake up early, drain themselves.


I know I should be thinking about going to college when I graduate if I don't want that life, but I'd have to stay at home to afford it. Nine of us in a one-bedroom apartment, no privacy, one bathroom and toys everywhere. I don't know if I can make myself do it.


Now I'm working 13-hour shifts, making food deliveries on a bike. Honestly, I'd rather do that and earn money for my own place. We're told, "If you work hard, you'll get results." But for my family, there haven't been any results — just survival.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

Attendance

(noun) the action or state of going regularly to or being present at a place or event

Poverty

(noun) the state of being extremely poor

Priority

(noun) a thing that is regarded as more important than another

Trimester

(noun) in North America, each of the three terms in an academic year split into three parts

View the Original Article from NPR

I failed every class that year. That made me finally realize that if I ever wanted to graduate, I needed to be in school. I switched to a transfer school, and my first trimester, I got perfect attendance. I told my mom I wasn't going to take care of the little ones anymore.


"At first I felt annoyed, like, 'How could this kid dare to say that to me?' " my mom says, "when I feel that I try my best to give what's necessary. But then I thought about it, and I thought, 'Maybe I'm not doing my job right. I'm not providing enough.' "


Hearing her say that makes me feel selfish, especially since now my sisters are stuck at home every day.


"Sometimes I wish, like, yeah, you would stay home and, like, help," Judy says.


Judy is 14. She and my older sister, Sarahi, who is in college, are always home baby-sitting, cleaning up after my little sisters and helping feed them.


"I don't want to put this all on Mom," Judy says.


Sometimes I feel like I blame my mom too much for having more kids than she could afford.  She's always telling us we're lucky because we'll have each other to go to. But when we still had two of our sisters in diapers, and the pregnancy tests came out positive again and again, Judy, Sarahi and I were like, "I'm not washing the bottles this time."


i

Because he's often babysitting his younger siblings and trying to keep his grades up, Jairo hardly has any time to do what he loves — skateboarding. Emily Kwong/WNYC


I asked my mom why she had so many of us.


"With each pregnancy, I accepted it and let it happen," she says. "And I felt happy, but I never thought, 'This son I'm gonna have, I'm gonna educate and motivate to become a doctor, or this daughter I'm going to have I'm gonna motivate to become a lawyer.'


"The job of the mother is to feed and clothe them, to give them love, when maybe I didn't have time to give them each enough love," she adds.


It gets me mad that my mom works so hard. And there are people out there who are just born into it. They make money like nothing. They don't have to clean houses, wake up early, drain themselves.


I know I should be thinking about going to college when I graduate if I don't want that life, but I'd have to stay at home to afford it. Nine of us in a one-bedroom apartment, no privacy, one bathroom and toys everywhere. I don't know if I can make myself do it.


Now I'm working 13-hour shifts, making food deliveries on a bike. Honestly, I'd rather do that and earn money for my own place. We're told, "If you work hard, you'll get results." But for my family, there haven't been any results — just survival.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

Attendance

(noun) the action or state of going regularly to or being present at a place or event

Poverty

(noun) the state of being extremely poor

Priority

(noun) a thing that is regarded as more important than another

Trimester

(noun) in North America, each of the three terms in an academic year split into three parts

View the Original Article from NPR

title: Home Is Where You Find It
body_one:
Watch the film HOME IS WHERE YOU FIND IT to learn the story of Alcides Soares. Alcides is a young boy in Mozambique, Africa who is on a journey to find his brother and create a new sense of family. After the film, read the article below to review Alcides story, learn about his home country, Mozambique, and discover ways that you and your PenPals can help people like Alcides. As you explore his story, share your reactions with your PenPals and talk about ways family, disease, and poverty impact people in your community.




Alcides Soares is a 16 year old boy who lives in Mozambique. Alcides is one of the 500,000 children in Mozambique who has lost both parents to AIDS. Alcides had the chance to create a film with special mentors.


These mentors helped Alcides learn how to use a camera. They also helped Alcides learn to direct and edit film. In Home is Where You Find it, Alcides tells his courageous story through film.



Home Is Where You Find It was directed and narrated by Alcides. The film shows how AIDS has made life difficult for young people in Mozambique. Home Is Where You Find It shows the issue from Alcides’ point of view.


Alcides invites us to share his world.  He creates a new sense of family with friends and siblings. His film helps us understand the impact of AIDS.





Mozambique is one of the world’s poorest countries. Many of the people who live in Mozambique live on less than US$1.25 a day. Many of these people don't have access to safe water, hospitals, or schools.


Many people in Mozambique depend on farming. Farmers and fishers often have just enough food to feed their families.


The roads are in poor condition. Only about 60 per cent of rural people have access to safe water. While conditions in Mozambique have improved over the past decade, there is still much work to do.





AIDS-related diseases are  a major cause of death among children in Mozambique.  


Many children with the HIV infection in Mozambique do not gain weight or grow as normal children do. Children with HIV often do not have access to nutritious foods. Many of these children are not aware of nutritious eating habits or cannot buy healthy foods. Without access to nutritious foods, children with HIV will likely remain sick and die.


Children living with HIV suffer many of the usual childhood infections and illnesses. Children living with HIV have stronger reactions to common illnesses. When a child living with HIV gets sick, common illnesses can cause seizures, fever, and colds. When this happens, these children often need medical attention.


In  Mozambique, there are not enough doctors and medical facilities. This makes treating children with HIV or AIDS even harder.



Word

Definition

AIDS

(noun) a disease of the immune system. The disease is passed primarily through blood

direct

(verb) to manage a project such as the creation of a film

edit

(edit) to make changes or corrections

mentor

(noun) an experienced and trusted advisor

narrate

(verb) to provide spoken commentary

nutritious

(adj) quality of healthy things that help you grow

point of view

(noun) the perspective from which a story is told
body_two:
Watch the film HOME IS WHERE YOU FIND IT to learn the story of Alcides Soares, a young boy in Mozambique, Africa who is on a journey to find his brother and create a new sense of family. Then, read the article below to review Alcides story, learn about his home country, Mozambique, and discover ways that you and your PenPals can take action to support people like Alcides. As you explore his story, share your reactions with your PenPals and talk about ways family, disease, and poverty impact people in your community.




Alcides Soares, 16 years old, is one of the 500,000 children in Mozambique who has lost a parent to AIDS. Alcides had the chance to create his films thanks to some special mentors. Alcides worked with television producer Neal Baer from Law & Order: SVU. He also worked with Sundance Grand Jury Prize winner Chris Zalla. Baer and Zalla helped Alcides learn how to use a camera. They also helped Alcides learn to direct and edit film. Baer and Zalla worked together to help Alcides tell his courageous story through film.



Home Is Where You Find It was both directed and narrated by Alcides himself. The film shows the ravages of AIDS for a whole generation of young people in Mozambique. Home Is Where You Find It shows the issue from a point of view rarely seen by mainstream media.


Alcides brings us into his world. He tries to create a new sense of family with his friends and siblings. His film is a valuable tool for understanding the deeper social and economic effects of AIDS.





Mozambique is one of the world’s poorest countries. Most of Mozambique's rural population live on less than US$1.25 a day. Many of these people lack access to safe water, health facilities and schools.


While conditions in Mozambique have improved over the past decade, there is still much work to do. Many people in Mozambique, especially the country’s rural areas, depend on agriculture and farming. Farmers and fishers generally make just enough to feed their families. The road network is in poor condition. Only about 60 per cent of rural people have access to safe water. Rural poverty is also related to a lack of access to health care and education.



Population

25,300,000

Languages

Emakhuwa 25.3%

Portuguese (official) 10.7%

Xichangana 10.3%

Cisena 7.5%

Elomwe 7%

Echuwabo 5.1%

other Mozambican languages 30.1%

Age Structure

0-14 years: 45.13%

15-24 years: 21.43%

25-54 years: 27.09%

55-64 years: 3.44%

65 years and over: 2.91%

Life Expectancy

53 years

Literacy Rate*

58.8%

Major Industries

manufacturing (cement, glass, textiles, aluminum)

agriculture

Gross Domestic Product (GDP)

$31.1 Billion

*age 15+ who can read & write




AIDS-related diseases are  a major cause of mortality among children in Mozambique. In 2012, UNAIDS estimated that 10,375 children under the age of 15 died as a result of the disease.

Many children with HIV infection do not gain weight or grow as normal children do. Malnutrition is associated with HIV. Current mortality rates for severely malnourished patients are high in Mozambique.


Children living with HIV suffer many of the usual childhood infections and illnesses. Unfortunately, children living with HIV have more severe reactions to these common illnesses. When a child living with HIV gets sick, common illnesses can cause seizures, fever, and colds. When this happens, these children often need medical attention.


A lack of food and a lack of knowledge about nutrition also create  problems for children living with HIV. Many of these children are not aware of nutritious eating habits or can not buy healthy foods. These children often times do not have clean water or restrooms. As a result, their health is further at risk.


In  Mozambique, the lack of doctors and medical facilities makes treating children with HIV or AIDS even harder. In countries like Mozambique, there simply aren't enough doctors and health staff to treat the population.



  1. Sign a petition or start one of your own to raise awareness about the far-reaching effects of the AIDS epidemic in Africa. Visit: www.change.org/petitions (and search AIDS/Africa)


  1. Download the Keep A Child Alive - Kid Power Toolkit and organize a fundraising drive at your school. Remind parents and community members in your neighborhood about the great work that kids can do when they have the tools and support. See: www.keepachildalive.org/get-involved/kid-power




Word

Definition

AIDS

(noun) a disease of the immune system. The disease is passed primarily through blood

generation

(noun) the people born or living at the same time

malnutrition

(noun) lacking in proper nutrition caused by either not having enough to eat or not eating healthy foods

petition

(noun) a formal written request that is typically signed by many people

ravage

(noun) the damaging or destructive effects of something
body_three:
Watch the film HOME IS WHERE YOU FIND IT to learn the story of Alcides Soares, a young boy in Mozambique, Africa who is on a journey to find his brother and create a new sense of family. Then, read the article below to review Alcides story, learn about his home country, Mozambique, and discover ways that you and your PenPals can take action to support people like Alcides. As you explore his story, share your reactions with your PenPals and talk about ways family, disease, and poverty impact people in your community.




Alcides Soares, 16 years old, is one of the 500,000 children in Mozambique who has lost a parent to AIDS. BYkids Film Mentors, television producer Neal Baer (Law & Order: SVU) and movie director Chris Zalla (2007 Sundance Grand Jury Prize winner), mentored Alcides in camera work, directing and editing, helping him to tell his courageous story through film.



Filmed, directed and narrated by Alcides himself, Home Is Where You Find It shows the ravages of AIDS for a whole generation in a way that is rarely seen in mainstream media – through the eyes of the child.


Alcides brings us into his world as he tries to create a new sense of family - with friends, with his siblings who have been scattered, with strangers. His film is a valuable tool for understanding the deeper social and economic implications of AIDS.





Mozambique is one of the world’s poorest countries. The vast majority of the rural population still lives on less than US$1.25 a day and lacks basic services such as access to safe water, health facilities and schools.


Many people in Mozambique, especially the country’s rural areas, depend on agriculture and farming. Farmers and fishers generally make enough to meet their household's’ basic food requirements, with a small surplus for sale in some cases. The road network is in very poor condition, for example, and only about 60 per cent of rural people have access to safe water. Rural poverty is also closely related to lack of access to health care and education. Although the situation has improved over time, significantly more progress has been made in recent years.



Population

25,300,000

Languages

Emakhuwa 25.3%

Portuguese (official) 10.7%

Xichangana 10.3%

Cisena 7.5%

Elomwe 7%

Echuwabo 5.1%

other Mozambican languages 30.1%

Age Structure

0-14 years: 45.13%

15-24 years: 21.43%

25-54 years: 27.09%

55-64 years: 3.44%

65 years and over: 2.91%

Life Expectancy

53 years

Literacy Rate*

58.8%

Major Industries

manufacturing (cement, glass, textiles, aluminum)

agriculture

Gross Domestic Product (GDP)

$31.1 Billion

*age 15+ who can read & write




AIDS-related diseases are fast emerging as a major cause of mortality among children in Mozambique. A growing proportion of all child deaths are a result of HIV-related illnesses. In 2012, UNAIDS estimated that 10,375 children under the age of 15 died as a result of the disease.


Many children with HIV infection do not gain weight or grow normally. Severe malnutrition, especially wasting, is highly associated with HIV, and current mortality rates for severely malnourished patients in most health facilities are high in Mozambique.


Children living with HIV suffer the usual childhood bacterial infections more frequently and more severely than uninfected children. These illnesses can cause seizures, fever, pneumonia, recurrent colds, diarrhea, dehydration and other problems that need urgent medical attention.


Food insecurity and insufficient knowledge of nutrition as well as low coverage of water and sanitation facilities and insufficient knowledge on hygiene practices put the health of HIV infected children further at risk.


In developing countries such as Mozambique, the difficulties in treating children with HIV or AIDS are made worse by the lack of medical facilities and technologies for early diagnosis of HIV, poor healthcare infrastructure and systems and insufficient skilled health staff.



  1. Sign a petition or start one of your own to raise awareness about the far-reaching effects of the AIDS epidemic in Africa. Visit: www.change.org/petitions (and search AIDS/Africa)


  1. Download the Keep A Child Alive - Kid Power Toolkit and organize a fundraising drive at your school. Remind parents and community members in your neighborhood about the great work that kids can do when they have the tools and support. See: www.keepachildalive.org/get-involved/kid-power




Word

Definition

AIDS

(noun) a disease of the immune system. The disease is passed primarily through blood

infrastructure

(noun) the basic structures and facilities (e.g., buildings, roads, water, sanitation and power supplies) needed in a community

malnutrition

(noun) lacking in proper nutrition caused by either not having enough to eat or not eating healthy foods

petition

(noun) a formal written request that is typically signed by many people

plight

(noun) a dangerous or difficult situation

title: Introduction
body_one:
There are over 6,000 languages in the world! There are over 4,000 different religions! 7 billion people live in about 190 different countries! Unfortunately, these differences sometimes lead to violence and discrimination.



Wherever there is violence and hate there are also people who try to help. Some people try to help through education. Other people think  governments can help by creating new laws. Some people think that the internet can help victims of discrimination.



Over the next six weeks, you will learn about people and communities from around the world! You will learn about communities where people discriminate based on history, religion, or appearance. You will also learn about communities where people celebrate differences and live in harmony.


Walking to Freedom


First, you will learn about Ruby Bridges. Ruby Bridges is young girl who fought discrimination in the United States.


In Week 2, you and your PenPals will learn about the history of discrimination. You learn about how people moved around the world during the Age of Discovery. You will learn how European travelers met indigenous peoples in Australia, South America, and the United States.


From Weeks 3 through Week 5, you and your PenPals will learn about civil rights leaders. You will learn about the lives of Mahatma Gandhi. You will compare the lives of Martin Luther King Jr. and Nelson Mandela. And you will learn about Rosa Parks and Helen Joseph.


In Week 6, you and your PenPals will learn about people who are fighting for equality today. As you learn about these heroes, you and your PenPals will brainstorm ways you can help promote peace and equality in your communities.


How to be a Great PenPal


Being a great PenPal starts with respect. Your PenPals are students just like you. Sometimes, you and your PenPals might agree. Sometimes, you and your PenPals might disagree.


Show respect by writing every week. Also show respect by using appropriate language. If your PenPal has a question, make sure to help.



If your PenPals say something that you don’t agree with, ask your PenPals a question about what they said. If your PenPal writes something inappropriate, report the message and our team will reviewed it.



Write to Your Future PenPals


Soon you will be matched with PenPals! So let’s get ready by answering this week’s discussion question! Scroll to the top of the page. There you will find the discussion question on the right.



Each week, answer the weekly discussion question.


After you answer this week’s discussion question, use the chat section underneath to tell your future PenPals about yourself. Then ask your PenPals some questions about their communities.
body_two:
There is a tremendous amount of diversity in the world. For example, there are over 6,000 spoken languages and an estimated 4,000 different religions. The 7 billion people who live on Earth are divided into about 190 different countries.


Unfortunately, these differences are often used as excuses to treat people differently. In Burma, for example, Buddhists have attacked Muslims and Christians. In the Middle East and parts of North Africa, different religious groups within the Muslim community have engaged in sectarian violence. Atheists who reject all formal religions are often targeted and humiliated by religious groups in the United States. In the Central African Republic, religious minorities have been driven from the country by Christians.



Fortunately, there are solutions to prejudice and discrimination. Some people suggest that access to quality education empowers people to stand up for themselves in constructive and nonviolent ways. Others think governments must create laws that give everyone access to employment opportunities and affordable housing. Possibly the internet and the ability to share information can help victims of discrimination draw attention to their plight.



Over the next six weeks, you and your PenPals have the chance to learn about different people from communities all around the world! You might feel angered as you learn about communities that separate and excluded people based on their history, their religion, or the color of their skin. You might also feel inspired as you learn about other communities where people embrace their differences and live in peace and harmony.

Walking to Freedom


The course begins with the story of a brave young girl who fought to overcome discrimination and segregation in the United States. Ruby Bridges and her story will help you and your PenPals start the conversation about diversity and discrimination in both the United States and South Africa.


As you continue to Week 2, you and your PenPals will learn about the history of discrimination and racism. You learn about the movement of people around the world during the Age of Discovery. You will study the interactions between European travelers and the indigenous peoples of Australia, South America, and the United States.


From Weeks 3 through Week 5, you and your PenPals will learn about civil rights leaders who  fought for equality. You will discuss and compare the lives of leaders Mahatma Gandhi, Martin Luther King Jr., Nelson Mandela, Rosa Parks, and Helen Joseph.


During the final week of your PenPal exchange, you and your PenPals will learn about people who are fighting for social justice and equality today. As you learn about these contemporary heroes, you and your PenPals are encouraged to think about what you can do to advocate for peace, acceptance, and equality in your own communities.

How to be a great PenPal


You are about to join thousands of students from more than one hundred different countries who are learning and sharing perspectives with PenPals from around the world!



Being a great PenPal starts with respect. Your PenPals are students just like you, so remember to always be respectful of them and their opinions! Write to your PenPals every week, use appropriate language, and help your PenPals when they have questions.



It's ok to disagree with your PenPals as long as you are polite. If your PenPals say something that you don’t agree with, ask your PenPals to explain their thinking. Remember, if your PenPal writes something inappropriate, flag the message and it will be reviewed by the PenPal Schools team.



Write to Your Future PenPals


So let’s get ready for your PenPal exchange by answering this week’s discussion question! Scroll to the top of the page and find the discussion question on the right side. Make sure to refer to the text and video when answering the question.



Each week, answer the weekly discussion question.


After you answer this week’s discussion question, use the chat section underneath to tell your future PenPals about yourself. Then ask your PenPals some questions about their communities.


Once matched, your PenPals can read and reply to your answers so you’ll already have something to talk about!

title: The Intro and Body
body_one:
In the last lesson, you and your pen pal worked hard to plan and prewrite; now it’s time to draft! We are going to begin this week working on your paragraph introduction. You and your pen pal will explore how to write a strong two-sentence introduction that introduces a claim and the reasons that support it. Then, you will use transitions to connect reasons and build the body of your paragraph. We’ll conclude this lesson with another round of peer review.


Lesson Objectives:

  • Watch a short video to explore vocabulary related to argument writing

  • Draft a two sentence introduction to your argument paragraph

  • Use transitions to connect claims and draft the body of your argument paragraph

  • Review your pen pal’s work and share your feedback



We can break down the introduction to an argument paragraph into two parts. The first part of the introduction consists of the claim sentence. The claim sentence tells the position you will take on a particular issue. This claim is stated in the topic sentence of the piece of argument writing. The second part of the introduction is a plan sentence. A plan sentence tells the big ideas the writer is going to share. These ideas are the reasons that support the claim and address an opposing claim.


Online vs. Classroom Education


Although online learning offers the advantages of flexibility and convenience, it has significant drawbacks. The classroom learning experience offers interaction with teachers and classmates; hands-on-experiences; and a planned daily schedule for learning—benefits the online experience cannot offer.


Notice how the first sentence in the example states the writer's claim: “[online learning] has significant drawbacks.” The second sentence, the plan sentence, lists the writer’s reasons for making the claim. These include the advantages of classroom learning: personal interaction with teachers and classmates, active hands-on experiences, and a planned daily schedule for learning.


Directions: Now it’s your turn! Using the outline from Lesson 4, write the introduction to your argument paragraph in the questions below. Use a claim sentence to establish your position. Then, use a plan sentence to list the reasons that you use to support the claim.


Complete the Questions for Part 1 before moving on to Part 2!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)


You’ve written your introduction sentences! Now what?! Now it is time to support your claim with those reasons you previewed in the plan sentence. Transition words are helpful in their ability to connect reasons and their supporting evidence.  Transition words also help your reader follow along.


Let’s revisit our sample paragraph from Lesson 4: “Sports Drinks: Not work the $$$.”


Sports Drinks: Not Worth the $$$


       TV commercials for sports drinks try to make the viewer think that using the products will turn ordinary people into superheroes. Sports drinks are, in fact, an expensive and unnecessary sideshow. First of all, food provides the energy the body needs for exercise: energy which is stored as glucose in our cells. Glucose is mostly formed from carbohydrates that we get from food and drink. If we have a healthy diet, our bodies should already have enough glucose stored for ninety minutes of exercise. Most sports drinks contain a little salt and carbohydrates in the form of sugar—pretty normal ingredients. Also, sports drinks are expensive. Why are people willing to hand over a couple of dollars for a sports drink? Why are people willing to hand over a couple dollars for a sports drink? Maybe because friends drink it, or ads give them hope the drink will give them an edge. It won’t. Some experts argue that sports drinks can be helpful for endurance athletes. The drinks taste good, so a long-distance runner may drink more and stay better hydrated, for example. However, these athletes could stay equally hydrated with water. Athletes who exercise hard for more than 90 minutes can restore some energy they have burned by consuming a sports drink. These competitors could also restore energy by eating a banana or some other healthy snack. Besides, most people aren’t endurance athletes. The truth is, sports drinks exist so people can make money by selling what is basically colored sugar water. For most people out for a bike ride or neighborhood pickup game, drinking free tap water and eating a healthy diet will give them everything they need plus a little more money in their pockets.


Notice how the writer of the paragraph above uses the transitions “first of all,” and “also.” Each transition word shows the reader when a new reason is about to be presented. Take a look at the following chart with transitions and revisit the transitions you used in your argument outline. Are there any transitions that might make your argument flow better?



Using the outline from Lesson 4 and the introduction sentences from Part 1, write the body of your argument paragraph. Remember, we use the color yellow to identify transitions because they are the glue that slows your reader down and connects the reasons (key/star ideas) to the claim. We use red to represent the evidence because your reader should stop to think about each and every piece of evidence.

Complete the Questions for Part 2 before moving on to Part 3!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)




After working hard on your paragraph introduction and body, it is time to get feedback from your penpal with peer review!


Directions: Review the roles of a peer reviewer. Then, read the current draft of your pen pal’s argument paragraph. Celebrate your pen pal’s great ideas! Ask questions about the ideas that are still confusing and need more support. Last, thank your pen pal for the feedback he or she shares on your own writing!



Complete the questions located at the bottom of this page! After answering each of your questions, read and respond to your pen pal’s answers!



Word

Definition

flow

(verb) to move along in a steady or smooth way

transition word

(noun) a word or phrase that introduces reasons or key/star ideas in an argument

Complete the Questions for Part 1 before moving on to Part 2!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)


You’ve written your introduction sentences! Now what?! Now it is time to support your claim with those reasons you previewed in the plan sentence. Transition words are helpful in their ability to connect reasons and their supporting evidence.  Transition words also help your reader follow along.


Let’s revisit our sample paragraph from Lesson 4: “Sports Drinks: Not work the $$$.”


Sports Drinks: Not Worth the $$$


       TV commercials for sports drinks try to make the viewer think that using the products will turn ordinary people into superheroes. Sports drinks are, in fact, an expensive and unnecessary sideshow. First of all, food provides the energy the body needs for exercise: energy which is stored as glucose in our cells. Glucose is mostly formed from carbohydrates that we get from food and drink. If we have a healthy diet, our bodies should already have enough glucose stored for ninety minutes of exercise. Most sports drinks contain a little salt and carbohydrates in the form of sugar—pretty normal ingredients. Also, sports drinks are expensive. Why are people willing to hand over a couple of dollars for a sports drink? Why are people willing to hand over a couple dollars for a sports drink? Maybe because friends drink it, or ads give them hope the drink will give them an edge. It won’t. Some experts argue that sports drinks can be helpful for endurance athletes. The drinks taste good, so a long-distance runner may drink more and stay better hydrated, for example. However, these athletes could stay equally hydrated with water. Athletes who exercise hard for more than 90 minutes can restore some energy they have burned by consuming a sports drink. These competitors could also restore energy by eating a banana or some other healthy snack. Besides, most people aren’t endurance athletes. The truth is, sports drinks exist so people can make money by selling what is basically colored sugar water. For most people out for a bike ride or neighborhood pickup game, drinking free tap water and eating a healthy diet will give them everything they need plus a little more money in their pockets.


Notice how the writer of the paragraph above uses the transitions “first of all,” and “also.” Each transition word shows the reader when a new reason is about to be presented. Take a look at the following chart with transitions and revisit the transitions you used in your argument outline. Are there any transitions that might make your argument flow better?



Using the outline from Lesson 4 and the introduction sentences from Part 1, write the body of your argument paragraph. Remember, we use the color yellow to identify transitions because they are the glue that slows your reader down and connects the reasons (key/star ideas) to the claim. We use red to represent the evidence because your reader should stop to think about each and every piece of evidence.

Complete the Questions for Part 2 before moving on to Part 3!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)




After working hard on your paragraph introduction and body, it is time to get feedback from your penpal with peer review!


Directions: Review the roles of a peer reviewer. Then, read the current draft of your pen pal’s argument paragraph. Celebrate your pen pal’s great ideas! Ask questions about the ideas that are still confusing and need more support. Last, thank your pen pal for the feedback he or she shares on your own writing!



Complete the questions located at the bottom of this page! After answering each of your questions, read and respond to your pen pal’s answers!



Word

Definition

flow

(verb) to move along in a steady or smooth way

transition word

(noun) a word or phrase that introduces reasons or key/star ideas in an argument
body_three:
In the last lesson, you and your pen pal worked hard to plan and prewrite; now it’s time to draft! We are going to begin this week working on your paragraph introduction. You and your pen pal will explore how to write a strong two-sentence introduction that introduces a claim and the reasons that support it. Then, you will use transitions to connect reasons and build the body of your paragraph. We’ll conclude this lesson with another round of peer review.


Lesson Objectives:

  • Watch a short video to explore vocabulary related to argument writing

  • Draft a two sentence introduction to your argument paragraph

  • Use transitions to connect claims and draft the body of your argument paragraph

  • Review your pen pal’s work and share your feedback



We can break down the introduction to an argument paragraph into two parts. The first part of the introduction consists of the claim sentence. The claim sentence tells the position you will take on a particular issue. This claim is stated in the topic sentence of the piece of argument writing. The second part of the introduction is a plan sentence. A plan sentence tells the big ideas the writer is going to share. These ideas are the reasons that support the claim and address an opposing claim.


Online vs. Classroom Education


Although online learning offers the advantages of flexibility and convenience, it has significant drawbacks. The classroom learning experience offers interaction with teachers and classmates; hands-on-experiences; and a planned daily schedule for learning—benefits the online experience cannot offer.


Notice how the first sentence in the example states the writer's claim: “[online learning] has significant drawbacks.” The second sentence, the plan sentence, lists the writer’s reasons for making the claim. These include the advantages of classroom learning: personal interaction with teachers and classmates, active hands-on experiences, and a planned daily schedule for learning.


Directions: Now it’s your turn! Using the outline from Lesson 4, write the introduction to your argument paragraph in the questions below. Use a claim sentence to establish your position. Then, use a plan sentence to list the reasons that you use to support the claim.


Complete the Questions for Part 1 before moving on to Part 2!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)

The drinks taste good, so a long-distance runner may drink more and stay better hydrated, for example. However, these athletes could stay equally hydrated with water. These competitors could also restore energy by eating a banana or some other healthy snack. Besides, most people aren’t endurance athletes. For most people out for a bike ride or neighborhood pickup game, drinking free tap water and eating a healthy diet will give them everything they need plus a little more money in their pockets.

Take a look at the following chart with transitions and revisit the transitions you used in your argument outline. Are there any transitions that might make your argument flow better?



Using the outline from Lesson 4 and the introduction sentences from Part 1, write the body of your argument paragraph. Remember, we use the color yellow to identify transitions because they are the glue that slows your reader down and connects the reasons (key/star ideas) to the claim. We use red to represent the evidence because your reader should stop to think about each and every piece of evidence.

Definition

title: A Groundbreaking Crisis
body_one:
In 2007, Oklahoma had one earthquake. Last year, there were more than 900. What happened?


By Josh Sanburn for TIME, adapted by TFK editors

April 11, 2016


Angela Spotts dreams of earthquakes. She often gets jolted awake at night, not knowing if she’s feeling an actual quake or if it’s in her mind. These days, it’s often real. When that’s the case, she notes the time so she can report the quake. Then she tries to go back to sleep.


Spotts is 54. She lives in Stillwater, Oklahoma. The city got its name because the water was always calm. But today, it is one of the most earthquake-prone places on the planet.


In 2007, Oklahoma had one earthquake of magnitude 3 or higher. (That’s the lowest level at which an earthquake can be felt.) Last year, there were 907. The state now has more 3-plus earthquakes than California. Ten of the 12 largest quakes in state history have occurred since 2011. Four have struck since November, including the third-largest. That 5.1 tremor hit outside Fairview on February 13. The town has felt more than 50 quakes since then.


No place in the world has experienced so many earthquakes in such a short time. And Oklahoma was unprepared for them. It’s gotten so bad that some people are considering leaving the state.


At the center of it all is Oklahoma's most important industry: oil and gas. It has been Oklahoma's biggest economic engine for decades. The energy business indirectly accounts for 20% of jobs around the state. It makes up roughly 10% of the state GDP. The fuel industry makes or breaks Oklahoma. And right now, it’s breaking it.


State officials long denied any connection between the oil industry and earthquakes. Last April, they finally acknowledged what scientists had been saying for some time. Oklahoma’s transformation into a seismic hot zone is connected to its most important industry. From 2010 to 2014, oil production in the state nearly doubled. Natural-gas production grew by almost 50%, according to the research firm RegionTrack. New drilling technologies were invented. They made it possible to extract oil from sites once considered too watery. High oil prices made these new techniques worth the trouble.


DIAGRAM BY EMILY BARONE AND LON TWEETEN FOR TIME


The diagram shows how drilling activity is triggering earthquakes in Oklahoma.

But the new technology has a downside. It makes use of disposal wells. Wastewater often comes to the surface alongside oil and gas. Disposal wells inject the water back into the ground. The wells send water to fault lines deep in the earth. This process has led to many earthquakes. The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) now ranks Oklahoma as one of the most quake-prone states in the nation.


Boom and Bust


Oklahoma had been one of the biggest winners in America’s oil boom. As oil prices climbed past $100 a barrel, Oklahoma’s population grew. Its unemployment rate fell. The state even landed its first big-league sports team–the NBA’s Oklahoma City Thunder.


But recently, the price of oil has fallen to $30 a barrel. The decline is due to decreased demand and excess global supply. The downturn has hurt Oklahoma. Thousands of employees at large energy companies have lost their jobs. Chesapeake Energy, one of the big players in the state’s boom, lost 80% of its value in the past year. Businesses that depended on the energy sector are suffering as a result. Greco Motors, near Oklahoma City, has gone from selling a car a day to 12 a month.


Oklahoma has weathered hard times before. Nearly any longtime resident will tell you so. But there is a big difference between the current situation and the 1980s. That’s the last time the price of oil fell so fast. This time, it's not just lost jobs and financial difficulties. Oklahomans now have to contend with the ground shaking beneath their feet. The energy boom may be over. But the man-made geological mess it created has gotten worse.


JOHN FRANCIS PETERS FOR TIME


Signs of the oil industry are common in Oklahoma. This oil pump is in suburban Edmond.


“You have scientists warning us that a big [earthquake] is coming,” says Spotts. She became an oil-industry critic when an oil well showed up within 900 feet of her house. “The more we shake, the worse it’s going to get. It’s coming.”


On Shaky Ground


Historically, Oklahoma had about one earthquake a year. But the frequency rose as the oil boom took hold. By 2009, it had 20 in a single year. The next year it had 35. Then on November 5, 2011, around 10:53 p.m., an earthquake measuring 5.6 struck near Prague. It is a small town about 50 miles east of Oklahoma City. The quake was powerful. It collapsed a tower at a nearby college. Parts of Arkansas, Kansas, and Missouri even felt the quake.


“It felt like a plane hit the front of our house,” says resident Sandra Ladra, 65. Her stone fireplace began to crumble. One of the stones fell and crushed her knee. “I thought we were going to die,” she says. Ladra is suing two energy companies for damages.


The Prague earthquake was the strongest ever recorded in Oklahoma. The timing, scientists say, was no coincidence. For years, the main way to extract fossil fuels was by drilling a hole vertically into the Earth. It was expensive. And it had a success rate of only about one in three wells. But over the past decade, new technologies have emerged. They include horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing. The latter is better known as fracking. These methods allow drillers to complete wells more quickly and efficiently. Today, the industry’s drilling success rate is closer to 80%.


Those technologies caused oil production to soar in Oklahoma. But they had unforeseen consequences. Both techniques allow access to oil that used to be hard and costly to reach because it was surrounded by too much water. Kyle Murray, a hydrogeologist with the Oklahoma Geological Survey (OGS), says some wells produced 65 barrels of water for every barrel of oil. The wastewater is injected back into the ground. That can impact fault lines and lead to seismic activity. All that wastewater reactivated faults that hadn’t moved in 300 million years, according to Art McGarr. He is a geophysicist with the USGS’s Earthquake Hazards Program.


Since the late 1960s, scientists have known that humans can bring about earthquakes. By 2013, many leading experts were confident that this was happening in Oklahoma. But the OGS repeatedly said there wasn’t enough information to establish a link between oil and gas drilling and the state’s increased earthquake activity. In March 2013, the agency attributed the Prague quake to “natural causes.”


JOHN FRANCIS PETERS FOR TIME


An oil rig stands in front of the Oklahoma State Capitol building, in Oklahoma City.


It would take another two years until the state acknowledged what scientists and the public already knew. “They were finally forced into the realization that their techniques . . . led to some large, damaging earthquakes,” McGarr says.


Rumblings Linger


The slowdown in the oil industry could lessen the earthquake problem. In March, there were just 70 active oil rigs in the state. That's down from a high of 214 in September 2014. Wastewater-disposal volume also decreased in 2015. And the number of quakes is down by about 20% compared with last year.


The oil boom is receding. But its dangerous legacy will remain. Earthquakes create their own momentum. The more magnitude-3 quakes you have, the more 4s. The more 4s there are, the more 5s. Some researchers worry about longer-term consequences. Daniel McNamara is a USGS geophysicist. He believes that if all wastewater-injecting activity stopped today, the state could still have earthquakes for decades. “I have never seen anything like it and never read anything like it in history,” he says.


SUE OGROCKI—AP


An underground seismic station is installed in Waynoka, Oklahoma. Its job is to monitor earthquake activity.


In March, the USGS released its new earthquake-hazard map. The map used to come out every six years. But Oklahoma has changed the agency’s plan. The map will now be released annually. On the map, Oklahoma now looks a lot like California. There is a big splotch of bright red, which indicates a high risk of earthquake damage.


SOURCE: USGS


This map displays the risk of experiencing damage from earthquakes across the country in 2016. The USGS did not provide information about Alaska or Hawaii.


Residents like Spotts live inside that red zone. In the fall, she and her husband were sitting on the sofa when a 4.3 quake hit Stillwater. “It whiplashed us,” she says. “We looked at each other. And [we] said, ‘I don’t want to own a home anymore.’” They want to move. But they worry they won’t be able to sell their home for enough money, given the quakes. “I’m not going to run from the fight,” Spotts says. “But I don’t know if I can live in it anymore.”


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

extract

verb: to remove something

GDP

noun: gross domestic product; the total value produced by a state or nation’s economy during a set period of time

magnitude

noun: a number that indicates the size and power of an earthquake

momentum

noun: the strength or force that allows something to continue or to grow stronger or faster as time passes

seismic

adjective: of, relating to, or caused by an earthquake

The diagram shows how drilling activity is triggering earthquakes in Oklahoma.

The wells send water to fault lines buried deep beneath the prairie floor. Businesses that depended on the energy sector are suffering as a result. Greco Motors, near Oklahoma City, said it has gone from selling a car a day to 12 a month.

That’s the last time the price of oil fell so fast. In addition to lost jobs and financial difficulties, Oklahomans now have to contend with the ground shaking beneath their feet. The energy boom may be over. But the man-made geological mess it created has gotten worse.


“You have scientists warning us that a big [earthquake] is coming,” says Spotts. She became an oil-industry critic when an oil well showed up within 900 feet of her house. “The more we shake, the worse it’s going to get. It’s coming.”


JOHN FRANCIS PETERS FOR TIME


Signs of the oil industry are common in Oklahoma. This oil pump is in suburban Edmond.


On Shaky Ground


Historically, Oklahoma had about one earthquake a year. But the frequency rose as the oil boom took hold. By 2009, it had 20 in a single year. The next year it had 35. Then on November 5, 2011, around 10:53 p.m., an earthquake measuring 5.6 struck near Prague. It is a small town about 50 miles east of Oklahoma City. For years, the main way to extract fossil fuels was by drilling a hole vertically into the Earth. It was expensive and had a success rate of only about one in three wells. But over the past decade, new technologies have emerged. They include horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing, better known as fracking. These methods allow drillers to complete wells more quickly and efficiently. Today, the industry’s drilling success rate is closer to 80%.


Those technologies caused oil production to soar in Oklahoma. But they had unforeseen consequences. Both techniques allow access to oil that used to be hard and costly to reach because it was surrounded by too much water. Kyle Murray, a hydrogeologist with the Oklahoma Geological Survey (OGS), says some of the wells he was drilling produced 65 barrels of water for every barrel of oil. All that wastewater reactivated faults that hadn’t moved in 300 million years, according to Art McGarr. He is a geophysicist with the USGS’s Earthquake Hazards Program.

At that time, researchers found that chemical waste injected underground at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal caused a series of quakes that were felt in nearby Denver. By 2013, many leading experts were confident that the same phenomenon was at play in Oklahoma. But the OGS repeatedly said there wasn’t enough information to establish a link between oil and gas drilling and the state’s increased earthquake activity. In March 2013, the agency attributed the Prague quake to “natural causes.”


It would take another two years until the state acknowledged what the scientific community and many in the public already knew. “They were finally forced into the realization that their techniques . . . led to some large, damaging earthquakes,” McGarr says.


JOHN FRANCIS PETERS FOR TIME


An oil rig stands in front of the Oklahoma State Capitol building, in Oklahoma City.

The slowdown in the oil industry could lessen the earthquake problem. In March, there were just 70 active oil rigs in the state, down from a high of 214 in September 2014. Wastewater-disposal volume also decreased in 2015. And the number of quakes is down by about 20% compared with last year.


But even as the oil boom recedes, its dangerous legacy will remain. Earthquakes create their own momentum. The more magnitude-3 quakes you have, the more 4s; the more 4s there are, the more 5s. Daniel McNamara, a USGS geophysicist, says he believes that if all wastewater-injecting activity stopped today, the state could still have earthquakes for decades. “I have never seen anything like it and never read anything like it in history,” he says.

An underground seismic station is installed in Waynoka, Oklahoma. Its job is to monitor earthquake activity.


In March, the USGS released its new earthquake-hazard map. The map used to come out every six years. But Oklahoma has changed the agency’s plan. The map will now be released annually. On the map, Oklahoma now looks a lot like California. There is a big splotch of bright red, which indicates a high risk of earthquake damage.


SOURCE: USGS


This map displays the risk of experiencing damage from earthquakes across the country in 2016. The USGS did not provide information about Alaska or Hawaii.


Living inside that red zone will be residents like Spotts. In the fall, she and her husband were sitting on the sofa when a 4.3 quake hit Stillwater. “It whiplashed us,” she says. “We looked at each other and said, ‘I don’t want to own a home anymore.’” They want to move. But they worry they won’t be able to sell their home for enough money, given the quakes. “I’m not going to run from the fight,” Spotts says. “But I don’t know if I can live in it anymore.”


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

extract

verb: to remove something

GDP

noun: gross domestic product; the total value produced by a state or nation’s economy during a set period of time

magnitude

noun: a number that indicates the size and power of an earthquake

momentum

noun: the strength or force that allows something to continue or to grow stronger or faster as time passes

seismic

adjective: of, relating to, or caused by an earthquake

tremors

noun: a shaking movement of the ground before, during, or after an earthquake
