Those technologies caused oil production to soar in Oklahoma. But they had unforeseen consequences. Both techniques allow access to oil that used to be hard and costly to reach because it was surrounded by too much water. Kyle Murray, a hydrogeologist with the Oklahoma Geological Survey (OGS), says some of the wells he was drilling produced 65 barrels of water for every barrel of oil. The wastewater is injected straight back into the ground. That can impact fault lines and lead to seismic activity. All that wastewater, according to Art McGarr, a geophysicist with the USGS’s Earthquake Hazards Program, reactivated faults that hadn’t moved in 300 million years.


Scientists have known that humans can bring about earthquakes since the late 1960s, when researchers found that chemical waste injected underground at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal caused a series of quakes that were felt in nearby Denver. By 2013, many leading experts were confident that the same phenomenon was at play in Oklahoma. But the OGS repeatedly said there wasn’t enough information to establish a link between oil and gas drilling and the state’s increased earthquake activity. In March 2013, the agency attributed the Prague quake to “natural causes.”


It would take another two years until the state acknowledged what the scientific community and many in the public already knew. “They were finally forced into the realization that their techniques . . . led to some large, damaging earthquakes,” McGarr says.


JOHN FRANCIS PETERS FOR TIME


An oil rig stands in front of the Oklahoma State Capitol building, in Oklahoma City.


Rumblings Linger


The slowdown in the oil industry could lessen the earthquake problem. In March, there were just 70 active oil rigs in the state, down from a high of 214 in September 2014. Wastewater-disposal volume also decreased in 2015. And the number of quakes is down by about 20% in 2016 compared with last year.


But even as the oil boom recedes, its dangerous legacy will remain. Earthquakes create their own momentum. The more magnitude-3 quakes you have, the more 4s; the more 4s there are, the more 5s. Some researchers worry about longer-term consequences. Daniel McNamara, a USGS geophysicist, says he believes that if all wastewater-injecting activity stopped today, the state could still have earthquakes for decades. “I have never seen anything like it and never read anything like it in history,” he says.


SUE OGROCKI—AP


An underground seismic station is installed in Waynoka, Oklahoma. Its job is to monitor earthquake activity.


In March, the USGS released its new earthquake-hazard map. The map used to come out every six years, but Oklahoma has changed the agency’s plan. The map will now be released annually. On the map, Oklahoma now looks a lot like California: There is a big splotch of bright red, which indicates a high risk of earthquake damage.


SOURCE: USGS


This map displays the risk of experiencing damage from earthquakes across the country in 2016. The USGS did not provide information about Alaska or Hawaii.


Living inside that red zone will be residents like Spotts. In the fall, she and her husband were sitting on the sofa when a 4.3 quake hit Stillwater. “It whiplashed us,” she says. “We looked at each other and said, ‘I don’t want to own a home anymore.’” They want to move but worry they won’t be able to sell their home for enough money, given the quakes. “I’m not going to run from the fight,” Spotts says. “But I don’t know if I can live in it anymore.”


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

extract

verb: to remove something

GDP

noun: gross domestic product; the total value produced by a state or nation’s economy during a set period of time

magnitude

noun: a number that indicates the size and power of an earthquake

momentum

noun: the strength or force that allows something to continue or to grow stronger or faster as time passes

seismic

adjective: of, relating to, or caused by an earthquake

tremors

noun: a shaking movement of the ground before, during, or after an earthquake

title: Technology in the United States
body_one:
Astronauts Grow Lettuce in Space


It took astronauts 33 days to grow enough red romaine lettuce to make a small salad.

Photo Credit: NASA


In space all food is freeze-dried or prepackaged.  Food like this does not always taste good.


Recently on the International Space Station astronauts grew fresh lettuce. The red romaine lettuce was part of NASA's Veggie project.  The goal of the project was to bring salad to space.


"It's just one of those things that we have to learn.   If we're going to travel to places like Mars, we need to grow fresh food." says the Veggie project manager.


There are a few issues that come up when you try to farm in space.


First, there's the problem of water. On Earth, gravity pulls water down toward the roots.  In space, water can ball up in the corner of a pot and leave the roots dry and malnourished.  


Smith's team solved the problem with: a "pillow" of clay which helps hold water near the roots.


Second, plants need fresh air to breathe. On Earth, wind keeps fresh air coming, but inside the space station, there is no wind. Smith’s team solved this problem with fans.


Finally there's the issue of light. The space station moves around the Earth fast: "Every 90 minutes there's a new sunrise." Smith says. The Veggie team added some artificial lights to keep the orbiting lettuce on an Earthly schedule.

The system took years for engineers on Earth to develop.  The lettuce took 33 days to grow. says.


When the lettuce was ready, the astronauts were hungry. There was just one question left: How would the crew like to eat their leafy greens?


The astronauts went with a simple salad dressing and reported that the space salad tasted out of this world.


This lettuce could be just the tip of the iceberg. There are plans for cabbage, cherry tomatoes and even potatoes.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

gravity

(noun) the force that acts upon objects on the Earth that keeps them on the ground

malnourished

(adj) underfed and without proper nutrition

aerated

(verb) to treat with air or gas

circulate

(verb) to move around or through

orbit

(noun) the circular path of a planet, satellite, etc. around a point, such as the sun

Read the original article on NPR
body_two:
Astronauts Grow Lettuce in Space


It took astronauts 33 days to grow enough red romaine lettuce to make a small salad.

Photo Credit: NASA


In space all food is freeze-dried, prepackaged, and does not always taste good. But recently aboard the International Space Station, astronauts got a rare treat: fresh lettuce. The red romaine lettuce was grown by NASA's Veggie project, which has one goal — to bring salad to space.


"It's just one of those things that we have to learn if we're going to step into the solar system and go to Mars," says Trent Smith, the Veggie project manager. "How will you grow your plants?"


There are a few issues that arise when you attempt to farm in space. First, there's the problem of water. On Earth, gravity pulls it down toward the roots, but in space, it can ball up in the corner of a pot and leave the roots dry and malnourished.  Smith's team has developed a solution: a "pillow" of aerated clay, to which you add water. The clay provides structure for the roots to spread out in zero G.


Second, plants also need fresh air to breathe. On Earth, wind keeps fresh air coming, but inside the space station, there is no wind. So fans must constantly circulate air.


Finally there's the issue of light. The space station is whipping around the Earth fast: "Every 90 minutes there's a new sunrise, so for a plant, that would be extremely confusing," Smith says. The Veggie team added some artificial lights to keep the orbiting lettuce on an Earthly schedule.

The system took years for engineers on Earth to develop, but the growth cycle of the lettuce was not nearly as long.


"We had 33 days of growth, and the plants were just fantastic, I mean, big, large leaves," Smith says.


The lettuce was ready. The astronauts were hungry. There was just one question left: How would the crew like to eat their leafy greens?


The astronauts went with a simple balsamic dressing and reported that the space salad tasted out of this world.


"That's awesome, tastes good," astronaut Kjell Lindgren told mission control in Houston.


This wasn't the first time astronauts had grown lettuce in space. Last year, astronauts grew an equal amount of tasty greens, but they were frozen and returned to Earth for careful analysis — though Smith suspects the crew at the time may have sneaked a bite: "I am fairly certain we didn't get all the lettuce home last time," he says.


This lettuce could be just the tip of the iceberg. There are plans for cabbage, cherry tomatoes and even potatoes.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

gravity

(noun) the force that acts upon objects on the Earth that keeps them on the ground

malnourished

(adj) underfed and without proper nutrition

aerated

(verb) to treat with air or gas

circulate

(verb) to move around or through

orbit

(noun) the circular path of a planet, satellite, etc. around a point, such as the sun

Read the original article on NPR
body_three:
Astronauts Grow Their Own Lettuce in Space


It took astronauts 33 days to grow enough red romaine lettuce to make a small salad.

Photo Credit: NASA


In space all food is freeze-dried, prepackaged, and does not always taste good. But recently aboard the International Space Station, astronauts got a rare treat: fresh lettuce. The red romaine lettuce was grown by NASA's Veggie project, which has one goal — to bring salad to space.


"It's just one of those things that we have to learn if we're going to step into the solar system and go to Mars," says Trent Smith, the Veggie project manager. "How will you grow your plants?"


There are a few problems that come up when you try to farm in space.


First, there's the problem with water. On Earth, gravity pulls water down toward the roots, but in space, the water can ball up in the corner of a pot and leave the roots dry and malnourished.  Smith's team has created a solution: a "pillow" of aerated clay, to which you add water. The clay provides structure for the roots to spread out in an environment without gravity.


Second, plants also need fresh air to breathe. On Earth, wind keeps fresh air coming, but inside the space station, there is no wind. So fans must constantly circulate air.


Finally there's the issue of light. The space station moves around the Earth fast: "Every 90 minutes there's a new sunrise, so for a plant, that would be extremely confusing," Smith says. The Veggie team added some artificial lights to keep the orbiting lettuce on an Earthly schedule.  


The system took years for engineers on Earth to design and build.


"We had 33 days of growth, and the plants were just fantastic, I mean, big, large leaves," Smith says.


The lettuce was ready. The astronauts were hungry. There was just one question left: How would the crew like to eat their leafy greens?  The astronauts went with a simple balsamic salad dressing and reported that the space salad tasted out of this world.


This lettuce could be just the tip of the iceberg. There are plans for cabbage, cherry tomatoes and even potatoes.

title: Nelson Mandela and Martin Luther King Jr.
body_one:
Martin Luther King Jr. and the Civil Rights Movement


In the 1960s, black Americans (also referred to as African-Americans) were discriminated against by people across the United States.


In many Southern States black and white people were not allowed to use the same spaces.  Restaurants, swimming pools, movie theatres, and water fountains were segregated based on race.



Across the country, black people could not do the same things as white people. The African-American community could not go to the same schools or have the same jobs.


It was against this background that the American Civil Rights Movement began.


Martin Luther King Jr. (1929-1968) was a leader in the Civil Rights Movement. Dr. King spent his life fighting for equality for black people in America.


Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his famous, “I Have a Dream,” speech during the 1963 march on Washington, D.C.


Dr. King led many non-violent protests. The teachings of Gandhi inspired him to use non-violent protest.


During these protests, police used police dogs and water cannons against protesters. Pictures and video from these protest helped change the hearts and minds of many Americans - just as King had hoped.


King was arrested a total of 29 times during his life, but he never stopped fighting for what he knew to be fair and just.


Dr. King was assassinated on in Memphis, Tennessee at the age of 39. He gave his life fighting for equality.


Nelson Mandela and the Anti-Apartheid Revolution


Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela (1918-2013) is one of the most famous South African people from the 20th Century.


Mr.Mandela was as a fighter for equality, and is one of the founding fathers of the modern, democratic Republic of South Africa.


FW de Klerk and Nelson Mandela shake hands at the World Economic Forum in 1992


Mandela joined the African National Congress (ANC), a political party, in 1944. The ANC fought against the discrimination of the National Party.


Mandela was arrested the first time on 5 December 1955. This arrest led to the Treason Trial. He was arrested again on 11 June 1964 and sent to prison with a life sentence.


Mandela spent the next 29 years in prison because he refused to stop fighting for freedom and equality.


While in jail Mr. Mandela wrote The Long Walk to Freedom, his famous autobiography.


This comes from Nelson Mandela’s famous statement at the Pretoria Supreme Court, 20 April 1964:



Mandela was released from prison on 11 February 1990. Nine days later, then-president FW de Klerk welcomed the African National Congress to the government.


Nelson Mandela entered talks to end the discrimination in South Africa.  He was elected President of the ANC in 1991.


Nelson Mandela died on 5 December 2013.  Mr. Mandela lived a life dedicated to freedom for all the people of South Africa.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

apartheid

(noun) in South Africa, a system of discrimination on grounds of race

assassinate

(verb) to murder a person in a surprise attack

civil rights

(noun) the rights of citizens to political and social freedom and equality

equality

(noun) being treated the same, especially with rights and opportunities

protest

(noun) an objection to what has or is being done
body_two:
Martin Luther King Jr. and the Civil Rights Movement


In the 1960s, black Americans (also referred to as African-Americans) were discriminated against by laws and people across the United States. In many Southern States there were segregated spaces like restaurants, swimming pools, movie theatres, and water fountains.



Nationwide, black people could not do the same things as white people. The African-American community could often not go to the same schools or have the same jobs as their white peers. Violence by white Americans against black people was tolerated.


It was against this background that the American Civil Rights Movment began. One of the key events in this struggle took place in August 1963, when a man stood in front of 250 000 people to deliver a speech. The speech started with the sentence: “I have a dream.”


This man was Martin Luther King Jr. (1929-1968), who was a leader in the Civil Rights Movement. Dr. King spent the rest of his life fighting for equality for black people in America.


Martin Luther King Jr. addresses a crowd from the steps of the Lincoln Memorial.  Here he delivered his famous, “I Have a Dream,” speech during the 1963 march on Washington, D.C.


Dr. King led many non-violent protests. The teachings of Gandhi inspired him to use non-violent protest. In 1963, King was arrested at a March in Alabama during a campaign against racial segregation.


During these protests, police used police dogs and water cannons against protesters, including children.  This footage was shown across America, and helped change the hearts and minds of many Americans - just as King hoped.


King was arrested a total of 29 times during his life, but he never stopped fighting for what he knew to be fair and just.


His speech, “I Have a Dream” was broadcast across the United States. This speech was an example of King’s battle against segregation and discrimination in the United States. He received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1964 for his work against discrimination.


On the 3rd of April 1968, King delivered a speech in Memphis, Tennessee. In closing, he spoke about the future of the civil rights movement:



The following morning, he was assassinated on the balcony of the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, Tennessee.


Although King died at the young age of 39, his contribution to the civil rights movement in America was enormous. He gave his life for the cause.


Nelson Mandela and the Anti-Apartheid Revolution


Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela (1918-2013) is perhaps the most famous South African person from the 20th Century. His open smile, friendly face and wise words are recognised in many countries across the world.


Mr.Mandela is known as a fighter for liberation, and is considered one of the founding fathers of the modern, democratic Republic of South Africa.


FW de Klerk and Nelson Mandela shake hands at the World Economic Forum in 1992


Mandela joined the African National Congress (ANC), a political party, in 1944 where he helped form the ANC Youth League. During most of the 1900s, the ANC fought the oppressive racist regime of the National Party.

Mandela was arrested the first time on 5 December 1955. This arrest led to the Treason Trial, and he was only acquitted in 1961. He was arrested on 11 June 1964 and sent to prison with a life sentence.


Mandela spent the next 29 years in prison because he refused to stop fighting for freedom and equality. While in jail on Robben Island in Cape Town, Mr. Mandela continued the struggle together with other prisoners. In prison, his wrote The Long Walk to Freedom, his famous autobiography.


This excerpt comes from Nelson Mandela’s famous statement at the Pretoria Supreme Court, 20 April 1964:



Mandela was released from prison on 11 February 1990, nine days after then-president FW de Klerk unbanned the African National Congress.


Nelson Mandela immediately entered into official talks to end the white minority rule in South Africa, and in 1991 he was elected President of the ANC.


Nelson Mandela died on 5 December 2013, having lived a life singularly dedicated to freedom for all the people of South Africa.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

acquit

(verb) to free from criminal charges

apartheid

(noun) in South Africa, a system of discrimination on grounds of race

assassinate

(verb) to murder a person in a surprise attack

civil rights

(noun) the rights of citizens to political and social freedom and equality

equality

(noun) being treated the same, especially with rights and opportunities

liberation

(noun) free from oppression

protest

(noun) an objection to what has or is being done
body_three:
Martin Luther King Jr. and the Civil Rights Movement


In the 1960s, black Americans (also referred to as African-Americans) were discriminated against by law and by custom. In many Southern States there were segregated spaces like restaurants, swimming pools, movie theatres, and water fountains



Nationwide, black people did not have access to the same educational and economic opportunities that white individuals of European descent had. Acts of violence by white Americans against black people were tolerated and sometimes even condoned by the police.


It was against this background that the American Civil Rights Movement grew from 1955 onwards. One of the key events in this struggle took place in August 1963, when a man stood in front of 250 000 people to deliver a speech that started with this sentence: “I have a dream.”


This man was Martin Luther King Jr. (1929-1968), who at the time was the leader in the African-American Civil Rights Movement. King became involved in politics at an early age, and eventually helped found the Southern Christian Leadership Council (SCLC) in 1957. He spent the rest of his life fighting for equality for black people in America.


Martin Luther King Jr. addresses a crowd from the steps of the Lincoln Memorial where he delivered his famous, “I Have a Dream,” speech during the 1963 march on Washington, D.C.


As the first president of the SCLC, King led many non-violent protests inspired by the teachings of Gandhi as well as Leo Tolstoy and Jesus Christ. In 1963, King was arrested at a March in Alabama during a campaign against racial segregation. During the protests, police used police dogs and high pressure water cannons against protesters, including children.  This footage was shown across America, and had a huge impact on many Americans’ opinion - just as King intended.


King was arrested a total of 29 times during his life, but he never stopped fighting for what he knew to be fair and just. It was, however, his speech at the 1963 March on Washington that propelled him to the national, and international, stage.


His speech, “I Have a Dream” was broadcast across the United States. This speech was a prime example of King’s continuous battle against segregation and discrimination in the United States. He received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1964 for his continued efforts against discrimination.


On the 3rd of April 1968, King delivered a speech in Memphis, Tennessee. In closing, he spoke about the future of the Civil Rights Movement:



Here we can see King’s complete devotion to the cause he spent most of his life fighting for. The following morning, he was assassinated on the balcony of the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, Tennessee.


Although King died at the young age of 39, his contribution to the Civil Rights Movement in America was enormous. He gave his life for the cause. But like he said in his final speech: “We’ve got some difficult days ahead. But it doesn’t matter with me now. … I want you to know tonight, that we, as a people, will get to the promised land.”


Nelson Mandela and the Anti-Apartheid Revolution


Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela (1918-2013) is perhaps the most famous South African person from the 20th Century. His open smile, friendly face and wise words are recognized in many countries across the world. He is universally known as a fighter for liberation, and is considered one of the founding fathers of the modern, democratic Republic of South Africa.


FW de Klerk and Nelson Mandela shake hands at the World Economic Forum in 1992


Mandela joined the African National Congress (ANC), a political party, in 1944 where he helped form the ANC Youth League. During most of the 1900s, the ANC actively fought the oppressive racist regime of the National Party, and Mandela’s efforts echoed the ANC’s battle against discrimination.


Mandela was arrested the first time on 5 December 1955. This arrest led to the Treason Trial, and he was only acquitted in 1961. He was then arrested and sent to prison on 11 June 1964, with a life sentence in prison.


Mandela spent the next 29 years in prison because he refused to stop fighting for the freedom of his people. While in jail on Robben Island in Cape Town, he continued the struggle together with his fellow prisoners. This is also where he wrote The Long Walk to Freedom, his famous autobiography.


This excerpt comes from Nelson Mandela’s famous statement from the dock at the opening of the defense case in the Rivonia Trial at the Pretoria Supreme Court, 20 April 1964:



Mandela was released from prison on 11 February 1990, nine days after then-president FW de Klerk unbanned the African National Congress. Nelson Mandela immediately entered into official talks to end the white minority rule in South Africa, and in 1991 he was elected President of the ANC. In 1993 Mandela and de Klerk won the Nobel Peace Prize for managing to bring South Africa’s apartheid to a peaceful end, and ushering the country into a new era where discrimination in all forms has no place.


Nelson Mandela died on 5 December 2013, having lived a life singularly dedicated to freedom for all the people of South Africa.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

apartheid

(noun) in South Africa, a system of discrimination on grounds of race

civil rights

(noun) the rights of citizens to political and social freedom and equality

equality

(noun) being treated the same, especially with rights and opportunities

liberation

(noun) free from oppression

protest

(noun) an objection to what has or is being done

title: Government in the United States
body_one:
Nashville Shows How Immigrants Benefit All


Photo: George Walker IV / The Tennessean


Many Americans may not know that Nashville has one of the fastest-growing immigrant populations in the country.


The immigrants in Nashville are from Somalia, Nepal and Laos. They're from Mexico and Bangladesh. Nashville even has the largest Kurdish community in the United States.


Immigrants work as teachers in our schools, doctors in our hospitals, and police officers in our neighborhoods. They start businesses and create jobs making this city a better place.


Obama talks about immigration reform in Nashville speech


When done right, immigration helps everyone. But our immigration system has been broken for a long time.


None of us likes the idea that someone could enjoy living in America without being responsible for America. But there are undocumented immigrants who live in America and want to take responsibility for our country but our laws won’t let them.


President Obama believe that the best way to solve this problem is by working together to pass a new immigration law. Until a law is passed by Congress, there are actions the president can take that will help make our immigration system better.


While most Americans support immigration reform, many disagree with the actions taken by the President. President Obama understand that many people worry that immigration will change this country. But our history and the facts show that immigrants are good for the economy.


Cities like Nashville show us is that we can work together to make sure that immigration works for everybody – because it's the right thing to do for our country.


That's what makes America special. We welcome hard workers and dreamers from all around the world. And if we keep people who work hard and dream big, there's no limit to what this country can achieve.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

achieve

(verb) to complete or accomplish something

economy

(noun) the wealth and resources of a country or region, especially in terms of the production and consumption of goods and services

immigrant

(noun) a person who comes to live permanently in a foreign country

limit

(noun) a point or level beyond which something does not or may not extend or pass

population

(noun) all of the people who live in a town or community

undocumented

(adj) not having the appropriate legal document or license

View the Original Article from the Tennessean
body_two:
Nashville Shows How Immigrants Benefit All


Photo: George Walker IV / The Tennessean


Many Americans think of Nashville as the home of country music, barbecue, and a hit TV show. They may not realize that, in recent years, Nashville also has had one of the fastest-growing immigrant populations in the country.


"New Nashvillians" are from Somalia and Nepal and Laos. They're from Mexico and Bangladesh. Nashville even has the largest Kurdish community in the United States. They work as teachers in our schools, doctors in our hospitals, and cops in our neighborhoods. They start small businesses and create jobs making this city a better place.


Obama lauds immigration reform in Nashville speech


When done right, immigration benefits everyone. But our immigration system has been broken for a long time. Families who try to come here the right way can get stuck in line for years.


Business owners who treat their workers well see other businesses exploit undocumented immigrants. None of us likes the idea that someone could reap the rewards of living in America without its responsibilities. And undocumented immigrants who live in America and want to take responsibility for their country have no way to safely do that.


President Obama believes that the best way to solve this problem is by working together to pass a commonsense immigration law. But until then, there are actions the president can take that will help make our immigration system smarter and fairer.


We're providing more resources at the border to help law enforcement personnel stop illegal crossings, and send home those who do cross over. We'll focus enforcement resources on people who are threats to our security – felons, not families; criminals, not children.


Rather than deport students, and separate families, and make it harder for law enforcement to do its job, we just need Congress to work with us to pass a commonsense law to fix our broken immigration system.


While most Americans support immigration reform, many disagree with the actions the president has taken. President Obama understand the concerns of those who worry that immigration will change this country. Yet our history and the facts show that immigrants are beneficial for the economy.


What cities like Nashville prove is that we can work together to make sure that immigration works for everybody – because it's the right thing to do for our economy and our communities.


That's what makes America exceptional. We welcome strivers and dreamers from all around the world, people who share our ideals and have the same dreams for our kids. And if we keep harnessing that potential, there's no limit to what this country can achieve.


Barack Obama is the 44th president of the United States of America.



Vocabulary

Word

Definition

benefit

(verb) to be useful or profitable to

commonsense

(noun) sound and prudent judgment based on a simple perception of the situation or facts

exploit

(verb) to use (someone or something) in a way that helps you unfairly

reap

(verb) receive (a reward or benefit) as a consequence of one's own or other people's actions

View the Original Article from the Tennessean
body_three:
Nashville Shows How Immigrants Benefit All


(Photo: George Walker IV / The Tennessean)


Many Americans think of Nashville as the home of country music, barbecue, and a hit TV show. What they may not realize is that, in recent years, Music City also has had one of the fastest-growing immigrant populations in the country.


"New Nashvillians" are from Somalia and Nepal and Laos. They're from Mexico and Bangladesh. Nashville even boasts the largest Kurdish community in the United States. They work as teachers in our schools, doctors in our hospitals, and cops in our neighborhoods. They start small businesses and create jobs making this city a more prosperous, more innovative place. "They" are "us."

Obama lauds immigration reform in Nashville speech


When done right, immigration benefits everyone. But our immigration system has been broken for a long time. Families who try to come here the right way can get stuck in line for years. Business owners who treat their workers right see the competition exploit undocumented immigrants. None of us likes the idea that someone could reap the rewards of living in America without its responsibilities. And folks who desperately want to embrace those responsibilities have no way to come out of the shadows and get right with the law.


A year and a half ago, a big majority of Democrats, Republicans, and Independents in the Senate came together to pass a commonsense, compromise bill to fix our broken immigration system. It would have helped strengthen border security, while giving undocumented immigrants who already live here a pathway to citizenship if they paid a fine, started paying their taxes, and went to the back of the line. Independent experts said it would grow our economy and shrink our deficits.


If the House of Representatives allowed a simple yes-or-no vote on that kind of bill, it would have passed into law. But for more than a year and a half, Republican leaders in the House have blocked that simple vote.


I still believe that the best way to solve this problem is by working together to pass that kind of law. But until then, there are actions I have the legal authority to take that will help make our immigration system smarter and fairer. And I took those actions last month.

We're providing more resources at the border to help law enforcement personnel stop illegal crossings, and send home those who do cross over. We'll focus enforcement resources on people who are threats to our security – felons, not families; criminals, not children.


And we'll bring out of the shadows many undocumented immigrants with children who are U.S. citizens or lawful permanent residents so they can play by the rules, pass a criminal background check, and get right with the law. This isn't amnesty, or legalization, or even a path to citizenship. It doesn't apply to anyone who has come to this country recently, or who might come illegally in the future. This is accountability.


These are the kind of lawful actions taken by every President, Republican and Democrat, for the past 50 years. So when folks in Congress question these actions to make our immigration system work better, I have one answer: Pass a bill. I want to work with both parties to get this done. And the day I sign that bill into law, the actions I've taken will no longer be necessary.


What's disappointing is that, so far, the only response from Republicans in the House was their vote last week to try to force talented young people and workers to leave our country. It makes no sense. Rather than deport students, and separate families, and make it harder for law enforcement to do its job, we just need Congress to work with us to pass a commonsense law to fix our broken immigration system.


Meanwhile, Washington shouldn't let disagreement over one issue be a deal breaker on every issue. That's not how our democracy works. Americans are tired of gridlock. We're ready to work together and move forward, just like so many Americans across the country do every day.


While most Americans support immigration reform, many disagree with the actions I've taken. I understand the concerns of those who worry that immigration will change the fabric of this country, or take our jobs, or stick it to the middle class. We've had those concerns since the Irish and Italians were sailing to Boston and New York. Yet our history and the facts show that immigrants are a net plus for the economy.


What cities like Nashville prove is that we can work together to address those concerns and make sure that immigration works for everybody – because it's the right thing to do for our economy and our communities. And a couple of weeks ago, I created a Task Force on New Americans, which will focus on integrating immigrants into communities across the country.


That's what makes America exceptional. We welcome strivers and dreamers from all around the world, people who share our ideals and have the same dreams for our kids. And if we keep harnessing that potential, there's no limit to what this country can achieve.


Barack Obama is the 44th president of the United States of America.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

prosperous

(adj) successful in material terms; flourishing financially

innovative

(adj) (of a person) introducing new ideas; original and creative in thinking

reap

(verb) receive (a reward or benefit) as a consequence of one's own or other people's actions

deficit

(noun) the amount by which something, especially a sum of money, is too small

amnesty

(noun) an official pardon for people who have been convicted of political offenses.

View the Original Article from the Tennessean

title: War and Conflict in the United States
body_one:
Protesters march on Washington, demand end to police violence


Angry over the deaths of unarmed black men at the hands of police officers, protesters hold national 'Day of Resistance'


Thousands of people marched through Washington on Saturday, protesting the recent deaths of unarmed black men. Saul Loeb / AFP / Getty Images


Thousands of protesters marched in Washington as part of a national "Day of Resistance". The protest helped to bring attention to the deaths of unarmed black men. The protesters asked the government for legislative action.


The protesters, carrying signs that read "black lives matter," started the march in Freedom Plaza. Protest organizers and family members of victims of police violence spoke to the crowd.


"Let's keep it strong, long and meaningful," said Esaw Garner, the wife of Eric Garner, 43, who died after being choked by a police officer.


Afterwards, thousands of marchers moved through the city.


Speaking at the march, Reverend Al Sharpton said "this is not a black march or a white march, this is an American march for the rights of the American people."


"We come to Washington to help people who have police violence in their own communities," he said.


Before dying, Garner repeatedly gasped "I can't breathe" — a sentence that has become a part of nationwide protests against police violence.


Sharpton asked Congress to pass laws that would protect citizens from police violence.


Other speakers included Lesley McSpadden.


"What a sea of people," she said. "If they don't see this and make a change, then I don't know what we have to do. Thank you for having my back."


Sybrina Fulton, the mother of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin, who was killed in 2012, also spoke.


"Don’t just come to the rally and go home. The numbers look nice. You guys look good out there, but it cannot stop here. This has to be the start," she said.


Also present were relatives of 12-year-old Tamir Rice, a boy who was shot and killed by a police officer who thought the boy’s toy gun was a real weapon.


Protests have been held all over the United States since the officers who killed Brown and Garner were not charged with a crime.


In response to the protests, politicians have talked about the need for better police training and body cameras.


"We need more than just talk; we need laws that will change things both in the law and in the streets," Sharpton said.


Protesters want to see justice for the victims of police killings.


"We are speaking for the unspoken for," said Khalil Norris, 40.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

chant

(verb) a repeated rhythmic phrase, typically one shouted or sung in unison by a crowd

gasp

(verb) inhale suddenly with the mouth open, out of pain or astonishment

legislative

(adj) of or relating to laws or the making of them

protest

(verb) to publicly demonstrates strong objection to something; to demonstrate

resistance

(noun) the refusal to accept or comply with something; the attempt to prevent something by action or argument

Read the original article on AlJazeera
body_two:
Protesters march on Washington, demand end to 'blue on black crime'


Angry over the deaths of unarmed black men at the hands of white officers, protesters stage national 'Day of Resistance'


Thousands of people marched through Washington on Saturday, protesting the recent deaths of unarmed black men at the hands of white police officers. Saul Loeb / AFP / Getty Images


Thousands of protesters marched in Washington on Saturday as part of a national "Day of Resistance" aimed at drawing attention to the deaths of unarmed black men at the hands of white police officers and calling for legislative action.


The crowd, carrying signs that read "black lives matter," gathered before the march in Freedom Plaza, where protest organizers and family members of victims of police brutality addressed the crowd.


"Let's keep it strong, long and meaningful," Esaw Garner – the wife of Eric Garner, 43, who died after being choked by a New York City police officer in July – told the crowd.


Afterwards, thousands of marchers moved through the city.


As the protesters approached Capitol Hill, where a rally was staged, many chanted “hands up, don’t shoot” — a reference to the alleged last words of Michael Brown, 18, who was shot and killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Missouri. Other chants included “no justice, no peace,”


Speaking at the rally, Reverend Al Sharpton declared "this is not a black march or a white march, this is an American march for the rights of the American people."


"We don’t come to Washington as shooters and chokers. We come as the shot and the choked to help citizens who can’t breathe in their own communities," he said.


Before dying, Garner repeatedly gasped "I can't breathe" — a statement that has become a rallying cry at nationwide protests against police violence.


Sharpton called on Congress to pass laws that would protect citizens from police brutality.


Other speakers included Lesley McSpadden, Brown's mother.


"What a sea of people," she said. "If they don't see this and make a change, then I don't know what we have to do. Thank you for having my back."


Sybrina Fulton, the mother of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin, who was killed in 2012 by a neighborhood watch volunteer in Florida, also spoke, urging those present to lift their voices beyond the rally.


"Don’t just come to the rally and go home. The numbers look nice. You guys look good out there, but it cannot stop here. This has to be the start," she said.


Also present were relatives of Tamir Rice, 12, who was shot and killed in November by a Cleveland police officer who thought the boy’s pellet gun was a real weapon.


Protests have been staged throughout the United States since grand juries in Missouri and New York did not indict the officers who killed Brown and Garner.


In response to the growing movement, politicians and others have talked about the need for better police training, body cameras and changes in the grand jury process to restore faith in the legal system.

The lack of criminal charges from grand juries in Missouri and New York motivated people to take action across the country.


"We need more than just talk; we need legal action that will shift things both in the law and in the streets," Sharpton said.


Protesters expressed their desire to see justice for the victims of police killings.

"We are speaking for the unspoken for," said Khalil Norris, 40.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

brutality

(noun) savage physical violence; great cruelty

indict

(verb) formally accuse of or charge with a serious crime

legislative

(adj) of or relating to laws or the making of them

protest

(verb) to publicly demonstrates strong objection to something; to demonstrate

resistance

(noun) the refusal to accept or comply with something; the attempt to prevent something by action or argument

Read the original article on AlJazeera
body_three:
Protesters march on Washington, demand end to 'blue on black crime'


Angry over the deaths of unarmed black men at the hands of white officers, protesters stage national 'Day of Resistance'


Thousands of people marched through Washington on Saturday, protesting the recent deaths of unarmed black men at the hands of white police officers. Saul Loeb / AFP / Getty Images


Thousands of protesters marched down iconic Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington on Saturday, before making their way to Capitol Hill as part of a national "Day of Resistance" aimed at drawing attention to the deaths of unarmed black men at the hands of white police officers and calling for legislative action.


The crowd, carrying signs that read "black lives matter," gathered before the march in Freedom Plaza, where protest organizers and family members of victims of police brutality addressed the crowd.


"Let's keep it strong, long and meaningful," Esaw Garner – the widow of Eric Garner, 43, who died after being choked by a New York City police officer in July – told the crowd.


Afterwards, block after block of tightly packed marchers moved through the city. Organizers had predicted 5,000 people would participate in the event, but the crowd appeared to be much larger than that.


As the protesters approached Capitol Hill, where a rally was staged, many chanted slogans including “hands up, don’t shoot” — a reference to the alleged last words of Michael Brown, 18, who was shot and killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Missouri, in August. Other chants included “no justice, no peace” and “can’t stop, won’t stop until killer cops are in cell blocks.”


Speaking at the rally, Rev. Al Sharpton, whose National Action Alliance led the protest, declared "this is not a black march or a white march, this is an American march for the rights of the American people."

"We don’t come to Washington as shooters and chokers. We come as the shot and the choked to help deal with citizens who can’t breathe in their own communities," he said.


Before dying, Garner repeatedly gasped "I can't breathe" — a statement that has become a rallying cry at nationwide protests against police violence.


Sharpton called on Congress to pass laws that would protect citizens from police brutality and let federal prosecutors take over cases involving alleged police crimes. Local prosecutors who work with police regularly and then must investigate officers face a conflict of interest, he said.


Other speakers included Lesley McSpadden, Brown's mother.


"What a sea of people," she said. "If they don't see this and make a change, then I don't know what we got to do. Thank you for having my back."


Sybrina Fulton, the mother of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin, who was killed in 2012 by a neighborhood watch volunteer in Florida, also spoke, urging those present to lift their voices beyond the rally.


"Don’t just come to the rally and go home. The numbers look nice. You guys look good out there, but it cannot stop here. This has to be the start," she said.


Also present were relatives of Tamir Rice, 12, who was shot and killed in November by a Cleveland police officer who said he mistook the boy’s pellet gun for a real weapon.


Protests – some violent – have been staged throughout the United States since grand juries in Missouri and New York declined to indict the officers who killed Brown and Garner.


In response to the growing movement, politicians and others have talked about the need for better police training, body cameras and changes in the grand jury process to restore faith in the legal system.

protests Terry Baisden, 52, of Baltimore said she is "hopeful change is coming" and that the movement is not part of a fleeting flash of anger.


She said she hasn't protested before but felt compelled to because "changes in action, changes in belief, happen in numbers."


The lack of criminal charges from grand juries in Missouri and New York have galvanized activists across the country.

"We need more than just talk; we need legislative action that will shift things both on the books and in the streets," Sharpton said in a statement ahead of Saturday's event.


While protesters marched in Washington, other events were also planned throughout the U.S. — including San Francisco and New York City, where organizers said thousands of people attended a march that temporarily shut down the Brooklyn Bridge.


New York City police said protesters assaulted two officers when they tried to arrest a man who was attempting to toss a garbage can off the bridge and onto police below. Some marchers then blocked traffic on the bridge for about an hour. Police say there were no arrests in that incident, but a backpack full of hammers and a mask was found.


The events were otherwise peaceful. Starting at 2 p.m., thousands of people marched up 6th Avenue in Manhattan before turning down Broadway at dusk. Like their counterparts in Washington, they expressed their desire to see justice for the victims of police killings.


"We are speaking for the unspoken for," said Khalil Norris, 40.


Many also lambasted what they said was racism in the New York City police department and other forces across the country.


“It’s open season on black people now,” New York march co-organizer Umaara Elliott said in a statement. “So we demand that action be taken at every level of government to ensure that these racist killings by the police cease.”


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

brutality

(noun) savage physical violence; great cruelty

galvanize

(verb) shocked or excited (someone), typically into taking action

indict

(verb) formally accuse of or charge with a serious crime

legislative

(adj) of or relating to laws or the making of them

protest

(verb) to publicly demonstrates strong objection to something; to demonstrate

resistance

(noun) the refusal to accept or comply with something; the attempt to prevent something by action or argument

Read the original article on AlJazeera

title: Introduction
body_one:
The decisions you make have an impact on the environment. For example, did you know that your shower might use two gallons of fresh water every minute? Taking shorter showers is one way to save water!


Do you use disposable plastic water bottles? Did you know that millions of barrels of oil are used to make disposable water bottles? Drinking water from a reusable bottle saves energy used making plastic bottles.



Every day, people around the world makes decisions that impact the environment. Because each of us has an impact on the environment, we all need to work together to protect it!


Protecting the Planet


Over the next six weeks, you will learn about important environmental issues.


First, you and your PenPals will learn about ways that humans impact the environment. You will learn about bees and important pollinating insects. You will study the oceans and coral reefs. Then, you and your PenPals will learn about earthquakes happening across the United States.


In Week 4 and Week 5, you and your PenPals will learn about people who help the environment. You will meet a group of young women fighting to protect animals in South Africa. You will then learn about a famous conservationist who helps protect the world’s oceans.


In Week 6, you and your PenPals will learn about young people just like you. These young people are working hard to help the environment in their own communities.


How to be a Great PenPal


Being a great PenPal starts with respect. Your PenPals are students just like you. Sometimes, you and your PenPals might agree. Sometimes, you and your PenPals might disagree.


Show respect by writing every week. Also show respect by using appropriate language. If your PenPal has a question, make sure to help.



If your PenPals say something that you don’t agree with, ask your PenPals a question about what they said. If your PenPal writes something inappropriate, report the message and our team will reviewed it.



Write to Your Future PenPals


Soon you will be matched with PenPals! So let’s get ready by answering this week’s discussion question! Scroll to the top of the page. There you will find the discussion question on the right.



Each week, answer the weekly discussion question.


After you answer this week’s discussion question, use the chat section underneath to tell your future PenPals about yourself. Then ask your PenPals some questions about their communities.
body_two:
Did you know that the everyday decisions you make have an impact on the environment? For example, did you know that your shower uses an average of two gallons of fresh water every minute?

Or how about those plastic water bottles we use then throw away? Did you know that over 17 million barrels of oil are used every year to make disposable plastic water bottles? Drinking water from a reusable bottle not only saves energy used making plastic bottles, but also saves energy used to transport and dispose of each bottle.



Every day, every person around the world makes decisions that impact the environment. And because each and every one of us has an impact on the environment, we need to work together to think of better ways to protect it!


Protecting the Planet


Over the next six weeks, you and your PenPals will learn about and discuss important environmental issues.


During the first three weeks, you and your PenPals will learn about different ways that humans impact the environment. You will learn about bees and the impact humans have on these important pollinating insects. You’ll study the oceans and learn how people around the world are harming coral reefs. Then, you and your PenPals will learn about earthquakes across the United States that may be caused by the extraction of natural gas from wells deep inside the earth.


In Week 4 and Week 5, you and your PenPals will learn about people who are working hard to protect the environment. You will meet a group of young women fighting to protect animals in South Africa. You will then learn about a famous conservationist who has dedicated her life to protecting the world’s oceans.


During Week 6, you and your PenPals will learn about young people just like you who are working hard to draw attention to environmental issues both in their communities and around the world.


How to be a Great PenPal


You are about to join thousands of students from more than one hundred different countries who are learning and sharing perspectives with PenPals from around the world!



Being a great PenPal starts with respect. Your PenPals are students just like you, so remember to always be respectful of them and their opinions! Write to your PenPals every week, use appropriate language, and help your PenPals when they have questions.


It's ok to disagree with your PenPals as long as you are polite. If your PenPals say something that you don’t agree with, ask your PenPals to explain their thinking. Remember, if your PenPal writes something inappropriate, flag the message and it will be reviewed by the PenPal Schools team.



Write to Your Future PenPals


So let’s get ready for your PenPal exchange by answering this week’s discussion question! Scroll to the top of the page and find the discussion question on the right side. Make sure to refer to the text and video when answering the question.



Each week, answer the weekly discussion question.


After you answer this week’s discussion question, use the chat section underneath to tell your future PenPals about yourself. Then ask your PenPals some questions about their communities.


Once matched, your PenPals can read and reply to your answers so you’ll already have something to talk about!

title: Saving Rhinos
body_one:
South Africa's rhinoceroses are under attack. A group of women rangers is working to protect the animals.


By Aryn Baker for TIME, adapted by TIME Edge Editors

November 2, 2015


One night in late September, Leitah Mkhabele, 22, was patrolling South Africa's Balule Nature Reserve when she heard poachers creeping through the underbrush. Mkhabele and Nkateko Mzimba, 24, stepped closer. Poachers had killed one of the reserve's rhinoceroses the month before. The two women weren't about to let it happen again. Mzimba radioed back to base for backup. The noise alerted the three poachers, who turned in their direction. Mkhabele was not armed. If one of the poachers had a gun, she could be shot. So she ran.


The poachers fled before backup arrived. But Mkhabele and Mzimba had done exactly what they were supposed to: They kept poachers out of the park. The two belong to the Black Mambas, a nearly all-woman group created to protect rhinos.


The crew of 23 women and three men is on the lookout for traps, poacher camps, broken fences, and animals that need help. They take their name from the black mamba snake. "We are strong, and fast like snakes, so they call us the Black Mambas," Mzimba says. "I am very proud of us, because we are working in the bush, without guns, as women. It means we are strong."


Black Mambas founder Craig Spencer has changed the rules in a war between poachers and wildlife protectors. Instead of men with guns, the scouts are unarmed women.


JULIA GUNTHER


Two of the Black Mambas disable a trap laid by poachers.


Rhinos Deserve to Survive


In parts of Asia, rhinoceros horn is believed to cure illnesses, even though scientific research has shown that it does not. The demand for rhino horn is high. A couple of pounds of it can sell for $65,000.


Of the estimated 28,000 rhinos left in the wild, approximately 90% are in South Africa. Poachers killed at least 1,215 rhinos last year, up from 13 in 2007.


GETTY IMAGES


Rhino horns sell for thousands of dollars on the international black market.


Mkhabele worries that by the time her 2-year-old son grows up, the only rhinos he sees will be on TV. Rhinos, she says, "deserve to survive."


The Power of Education


The Black Mambas' most important role may be in teaching the value of wildlife to people who live in the poor nearby townships. Many don't understand why they cannot graze their cattle in the reserves or hunt game freely. The Black Mambas, who come from the same neighborhoods, want to change that view.


Belinda Mzimba joined the Mambas 18 months ago. She visits schools to tell students about South Africa's "big five"—lions, elephants, rhinos, buffaloes, and leopards. She tells them, "When you grow up, you don't need to poach, because the big-five animals will earn the money." Jobs come from tourism, she explains, but without the big five, the tourists won't come.


JULIA GUNTHER


For the past two years, the Black Mamba Anti-Poaching Unit has patrolled the Balule Nature Reserve, in northern South Africa.


Spencer says the Mambas have played an important role in the reserve. But it is not certain that they can succeed in other areas. According to Mkhabele, the solution has to start with the poachers. "They won't stop unless they run out. After rhinos, they will go for the elephants. After the elephants, they will go for other things," she says.


COURTESY BLACK MAMBA ANTI-POACHING UNIT


Teaching children about wildlife conservation is an important part of the Black Mambas’ job.


"There will always be a reason to poach, until we make people understand that without our animals, South Africa is nothing," Mkhabele says. That's where the Black Mambas come in. They may not be able to stop poachers with force. But they can stop them with education.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

poacher

noun: one who kills or takes wild animals illegally

reserve

noun: a tract of public land set apart for a special purpose

underbrush

noun: shrubs and small trees in a forest
body_two:
South Africa’s rhinos are under attack. A group of women scouts is working to protect the animals.


By Aryn Baker for TIME, adapted by TIME Edge Editors

November 2, 2015


One night in late September, 22-year-old Leitah Mkhabele was patrolling South Africa’s Balule Nature Reserve when she heard the sound of poachers creeping through the underbrush. They must have clipped a hole in the fence, thought Mkhabele. She and her patrolling partner, 24-year-old Nkateko Mzimba, stepped closer.


Poachers had killed one of the reserve’s rhinos the month before. The two women weren’t about to let it happen again. Mzimba radioed back to base for backup. The noise alerted the three poachers, who turned in their direction. Mkhabele raised her pepper spray, then paused. In the dark, she couldn’t tell what was slung over the first man’s shoulder. Was it a gun or equipment for setting a trap? She did a quick calculation. If it was a gun, she could be shot before the poacher got within range of her pepper spray. So she ran.


The poachers fled before backup arrived. Mkhabele and Mzimba were frustrated that the trespassers had gotten away. But to their bosses, they had done exactly what they were supposed to: They proved that the Black Mambas, a nearly all-woman anti-poaching group created to protect rhinos, could keep poachers out of the park.


JULIA GUNTHER


Two of the Black Mambas disable a trap laid by poachers.


The Race to Save Rhinos


The Black Mambas just may be the most innovative attempt to save wild rhinos. By employing women as scouts instead of men with guns, Black Mambas founder Craig Spencer has changed the rules in a war between poachers and wildlife protectors.


In parts of Vietnam and China, rhinoceros horn is believed to cure a number of medical ailments, even though scientific research has shown that it does not. As incomes rise in these countries, so does the demand for rhino horn. A little more than a couple of pounds of it can sell for $65,000.


Of the estimated 28,000 rhinos left in the wild, approximately 90% are in South Africa. But the country is struggling to keep them safe. At least 1,215 rhinos were killed by poachers in South Africa last year, up from 13 in 2007. At this rate, South Africa will see more rhinos killed for their horns than born within the next few years. Mkhabele worries that by the time her 2-year-old son grows up, the only rhinoceroses he will see will be on TV. Rhinos, she says, “deserve to survive. They shouldn’t be killed for something that is not true.”


GETTY IMAGES


Rhino horns sell for thousands of dollars on the international black market.


In order to stop the poachers, South African conservationists and law enforcement groups have deployed heavily armed guards, surveillance planes, drones, canine units, tracking devices, and even horn-mounted spy cameras. Private game-reserve operators have shaved down their rhinoceroses’ horns to make the animals less attractive as targets. (Like fingernails and horses’ hooves, rhino horn can be removed in a painless process.) Still the poachers come. The half-pound of horn embedded in a rhino’s skull makes the risk worthwhile.


A Low-Tech Solution


Armed only with walkie-talkies, handcuffs, and pepper spray, the Black Mambas may be the most low-tech solution of all. The 23 female and three male Black Mambas patrol for traps, poacher camps, broken fences, and distressed animals. They take their name from the black mamba snake, says Mzimba. “We are strong, and fast like snakes, so they call us the Black Mambas.”


Mkhabele would like to have a gun for self-protection. But Spencer argues that arming the Mambas would make them even more vulnerable to attack. “The role they play is purely observation. If they had weapons, the poachers would up their game,” says Spencer. He may have a point: Despite several run-ins with poachers, none of the Mambas has been seriously wounded.


Not only are they challenging poachers, but they are taking on stereotypes, says Mzimba. “They say women can’t work in the bush. So I am very proud of us here, because we are working in the bush. Without guns, as women. It means we are strong.”


JULIA GUNTHER


For the past two years, the Black Mamba Anti-Poaching Unit has patrolled the Balule Nature Reserve, in northern South Africa.


Valuable Lessons


Their most important role, however, isn’t in the reserve. It is in teaching the value of wildlife to Their most important role, however, isn’t in the reserve. It is in teaching the value of wildlife to residents of the impoverished townships nearby, where most poachers originate. Many locals see wildlife sanctuaries as places for wealthy tourists. They find it frustrating that they cannot graze their cattle in the reserves or hunt game freely like their ancestors did.


The Black Mambas, who come from the same neighborhoods, are tasked with changing that view. Spencer chose to hire women. He thought they would be better at bringing the conservation message home. They have embraced the responsibility. Belinda Mzimba, who joined the Mambas 18 months ago with her cousin, Nkateko Mzimba, makes a point of visiting schools to tell students about South Africa’s “big five”—lions, elephants, rhinos, buffaloes, and leopards. She tells them, “When you grow up, you don’t need to go to poaching, because the big-five animals will earn the money.” Jobs come from tourism, she explains. Without the big five, the tourists won’t come. “You can’t be a tour guide, a field guide, if there is no nature left.”


COURTESY BLACK MAMBA ANTI-POACHING UNIT


Teaching children about wildlife conservation is an important part of the Black Mambas’ job.


Spencer says the Mambas have played a significant role in reducing traps and keeping poachers from setting up camp in the privately-run reserve. But it is not certain that their successes can be reproduced in other areas. Rhinos may be safe in Balule’s 154 square miles. But once they cross the open border into Kruger National Park, with its 7,523 square miles of unfenced savanna, they are much more vulnerable. To duplicate the Mambas’ successes, Kruger would require thousands of patrollers. As it is, Spencer spends about $20,000 a month on security for Balule, and he’s still lost five rhinos in the past two years.


According to Mkhabele, the solution has to start with the poachers, who earn little money risking their lives to deliver horns to the smugglers. Every time she questions a poacher, he says he does it because he doesn’t have a job. “They won’t stop unless they run out. After rhinos, they will go for the elephants. After the elephants, they will go for other things,” says Mkhabele. In Asia, there is now demand for lion bone. And rumors are now swirling in her community that giraffe parts can cure disease.


“There will always be a reason to poach, until we make people understand that without our animals, South Africa is nothing,” says Mkhabele. That’s where the Black Mambas come in. They may not be able to stop poachers with pepper spray. But they can stop them with education.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

the bush

noun: a large uncleared or sparsely settled area; wilderness

pepper spray

noun: a substance made from a chemical found in peppers that causes temporary blindness and pain to the nose, throat, and skin when it is sprayed on someone

poacher

noun: one who kills or takes wild animals illegally

stereotype

noun: a shared, often unfair and untrue belief people about a particular gender, race, or background

vulnerable

adjective: open to attack or harm
body_three:
South Africa’s rhinos are under attack. A group of women scouts is working to protect the animals.


By Aryn Baker for TIME, adapted by TIME Edge Editors

November 2, 2015


One night in late September, 22-year-old Leitah Mkhabele was patrolling South Africa’s Balule Nature Reserve when she heard the sound of poachers creeping through the underbrush. “They must have clipped a hole in the fence,” thought Mkhabele, as she and her patrolling partner, 24-year-old Nkateko Mzimba, stepped closer.


Poachers had killed one of the reserve’s rhinos the month before, and the two women weren’t about to let it happen again. Mzimba radioed back to base for backup. The noise alerted the three poachers, who turned in their direction. Mkhabele raised her pepper spray, then paused. In the dark, she couldn’t tell what was slung over the first man’s shoulder. Was it a gun, or equipment for setting a trap? She did a quick calculation. If it was a gun, she could be shot before the poacher got within range of her pepper spray. So she ran.


The poachers fled before backup arrived. Mkhabele and Mzimba were frustrated that the trespassers had gotten away. But to their bosses, they had done exactly what they were supposed to: They proved that the Black Mambas, a nearly all-woman anti-poaching group created to protect rhinos, could keep poachers out of the park.


JULIA GUNTHER


Two of the Black Mambas disable a trap laid by poachers.


The Race to Save Rhinos


The Black Mambas just may be the most innovative attempt to save wild rhinos. By employing women as scouts instead of men with guns, Black Mambas founder Craig Spencer has changed the rules in a war between poachers and wildlife protectors.


In parts of Vietnam and China, rhinoceros horn is believed to cure a number of medical ailments, even though scientific research has shown that it does not. As incomes rise in these countries, so does the demand for rhino horn. A little more than a couple of pounds of it can sell for $65,000.


Of the estimated 28,000 rhinos left in the wild, approximately 90% are in South Africa, but the country is struggling to keep them safe. At least 1,215 rhinos were killed by poachers in South Africa last year, up from 13 in 2007. At this rate, South Africa will see more rhinos killed for their horns than born within the next few years. Mkhabele worries that by the time her 2-year-old son grows up, the only rhinoceroses he will see will be on TV. Rhinos, she says, “deserve to survive. They shouldn’t be killed for something that is not true.”


GETTY IMAGES


Rhino horns sell for thousands of dollars on the international black market.


In order to stop the poachers, South African conservationists and law enforcement groups have deployed heavily armed guards, surveillance planes, drones, canine units, tracking devices, and even horn-mounted spy cameras. Private game-reserve operators have shaved down their rhinoceroses’ horns to make the animals less attractive as targets. (Like fingernails and horses’ hooves, rhino horn can be removed in a painless process.) Still the poachers come—the half-pound of horn embedded in a rhino’s skull makes the risk worthwhile.


A Low-Tech Solution


Armed only with walkie-talkies, handcuffs, and pepper spray, the Black Mambas may be the most low-tech solution of all. The 23 female and three male Black Mambas patrol for traps, poacher camps, broken fences, and distressed animals. They take their name from the black mamba snake, says Mzimba: “We are strong, and fast like snakes, so they call us the Black Mambas.”


Mkhabele would like to have a gun for self-protection, but Spencer argues that arming the Mambas would make them even more vulnerable to attack. “The role they play is purely observation. If they had weapons, the poachers would up their game,” says Spencer. He may have a point: Despite several run-ins with poachers, none of the Mambas has been seriously wounded.


Not only are they challenging poachers, but they are taking on stereotypes, says Mzimba. “They say women can’t work in the bush, so I am very proud of us here, because we are working in the bush. Without guns, as women. It means we are strong.”


JULIA GUNTHER


For the past two years, the Black Mamba Anti-Poaching Unit has patrolled the Balule Nature Reserve, in northern South Africa.


Valuable Lessons


Their most important role, however, isn’t in the reserve. It is in teaching the value of wildlife to residents of the impoverished townships nearby, where most poachers originate. Many locals see wildlife sanctuaries as places for wealthy tourists. They find it frustrating that they cannot graze their cattle in the reserves, or hunt game freely like their ancestors did.


The Black Mambas, who come from the same neighborhoods, are tasked with changing that view. Spencer chose to hire women because he thought they would be better at bringing the conservation message home. They have embraced the responsibility. Belinda Mzimba, who joined the Mambas 18 months ago with her cousin, Nkateko Mzimba, makes a point of visiting schools to tell students about South Africa’s “big five”—lions, elephants, rhinos, buffaloes, and leopards. She tells them, “When you grow up, you don’t need to go to poaching, because the big-five animals will earn the money.” Jobs come from tourism, she explains, and without the big five, the tourists won’t come. “You can’t be a tour guide, a field guide, if there is no nature left.”


COURTESY BLACK MAMBA ANTI-POACHING UNIT


Teaching children about wildlife conservation is an important part of the Black Mambas’ job.


Spencer says the Mambas have played a significant role in reducing traps and keeping poachers from setting up camp in the privately run reserve. But it is not certain that they can succeed in other areas. Rhinos may be safe in Balule’s 154 square miles, but once they cross the open border into Kruger National Park, with its 7,523 square miles of unfenced savanna, they are much more vulnerable. To reproduce the Mambas’ successes, Kruger would require thousands of patrollers. As it is, Spencer spends about $20,000 a month on security for Balule, and he’s still lost five rhinos in the past two years.


According to Mkhabele, the solution has to start with the poachers, who earn little money risking their lives to deliver horns to the smugglers. Every time she questions a poacher, he says he does it because he doesn’t have a job. “They won’t stop unless they run out. After rhinos, they will go for the elephants. After the elephants, they will go for other things,” says Mkhabele. In Asia, there is now demand for lion bone. And rumors are now swirling in her community that giraffe parts can cure disease.


“There will always be a reason to poach, until we make people understand that without our animals, South Africa is nothing,” says Mkhabele. That’s where the Black Mambas come in. They may not be able to stop poachers with pepper spray. But they can stop them with education.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

pepper spray

noun: a substance made from a chemical found in peppers that causes temporary blindness and pain to the nose, throat, and skin when it is sprayed on someone

poacher

noun: one who kills or takes wild animals illegally

stereotype

noun: a shared, often unfair and untrue belief people about a particular gender, race, or background

vulnerable

adjective: open to attack or harm

title: The Conclusion
body_one:
Effective argument writing contains a conclusion. The conclusion comes at the end of a piece of writing, and its purpose is to tie all parts of the argument together and reinforce the claim that was made in the topic sentence. This week, you and your pen pal will learn about three different types of conclusion sentences. Then, you and your pen pal will draft the conclusion to your argument paragraph. Finally, you and your pen pal will share your conclusions and peer review one another’s argument paragraph.


Lesson Objectives:

  • Watch a short video to explore vocabulary related to argument writing

  • Learn the difference between formal and informal style

  • Draft a conclusion to your own argument paragraph

  • Review your pen pal’s work and share your feedback



Effective argument writing contains a conclusions. The conclusion often provides the “clincher” to an argument and may be the final piece of information needed to motivate and convince your reader.


A conclusion:


  • Ties all of the parts of the argument together and reminds readers about the claim in light of the evidence presented in the paragraph


  • Rounds off the paragraph, flows naturally from what has been written, and does not raise new issues or present new reasoning


  • Reinforces the claim stated in the topic sentence and shares a final observation or thought


So now that you know what a conclusion does, let’s take a look at three different types of conclusions:



Complete the Questions for Part 1 before moving on to Part 2!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)




Using a variety of words and sentences in writing is a great way to add interest and establish a formal style.  Let’s take a look at two argument writing samples: one written in a formal style, and the other written in an informal style.



What are the differences between the formal and informal writing samples? Who might be the audience of each paragraph? What evidence does each piece of writing present to support the writer’s claim?


First, you might notice that the two paragraphs share a different point of view. The informal paragraph uses first-person point of view. The writer uses language like “I,” “we,” and “myself,” and is limited to talking about his or her own experiences. Using third-person point of view, like in the formal sample, allows the writer to approach the topic as an outsider. As an outsider, the writer seems less biased and more convincing.


You might also notice that the formal writing sample follows the traffic light colors. Each new idea is introduced with a transition and supported by evidence. The introduction and conclusions sentences state the writer’s claim and support the argument that violence on television is harmful to viewers. The informal paragraph, on the other hand, sounds as if it were a conversation between two friends. While a claim is made in the introduction, the claim is not well supported throughout the paragraph.


Directions: Now it is your turn. Think about the strategies described in parts one and two and add a conclusion to your argument paragraph. Then check your draft to see if you have maintained a formal style and objective tone in your writing. A formal style and objective tone will help make your argument more convincing.


Complete the Questions for Part 2 before moving on to Part 3!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)





After working hard on formal style and drafting your paragraph’s conclusion, it is time for another round of peer review!


Directions: Review the roles of a peer reviewer. Then, study your pen pal’s argument paragraph draft. Celebrate your pen pal’s great ideas! Ask questions about the ideas you find confusing. Last, thank your pen pal for the feedback he or she shares on your own writing!



Complete the questions located at the bottom of this page! After answering each of your questions, read and respond to your pen pal’s answers!



Word

Definition

biased

(adj) when someone is prejudiced for or against something

clincher

(noun) a statement made at the end of a piece of writing that is direct and motivates your reader

conclusion

(noun) a statement made at the end of a piece of writing that is formal and offers food for thought

convince

(verb) to cause someone to believe something
