title: Helen Joseph and Rosa Parks
body_one:
Women Fight for Equality


Discrimination takes many shapes. People are discriminated against based on their race, religion, ethnic group, economic status, and also gender.


Women around the world dedicate their lives to challenge these different kinds of inequality. Like Dr. King, Mr. Mandela, and Mahatma Gandhi, women around the world play a crucial role in the fight against racial discrimination.


Helen Joseph and Apartheid Opposition


Helen Joseph was a South African anti-apartheid activist.  Helen Joseph was born in England went to college in London. From London she went to work as a teacher in India.  In 1931, Joseph went to South Africa.


The four leaders of the Women’s March delivering their petitions to the Union Buildings on 9 August 1956.  They are from Left to Right (Rahima Moosa, Lilian Ngoyi, Helen Joseph, and Sophie Williams).

Source: T Nuttal et al., From Apartheid to Democracy: South Africa 1948 - 1994 1997, Shuter & Shooter


Ms. Joseph was shocked by the cruel way black women were treated.  She decided to help start the Federation of South African Women.


Through her work she led a march of 20 000 women to Pretoria to protest pass laws. This day, 9 August 1956, is still celebrated in South Africa as Women’s Day.


Helen was also accused in the 1956 Treason Trial alongside Nelson Mandela. She was arrested on a charge of high treason in December 1956 and banned in 1957.


She narrowly escaped death more than once. Joseph was attached by bullets shot through her bedroom and a bomb wired to her front gate.


Her last banning order was lifted when she was 80 years old. Helen Joseph died on 25 December 1992 at the age of 87


Rosa Parks and Montgomery, Alabama


An important event in the American Civil Rights Movement happened in December 1955 in Montgomery, Alabama.


During the 1950s segregation laws were strong in Alabama. Theatres, schools, parks, restaurants and buses were segregated.


Rosa Parks is fingerprinted at a police station after her arrest in Montgomery, Alabama on 1 December 1955.

Credit: usembassythehague via flickr


On 1 December 1955 a black woman named Rosa Parks was arrested after refusing to give up her seat for a white man on a bus.


The next day, black people in Montgomery started to boycott the bus service.  The boycott lasted a year for the whole year. In 1956, the US Supreme Court ruled that segregated transportation was illegal.


Rosa Parks was born in 1913 in Tuskegee, Alabama. She saw racism and segregation from an early age.


Parks recalled going to elementary school and seeing that the white children took the bus, and that black children had to walk:



Rosa Parks was one of the most influential people in the American Civil Rights Movement.


The United States Congress called her “the first lady of civil rights” and “the mother of the freedom movement”.  


Rosa Parks was brave in standing up against discrimination laws in Alabama. Her non-violent protest inspired people across the United States stand-up for equality.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

activist

(noun) a person who works with others to make changes

banning

(verb) an action by South Africa’s apartheid government that prohibited people and organizations from gathering

boycott

(verb) to refuse to buy or use something as a way of protest

gender

(noun) traditionally, being a male or female

pass laws

(noun) laws during apartheid South Africa that forced black people to carry passes. The passes only allowed South Africa’s black population access to certain areas, and it was used as a tool to further the racial segregation in the country.

economic

(adj) the relationship of both social and economic (wealth) factors.
body_two:
Women in the Fight Against Discrimination


Discrimination takes many forms. People are discriminated against based on their race, religion, ethnic group, economic status, and also gender. Women around the world dedicate their lives to challenge these different kinds of inequality.


Women like Esther Murugi Mathenge, a Kenyan Member of Parliament, advocate equality for women in politics, as well as elderly women in rural Kenya.


In India, Lakshmi Nayak organised self-help groups in her community before being elected as chairperson of her provincial forest constituency. She now helps build roads and other important projects in India’s poverty-stricken communities.


Gender inequality still exists around the world. But despite often unfair treatment, women work hard to overcome obstacles and become champions for equality and change. Like Dr. King, Mr. Mandela, and Mahatma Gandhi, women around the world play a crucial role in fighting racial discrimination.


Helen Joseph and Apartheid Opposition


Helen Joseph was a South African anti-apartheid activist.  Helen Joseph was born in England and attended college in London. From London she went to work as a teacher in India for three years.  In 1931, Joseph came to South Africa. She served in the Women’s Auxiliary Air Force during World War II and later became a social worker.


The four leaders of the Women’s March delivering their petitions to the Union Buildings on 9 August 1956.  They are from Left to Right (Rahima Moosa, Lilian Ngoyi, Helen Joseph, and Sophie Williams).

Source: T Nuttal et al., From Apartheid to Democracy: South Africa 1948 - 1994 1997, Shuter & Shooter


Ms. Joseph was shocked by the cruel treatment of black women.  She played an important role in starting the Federation of South African Women.


Through her work with the Federation of South African women she led a march of 20 000 women to Pretoria, one of South Africa’s capital cities, to protest pass laws. This day, 9 August 1956, is still celebrated in South Africa as Women’s Day.


Helen was also a defendant at the 1956 Treason Trial alongside Nelson Mandela. She was arrested on a charge of high treason in December 1956 and banned in 1957.


She narrowly escaped death more than once. Joseph was attached by bullets shot through her bedroom and a bomb wired to her front gate. Her last banning order was lifted when she was 80 years old. Helen Joseph died on 25 December 1992 at the age of 87


Rosa Parks and Montgomery, Alabama


A key event in the history of the American Civil Rights Movement took place in December 1955 in Montgomery, Alabama. During the 1950s segregation laws were strong in Alabama. Theatres, schools, parks, restaurants and buses were segregated.


Rosa Parks is fingerprinted at a police station after her arrest in Montgomery, Alabama on 1 December 1955.

Credit: usembassythehague via flickr


On 1 December 1955 a black woman named Rosa Parks, the secretary of the local branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), was arrested after refusing to give up her seat for a white man on a bus.


The next day, black people in Montgomery started to boycott the bus service.  The boycott lasted a year for the whole year. In 1956, the US Supreme Court ruled that segregated transportation was illegal.


Rosa Parks was born in 1913 in Tuskegee, Alabama. She saw racism and segregation from an early age.


Parks recalled when going to elementary school that white children took the bus, but that black children had to walk:



Rosa Parks was one of the most influential people in the American Civil Rights Movement. The United States Congress called her “the first lady of civil rights” and “the mother of the freedom movement”.


The conversation below is from questions she was asked about 1 December 1955, when she refused to get out of her seat for a white person.



Vocabulary

Word

Definition

banning

(verb) an action by South Africa’s apartheid government that prohibited people and organizations from gathering

boycott

(verb) to refuse to buy or use something as a way of protest

gender inequality

(noun) unequal or discriminatory treatment of people based on their gender (traditionally male or female)

pass laws

(noun) laws during apartheid South Africa that forced black people to carry passes. The passes only allowed South Africa’s black population access to certain areas, and it was used as a tool to further the racial segregation in the country.

economic

(adj) the relationship of both social and economic (wealth) factors.
body_three:
Women in the Fight Against Discrimination


Discrimination takes many forms. People are discriminated against based on their race, religion, ethnic group, socioeconomic class, and also gender. Women around the world dedicate their lives to challenge these different kinds of inequality.


Women like Esther Murugi Mathenge, a Kenyan Member of Parliament, advocate equality for women in politics, as well as elderly women in rural Kenya.


In India, Lakshmi Nayak organised self-help groups in her community before being elected as chairperson of her provincial forest constituency. In this role, Ms. Nayak enables the building of roads and other important infrastructure in poverty-stricken communities.


Gender inequality still exists around the world. But despite often unfair treatment, women have worked hard to overcome countless obstacles and become champions for equality and change. Like Dr. King, Mr. Mandela, and Mahatma Gandhi, women around the world play a crucial role in fighting racial discrimination.


Helen Joseph and Apartheid Opposition


Helen Joseph was a South African anti-apartheid activist who was born in England and graduated from King’s College in London in 1927. After working as a teacher in India for three years, Joseph came to South Africa in 1931. She served in the Women’s Auxiliary Air Force during World War II as an information and welfare officer, and later became a social worker.


In 1951 Helen Joseph took a job with the Garment Workers’ Union, led by Emil Solomon “Solly” Sachs. Joseph was a founding member of the Congress of Democrats, and one of the leaders who read out clauses of the Freedom Charter at the Congress of the People in Kliptown in 1955.


The four leaders of the Women’s March delivering their petitions to the Union Buildings on 9 August 1956.  They are from Left to Right (Rahima Moosa, Lilian Ngoyi, Helen Joseph, and Sophie Williams).

Source: T Nuttal et al., From Apartheid to Democracy: South Africa 1948 - 1994 1997, Shuter & Shooter


Ms. Joseph was shocked by the plight of black women, and played an important role in the formation of the Federation of South African Women. Along with the organisation’s leadership, she headed a march of 20 000 women to the Union Buildings in Pretoria to protest against pass laws, on 9 August 1956. This day is still celebrated in South Africa as Women’s Day.


Helen was also a defendant at the 1956 Treason Trial alongside Nelson Mandela. She was arrested on a charge of high treason in December 1956 and banned in 1957. On 13 October 1962 she became the first person to be placed under house arrest under the Sabotage Act introduced by the apartheid government. She narrowly escaped death more than once, surviving bullets shot through her bedroom and a bomb wired to her front gate. Her last banning order was lifted when she was 80 years old. Helen Joseph died on 25 December 1992 at the age of 87


Rosa Parks and Montgomery, Alabama


One of the key events that triggered the American Civil Rights Movement took place in December 1955 in the town of Montgomery, Alabama. During the 1950s segregation laws were still strong in Alabama. Theatres, schools, parks, restaurants and buses were all segregated – black people were not allowed to use the parts of these places designated for whites only.


Rosa Parks is fingerprinted at a police station after her arrest in Montgomery, Alabama on 1 December 1955.

Credit: usembassythehague via flickr


On 1 December 1955 a black woman named Rosa Parks, the secretary of the local branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), was arrested after refusing to give up her seat for a white man on a bus.


The next day, black people in Montgomery started to boycott the bus service, a campaign that lasted a year. They took the matter to court and, in 1956, the US Supreme Court ruled that segregated transport was unconstitutional – and therefore illegal.


Rosa Parks was born in 1913 in Tuskegee, Alabama. She was confronted with racism and segregation from an early stage in her life.


Parks recalled when going to elementary school that white children took the bus, but that black children had to walk:



Rosa Parks was one of the most influential people in the American Civil Rights Movement. The United States Congress called her “the first lady of civil rights” and “the mother of the freedom movement”. Together with other civic leaders like Martin Luther King Jr., Rosa Parks spent her life advocating equality for black people in America. She died in 2005, at the age of 92.


The extract below is from questions she was asked about 1 December 1955, when she refused to get out of her seat for a white person.



Vocabulary

Word

Definition

banning

(verb) an action by South Africa’s apartheid government that prohibited people and organizations from gathering

boycott

(verb) to refuse to buy or use something as a way of protest

gender inequality

(noun) unequal or discriminatory treatment of people based on their gender

pass laws

(noun) laws during apartheid South Africa that forced black people to carry passes. The passes only allowed South Africa’s black population access to certain areas, and it was used as a tool to further the racial segregation in the country.

plight

(noun) a dangerous or difficult situation

socioeconomic

(adj) the relationship of both social and economic (wealth) factors.

title: Education
body_one:
The Future of Education In America


If you were in charge of the schools in your town, what would you change?


In the US politics, many politicians, candidates, and citizens are asking questions about the US education system.


Education has been an important part in helping the United States grow. Schools and education help people find jobs and stay healthy. For example, public education is one of the best ways to reduce  and prevent crime.


The government began to support and build free public schools after the American Revolution. Since then, schools have grown to include more students, more topics and better student learning outcomes. As a result, the United States creates some of the best educated citizens.


Credit: Card Cow


An old schoolhouse built around 1770


US Public Education Today


One way that policymakers have tried to improve education is through standardized testing. A standardized test is a form of test where all students answer the same questions. The questions are then graded in a “standard” or identical manner.



Standardized tests can take up valuable time during a school day


Schools in the United States spend more than $10,000 per student per year for public school education. However, spending is different in every state state, ranging from $6,064 per student in Utah to $18,618 per student in New York. Many wonder if this difference in price creates a difference in quality of education.


Finally, parents and teachers say that both public and private schools have problems with cheating, bullying, and disrespect for teachers.


Debate


While nearly all education leaders and politicians believe that good schools are very important to our progress as a nation they have very different ideas and plans of action.


Some policymakers think that making class sizes smaller would help.  Others think that paying teachers more money would make a difference. Others think that using technology in the classroom could increase learning outcomes.


In considering the different options, you might think we should try them all, or at least most of them. But there are many good ways to use our government’s limited tax dollars, including health, safety, defense, transportation, energy development and others.


Our states and communities face some difficult choices on public education, and many politicians, policymakers, and citizens are thinking about which possible policy solutions will best move the country forward.


One way politicians want to improve education is by having all 50 states use the new Common Core standards and tests. The Common Core includes Standardized Tests that are more challenging academic standards, but not everyone agrees that the Common Core will help.


Supporters say that students and teachers need to know what’s expected. If you expect more, you get more.




People who oppose the Common Core argue that rather than teaching students to be curious, the curriculum and tests stress memorization. Others say this approach puts too much emphasis on testing.


The debate between political parties focuses on topics such as technology, teacher salary, public vs. voucher systems and the increase of standardized testing. What do you think we can do to improve schools in the United States?


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

candidate

noun: A person who hopes to win a political office

citizen

noun: A person who belongs to a state or country

Common Core

proper noun:  an education program that says what K-12 students should know in English Language Arts and Mathematics by the end of every grade level

learning outcome

noun: A statement that describes how much and what students learn after finishing a course of study

politician

noun: A person who is involved in the political system professionally

policymaker

noun: A person who helps a government decide on a course of action

Sources:

http://www.elc-pa.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/BestInvestment_Full_Report_6.27.11.pdf

http://www.centerforpubliceducation.org/Main-Menu/Public-education/An-American-imperative-Public-education-#sthash.n8ybQbgB.dpuf

http://www.elc-pa.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/BestInvestment_Full_Report_6.27.11.pdf

https://cdn.americanprogress.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/LazarinOvertestingReport.pdf

http://educationnext.org/whystudentsinsomecountriesdobetter/

http://www.ascd.org/publications/educational_leadership/may10/vol67/num08/Using_Value-Added_Measures_to_Evaluate_Teachers.aspx

Claudia Goldin and Lawrence Katz, "Human Capital and Social Capital: The Rise of Secondary Schooling in America, 1910–1940," Journal of Interdisciplinary History 29 (1999): 683–723.
body_two:
The Future of Education In America


If you were in charge of the schools in your town, what would you change?


Education has long been seen as essential to maintaining and growing a country. Schools and widespread education help people find jobs, stay healthy, and enjoy a generally high quality of life. For example, public education is one of the best ways to reduce crime and its cost to society.


Government-supported and free public schools were established after the American Revolution. Since then, schools have grown to include more students, more topics and better student learning outcomes. Schools improvements help the United States prepare some of the most educated and productive citizens in the world.


Credit: Card Cow


Reconstruction of the first schoolhouse in Ohio at Schoenbrunn Village. The original school was built ca. 1772 in New Philadelphia, Tuscarawas County, Ohio


From 1910 to 1940, high schools grew in number and size. In 1910, 9% of Americans had a high school diploma; in 1935, the rate was 40%. By 1940, the number had increased to 50%. Today, almost 80% of 18- to 24-year-olds have completed high school.


Where does Education in The United States stand now? How does education in the United States compare to countries around the world? And what can we do to make our education system even better?


US Public Education: Current Day


One way that policymakers worldwide have thought to improve education is through standardized testing. A standardized test requires all test takers to answer the same questions. The answers are then evaluated in a “standard” or identical manner.



Standardized tests can take up valuable time during a school day


Compared to students in 34 developed countries, American teens earn below average scores in mathematics and average scores in science. In mathematics, US students scored below countries like South Korea, Hong Kong, and Shanghai, China. When these numbers were released in 2010, Secretary of Education Arne Duncan emphatically said they were a “wake up call’ to improve public education.


When it comes to the cost of education, schools in the United States spend more than $10,000 per pupil per year. However, spending can vary widely by state, ranging from $6,064 per pupil in Utah to $18,618 per pupil in New York.  Many wonder whether this difference in price creates a difference in quality of education.


Furthermore, many parents say public and private schools have serious problems such as cheating, bullying, and disrespect for teachers.


Debate


Nearly all education leaders and politicians at the national, state, and local levels emphasize how important good schools are to our progress as a nation. But even though many may use similar words and rhetoric to talk about public education, politicians and policymakers have very different ideas and plans of action.


Some policymakers think that shrinking class sizes would help. Others believe that increases in teacher salary and quality would have a positive impact. Others, like tech innovator and educator Salman Khan, think that using technology in the classroom could increase the quality of education.


In considering the different options, you might think we should pursue them all—or at least most of them. But the country’s resources are stretched, and there are many good ways to use our government’s limited tax dollars, including health, safety, defense, transportation, energy development and others.


Our states and communities face some difficult choices on public education, and many politicians, policymakers, and citizens are thinking about which possible policy solutions will best move the country forward.


Credit: http://smeharbinger.net/news/teaching-regulations-change-with-common-core


One proposal to improve education in the US is having all 50 states adopt the new Common Core standards and tests. The Common Core includes Standardized Tests that are based on more challenging academic standards and include topics that are closer to what students in other countries are expected to learn. However, not everyone agrees that the Common Core will help.


Supporters say that students and teachers alike need to know what’s expected of them. If you expect more, you get more.



People who oppose the Common Core argue that rather than teaching students to be curious, the curriculum and tests stresses memorization. Others say this approach puts too much emphasis on testing.


Testing is just one of the topics that politicians will debate with the new president coming into office. The debate will also focus on topics such as technology, teacher salary, public vs. voucher systems and the increase of standardized testing. With so many different routes to improve education in the United States, it will be interesting to see which topics the politicians and public favor the most.


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

candidate

noun: A person who hopes to win a political office

Common Core

proper noun:  an education initiative in the United States that details what K-12 students should know in English Language Arts and Mathematics by the conclusion of every grade level

emphatic

adjective: spoken with or marked by emphasis

learning outcome

noun: A statement that describes how much and what students learn after finishing a course of study

politician

noun: A person who is involved in the political system professionally

policymaker

noun: A person who helps a government decide on a course of action

rhetoric

noun: study of the technique and rules for using language effectively, especially in public speaking

Sources:

http://www.elc-pa.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/BestInvestment_Full_Report_6.27.11.pdf

http://www.centerforpubliceducation.org/Main-Menu/Public-education/An-American-imperative-Public-education-#sthash.n8ybQbgB.dpuf
body_three:
The Future of Education In America


If you were in charge of the schools in your town, what would you change?


Education has long been seen as essential to maintaining and growing a country.  Schools and widespread education have been linked with externalities like increases in economic outputs, health, and general quality of life. For example, public education has been proven to provide one of the best opportunities to reduce crime and its cost to society. This is just one example of how over time education has benefited the United States.


So how and when did the US education system begin? Government-supported and free public schools were established after the American Revolution. Since then, schools have largely improved to include more students, more topics and better student learning outcomes. Increased student learning helped the United States create some of the most qualified citizens in the world.


Credit: Card Cow


Reconstruction of the first schoolhouse in Ohio at Schoenbrunn Village. The original school was built ca. 1772 in New Philadelphia, Tuscarawas County, Ohio.


From 1910 to 1940, high schools grew in number and size. In 1910, nine percent of Americans had a high school diploma; in 1935, the rate was forty percent. By 1940, the number had increased to fifty percent.


The United States has since become a world leader in high school completion. Eighty-seven percent of 18- to 24-year-olds have completed high school, and more than two-thirds of 25- to 29-year-olds have some college education.


This increase in access to quality education and high school graduation has had a number of positive effects. Education also tends to improve the quality of health, reduces dependence on public health programs, and cuts alcohol abuse.


However, since its inception, a number of changes have affected the American public school system leaving many asking questions. Where does education in The United States stand now? How does education in the United States compare to countries around the world? And what can we do to make our education system better?


US Public Education: Current Day


One way that policymakers worldwide have thought to improve education is through standardized testing. A standardized test requires all test takers to answer the same questions and has them graded in a “standard” or identical manner.


Since the 1990’s, testing has gained significant traction in the United States. A recent study by the Center for American Progress looked at 14 school districts. It found that students in grades 3-8 take an average of 10, up to a high of 20, standardized assessments per year.



Standardized tests can take up valuable time during a school day.


Compared to students in 34 developed countries, American teens earn below average scores in mathematics and average scores in science. When these numbers were released in 2010, Secretary of Education Arne Duncan emphatically said they were a “wake up call’ to improve public education.


When it comes to the cost of education, on average, the country spends more than $10,000 per pupil per year for public school education, and K-12 education spending consumes about a fifth of state budgets, based on 2010 figures. However, spending can vary widely by state, ranging from $6,064 per pupil in Utah to $18,618 per pupil in New York.  Many wonder whether this difference in price creates a difference in quality of education.


Although most Americans recognize how tough today’s economy is for young people who aren’t well educated, not as many have focused on how shortfalls in the public education system nationwide could imperil our entire economy. Major businesses are predicting shortages of skilled, well-educated workers within just a few years.


In a recent report, the Industry Manufacturing Institute predicted that as many as 2 million future jobs could go unfilled from the lack of workers with the right technology, computer and technical skills. These skills are needed to help in the production of new efficient automobiles, innovative electronics and advanced medicines.


Furthermore, the majorities of parents and the public say public and private schools have serious problems such as cheating, bullying, and disrespect for teachers.


Debate


Nearly all education leaders and politicians at the national, state, and local levels emphasize how good schools are crucial to our progress as a nation. But even though many politicians use similar words and rhetoric to talk about public education, there are competing visions among policymakers about what works best.


Some think that shrinking class sizes would help, while others believe that increases in teacher salary and quality would create the largest benefit. Other influencers, like tech innovator and educator Salman Khan, think that the use of technology in the classroom could increase the quality of education.


In weighing your options, it might initially seem as if we ought to pursue all of them—or at least most of them—and creating and sustaining strong public schools does require action on multiple fronts.


But the nation’s resources are stretched, and there are many good purposes for limited tax dollars, including health, safety, defense, transportation, energy development and others.


What’s more, schools and communities generally need to focus on a few specific goals and strategies in order be effective. So what should our priority be? Should we as a nation focus on incorporating technology into classrooms, as advocated by Salman Khan? Should we pursue another method like the provision of school vouchers which would allow all students to attend private school at low costs?


Because of this, the country—and our states and communities—face some difficult choices on public education, and many politicians, Policymakers and citizens are thinking about which possible policy solutions will best move the country forward.



One proposal to improve education in the US is having all 50 states adopt the new Common Core standards and tests. The Common Core includes Standardized Tests that are based on more challenging academic standards and include topics that are closer to what students in other countries are expected to learn. However, not everyone agrees that the Common Core will help. Supporters say that students and teachers alike need to know what’s expected of them. If you expect more, you get more.


Credit: Kelsey Fowler/Piktochart


Public school parents and teachers remain closely divided when it comes to their overall attitudes toward the Common Core standards, split between positive and negative impressions.


They also look abroad and argue that almost every other advanced industrial nation has an agreed-upon core curriculum that specifies what students are expected to learn at each grade level. That system has produced higher and more equitable academic achievement than our own. All things being equal, students in countries like Singapore, Korea and Japan have experienced increased 16 points higher in math and 11 points higher in science,  with the use of standardized exams.


Opposition say that rather than teaching students to be curious, the test stresses memorization. Others say this approach puts too much emphasis on testing. Standardized tests have a role, but they shouldn’t be used as a central basis for determining whether teachers are effective or whether students are really learning.


Some systems, like the Value Added System use test scores to evaluate how well teachers have educated their students. Teachers’ salaries are then often raised or lowered depending on the scores of his/her students.


With so many different routes to improve education in the United States, it will be interesting to see which topics the politicians and public favor the most.


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

traction

noun: attracting power or influence; attraction

rhetoric

noun: study of the technique and rules for using language effectively, especially in public speaking

Common Core

proper noun:  an education initiative in the United States that details what K-12 students should know in English Language Arts and Mathematics by the conclusion of every grade level

emphatic

adjective: spoken with or marked by emphasis

Sources:

http://www.elc-pa.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/BestInvestment_Full_Report_6.27.11.pdf

http://www.centerforpubliceducation.org/Main-Menu/Public-education/An-American-imperative-Public-education-#sthash.n8ybQbgB.dpuf

http://www.elc-pa.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/BestInvestment_Full_Report_6.27.11.pdf

https://cdn.americanprogress.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/LazarinOvertestingReport.pdf

http://educationnext.org/whystudentsinsomecountriesdobetter/

http://www.ascd.org/publications/educational_leadership/may10/vol67/num08/Using_Value-Added_Measures_to_Evaluate_Teachers.aspx

Claudia Goldin and Lawrence Katz, "Human Capital and Social Capital: The Rise of Secondary Schooling in America, 1910–1940," Journal of Interdisciplinary History 29 (1999): 683–723.

title: The Economy
body_one:
Ups & Downs: The Economy


For most Americans, understanding the economy comes down to one thing: having a decent job.


Most Americans get their money from wages. For many Americans, where they live, what activities they do, and what foods they eat depend on their work. Unemployment is a problem for many Americans.


The financial crisis of 2008-9 was so bad that some people called the two years that followed “The Great Recession.” Between 2008 and 2010, about 8.4 million jobs were lost in the United States, and the unemployment rate soared from about 5 percent to nearly 10 percent.



Graph of unemployment rate in the United States from 2004-2014.


Today, the Great Recession is over. The economy is growing and jobs are being created.


What Has Changed In Our Economy?  


Being unemployed has a lot to do with who you are and where you are. If you went to college, for example, you’re less likely to be unemployed.


Geography matters, too. The unemployment rate is not the same in every state. In fact, the unemployment rate in states like California and Florida was over 10 percent, while in Nevada, the unemployment rate was 16 percent.


Many people became unemployed in cities like New Orleans, LA because many tourists stopped visiting and spending money. Silicon Valley, did not see as many unemployed due to more people paying for internet and technology services. Some cities and states are looking at Silicon Valley as an example and want more balanced sources jobs.


Another problem is that people are staying out of work for longer periods of time. Research from the United States and around the world shows that is someone is unemployed for a long time, it is harder to get a job. Some think the government should help create jobs and train people who have been unemployed for a long time.


Manufacturing in the US: Change in South Carolina


In the old Greenville, they say, the mills ran all day, and restaurants like Christie’s were busy morning, noon and night.


Credit: WBUR via Flickr


A shuttered cotton mill in Greenville County in South Carolina.


"You could just make money," Terry Leah Suttles, the restaurant Christie’s owner says. "You could get a job. Everybody knew somebody that worked in the mill, and usually they was hiring.


Suttles, like many people in Greenville, dropped out of high school to start work.


People with little to no education could work in a factory and support a family.


Madeline "Maddie" Parlier is a worker at a new factory in Greenville County, South Carolina. She did not go to college. She does not need a college degree to operate her machine. It runs with a push of a button. Machines do so much more of the work in today's factory and companies do not need as many people like Maddie.


Credit: WBUR via Flickr


The Standard Motor Products plant in Greenville County, S.C.


New manufacturing has helped factories make more with less money. New factories have created roles for educated workers like Ralph who are needed to fix complex technology in the factory. Ralph is the future of manufacturing. He has adapted to the new technology on the factory floor.


Future Solutions


The economy is a large and complicated system of businesses, banks, politicians, and 300 million Americans consumers. We can’t order Washington to make the economy better.


But we’re not helpless, either. We can make the political choices on trade, tax policy, education and personal choices on what we buy and what type of business we support. So what should we and our politicians do?


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

adapt

verb:  to become adjusted to new and changing conditions

bewilder

verb:  to become perplexed and confused

finance

noun:  the management of large systems of money by a government, company, or an individual

hire

verb: to give someone a job for a paid wage

mill

noun: a factory with machinery used for processing and building goods

unemployment rate

noun: a measure of the prevalence of people without jobs who currently want jobs

wage

noun:  how much money a worker is paid on a weekly or monthly basis

Sources:

http://www.publicagenda.org/files/PublicAgenda_CitizensSolutionsGuide_Jobs.pdf

http://www.wbur.org/npr/145038754/the-history-of-factory-jobs-in-america-in-one-town

http://www.publicagenda.org/pages/csg-jobs
body_two:
Ups & Downs: The Economy


Economists develop formulas to explain the economy, but for most Americans, understanding the economy comes down to having a decent job.


Most Americans get their money from wages. For many Americans, their lifestyles depend on their work. Unemployment impacts the daily life of many Americans. And the longer this unemployment trend continues, the weaker the unemployed, and the rest of us, become.


The financial crisis of 2008-9 was so bad that the period that followed has been called “The Great Recession.” Between 2008 and 2010, about 8.4 million jobs were lost in the United States, and the unemployment rate soared from about 5 percent to nearly 10 percent.



Graph of unemployment rate in the United States from 2004-2014.


Despite the fact that many Americans continue to struggle financially, the Great Recession is over. The economy is growing and jobs are being created. But getting back to where we were may take some time. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office projects that unemployment won’t return to pre-recession levels of around 5 percent until 2017.


What Has Changed In Our Economy?  


Being unemployed has a lot to do with who you are and where you are. If you went to college, for example, you’re less likely to be unemployed.


Geography matters, too. A nine percent national unemployment rate is not the same in every state. In fact, the unemployment rate in states like California and Florida was over 10 percent, while Nevada’s unemployment rate was 16 percent. Other economies in cities like New Orleans, LA were particularly hard hit by a slow in tourism. Other areas, like Silicon Valley, grew rapidly due to increased use of the internet and technology services. This has caused some cities and states to look for more balanced sources of economic growth.


Manufacturing in the US: An Example of Change in South Carolina


Greenville County in South Carolina is where manufacturing's past and future live side by side. In South Carolina, and throughout America, factories produce more than ever. Yet in Greenville, there are abandoned textile mills everywhere you look.


In the old Greenville, they say, the mills ran three shifts a day, and restaurants like Christie’s were packed morning, noon and night.


Credit: WBUR via Flickr


A shuttered cotton mill in Greenville County in South Carolina.


"You could just make money," Terry Leah Suttles, the restaurant Christie’s owner says. "You could get a job. Everybody knew somebody that worked in the mill, and usually they was hiring.


Suttles, like many people in Greenville, dropped out of high school to start work.


This is what made life in the old Greenville so rewarding. People with little to no education could work in a factory and support a lifestyle that their grandparents could only dream of.


Madeline "Maddie" Parlier is a day worker at a new factory in Greenville County, South Carolina. She doesn't have a college degree, and she doesn't need one to operate her machine. It runs with a push of a button.


Machines do so much more of the work in today's factory. This has decreased the number of jobs offered at factories and can decrease the wage for unskilled workers like Maddie.


Credit: WBUR via Flickr


The Standard Motor Products plant in Greenville County, S.C.


However, others have benefited from increased use of technology. New manufacturing has caused factories to create more with less money. This has resulted in the creation of less expensive things that are available to an increased number of people. It has also created roles for highly educated workers like Ralph who are needed to fix and correct complex technology in the factory. Ralph is the future of manufacturing. He has adapted to the new technology on the factory floor.


The question is, can Maddie — and the 11 million other manufacturing workers in the U.S. — keep up with the changing requirements in jobs being changed by technology?


Future Solutions


The economy is a large and complicated system of businesses, banks, politicians, and 300 million Americans consumers. We can’t order Washington to make the economy better.


But we’re not helpless, either. We can make the political choices on trade, tax policy, education and personal choices on what we buy and what type of business we support.


Eventually, the economy will recover, whatever we do. But our choices will shape how fast that will happen, and what the economy will look like when we’re done. So what should our politicians prioritize?


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

adapt

verb: to become adjusted to new and changing conditions

bewilder

verb: to become perplexed and confused

finance

noun: the management of large systems of money by a government, company, or an individual

unemployment rate

noun: a measure of the prevalence of people without jobs who currently want jobs

prioritize

verb: designate or treat (something) as more important than other things

wage

noun: how much money a worker is paid on a weekly or monthly basis

Sources:

http://www.publicagenda.org/files/PublicAgenda_CitizensSolutionsGuide_Jobs.pdf

http://www.wbur.org/npr/145038754/the-history-of-factory-jobs-in-america-in-one-town

http://www.publicagenda.org/pages/csg-jobs
body_three:
Ups & Downs: The Economy


Economists develop formulas and theories to explain the economy, but for most Americans, understanding the economy comes down to one thing: having a decent job.


Most Americans get their money from wages, and that means their standard of living, their insurance benefits, and even their social status all depend on their work. Unemployment – particularly the sustained unemployment we’re facing now – strikes at the foundations of daily life. And the longer it goes on, the weaker the unemployed, and the rest of us, become.


The financial crisis of 2008-9 was cataclysmic, so bad that the downturn that followed has been tagged “The Great Recession.” Between 2008 and 2010, the nation lost about 8.4 million jobs, and the unemployment rate soared from about 5 percent to nearly 10 percent.



Graph of unemployment rate in the United States from 2004-2014.


Even if you kept your job, you still felt the pain. Nearly one in 10 Americans report they’ve had to take unpaid furlough in the past few years, and one in three say their hours or pay have been cut. Plus, workers took hits on their retirement savings as the stock market plunged, and millions found themselves in the almost unprecedented situation of being “underwater” on their homes, now worth less than what they originally paid.


Despite the lingering misery for many Americans, the Great Recession is in fact over. The economy is growing and jobs are being created. But getting back to where we were may take some time.


The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office projects that unemployment won’t return to pre-recession levels of around 5 percent until 2017. Other projections are more pessimistic.


The question isn’t whether the economy is growing; it is. It’s whether it’s growing fast enough. We don’t just have to make up for the 8.4 million jobs that were lost, we also need to accommodate new people entering the workforce as the population grows.


What Has Changed In Our Economy?  


Being unemployed has a lot to do with who you are and where you are. If you’re college educated, for example, you’re less likely to be unemployed. In 2011, the overall unemployment rate was about 9 percent; but if you were a college graduate it was only 4.3 percent. If you didn’t have a high school diploma, it was more than 14 percent. This has led to many calls for increases in educational performance.


Geography matters, too. That 9 percent rate translated into more than 10 percent in states like California and Florida, while Nevada posted an unemployment rate of 16 percent. Other economies in cities like New Orleans, LA were particularly hard hit by decreases in tourism while other like Silicon Valley grew rapidly due to increased use of the internet and technology services. This has caused some cities and states to look for more balanced sources of economic growth.


Another problem is that people are staying out of work for longer periods of time. As of June 2012, more than two-fifths of the estimated 12.8 million unemployed had been out of work 26 weeks or more. Research from the United States and around the world shows that the longer someone is unemployed, the harder it is for them to get a job, until they’ll likely just give up and drop out of the workforce altogether.


Some think this is a place for the government to get involved and provide the funding to create jobs and training programs to help prevent long periods of unemployment. Many are worried about where the money to support workers would come from. Some fear increases to the debt of the national government - they think that lowering taxes would leave businesses with more money to grow and offer more jobs.


Fundamental changes in the type of business we do in the United States may also be creating less jobs. If you look at the numbers by decade, in the 1980s and 1990s (where there were a couple of sharp recessions) the number of paid jobs in the United States grew by about 20 percent. During the 2000s, however, the country only broke even: we lost as many jobs as we created. This is partly because businesses are wary about rehiring workers until they’re sure the economy is coming back. One industry that has been particularly affected in Manufacturing.


Manufacturing in the US: An Example of Change in South Carolina


Greenville County in South Carolina is where manufacturing's past and future live side by side. This is not a metaphor; it's a visible fact. In South Carolina, and throughout America, factories produce more than ever. Yet in Greenville, there are abandoned textile mills everywhere you look.


In the old Greenville, they say, the mills ran three shifts a day, and restaurants like Christie’s were packed morning, noon and night.


Credit: WBUR via Flickr


A shuttered cotton mill in Greenville County in South Carolina.


"You could just make money," Terry Leah Suttles, the restaurant Christie’s owner says. "You could get a job. Everybody knew somebody that worked in the mill, and usually they was hiring. ... I wasn't really old enough to work, but I went to work. I was about 16." However, things have changed significantly.


Suttles, like many people in Greenville, dropped out of high school to start work.


This is what made life in the old Greenville so rewarding. People with minimal education could work in a factory and support a lifestyle that their grandparents could only dream of. And the people here — they knew it.


Madeline "Maddie" Parlier is a current day worker at a new factory in Greenville County, South Carolina. She doesn't have a college degree, and she doesn't need one to operate her machine. It runs with a push of a button.


Machines do so much more of the work in today's factory. This has decreased the number of jobs offered at factories and can decrease the wage for unskilled workers like Maddie.


Credit: WBUR via Flickr


The Standard Motor Products plant in Greenville County, S.C.


However, others have benefited from increased use of technology. New manufacturing has caused factories to create more with less money. This has resulted in the creation of more less expensive products that are available to an increased number of people. It has also created roles for highly educated workers like Ralph who are needed to fix and correct complex technology parts of the factory.


Ralph is the future of manufacturing. He has adapted to the new technology on the factory floor. But for Maddie, the pace of change has been bewildering. She is still adjusting, and she will have to keep adjusting as the machines grow more sophisticated and the work less physical.


The question is, can Maddie — and the 11 million other manufacturing workers in the U.S. — keep up and will changes in technology create more jobs than they render obsolete?


Future Solutions


The economy is the sum total of the choices of businesses, banks and politicians, as well as the work and shopping habits of over 300 million Americans. We can’t simply order Washington to make the economy better.


But we’re not helpless, either. We can make the political choices on trade, tax policy, education and personal choices on what we buy and what type of business we support.


Eventually, the economy will recover, whatever we do. But our choices will shape how fast that will happen, and what the economy will look like when we’re done.


The combination of short-term recovery and long-term change makes our jobs challenge more complex, and harder to discuss. Steps that spur the economy to grow faster may or may not produce jobs in proportion. And moves to address the long-term trends won’t pay off anytime soon. So what should our politicians prioritize?


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

adapt

verb: to become adjusted to new and changing conditions

bewilder

verb: to become perplexed and confused

cataclysmic

adjective: used to emphasize the extent of something bad or unwelcome

unemployment Rate

noun: a measure of the people without jobs who currently want jobs

furlough

verb: grant a leave of absence to.

prioritize

verb: designate or treat (something) as more important than other things

Sources:

http://www.publicagenda.org/files/PublicAgenda_CitizensSolutionsGuide_Jobs.pdf

http://www.wbur.org/npr/145038754/the-history-of-factory-jobs-in-america-in-one-town

http://www.publicagenda.org/pages/csg-jobs

title: Introduction
body_one:
Young people tell important stories. Over the next six weeks, you and your PenPals will learn about the lives of five young storytellers. Each storyteller is from different community around the world. Each story will help you explore interesting places and global issues.


Week 1: Home Is Where You Find It


In Week 1, you’ll meet Alcides Soares. Alcides is a young boy who lives in Mozambique, Africa. Alcides is on a journey to find his brother. In his story, you will learn about poverty, family, and how diseases like HIV/AIDS can affect a community.


Week 2: My Country Is Tibet


Next, you and your PenPals will meet Namgyal Wangchuk Trichen Lhagyari. Trichen is a the teenage who lives in Tibet. Trichen is also a king! In his story, you will learn about the importance of family history. You will also learn about refugees around the world and the conflict between China and Tibet.



Week 3: Displaced But Not Defeated


Third, you and your PenPals will travel to Colombia, South America. In this film you will meet María Ceballos Paz. María has been living in displacement for the past nine years. In her film you will learn about the nation of Colombia. You will then learn about the effects war and conflict can have on a community.


Week 4: Fire In Our Hearts


Next, you and your PenPals will meet Jayshree Janu Kharpade. Jayshree is from the Warli tribe in the Maharashtra State, India. Jayshree shares her journey from illiterate laborer, to scholar and young activist. Her story will help you and your PenPals discuss the importance of education.



Week 5: Poet Against Prejudice


In the last video, you and your PenPals will travel to New York City, United States of America. You will meet a brave young woman named Faiza Almontaser. Faize is a 17-year old immigrant from Yemen. Her story will help you learn about the violence and discrimination that many immigrant students face today in the United States.


Week 6: The World Through Our Eyes


In the final week, you and your PenPals will work together to make a plan of action. After discussing the five BYKids films, you will choose a story to share with your community. This week is your chance to help tell a story and be an agent for change!


How to be a Great PenPal


Being a great PenPal starts with respect. Your PenPals are students just like you. Sometimes, you and your PenPals might agree. Sometimes, you and your PenPals might disagree.


Show respect by writing every week. Also show respect by using appropriate language. If your PenPal has a question, make sure to help.



If your PenPals say something that you don’t agree with, ask your PenPals a question about what they said. If your PenPal writes something inappropriate, report the message and our team will reviewed it.



Write to Your Future PenPals


Soon you will be matched with PenPals! So let’s get ready by answering this week’s discussion question! Scroll to the top of the page. There you will find the discussion question on the right.



Each week, answer the weekly discussion question.


After you answer this week’s discussion question, use the chat section underneath to tell your future PenPals about yourself. Then ask your PenPals some questions about their communities.
body_two:
Young people tell honest and important stories, yet these stories often go unheard. Over the next six weeks, you and your PenPals will learn about the lives of five young storytellers from different communities around the world. These stories reflect critical global issues from a perspective rarely told in the mainstream media.


Week 1: Home Is Where You Find It


In Week 1, you’ll meet Alcides Soares, a young boy in Mozambique, Africa who is on a journey to find his brother. As Alcides tells his story, you and your PenPals will learn about poverty, family, and how diseases like HIV/AIDS can affect a community.


Week 2: My Country Is Tibet


Next, you and your PenPals will meet Namgyal Wangchuk Trichen Lhagyari, the teenage king of Tibet. You will learn about and discuss the importance of family history, the plight of refugees around the world, the conflict between China and Tibet.



Week 3: Displaced But Not Defeated


We’ll then travel across the world from Tibet to Colombia, South America. There, you and your PenPals will meet María Ceballos Paz. María has been living in displacement for the past nine years as a result of Colombia's civil war. You and your PenPals will learn about the nation of Colombia and discuss the effects civil war and armed conflict can have on a community like Maria’s.


Week 4: Fire In Our Hearts


From Colombia, you and your PenPals return to South Asia where you will meet Jayshree Janu Kharpade, a sixteen-year-old girl from the Warli tribe in the Maharashtra State, India. Jayshree shares her journey as she advances from illiterate laborer, to scholar and young activist. You and your PenPals will discuss the importance of education and learn about the more than 60 million school-age girls around the world who do not have the opportunity to attend school.



Week 5: Poet Against Prejudice


You and your PenPals will then travel to New York City, United States of America. You’ll meet a brave young woman named Faiza Almontaser, a 17-year old immigrant from Yemen. Despite losing close friends to violence and facing discrimination at school, Faiza and her family continue to embrace their new life in the United States.


Week 6: The World Through Our Eyes


In the final week, you and your PenPals will work together to make a plan of action! After discussing the five BYKids films, you will choose a story to share with your community. Whether you and your classmates decide to organize a community event or gather signature for a petition, this week is your chance to be an agent for change!

How to be a great PenPal

You are about to join thousands of students from more than one hundred different countries who are learning and sharing perspectives with PenPals from around the world!



Being a great PenPal starts with respect. Your PenPals are students just like you, so remember to always be respectful of them and their opinions! Write to your PenPals every week, use appropriate language, and help your PenPals when they have questions.


It's ok to disagree with your PenPals as long as you are polite. If your PenPals say something that you don’t agree with, ask your PenPals to explain their thinking. Remember, if your PenPal writes something inappropriate, flag the message and it will be reviewed by the PenPal Schools team.



Write to Your Future PenPals


So let’s get ready for your PenPal exchange by answering this week’s discussion question! Scroll to the top of the page and find the discussion question on the right side. Make sure to refer to the text and video when answering the question.



Each week, answer the weekly discussion question.


After you answer this week’s discussion question, use the chat section underneath to tell your future PenPals about yourself. Then ask your PenPals some questions about their communities.


Once matched, your PenPals can read and reply to your answers so you’ll already have something to talk about!
