title: Walking to Freedom
body_one:
Acceptance and Ubuntu


Each of us is unique. And with more than 7 billion people on earth, we need to grow accept and respect each other.


In southern Africa, people use a wonderful expression: Ubuntu. Ubuntu means, “I am because you are.”  Ubuntu means that we are separate individuals, but we are connected to each other.


Let us look at real stories of acceptance and Ubuntu from all over the world.


Nkosi Johnson – a Little Guy with a Big Heart


This young boy from made the whole world think about prejudice against people with AIDS.


Nkosi Johnson was born in 1989 in Johannesburg, South Africa. Nkosi’s mother was HIV-positive.  She quickly became too ill to look after him.  When he was four years old, Nkosi was adopted by Gail Johnson.


Ms. Johnson tried to take Nkosi to a local primary school in 1997, but the school refused to accept Nkosi because he was HIV-positive.


Gail Johnson took the matter to court and won the case. The school had to change its decision and let Nkosi enroll.  


The ruling showed schools across South Africa that they could not discriminate against children with AIDS.


Nkosi spoke at the 13th International AIDS Conference held in 2000 in Durban, South Africa. He was just 11 years old, but he wrote his own speech and spoke to over 10 000 people.


Nkosi ended his speech with these words:




Nkosi’s died in 2001 at the age of just 12 years old. Nkosi Johnson, a young boy, gave the world something to think about: prejudice against people who are sick.


The German Woman and the Syrian Refugees


A 79-year-old German woman has helped Syrian refugees in their new life:




The DREAM Act and the Long Walk of Dreamers


In 2001, America introduced the DREAM Act. The Act was introduced to the American Congress in 2001 and has taken many shapes over the years.


The DREAM Act helps young, undocumented immigrants who came to the United States as children and graduated from high school (called college) in the USA, become American citizens.


The word Dreamers is a wonderful word. These students identify as Americans and want a future where they are legal citizens.  As legal citizens, these Dreamers hope to live without experiencing discrimination.


Felipe Sousa-Rodriguez is a Dreamer. He came to the USA from Brazil when he was 14 years old. He started out with dreams of becoming a teacher.


Felipe did very well in college: he was one of the top 20 community college students in the United States and the best student in the State of Florida in 2008.


Communities around the United States are gathering to support the DREAM Act


Felipe walked on the Trail of Dreams in 2010. The Trail of Dreams was a walk modelled on the non-violent protest action inspired by Martin Luther King.


Walk to Freedom


These people from different backgrounds give their time and energy to the long walk towards freedom. They are models to all of us. They stand up for equality and freedom in their own ways.


Now, let us go out into our communities and do the same!


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

citizen

(noun) a legal member of a country or a state

immigrant

(noun) a person who permanently moves from one country to another

prejudice

(noun) when someone has an opinion about people who he or she has never met.  An opinion not based on experience.

refugee

(noun) a person who has left his/her country of birth to escape war

ubuntu

(noun) Southern African expression denoting compassion and kindness towards others

undocumented

(adj) not recorded or able to provide proof
body_two:
Acceptance and Ubuntu


Each of us is unique. But as the world’s population grows to more than 7 billion people, we need to grow together and learn to accept differences.


In southern Africa, people use a wonderful expression: Ubuntu. One translation of Ubuntu means, “I am because you are.”  Ubuntu means that we are separate individuals, but we are connected to each other.


Over the past six weeks, you have seen how discrimination, a sense of hatred that comes from people being different, has created problems in the world. You have learned how campaigns and activists have fought discrimination.


So how can we move away from discrimination and step into a brighter future?

Let us look at real stories of acceptance and Ubuntu from all over the world.


Nkosi Johnson – a Little Guy with a Big Heart


This ordinary boy from humble beginnings made the whole world think about prejudice against people with AIDS. He helped encouraged AIDS victims in Africa to be open about the disease.


Nkosi Johnson was born in 1989 in Johannesburg, South Africa. Nkosi’s mother was HIV-positive, and as she became too ill to look after him.  When he was four years old, Nkosi was adopted legally by Gail Johnson.


Ms. Johnson tried to take Nkosi to a local primary school in 1997, but the school refused to accept Nkosi because he was HIV-positive.


South Africa’s Constitution states that people may not be discriminated against because of a medical condition. Gail Johnson took the matter to court and won the case. The school had to change its decision and let Nkosi enroll.  The ruling showed schools across South Africa that they could not discriminate against children with AIDS.


This event inspired Nkosi to speak about discrimination on the grounds of ill health, and AIDS in particular.  Nkosi spoke at the 13th International AIDS Conference held in 2000 in Durban, South Africa. He was just 11 years old, but he wrote his own speech and spoke to over 10 000 people.


Nkosi ended his speech with these words:




Nkosi’s died in 2001 at the age of just 12 years old. Nelson Mandela referred to Nkosi as an “icon of the struggle for life.”


Nkosi Johnson, a young boy, gave the world something to think about: prejudice against people who are sick.


The German Woman and the Syrian Refugees


Read this article about a 79-year-old German woman who has helped Syrian refugees in their new life:




The DREAM Act and the Long Walk of Dreamers


In 1963, Martin Luther King delivered his iconic “I have a dream’’ speech. Thirty eight years later, in 2001, America introduced the DREAM Act.


The Act was introduced to the American Congress in 2001 and has taken many shapes over the years.


The intention of the DREAM Act is to offer young, undocumented immigrants who came to the United States as children and graduated from high school (called college) in the USA, the opportunity to become American citizens. It is estimated that about 65 000 undocumented students graduate per year from high schools in the United States.


The word Dreamers is a wonderful word that describes all the undocumented immigrants who not only identify as Americans, but want a future where they are legal citizens.  As legal citizens, these Dreamers hope to live without experiencing discrimination.


Felipe Sousa-Rodriguez is a Dreamer. He came to the USA from Brazil when he was 14 years old. He started out with dreams of becoming a teacher. Felipe did very well in college: he was one of the top 20 community college students in the United States and the best student in the State of Florida in 2008.


Communities around the United States are gathering to support the DREAM Act


Felipe walked on the Trail of Dreams in 2010. The Trail of Dreams was a 1500 mile-long walk (approximately 2400 kilometres) to draw attention to and support the DREAM Act. The walk began in Miami, Florida and ended in Washington DC. This walk was modelled on the non-violent protest action inspired by Martin Luther King.


Walk to Freedom


These three individuals from different backgrounds have dedicated their time and energy to the long walk towards freedom. They are models of inspiration to all of us and have stood up for equality and freedom in their own ways.


Now, let us go out into our communities and do the same!


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

citizen

(noun) a legal member of a country or a state

icon

(noun) an important symbol of something

immigrant

(noun) a person who permanently moves from one country to another

prejudice

(noun) when someone has an opinion about people who he or she has never met.  An opinion not based on experience.

reception centre

(noun) temporary accommodation for refugees

refugee

(noun) a person who has left his/her country of birth to escape war

ubuntu

(noun) Southern African expression denoting compassion and kindness towards others

undocumented

(adj) not recorded or able to provide proof
body_three:
Acceptance and Ubuntu


Each of us is unique. But as the world population swells over 7 billion people, we need to evolve socially and learn to accept differences.


In southern Africa, people use a wonderful expression: the word Ubuntu. One translation of Ubuntu means: I am because you are. The spirit of Ubuntu acknowledges that we are separate individual human beings, but that we are connected to each other. Compassion is critical to overcoming discrimination.


Over the past six weeks, you have seen how discrimination, a sense of otherness, has got the world into all kinds of trouble. Discrimination has caused wars and violence. You have learned how movements and activism have risen out of discrimination.


How can we move away from discrimination and step into a brighter future?

Let us look at real stories of acceptance and Ubuntu from all over the world.


Nkosi Johnson – a Little Guy with a Big Heart


This ordinary boy from humble beginnings made the whole world think about prejudice against people with AIDS. He helped encouraged AIDS victims in Africa to be open about the disease.


Nkosi Johnson was born in 1989 in Johannesburg, South Africa. Nkosi’s mother was HIV-positive, and as she became too ill to look after him, he was adopted legally by Gail Johnson. Nikosi was only four years old when he left his mother to live with Ms. Johnson. Johnson was a volunteer worker at an AIDS home who quickly established a close bond with Nkosi.


Ms. Johnson attempted to enrol Nkosi in a local primary school in 1997, but the school refused to accept Nkosi because he was HIV-positive. South Africa’s Constitution states that people may not be discriminated against because of their medical status. Gail Johnson took the matter to court and won the case. The school had to change its decision, and the ruling helped to clarify that schools in South Africa may not discriminate against children with AIDS.


This event inspired Nkosi to speak about discrimination on the grounds of ill health, and AIDS in particular.


Nkosi was a keynote speaker at the 13th International AIDS Conference held in 2000 in Durban, South Africa. He was just 11 years old, but he wrote his own speech and spoke to over 10 000 people.


Nkosi ended his speech with these words:




Quickly Nkosi became known all over the world for his stand against discrimination towards people with AIDS. He travelled to Atlanta, Georgia to speak at an AIDS conference there in October, 2000.


After Nkosi’s death in 2001 at the age of just 12 years old, Nelson Mandela referred to him as an “icon of the struggle for life.”


Nkosi’s memory lives on: together with Gail Johnson, he established a home for HIV positive mothers and children called Nkosi’s Haven, in Johannesburg.


In November 2005, Gail Johnson received the first International Children’s Peace Prize on behalf of Nkosi Johnson. Nkosi’s Haven has received hundreds of thousands of dollars (US) in donations, grants, and prize money in Nkosi Johnson’s honour.


Nkosia Johnson, a young boy, gave the world something to think about: prejudice against people who are sick.


The German Woman and the Syrian Refugees


The year 2015 has seen media attention focused on Syrian refugees in particular.  Read this article about a 79-year-old German woman who has helped Syrian refugees in their new life:



Germany - Hilde Schramm, the 79-year-old daughter of Hitler's architect, Albert Speer - has spent a life campaigning for peace, fighting racism, and supporting Germany's green movement. This year she decided to help two Syrian refugees, but they have ended up helping her in return.


Schramm has been sharing her home, her kitchen and bathroom for eight months now with two Syrian refugees, Nizar and Ahmad.  For Schramm it seemed the logical thing to do, as the country's reception centres struggle to cope with the influx of refugees and migrants.


"Whoever has space for a refugee, should take one home," she says, batting away my suggestion that this takes a certain amount of courage.


"The decision was very simple," she tells me. "We had space here and everyone agreed to it."


Schramm shares her floor of the house with the two young Syrians - and even she has been surprised quite how well the first few months have worked out.


"I was afraid there would be too much to organise, that I would freak out and think it was a burden," she says.  "Quite frankly, it's astonishing. There are no problems, really."


This is fortunate because Schramm is a woman with little time on her hands. She is devoted to her work: one of her long-term foundations is called Zurueckgeben, or "giving back"; it supports Jewish women working in the arts and academia in Germany.


"Most Germans really profited from the persecution of the Jews, taking away their jobs, taking away their goods and houses," she says. Giving something back to the Jewish people is a collective duty, in her eyes.


I cautiously enquire about the chores and house rules, who takes the rubbish out, who does the cleaning?


"There is a wonderful answer," she tells me. "They do it all. I always say, 'Let me do it,' but they are faster than me. There are no rules. They just do it."


For Ahmed, coming to Schramm's home meant finally being able to lead a normal life. "In the reception centre, there is nothing to do," he says. "You just sit and wait. You can't do anything. You can't learn German, there's no internet. It's bad. Coming here, it was so fantastic. I could call my family and cook again."


The new flavours in this Berlin kitchen, from Ahmad's meat and rice dishes, tabbouleh salads and lentil soups, are something Schramm relishes.


"When he starts cooking, I've usually already had my supper," she says. "But it smells so wonderful, so I do take a little bit. And that happens quite often."


The DREAM Act and the Long Walk of Dreamers


In 1963, Martin Luther King delivered his iconic “I have a dream’’ speech. Thirty eight years later, in 2001, America introduced the DREAM Act.


The acronym DREAM stands for Development, Relief and Education for Alien Minors. The Act was introduced to the American Congress in 2001 and has taken several forms over the years, but the official Bill has never been passed.


The intention of the DREAM Act is to offer young, undocumented immigrants who came to the United States as children and graduated from high school (called college) in the USA, the opportunity to become American citizens once they have completed higher education at a university in the USA. Activists today are still working towards getting this bill passed at a national level. It is estimated that approximately 65 000 undocumented students graduate per year from high schools in the United States.


The word Dreamers is a wonderful double-meaning word that describes all the undocumented immigrants who not only identify as Americans, but also aspire to a future when they are legal American citizens.  As legal citizens, these Dreamers hope to live without experiencing racial discrimination and the constant fear of being deported.


Felipe Sousa-Rodriguez is a Dreamer. He came to the USA from Brazil when he was 14 years old. He started out with dreams of becoming a teacher. Felipe moved on to excel in college: he was one of the top 20 community college students in the United States and the best student in the State of Florida in 2008.


Communities around the United States are gathering to support the DREAM Act


Felipe joined immigrants who walked on the Trail of Dreams in 2010. The Trail of Dreams was a 1500 mile-long walk (approximately 2400 kilometres) to draw attention to and support the DREAM Act. The walk began in Miami, Florida and ended in Washington DC. This walk was modelled on the non-violent protest action inspired by Martin Luther King.


Today Felipe is the head of an organisation called UnitedWeDream, the largest immigrant youth-led organization in the USA. Felipe was awarded the “Freedom From Fear” award from Public Interest Projects in 2011 for his work on the Trail of Dreams. He was also named one of the “Top 15 Civil Rights Leaders of the 21st Century” by News One.


Walk to Freedom


These three individuals from disparate backgrounds have dedicated their time and energy to the long walk towards freedom. They are models of inspiration to all of us and have stood up for equality and freedom in their own ways.


Now, let us go out into our communities and do the same!


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

compassion

(noun) concern for other people

disparate

(adj) extremely different

icon

(noun) an important symbol of something

prejudice

(noun) when someone has an opinion about people who he or she has never met.  An opinion not based on experience.

reception centre

(noun) temporary accommodation for refugees

refugee

(noun) a person who has left his/her country of birth to escape war

ubuntu

(noun) Southern African expression denoting compassion and kindness towards others

title: Revise, Edit, Publish
body_one:
Many writers write to share ideas! Whether you are a journalist with the goal of telling an important story, or an author trying to persuade people of a specific argument, writing is a powerful way to share ideas. Now that you have an argument paragraph, let’s share it!


First we’re going to look at a few ways to polish your paragraph. You and your pen pal will explore ways that will make your writing more precise and interesting. Then, you will proofread your pen pal’s argument paragraph using the CUPS checklist. Finally, you will share your argument paragraph with your pen pal and your teacher before wishing your pen pal farewell and best of luck in his or her future as a writer.


Lesson Objectives

  • Watch a short video to explore vocabulary related to argument writing

  • Explore ways to improve the language in argument writing

  • Revise, edit, and proofread your argument paragraph

  • Share your final argument paragraph with your pen pal and your community!




Tip #1 - Avoid the Things Trap!


Compare the two sentences:


  • Having a companion animal, such as a cat or dog, adds things to a family.


  • Having a companion animal, such as a cat or dog, adds joy, excitement, and companionship to a family.


The second sentence is much stronger than the first. Notice, where the first sentence uses the world “things,” the second sentence adds more details. Look for words in your argument paragraph that you can replace with more descriptive words.


Directions: Use the list below to find words that you can use to replace vague words in your argument paragraph. The list below contains many excellent descriptive words that can help you avoid the Things Trap.



Tip #2 - Action Verbs


Another way to strengthen your argument writing is to use strong, active verbs whenever possible. Writers often use “to be” verbs. “To be” verbs help us express or describe a state of being. While these verbs are essential to our language, they do not make for very exciting argument writing. Take a look at the two sentences below. The first sentence uses a “to be” verb while the second uses an action verb. Read both sentences aloud and consider how the action verb makes the second sentence more exciting.


Sentence 1:


We need to make sure the data are correct.


Sentence 2:


We need to verify the data.


Use the list below to replace “to be” verbs with action verbs in your argument paragraph.



Complete the Questions for Part 1 before moving on to Part 2!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)




Your argument paragraph is almost complete! You and your pen pal have worked hard to learn the elements of both argument writing and the Writing Process. This will be the final time you give your pen pal feedback on his or her paragraph!


Read your pen pal’s argument paragraph from Part 1. Using the CUPS (capitalization, usage, punctuation, spelling) checklist, help your pen pal decide if his or her paragraph is ready to share. In the final part of this lesson, you and your pen pal will each have the chance to revise your own paragraph before proofreading and submitting the final version to your teacher.



Complete the Questions for Part 2 before moving on to Part 3!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)




In this, the final part of the argument writing course, it is your job to finish strong! First, edit your argument paragraph using the proofreading suggestions your pen pal made in Part 2. Read the paragraph in its entirety; this is the last time you will be able to change your argument paragraph.


Once finished, use the argument paragraph checklist to evaluate your argument paragraph.


Revise your argument paragraph one last time. Use tips from Part 1 and the suggestions your pen pal made in Part 2 to make your argument paragraph as strong as it can be. Then, use the checklist to make sure your argument paragraph has all the traits of effective argument writing.



Complete the questions located at the bottom of this page! After answering each of your questions, read and respond to your pen pal’s answers!



Word

Definition

formal style

(adj) a style that is professional, objective, and precise

informal style

(adj) a style that often sounds like someone talking

point of view

(noun) the position from which a story is told or a piece of information is written

proofread

(verb) checking a final written draft to catch small mistakes before turning in the work
body_two:
Many writers write to share ideas! Whether you are a journalist with the goal of telling an important story, or an author trying to persuade people of a specific argument, writing is a powerful way to share ideas. Now that you have an argument paragraph, let’s share it!


First we’re going to look at a few ways to polish your paragraph. You and your pen pal will explore ways that will make your writing more precise and interesting. Then, you will proofread your pen pal’s argument paragraph using the CUPS checklist. Finally, you will share your argument paragraph with your pen pal and your teacher before wishing your pen pal farewell and best of luck in his or her future as a writer.


Lesson Objectives

  • Watch a short video to explore vocabulary related to argument writing

  • Explore ways to improve the language in argument writing

  • Revise, edit, and proofread your argument paragraph

  • Share your final argument paragraph with your pen pal and your community!




Tip #1 - Avoid the Things Trap!


Compare the two sentences:


  • Having a companion animal, such as a cat or dog, adds things to a family.


  • Having a companion animal, such as a cat or dog, adds joy, excitement, and companionship to a family.


The second sentence is much stronger than the first. Notice, where the first sentence uses the world “things,” the second sentence adds more details. Look for words in your argument paragraph that you can replace with more descriptive words.


Directions: Use the list below to find words that you can use to replace vague words in your argument paragraph. The list below contains many excellent descriptive words that can help you avoid the Things Trap.



Tip #2 - Action Verbs


Another way to strengthen your argument writing is to use strong, active verbs whenever possible. Writers often use “to be” verbs. “To be” verbs help us express or describe a state of being. While these verbs are essential to our language, they do not make for very exciting argument writing. Take a look at the two sentences below. The first sentence uses a “to be” verb while the second uses an action verb. Read both sentences aloud and consider how the action verb makes the second sentence more exciting.


Sentence 1:


We need to make sure the data are correct.


Sentence 2:


We need to verify the data.


Use the list below to replace “to be” verbs with action verbs in your argument paragraph.



Complete the Questions for Part 1 before moving on to Part 2!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)




Your argument paragraph is almost complete! You and your pen pal have worked hard to learn the elements of both argument writing and the Writing Process. This will be the final time you give your pen pal feedback on his or her paragraph!


Read your pen pal’s argument paragraph from Part 1. Using the CUPS (capitalization, usage, punctuation, spelling) checklist, help your pen pal decide if his or her paragraph is ready to share. In the final part of this lesson, you and your pen pal will each have the chance to revise your own paragraph before proofreading and submitting the final version to your teacher.



Complete the Questions for Part 2 before moving on to Part 3!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)




In this, the final part of the argument writing course, it is your job to finish strong! First, edit your argument paragraph using the proofreading suggestions your pen pal made in Part 2. Read the paragraph in its entirety; this is the last time you will be able to change your argument paragraph.


Once finished, use the argument paragraph checklist to evaluate your argument paragraph.


Revise your argument paragraph one last time. Use tips from Part 1 and the suggestions your pen pal made in Part 2 to make your argument paragraph as strong as it can be. Then, use the checklist to make sure your argument paragraph has all the traits of effective argument writing.



Complete the questions located at the bottom of this page! After answering each of your questions, read and respond to your pen pal’s answers!



Word

Definition

formal style

(adj) a style that is professional, objective, and precise

informal style

(adj) a style that often sounds like someone talking

point of view

(noun) the position from which a story is told or a piece of information is written

proofread

(verb) checking a final written draft to catch small mistakes before turning in the work
body_three:
Many writers write to share ideas! Whether you are a journalist with the goal of telling an important story, or an author trying to persuade people of a specific argument, writing is a powerful way to share ideas. Now that you have an argument paragraph, let’s share it!


First we’re going to look at a few ways to polish your paragraph. You and your pen pal will explore ways that will make your writing more precise and interesting. Then, you will proofread your pen pal’s argument paragraph using the CUPS checklist. Finally, you will share your argument paragraph with your pen pal and your teacher before wishing your pen pal farewell and best of luck in his or her future as a writer.


Lesson Objectives

title: Under the Sea
body_one:
Sylvia Earle is on a mission to protect the world’s oceans.


By Jaime Joyce

April 15, 2016


On a recent Sunday morning, 28 kids from the Cabo Pulmo Youth Center stood on a beach in Cabo Pulmo, Mexico. They wore life jackets and flippers. They fitted snorkel tubes in their mouths. And they strapped on masks. Then they waddled into the cool water. Teachers were there to help. One of them was a famous oceanographer. Her name is Sylvia Earle.


“It was very, very exciting,” 12-year-old Edmundo Minjares told TIME Edge, in Spanish.


The kids waded to about 60 feet offshore. Edmundo and his friends dunked their heads into the salty water. What they saw was beautiful. There were rocks and coral. Fish were feeding along the ocean floor.


For many of the children, it was their first time exploring this underwater world. But it was nothing new for Earle. “It was glorious,” she has said about her first time diving in the Gulf of California, years ago. “It still is glorious.”


KIP EVANS


Kids explore the underwater world during the Mission Blue trip to Cabo Pulmo, Mexico.


A Shining Example


Sylvia Alice Earle was born on August 30, 1935, in Gibbstown, New Jersey. She has been interested in the ocean since she was small. “When I was 3 years old, I got knocked over by a wave and it got my attention,” she told TIME in 2014. "It’s held my attention ever since." She has spent more than 7,000 hours underwater.


KIP EVANS


Sylvia Earle was captivated by the ocean as a child. “It’s held my attention ever since,” she says.


In 2008, Earle started Mission Blue. The group works to protect the ocean. Earle calls the ocean the “blue heart” of the planet. Mission Blue has named 59 Hope Spots around the world. These are areas of the ocean that are either protected or in need of protection. The Gulf of California Hope Spot is one of the world’s most protected ocean areas.


It wasn’t always that way. Overfishing in the 1980s caused a sharp drop in the number of fish in the area. The health of the reef was in danger. The people of Cabo Pulmo were worried. They asked the Mexican government to protect the waters. In 1995, the government took action by creating the Cabo Pulmo National Marine Park. Fishing is not allowed.


Today, the number of fish in the area has increased by nearly 500%. The change has given the area an economic boost. Tourism has become an important business in Cabo Pulmo. “It’s a shining example of what a marine protected area should look like,” says Mission Blue’s Kip Evans.


Hope for the Future


The Mission Blue team wants the world to know that Cabo Pulmo is a priceless treasure. “The kids know Cabo Pulmo is a special place,” says Pilu Hermosilla of Cabo Pulmo Diving. She was one of the teachers on the Sunday morning trip with Earle. “The kids, the village, and the families here, they protect the reefs like nothing [else].”


KIP EVANS


Students select gear for their underwater adventure.


What can you do? Kip Evans says snorkeling will help you learn about sea life. “It’s a great way to introduce yourself to the ocean,” he says. But even if you don’t live near the water, you can still make a difference. “The most important thing is to be passionate about one of the most important features on our planet,” says Evans.


KIP EVANS


These kids went snorkeling with Sylvia Earle.


After all, as Earle says, “We’re just getting started, as far as ocean exploration is concerned.”


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

economic

adjective: describing how resources are shared and money is made

oceanographer

noun: a scientist who studies the ocean

tourism

noun: traveling somewhere for fun
body_two:
Sylvia Earle is on a mission to protect the world’s oceans.


By Jaime Joyce

April 15, 2016


On a recent Sunday morning, 28 kids from the Cabo Pulmo Youth Center stood on a white-sand beach in Cabo Pulmo, Mexico. They wore life jackets and flippers. They fitted snorkel tubes in their mouths and strapped on masks, then waddled into the cool water. Teachers were there to help. One of them was world-famous oceanographer Sylvia Earle.


“It was very, very exciting,” 12-year-old Edmundo Minjares told TIME Edge, in Spanish.

The kids waded to about 60 feet offshore. Edmundo and his friends dunked their heads under the rippling surface of the salty water. What they saw was beautiful. There were rocks and coral. A school of about 60 snapper was feeding along the ocean floor.


For many of the children, it was their first time exploring this underwater world. But it was nothing new for Earle. “It was glorious,” she has said about her first time diving in the Gulf of California, in the 1960s. “It still is glorious.”

She has spent more than 7,000 hours underwater.


Sylvia Earle was captivated by the ocean as a child. “It’s held my attention ever since,” she says.

“The kids know Cabo Pulmo is a special place,” says Pilu Hermosilla of Cabo Pulmo Diving. She was one of the teachers on the Sunday morning trip with Earle. “The kids, the village, and the families here, they protect the reefs like nothing [else].”

But even if you don’t live near the water, you can still make a difference. “The most important thing is to be passionate about one of the most important features on our planet,” says Evans.


KIP EVANS


These kids went snorkeling with Sylvia Earle.


After all, as Earle says, “We’re just getting started, as far as ocean exploration is concerned.”


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

designate

verb: to assign or label

economic

adjective: describing how resources are shared and money is made

oceanographer

noun: a scientist who studies the ocean

tourism

noun: traveling somewhere for enjoyment

Definition

captivate

verb: to hold someone’s interest

title: Introduction
body_one:
When you study civics, you learn about the rights of a citizen. Civics education is empowering.



A group of ninth grade students in Malden, Massachusetts studied civics. They learn how to contact their mayor to build the city’s first teen center in 2012. These students learned about a problem and helped create a solution!


In Louisiana, a group of sixth grade students spent weeks running a get-out-the-vote campaign. These students helped register voters and share information about candidates and election issues.



Young students who learn about civics in school are making the world a better place. Responsible citizens understand how government works and how to make a difference.


Who knows, after this course, you and your PenPals may even start a project and support a change! You might join a political campaign, a community organizing, or a nonprofit! You will soon learn that there are many ways to help people at all levels of government.


Week 1: Education


The government has a lot to do with what happens at school. This week you will study the history of education and education programs. You and your PenPals will discuss and compare programs that work. You will then discuss programs that you would like change.


Week 2: The Economy


The economy is the top political issue for most American voters. This week, you will learn about the economy and ways the government can help create jobs.


Week 3: Energy & The Environment


Energy comes from many different places. In Week 3, you and your PenPals will learn about common energy sources. You will then discuss what energy policies are best for the United States.


Week 4: Immigration


During Week 4, you and your PenPals will discuss immigration. First you will learn about the history of immigration. Then you will learn about the immigration process. You will use this information to decide what immigration policy should look like.


Week 5: Healthcare


In 2010, the United States government passed the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. This was a big change in the US healthcare system. But was the Affordable Care Act a good idea? In Week 5, you and your PenPals will discuss healthcare in the United States.


Week 6: Rock the Vote!


During the final week of the program, you and your PenPals will learn about elected officials and branches of the US government. You will learn about voting requirements and different types of election issues. Then, you will learn how young people across the country are involved in American civics!


How to be a Great PenPal


Being a great PenPal starts with respect. Your PenPals are students just like you. Sometimes, you and your PenPals might agree. Sometimes, you and your PenPals might disagree.


Show respect by writing every week. Also show respect by using appropriate language. If your PenPal has a question, make sure to help.



If your PenPals say something that you don’t agree with, ask your PenPals a question about what they said. If your PenPal writes something inappropriate, report the message and our team will reviewed it.



Write to Your Future PenPals


Soon you will be matched with PenPals! So let’s get ready by answering this week’s discussion question! Scroll to the top of the page. There you will find the discussion question on the right.



Each week, answer the weekly discussion question.


After you answer this week’s discussion question, use the chat section underneath to tell your future PenPals about yourself. Then ask your PenPals some questions about their communities.
body_two:
Civics education is personal, timely, and empowering. In a country like the the United States, every citizen has the right to vote and the ability to shape our government. Understanding civics helps you become informed and excited about the political process.



After studying American civics, a group of ninth grader students in Malden, Massachusetts successfully lobbied their mayor to build the city’s first teen center in 2012. These students became passionate about an issue after learning about local crime and the lack of safe spaces for young people.


After the murder of a fellow student in San Francisco, eighth grader students took action. The students learned about civic topics that directly affect young people and created a plan. They worked together with the school board to craft an antiviolence resolution. These students testified before the superintendent, and helped get the resolution passed providing support for at-risk youth.


In Louisiana, after studying American civics and learning about the importance of voting, a group of sixth grade students spent weeks running a get-out-the-vote campaign. In their community, these students helped register voters and share information about candidates and election issues.These same students later participated in a year-long project where they conducted research and proposed realistic solutions to problems affecting their community.



Young students who learn about civics at a the elementary, middle, and high school levels are the people who participate in civic activities. Excellent citizens understand how government works and what it means to be a citizen.


Who knows, after this course, you and your PenPals may participate in activism, dissent, or protest. You might join a political campaign, a community organizing, or a nonprofit! You will soon learn that there are many ways to be a public servant at all levels of government.


Week 1: Education


Your city, state, and the federal government have a lot to do with what happens at school. After studying the history of education and the programs working to improve our schools, you and your PenPals will discuss the programs that work for you and your school. You will then discuss the programs that you would like change and improve.


Week 2: The Economy


The economy is the top political issue for most American voters. During Week 2 you will learn about the economy, the unemployment rate, and how both the government and the private sector can work to create jobs.


Week 3: Energy & The Environment


Families and business across the United States get their energy from many different places. In Week 3, you and your PenPals will learn about some of the most common energy sources and discuss what energy policies will position the United States to be energy responsible in the future


Week 4: Immigration


Over the past two hundred years, millions of people have left their homes and immigrated to the United States. During Week 4, you and your PenPals will discuss immigration. You or your PenPals might even be part of an immigrant family and may have first hand knowledge about the role immigrants play in both politics and the economy.


Week 5: Healthcare


In 2010, the United States government passed the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. This was the most significant change in the US healthcare system since the 1960s! But was the Affordable Care Act a good idea? In Week 5, you and your PenPals will discuss the role a government should play in protecting the health of its citizens.


Week 6: Rock the Vote!


During the final week of the program, you and your PenPals will have the chance to learn about the presidential candidates and the election process. You will learn about voting requirements, political candidates, and different types of election issues. Then, you will learn about people across the country who are working hard to bring awareness to important civic causes.

How to be a Great PenPal


You are about to join thousands of students from more than one hundred different countries who are learning and sharing perspectives with PenPals from around the world!


Being a great PenPal starts with respect. Your PenPals are students just like you, so remember to always be respectful of them and their opinions! Write to your PenPals every week, use appropriate language, and help your PenPals when they have questions.


If your PenPals say something that you don’t agree with, ask your PenPals to explain their thinking. Remember, if your PenPal writes something inappropriate, flag the message and it will be reviewed by the PenPal Schools team.



Write to Your Future PenPals


So let’s get ready for your PenPal exchange by answering this week’s discussion question! Scroll to the top of the page and find the discussion question on the right side. Make sure to refer to the text and video when answering the question.



Each week, answer the weekly discussion question.


After you answer this week’s discussion question, use the chat section underneath to tell your future PenPals about yourself. Then ask your PenPals some questions about their communities.


Once matched, your PenPals can read and reply to your answers so you’ll already have something to talk about!

title: Health Care
body_one:
Caring for a Nation


How do we make sure everyone in the United States has what they need to be healthy?


People in the United States spend a lot of money on health care.  


Americans are proud of the advanced technology and treatments available. But technology, treatment, and prescription drugs can be expensive. The cost of these medicines is one reason why our health care spending is more than many other countries.


Credit: Newsroom UCLA


Many uninsured Americans turn to expensive hospitals when they are faced with an illness.


One sign that Americans may not have the best health care is in our average life expectancy. Americans have a shorter life expectancy than citizens in 30 other countries.


For the people without insurance, health care can be too expensive. As a result, many low-income people can not visit the doctor when they are sick.  


Another reason health care in the United States is expensive is because we have many elderly people. People older than 65 years old spend the most on health care and make the system more expensive for everyone.


So how can our country stop the cost of health care from rising? How can we make sure that everyone can visit the doctor when they need to? And do we always need to spend more money to get better care?


How do other countries provide health care?


Health care in other countries can teach us many things. People in less fortunate countries train doctors differently. They often design hospitals differently and include families and community in health care. Most importantly, people in other parts of the world spend more time teaching healthy living rather than how to fix diseases.


Countries like Denmark teach people how important it is to eat healthier food, cook at home, and to walk instead of drive a car use.


The elderly also live with families longer. Families help their elderly stay healthy and don’t have to spend as much money on home care or a retirement home.


Many European countries, like Spain use high-tech solutions and raise money for these services through taxes. While this system helps prevent people from getting sick, many people complain that the system is too expensive and leads to long lines at the doctor.


Future Solutions


Americans agree that people should have health care that they can pay for.  


Government programs like Medicare help people who are 65 or older as well as young people with disabilities. Other programs like Medicaid and CHIP help give health coverage to low-income families, children, the elderly, and people with disabilities. Both programs are run by the government.


This election you will likely hear about the Affordable Care Act, nicknamed Obamacare. The law forces insurance companies to give health care at a low cost to all people regardless of pre-existing conditions.


Opponents of the Affordable Care Act argue that the program would create a problems for the government. They say the government should not tell people and insurance companies how to manage health care. They argue a government system could cause people to wait longer for more expensive treatment like surgeries.


So what health care issues do you think our nation should prioritize in the election? Should our government help people learn about healthy? Should the government focus on programs like Medicare and Medicaid? What do you do to stay healthy?


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

insurance

noun: a service that protects you (financially) in the case of an emergency or disaster

life expectancy

noun: the average period someone or a group of people will live

prescription

noun: a medicine or treatment authorized by a doctor

Sources:

http://www.publicagenda.org/pages/csg-health-care

http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=125760327
body_two:
Caring for a Nation


How do we make sure health care and medical treatment are available when people need assistance?


The cost of health care takes a large part of the United States economy. In 2010, the United States spent eighteen percent of the nation’s economy on health care. In fact, the United States spends an average of  nine percent more on health care than thirty-four countries in Europe, Asia, South America, and Australia.


So the United States has the best health care since we spend the most, right?


Credit: Newsroom UCLA


Many uninsured Americans turn to expensive hospitals when they are faced with an illness.


One sign that Americans may not have the best health care is in our average life expectancy. Americans simply do not live as long as citizens from thirty other countries around the world. Many people think our life expectancy might be due to unhealthy eating and exercise habits. Others think that our life expectancy may not be as long because many people do not have medical coverage or access to health care.


For people without insurance, health care can often be too expensive. Low income individuals who can not buy insurance often can not afford to visit the doctor for basic and treatable illnesses. Today, we have about 20 million Americans who do not have insurance.


The rise in health costs also have a lot to do with a large number of people becoming older.  The elderly often require more medical care and account for the most health care spending.  


So how will our nation address the rising health care costs among our patients? With many health care systems providing high-quality care at relatively low cost, do we always need to spend more to get better care?


Future Solutions


Americans agree that people should have access to high-quality health care that is not too expensive. People should not be unable to access health care because they are too poor, unemployed, or have a pre-existing medical condition. Currently, federal health insurance programs like Medicare provide medical care for people who are 65 or older and certain younger people with disabilities.


Other programs like Medicaid and CHIP help low-income people and families with children access free or low-cost health coverage. Both programs run the state and federal governments.


Medicare and medicaid are different than insurance programs because they often can’t provide people with preventative care. Preventative care, such as regular doctor visits help people stay healthy and stop serious illnesses from arising.


One attempt to improve the health care system is called the Affordable Care Act, nicknamed Obamacare. The law requires insurance companies to cover all applicants within new standards and offer the same rates regardless of pre-existing conditions or gender.


Opponents of the Affordable Care Act, argue that the system would create problems for government. They argue that the government should not have any business being involved in health care. Opponents of the Affordable Care Act also argue that Government-run health care forces citizens to pay higher taxes while making it harder for people to get the care they want.


So what health care issues do you think our country should prioritize in the upcoming election?  Should our government be involved in helping us prevent and treat diseases? And how do you, as an individual, work to stay healthy?


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

insurance

noun: a service that protects you (financially) in the case of an emergency or disaster

life expectancy

noun: the average period someone or a group of people will live

Sources:

http://www.publicagenda.org/pages/csg-health-care

http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=125760327
body_three:
Caring for a Nation


How do we make sure health care and medical treatment are available to citizens when they need assistance?


The cost of health care takes a large share of the United States economy. In 2010, the United States spent eighteen percent of the nation’s economy on health care. The 2010 number is significantly larger than the seven percent spent by the United States in 1970, and to ten percent spent on average across thirty-four countries in Europe, Asia, South America, and Australia.


Americans are proud of the advanced medical technology created by the U.S. health care system. But technology, treatment, and prescription drugs can be expensive, and the cost of these services is one reason why our per capita spending on health care is higher than many other countries around the world.


So you might think that the United States has the best health care system since we spend the most, right?


One sign that Americans may not have the best health care is in our average life expectancy. Americans have a shorter life expectancy than the citizens of 30 other countries. Many credit this difference to unhealthy eating and exercise habits. Meanwhile, nearly 50 million people did not have medical coverage or access to health care in 2010.


For the uninsured, health care can often be too expensive. As a result, low income individuals can not receive basic doctor attention for treatable illnesses. Of the nearly 50 million people uninsured in the U.S. in 2010, three-quarters were members of families with one or more full-time workers. Even after current legislation from the Affordable Care Act, we still have about 20 million uninsured Americans.


Credit: Newsroom UCLA


Many uninsured Americans turn to expensive hospitals when they are faced with an illness.


The recent downturn in economic activity of the United States also contributed to decreases in health care coverage. In 1999, about 64 percent of Americans received health insurance from their employers. However, as companies tried to save money, by 2010, that had dropped to 55 percent.


The rise in health costs also have a lot to do with our aging population. People above the age of 65 account for the most health care spending. As the 79 million Baby Boomers are turning 65 at the rate of 10,000 a day, the amount of health care dollars devoted to older Americans will continue to increase. This fact, paired with gains in life expectancy, means that Medicare, a government funded program that provides aid to the elderly, will balloon from an enrollment of 47 million in 2010 to 85 million in 2035.


How will our nation address the rising health care costs among our patients?  With many health care systems providing high-quality care at relatively low cost, do we always need to spend more to get better care and outcomes?


How do other countries provide health care?


Health care in the developing world holds several "general lessons for richer countries," Nigel Crisp, a former permanent secretary of Britain's Department of Health, observed in a recent Times of London op-ed.


"Unconstrained by our history, [developing countries] train people differently, create new sorts of organisations, involve families and communities and concentrate more on promoting health rather than on just tackling disease."


Crisp’s comments help to outline that one of the largest obstacles between people and quality health care is the cost. While in the United States and other developed countries, there is a heavy use of expensive technology and highly skilled workers, sometimes simpler solutions are less expensive and more effective!


"Kangaroo care," an approach developed in Colombia, is another example. With a major shortage of incubators, doctors advised mothers to cradle preterm babies in a sling. The babies did so well that the program challenged what had been a conventional approach in the U.S., which encouraged only limited human contact while newborns were in incubators.


Credit: One.org


The Kangaroo Mother Care program teaches mothers how to increase the body temperatures of their newborns by wrapping the babies to their bare chests.


Other nations like Denmark have cultural practices that encourage the consumption of healthier home cooked meals and encourage walking or biking over car use. The elderly also tend to live with families longer which helps prevent injuries and provides less expensive home care rather than care provided at a retirement home. However, other countries take a step beyond culture and provide universal healthcare for their residents.


Many European countries, like Spain take advantage of high-tech solutions to health but raise money for these services through taxation. This care system helps prevent easy illnesses from growing worse by allowing citizens to receive care early on. However, many complain that this system is too expensive, leading to long lines and wait times to see doctors.


Future Solutions


Most Americans agree that citizens deserve to have access to affordable and high-quality health care, regardless of their income level, employment situation or pre-existing medical conditions. Currently, federal health insurance programs like Medicare provide aid for people who are 65 or older and certain younger people with disabilities.


Other programs like Medicaid and CHIP provide free or low-cost health coverage to millions of Americans including some low-income people, families and children, pregnant women, the elderly, and people with disabilities. Both programs are run jointly by federal and state governments, and details vary somewhat between states.


Medicare and medicaid are unlike insurance programs in that they often fail to provide the preliminary care people need to prevent a number of illnesses from arising. These programs are also different from insurance in that they may not deny care to those who are already sick or have preexisting conditions.


One attempt to improve the health care system is called the Affordable Care Act, nicknamed “Obamacare.” This law requires insurance companies to cover all applicants within new standards and offer the same rates regardless of pre-existing conditions or gender. In 2011 the Congressional Budget Office projected that the ACA would lower both future deficits and Medicare spending.


Universal Healthcare, yet another proposal, would simplify the system and vastly reduce paperwork since there would be one set of rules and forms for the entire system. They also think that workers, freed from having to stay at dead-end jobs solely for the health care benefits, would have greater freedom to start new businesses or take other jobs, stimulating the economy.


Opponents of the Affordable Care Act and Universal Healthcare Systems, argue that these systems would create a problem for government which may not have any business being involved in health care. A government organized health care system, opponents argue, could lead to less flexibility, and cause people to wait for surgeries and other important procedures. Opponents also argue that Government-run health care could burden citizens with higher taxes while leaving them unable to control many aspects of that care.


So what health care issues do you think our nation should prioritize in the upcoming election? What role should our government play in helping us prevent and treat illness and disease? Should our policy makers adopt new programs, or continue the ones we have? And how do you, as an individual, work to stay healthy?


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

baby boomer

noun: people born during the post–World War II baby boom; approximately between the years 1946 and 1964.

prescription

noun: a medicine or treatment authorized by a doctor

uninsured

adjective: without insurance

universal healthcare

noun: sometimes referred to as universal health coverage, universal coverage, or universal care, refers to a health care system which provides healthcare and financial protection to all citizens

Sources:

http://www.publicagenda.org/pages/csg-health-care

http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=125760327

title: Young Heroes for the Planet
body_one:
By TFK editors


It's our world. It's up to us to study it and protect it. That's the principle that motivates our kid heroes. TFK spoke with a few of them about their projects. You, too, can take a stand on an issue you care about. It will help make the world a better place!

Journey to the North Pole

GEIR EVENSEN—NRK


Four Norwegian teens pose in front of their tent on their way to the North Pole. They are, from left, Elias Damli, Johanne Jerijervi, Erika Gjelsvik, and Johannes Breivik.


How far would you go to spread the word about climate change? For four Norwegian teens, the answer was: all the way to the North Pole! They are (shown left to right above) Elias Damli, 14; Johanne Jerijervi, 14; Erika Gjelsvik, 14; and Johannes Breivik, 13. They made the journey on skis. They wanted to see the effects of warming temperatures on the Arctic wilderness. Their trip is the subject of a TV show in Norway.

The kids did a lot to prepare. They practiced dragging heavy sleds. They learned first aid. And they got used to frigid temperatures. They even joined a team of climate scientists on a research boat to learn about the Arctic environment.

The group set out in April. They skied for six days. The journey was far from easy. "There was one day I literally wanted to give up," Johannes told TFK. "But because of help from the other kids, I made it."

Polar explorer Børge Ousland traveled with the kids. He first visited the North Pole 20 years ago. Ousland helped the group understand how much the region has changed. "He told us that the first time he went to the North Pole, the ice was much thicker than it is now," Erika says.

The four teens have been busy since their trek. In December, they delivered a speech at a major climate conference, in Paris, France. "We kids are the future," Johannes says. "We need to have a say in how we're going to fix this problem."

Saving Sharks

Lilly and Trent Tougas have a soft spot for sharks. The siblings teach kids about protecting these big fish and their big habitat: the ocean.

Lilly, 15, organized Shark Week at her school to raise awareness about the threats to these top predators. She also helped design her middle school's ocean-studies class. Trent, 11, teamed up with his sister to create a video campaign aimed at stopping a food truck from serving shark tacos. They succeeded!


LILA PHOTO

Lilly and Trent Tougas

Lilly and Trent have taken their cause to Washington, D.C. They've spoken before Congress about the polluted Indian River Lagoon, near their home, in Florida. The lagoon is home to bull sharks. "We try to spread the word about why we should care about our oceans and their creatures," Lilly told TFK.

Helping Hands

When Isiah Britt, 7, heard there was a water crisis in Flint, Michigan, he decided to help. People there can't use the water because it contains dangerous chemicals. Isiah learned that kids were scared to wash their hands. But they needed to get rid of germs. With his parents' help, Isiah set up a fundraising website. He has raised almost $15,000. He is using the money to buy hand sanitizer and send it to every school in Flint. "I usually do small things to help," Isiah told TFK. "So I thought to myself, 'Why can't I do a big thing?'"


COURTESY DOUGAN FAMILY

Isiah Britt


Inspired by Nature

Casey Sokolovic, 17, will always remember her first trip to the Karen Beasley Sea Turtle Rescue and Rehabilitation Center, in North Carolina. It was about 10 years ago. She saw turtles that had been hurt. "I knew that I wanted to be able to help all these turtles and the hospital that serves them," she told TFK.


COURTESY CASEY SOKOLOVIC

Casey Sokolovic

Casey began by selling homemade turtle-shaped cookies. She coordinates an annual 5K run that raises funds for turtles. She also founded a free summer camp. It teaches kids about nature appreciation. "Being a young activist has really taught me to keep my eyes open," she says.

Sweet Rewards


COURTESY TESTA FAMILY


Hannah Testa

Hannah Testa, 12, helps elephants, rhinoceroses, and horses. "These beautiful animals don't have a voice of their own. It's up to us to speak up and help them," she told TFK. Hannah sold elephant-themed items at a Georgia store. The money goes to the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust. The group helps elephants and rhinos. Hannah also runs Pennies for Ponies to provide food and medicine for horses. "Don't ever think you're too young to make a difference," she says.

Vocabulary

Word

Definition

coordinate

verb: to act together in achieving a goal

fundraise

verb: to raise money for a cause

motivate

verb: to become interested in doing something

Polar explorer Børge Ousland traveled with the kids. He first visited the North Pole 20 years ago. Ousland helped the group understand how much the region has changed. "He told us that the first time he went to the North Pole, the ice was much thicker than it is now," Erika says.


The four teens have been busy since their trek. In December, they delivered a speech at a major climate conference, in Paris, France. "We kids are the future," Johannes says. "We need to have a say in how we're going to fix this problem."

Lilly and Trent Tougas have a soft spot for sharks. The siblings teach kids about protecting these big fish and their big habitat: the ocean.


Lilly, 15, organized Shark Week at her school to raise awareness about the threats to these top predators. She also helped design her middle school's ocean-studies class. Trent, 11, teamed up with his sister to create a video campaign aimed at stopping a food truck from serving shark tacos. They succeeded!


LILA PHOTO


Lilly and Trent Tougas


Lilly and Trent have taken their cause to Washington, D.C. They've spoken before Congress about the polluted Indian River Lagoon, near their home, in Florida. The lagoon is home to bull sharks. "We try to spread the word about why we should care about our oceans and their creatures," Lilly told TFK.


Helping Hands


When Isiah Britt, 7, heard there was a water crisis in Flint, Michigan, he decided to help. People there can't use the water because it contains dangerous chemicals. Isiah learned that kids were scared to wash their hands. But they needed to get rid of germs. So, with his parents' help, Isiah set up a fundraising website. He has raised almost $15,000 to buy hand sanitizer and send it to every school in Flint.


COURTESY DOUGAN FAMILY


Isiah Britt


Now he is working to get sanitizer and wipes to the city's homeless kids. "I usually do small things to help," Isiah told TFK. "So I thought to myself, 'Why can't I do a big thing?'"


Inspired by Nature


Casey Sokolovic, 17, will always remember her first trip to the Karen Beasley Sea Turtle Rescue and Rehabilitation Center, in North Carolina. It was about10 years ago. She saw turtles that had been hurt. She found her calling as an activist. "I knew that I wanted to be able to help all these turtles and the hospital that serves them," she told TFK.


COURTESY CASEY SOKOLOVIC


Casey Sokolovic


Casey began by selling homemade turtle-shaped cookies. She coordinates an annual 5K run that raises funds for turtles and other environmental causes. She also founded a free summer camp. It teaches kids about nature appreciation and preservation.


"Being a young activist has really taught me to keep my eyes open and expand my horizons in everything that I do," she says.


Sweet Rewards


COURTESY TESTA FAMILY


Hannah Testa


Hannah Testa, 12, helps elephants, rhinoceroses, and horses. "These beautiful animals don't have a voice of their own. It's up to us to speak up and help them," she told TFK. Hannah sold elephant-themed items such as cookies at a Georgia store. The money goes to the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust, which helps elephants and rhinos. She also runs Pennies for Ponies to provide food and medicine for horses. "Don't ever think you're too young to make a difference, because anything is possible," she says.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

coordinate

verb: to act together in achieving a goal

found

verb: to start or begin an organization

fundraise

verb: to raise money for a cause

motivate

verb: to become interested in doing something
