title: The Environment in the United States
body_one:
Sea Otters Are Superheroes Of The Marsh


This sea otter, about to eat a crab in the Elkhorn Slough National Estuarine Research Reserve is protecting the underwater ecosystem. Rob Eby/AP


On the roof of the Monterey Bay Aquarium in Monterey, Calif., in a large plastic tank, a sea otter mother named Abby floats with her adopted pup.  When the pup is ready, she will be released into a protected estuary called Elkhorn Slough, just off Monterey Bay.  That's where the pup will work to preserve the estuary.


Fewer than 3,000 southern sea otters live in the wild. Government laws now protect sea otters. Today, researchers are learning that the otters have a positive effect on the ecosystems where they live.


Elkhorn Slough is now a protected research reserve, but 20 years ago, there were no sea otters here, and the marsh was a mess.  Farmland runoff poured into this estuary, loading it with pollution.


A mother sea otter and her pup swim in a tide pool in Monterey Bay.

Mike Fiala/AP


The pollution caused the algae to take over. Bugs would normally keep the algae in check, but with no sea otters around, the otters' favorite food — crabs — ate the bugs. And there are lots and lots of crabs.


Eelgrass Food Chain:


Sea Otters ← Crabs ← Bugs ← Algae ← Sun

(Sea Otters eat Crabs, Crabs eat Bugs, Bugs eat Algae, Algae gets energy from the Sun)


Habitats like Elkhorn provide all sorts of benefits for humans as well.  Fishermen benefit from natural fish nurseries.  Homes benefit from a natural barrier to storms and sea rise.  The planet benefits from the carbon dioxide that marshland plants soak up.  


Under decades of government protection, the sea otters are back and eating crabs! That means the algae is down, the seagrass is up.


A sea otter plays in the water in Monterey, Calif.

Paul Sakuma/AP


It's not just about saving individual species, as cute as they are — it's about saving entire ecosystems.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

conservation

(noun) preservation, protection, or restoration of the natural environment, natural ecosystems, vegetation, and wildlife

ecosystem

(noun) a biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment

estuary

(noun) the tidal mouth of a large river, where the tide meets the stream

View the Original Article from NPR
body_two:
More Than Just Cute, Sea Otters Are Superheroes Of The Marsh


This sea otter, about to eat a crab in the Elkhorn Slough National Estuarine Research Reserve, is cute, sure. But more importantly, it's indirectly combating some harmful effects of agricultural runoff and protecting the underwater ecosystem. Rob Eby/AP


On the roof of the Monterey Bay Aquarium in Monterey, Calif., in a large plastic tank, a sea otter mother named Abby floats with her adopted pup.  For up to nine months, Abby will raise her little adoptee, and when the pup is ready, she will be released into a protected estuary called Elkhorn Slough, just off Monterey Bay.  That's where the pup will work to preserve the estuary.


Fewer than 3,000 southern sea otters live in the wild, only a quarter of their population of 150 years ago. Government laws now protect sea otters. Today, researchers along California's central coast are learning that the otters are also having a positive effect on the ecosystems where they live.


Elkhorn Slough is now a protected research reserve, but 20 years ago, there were no sea otters here, and the marsh was a mess.  Farmland runoff poured into this estuary, loading it with pollution.


A mother sea otter and her pup swim in a tide pool in Monterey Bay.

Mike Fiala/AP


"It's sort of just like throwing ... a bunch of fertilizer in here," says Tinker. "You're going to get a bunch of algae growing, and that algae grows over top of the eelgrass and chokes it out."

This eelgrass was home to an entire food chain of animals — or it was, until the algae took over. Bugs would normally keep the algae in check, but with no sea otters around, the otters' favorite food — crabs — ate the bugs. And there are lots and lots of crabs.


Eelgrass Food Chain:


Sea Otters ← Crabs ← Bugs ← Algae ← Sun

(Sea Otters eat Crabs, Crabs eat Bugs, Bugs eat Algae, Algae gets energy from the Sun)


All of these changes affect another animal: humans. Habitats like Elkhorn provide all sorts of benefits: Fishermen benefit from natural fish nurseries; homes benefit from a natural barrier to storms and sea rise; the planet benefits from the carbon dioxide that marshland plants soak up.  That's where sea otters come in. Under decades of government protection, they're back, and eating crabs. That means the algae is down, the seagrass is up.

A sea otter plays in the water in Monterey, Calif.

Paul Sakuma/AP


Tinker says that what they have learned has changed sea otter conservation. It's not just about saving individual species, as cute as they are — it's about saving entire ecosystems.


"They're saving us," he says. "They're saving ecosystems that we rely on, and so it's a different sort of message than the one that we started out with 15 years ago."


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

conservation

(noun) preservation, protection, or restoration of the natural environment, natural ecosystems, vegetation, and wildlife

ecosystem

(noun) a biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment

estuary

(noun) the tidal mouth of a large river, where the tide meets the stream

View the Original Article from NPR
body_three:
More Than Just Cute, Sea Otters Are Superheroes Of The Marsh


This sea otter, about to eat a crab in the Elkhorn Slough National Estuarine Research Reserve, is cute, sure. But more importantly, it's indirectly combating some harmful effects of agricultural runoff and protecting the underwater ecosystem. Rob Eby/AP


On the roof of the Monterey Bay Aquarium in Monterey, Calif., in a large plastic tank, a sea otter mother named Abby floats with her adopted pup, known as 671.  For up to nine months, Abby will raise her little adoptee, and when 671 is ready, she will be released into a protected inland salt marsh called Elkhorn Slough, just off Monterey Bay.  That's where 671 will set to work to preserve the estuary, says Tim Tinker, who tracks otters for the U.S. Geological Survey.


"The reason why we focus on sea otters is not just because they're cute and fun to watch, but because they have a very outsize role to play in the function of this system," Tinker says.

Fewer than 3,000 southern sea otters live in the wild, only a quarter of their population of 150 years ago. State and federal protections in recent decades have stabilized sea otter numbers. Now, researchers along California's central coast are learning that the otters are also having a positive effect on the ecosystems where they live.


Elkhorn Slough is now a protected research reserve, but 20 years ago, there were no sea otters here, and the marsh was a mess.  Farmland runoff regularly pours into this estuary, loading it with man-made nutrients.

A mother sea otter and her pup swim in a tide pool in Monterey Bay.

Mike Fiala/AP


"It's sort of just like throwing ... a bunch of fertilizer in here," says Tinker. "You're going to get a bunch of algae growing, and that algae grows over top of the eelgrass and chokes it out."

This eelgrass was home to an entire food chain of animals — or it was, until the algae took over. Bugs would normally keep the algae in check, but with no sea otters around, the otters' favorite food — crabs — ate the bugs. And there are lots and lots of crabs.


Eelgrass Food Chain:


Sea Otters ← Crabs ← Bugs ← Algae ← Sun

(Sea Otters eat Crabs, Crabs eat Bugs, Bugs eat Algae, Algae gets energy from the Sun)


"Within the marsh banks itself, there are all these holes," Tinker says. "Those are the crab condos ... that's what I call them."


Brent Hughes, a researcher at the University of California, Santa Cruz, says there were so many crab condos, the muddy banks couldn't support themselves.


"This ecosystem is literally collapsing into the ocean," Hughes says. "The reason being is that we're losing the banks, and we're losing the marsh plants that are stabilizing it."


All this upheaval affects another animal: humans. Habitats like Elkhorn provide all sorts of ecological benefits: Fishermen benefit from natural fish nurseries; homes benefit from a natural barrier to storms and sea rise; the planet benefits from the carbon dioxide that marshland plants soak up.  That's where sea otters come in. Under decades of government protection, they're back, and eating crabs. That means the algae is down, the seagrass is up, and with crab condo vacancies, the muddy marshland banks are still here.


Tinker says even he was surprised by the turnaround.


"All of a sudden, they teach us this entire new thing about how there's a food web that sea otters are a part of that can actually make sea grass healthy even when there's nutrients," he says. "This was something we had no clue about."


A sea otter plays in the water in Monterey, Calif.

Paul Sakuma/AP


Tinker says that realization has changed the philosophy behind sea otter conservation. It's not just about saving individual species, as cute as they are — it's about saving entire ecosystems.


"They're saving us," he says. "They're saving ecosystems that we rely on, and so it's a different sort of message than the one that we started out with 15 years ago."


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

conservation

(noun) preservation, protection, or restoration of the natural environment, natural ecosystems, vegetation, and wildlife

ecosystem

(noun) a biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment

estuary

(noun) the tidal mouth of a large river, where the tide meets the stream

outsize

(adj) exceptionally large

stabilized

(verb, past) made or became unlikely to change, fail, or decline

View the Original Article from NPR

title: Daily Life
body_one:
Communities Around the World


More than seven billion people live on earth! These people live in over one hundred ninety countries. In each country, people live in different states and cities. Life is similar in many places.



Around the world people do many similar things. People eat, sleep, and dress in clean clothes. People travel, work, and go to school. But while people need to do many of the same things, they do them in unique and different ways.


Urban and Rural Communities


Africa is a continent with over 50 countries. Nigeria and Egypt have some of Africa's largest cities. Many people in Africa are moving from the country to cities. People who lived in rural places are moving to cities for work, education, and a better life.


Credit: seun78 via flickr


Lagos is the capital of Nigeria.


Lagos is the capital of Nigeria. Lagos has many sights and sounds you might know. In Lagos you see people rushing to work each morning in cars, motorcycles, and bicycles. In Lagos, you meet people who moved to the city to find work and go to school. In Lagos, kids hang out with friends after school.


Many big cities are in South and Southeast Asia! Cities like Islamabad, Delhi, Shanghai, Seoul, and Tokyo are some of the biggest cities in the world! People move to these cities for work, education, and a better life.


Credit: dwimalu via flickr


In East and Southeast Asia, Rickshaws are used to get around.


But people still live outside of cities. In the United States, Canada, and Australia, many people live in rural communities. With computers, people in rural communities can do many jobs.


Sports & Recreational Activities


People like recreational activities. All over the world people like to spend time with friends and family. People like to watch movies. People also like to eat at restaurants and play sports.


Credit: string_bass_dave via flickr


Cricket is played all over South Asia.


Cricket is a popular sports. Cricket is popular in South Asia, Oceania, Europe, and the Caribbean. Cricket players are called cricketers!


Credit: spcbrass via flickr


Many of the best hockey players in the world come from Canada.


In Canada, people like similar activities. People like to visit parks, go to malls, and watch movies. Canadians also like to be outside. Canadians like sports that are played outside! Sports like ice hockey, skiing, and curling are popular in Canada. Canadians also like soccer, basketball, and golf.



School and Education


Around the world, school and education are important. More than 700 million young people around the world are school-age. That’s a pretty big number!


Credit: dlisbona via flickr


Children read aloud together at a school in Damascus, Syria.


While many kids are in school, many kids can not go to school. War, discrimination, and poverty keep many kids from going to school.


Daily Life in Your Community


Now it is your turn to share with your PenPal! What does your community look like? What things do you hear and see every day? What does school look like in your community? Share the answers to these questions with your PenPal as you explore daily life in communities around the world!



Vocabulary


Word

Definition

different

adjective: being unlike something else

discrimination

noun: treating people differently based on race, religion, gender, or other characteristics

recreation

noun: activities one enjoys when not working

rural

adjective: having the characteristics of a countryside rather than a town or city

similar

adjective: being like something else

unique

adjective: one of a kind; unlike anything else


Meet Your PenPal!
body_two:
There are over seven billion people living on earth today. These people are spread across one hundred and ninety countries. In each country people live in different states and cities. Believe it or not, daily life is similar no matter where you go.


All around the world, people eat, sleep, dress in clean clothing, earn and spend money, travel, work, and go to school. But while people need to do many of the same things, they do them in unique and different ways.


Communities Around the World


Credit: seun78 via flickr


Lagos is the capital of Nigeria.


Africa is a continent with over 50 diverse countries. African nations like Nigeria and Egypt have large and bustling cities. People across Africa are quickly moving from the country to cities. In fact, Africa is the fastest urbanizing continent in the world. Africans who lived in rural places are moving to cities for work, education, and a better life.


In Lagos, the capital of Nigeria, you might recognize many sights and sounds. You would hear people rushing to work each morning in cars, motorcycles, and bicycles. As a young person, you might head to school. In the afternoon, you might participate in an after-school program before hanging out with friends.



Many of the largest cities in the world are in South and Southeast Asia! South and Southeast Asia are home to cities like Islamabad, Delhi, Shanghai, Seoul, and Tokyo. These cities are growing as people from rural communities move for work, education, and a better life.


Credit: dwimalu via flickr


In East and Southeast Asia, Rickshaws are used to get around.


But while cities around the world are getting larger, this isn’t the case everywhere. In the United States, Canada, and Australia, many people still live in rural communities. With technology and the internet, people in rural communities can still do many jobs.


Sports & Recreational Activities


People in urban or rural communities enjoy recreational activities. From Canada to Sri Lanka, people like to spend time with friends and family. People also enjoy watching movies, eating in restaurants and cafes, and playing sports.


Credit: string_bass_dave via flickr


Cricket is played by amateurs and professionals all over South Asia.


Cricket is one of the most popular sports in the world! Particularly in South Asia, cricket players are popular and become celebrities.


Source: Top End Sports


In Canada, people enjoy many recreational activities. People like to visit parks, go to malls, hang out at coffee shops, and watch movies. Canadians also love the outdoors. Canadians appreciate sports and athletics that are played outside! Aside from ice hockey, skiing, and curling, people across Canada also enjoy soccer, basketball, and golf.


Credit: spcbrass via flickr


Many of the best hockey players in the world come from Canada.


School and Education


Whether you live in an urban community or a rural area, school and education are likely important. More students are in school now than at any point in history. There are over 700 million school-age people around the world.


Credit: dlisbona via flickr


Children read aloud together at a school in Damascus, Syria.


While many kids are in school, many educational challenges still exist. War, discrimination, and poverty keep many kids from receiving an education.


Daily Life in Your Community


Now it is your turn to reflect on your community and share with your PenPal!



What does your community look like? What familiar sights and sounds do you see and hear every day? What does school look like in the community where you live? What sports and recreational activities are popular? Share the answers to these questions with your PenPal as you explore daily life in communities around the world!


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

diverse

adjective: showing a large amount of variety

recreation

noun: activities one enjoys when not working

rural

adjective: having the characteristics of a countryside rather than a town or city

unique

adjective: one of a kind; unlike anything else

urban

adjective: having the characteristics of a city or town
body_three:
Communities Around the World


There are over seven billion people living on earth today. These people are distributed across one-hundred and ninety countries, countless states, and even more cities. Believe it or not, across this large and diverse world, daily life is remarkably similar no matter where you go.


All around the world, people eat, sleep, dress in clean clothing, earn and spend money, travel, work, and go to school. But while people do many of the same things, they do them in unique and different ways.


Credit: seun78 via flickr


Lagos is the capital of Nigeria.


Africa, for example, is a continent with over 50 diverse countries. Many African nations, like Nigeria, Egypt, and the Democratic Republic of Congo, have large and bustling cities. In fact, people across Africa are moving so quickly to African cities that Africa is the fastest urbanizing continent in the world. Africans who historically lived in rural environments are moving to Africa’s cities for work, education, and a better quality of life.


Travel to Lagos, the capital of Nigeria and you might recognize the familiar sounds of people rushing to work each morning in cars, motorcycles, and bicycles. In a city like Lagos, you might meet people from across the continent of Africa who have immigrated to find work and improve their lives. As a young person, you might head to school before participating in an after-school program, hanging out with friends, playing games outside in the park, or heading to a movie.



Across the Indian Ocean in South and Southeast Asia, you will find many of the largest and most populous cities in the world! Like urban centers across Africa, cities like Islamabad, Delhi, Shanghai, Seoul, and Tokyo are growing as people from rural communities migrate to cities for work, education, and a better quality of life.

Credit: dwimalu via flickr


In East and Southeast Asia, Rickshaws are used to get around.


But while cities around the world are getting larger, this isn’t the case everywhere. In places like the United States, Canada, and Australia, many people continue to live in rural communities. Thanks to advances in technology like the internet, people are able to live in rural communities while still being able to participate in many of the fast-paced and high-paying industries present in large cities like New York City, or Sydney.


Sports & Recreational Activities


Depending on whether you live in an urban or rural environment, people around the world enjoy and participate in many different recreational activities. From Canada to Sri Lanka, people enjoy spending time with friends and family, watching movies, visiting restaurants and cafes, and participating in athletics.


Credit: string_bass_dave via flickr


Cricket is played by amateurs and professionals all over South Asia.


Cricket is one of the most popular sports in the world! Across South Asia in particular, cricket players, known as cricketers, are extremely popular and can obtain celebrity status in the region!


Source: Top End Sports


On the other side of the world, in Canada, people might enjoy visiting parks, going to malls, hanging out at coffee shops, and watching movies. Canadians also love the outdoors and appreciate sports and athletics that are enjoyed outside! Aside from ice hockey, skiing, and curling, people across Canada and the Northern United States also enjoy soccer, basketball, and golf.


Credit: spcbrass via flickr


Many of the best hockey players in the world come from Canada.


School and Education


Whether you live in an urban community or a rural area, school and education are likely important. More students are in school now than at any point in history. There are over 700 million school-age people around the world. That’s a pretty big number! But out of all these students, between 50 and 100 million students do not have the opportunity to attend school.


Credit: dlisbona via flickr


Children read aloud together at a school in Damascus, Syria.


Around the world education coverage remains a challenge. In countries like Mexico, Brazil, Sudan, and Afghanistan, despite advances in education access and rising literacy rates, millions of students still exist outside the formal education system. Factors such as violent conflicts, gender inequality, and limited resources impede quality education around the world.


Daily Life in Your Community


Now it is your turn to reflect on your community and share with your PenPal!



What does your community look like? What familiar sights and sounds do you see and hear every day? What does school look like in the community where you live? What sports and recreational activities are popular? Share the answers to these questions with your PenPal as you explore daily life in communities around the world!


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

diverse

adjective: showing a large amount of variety

immigrate

verb: travel to live in a new location permanently

industry

noun: economic activity associated with the production of a specific good

populous

adjective: having many people; a large population

recreation

noun: activities one enjoys when not working

rural

adjective: having the characteristics of a countryside rather than a town or city

urban

adjective: having the characteristics of a city or town

title: Energy
body_one:
Energy’s Costs & The Future


Many people might not think about the energy they use, but energy is an important part of our daily lives. We use energy to get to work, to run our computers, and to keep buildings cool in the summer. In fact, almost everything we do uses energy.


Source: Reed Saxon/AP


Cars at a standstill in both directions on Interstate 405 in Los Angeles.


Thanks to technology, our cars and appliances are more energy efficient than ever. The problem, however, is that we are using a lot more energy as a country. Energy use in the U.S. has nearly tripled because of population growth. There are nearly 135 million more people in the U.S. today than there were in 1960, and more people simply use more energy.


Members of the United States government will make important decisions about energy.  What laws should our government pass? How will these laws affect the environment, the economy, and the lifestyles of the 320 million people living in the United States?



Energy use of major countries.


Energy Production and the Environment


How do we provide energy to a growing nation? Most experts say that all of the remaining oil in the United States is in Far away places, like offshore and in Alaska. Drilling for this oil could hurt the health of our forests, the quality of our air and water supplies, and the safety of our wildlife. The Keystone Pipeline in Alaska, has been at the center of energy debate for years.  This large oil pipeline will bring oil from the arctic ocean, across Canada, and into the continental United States.


Many worry that such a long pipeline could lead to an oil spill that could create permanent damage to the environments surrounding the line.


Source: DavisVanguard.org


A sample of the length and impact that an oil pipeline can have on an environment.


In addition the risks drilling has on the environmental, using coal and petroleum creates harmful greenhouse gasses. The unnatural release of greenhouse gasses can be linked to global warming.


Fracking & Natural Gas


America's Next Economic Boom Could Be Lying Underground. In recent history, oil production has been controlled by large and successful oil companies. Now, scientists are excited about fracking.  Fracking is the process of drilling down into the earth to release the gas inside.



A drill used for fracking.


While fracking does help create jobs and natural gas, people worry about the long run. Burning and transporting natural gas still causes global warming and the drilling process can pollute local water sources.


Possible Solutions


Most of our energy still comes from fossil fuels. Fossil fuels—petroleum, natural gas and coal—release carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases.  Fossil fuels are not renewable sources of energy, meaning that one day they will run out.


Clean energy sources like wind and solar power, are more expensive than fossil fuels. It may take years before we can make wind and solar power at low prices.


Energy may seem complicated, but we don’t need to be experts to have an options.  We need to know the basic facts, consider the tradeoffs, and always remember to turn off the lights when we leave a room!


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

fossil fuel

noun: fuel from buried combustible geologic deposits of organic materials. Fossil Fuels are decayed plants and animals that have been converted to crude oil, coal, and natural gas by exposure to heat and pressure over of millions of years.

fracking

verb: the process of drilling down into the earth before a high-pressure water mixture is directed at the rock to release the gas inside.

pipeline

noun: a long pipe, typically underground, for moving oil, gas, etc., over long distances.

population

noun: the people who live in a specific area

renewable fuels

noun: fuels produced from renewable resources such as wind or corn.

Sources:

http://www.publicagenda.org/files/PublicAgenda_CitizensSolutionsGuide_Jobs.pdf

http://www.npr.org/2015/06/11/413395080/americas-next-economic-boom-could-be-lying-underground
body_two:
Energy’s Costs & The Future


What can a nation provide energy to everyone?  


Many people might take energy for granted, but energy is an important part of our daily lives. We use energy to get to work, to run the dishwasher and household appliances, and to charge our mobile devices.


For better or for worse, almost everything we do requires energy. There are significant environmental and social tradeoffs to our energy consumption.


Source: Reed Saxon/AP


Cars at a standstill in both directions on Interstate 405 in Los Angeles.


On a per person basis, the energy we consume is not too much higher than the late 1960’s. Thanks to technology, our cars and appliances are more energy efficient than ever.


The problem, however, is that we are using a lot more energy as a society. Energy consumption in the U.S. has nearly tripled because of population growth. There are nearly 135 million more people in the U.S. today than there were in 1960, and more people simply use more energy.


In the coming years, our elected officials will make important decisions regarding energy. What laws should our government pass, and how will these laws affect the environment, the economy, and the lifestyles of the 320 million people living in the United States?



Energy use of major countries.

Energy Production and the Environment


How do we provide energy to a growing nation?


When it comes to domestic oil production, most experts say that all of the remaining oil reserves are in remote locations, like offshore and in Alaska. Drilling for this oil could hurt the health of our forests, the quality of our air and water supplies, and the safety of our wildlife.


The Keystone Pipeline in Alaska, has been at the center of energy debate for the past number of years. This large oil pipeline will bring oil from the arctic ocean, across Canada, and into the continental United States.


Many worry that such a long pipeline could lead to an oil spill that could create permanent damage to the environments surrounding the line.


Source: DavisVanguard.org


A sample of the length and impact that an oil pipeline can have on an environment.  


In addition the risks drilling has on the environmental, using coal and petroleum creates harmful greenhouse gasses. The unnatural release of greenhouse gasses can be linked to global warming.


About six in ten Americans don’t think global warming will have a serious impact on them during their lifetimes. Scientific argue, however, that temperatures are rising faster. Scientists think the impacts of climate change could cause a number of problems including coastal flooding and extreme weather and drought.


Not everyone agrees on how serious these issues are or what government should do to address them. But people across the United States do agree that our country needs a stable, and affordable sources of energy in order to protect our economy and our way of life.


America's Next Economic Boom Could Be Lying Underground


In recent history, oil production has been controlled by large and successful oil companies that drill, refine and sell oil to consumers. But now, scientists and economists are excited about fracking. Fracking is the process of drilling down into the earth before a high-pressure water mixture is directed at the rock to release the gas inside.


Source: NapaValley.edu


An example of the science and impact of Fracking.


This process of oil and gas extraction has helped the economy in a number of ways. Households on rural land can sell drilling rights to oil companies. Every new drill also creates new spillover jobs for truckers, drill-hands, and local restaurants and hotels that serve new workers.


However, while fracking does create a positive economic impact in the short run many worry about the long run. Burning and transporting natural gas still causes global warming and the drilling process can pollute local water sources.


Possible Solutions


Most of our energy still comes from fossil fuels. Fossil fuels—petroleum, natural gas and coal—not only release carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, but they are also nonrenewable sources of energy, meaning that one day they will run out.


Clean energy sources like wind and solar power, are currently more expensive than traditional fuel sources. It may take years before we can make wind and solar power at low prices.


One solution to our energy debate is to move away from fossil fuels as quickly and as safely as we can. Some think focusing on clean energy will protect the environment and give us cheaper and more reliable energy in the future. Some think that by taxing pollution and spending government money to on clean energy technology we can make this future a reality.


Others think that we still too close to the worst financial crises our country has ever seen. They say that our government simply cannot afford the costs involved in moving away from fossil fuels.


Energy may seem complicated, but we don’t need to be experts to weigh the options.  We need to know the basic facts, consider the tradeoffs, and always remember to turn off the lights when we leave a room!


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

consumption

(noun) to use a resource

fossil fuel

(noun) fuel from buried combustible geologic deposits of organic materials.  Fossil Fuels are decayed plants and animals that have been converted to crude oil, coal, and natural gas by exposure to heat and pressure over of millions of years.

fracking

(verb) the process of drilling down into the earth before a high-pressure water mixture is directed at the rock to release the gas inside.

population

(noun) the people who live in a specific area

renewable fuels

(noun)  fuels produced from renewable resources such as wind or corn.

spillover

(noun) an instance of overflowing or spreading into another area.

Sources:

http://www.publicagenda.org/files/PublicAgenda_CitizensSolutionsGuide_Jobs.pdf

http://www.npr.org/2015/06/11/413395080/americas-next-economic-boom-could-be-lying-underground
body_three:
Energy’s Costs & The Future


What can a nation provide energy to everyone?  


While many people might take energy for granted, energy plays an integral role in our daily lives.  We use energy in commuting to work, running the dishwasher, charging our mobile devices, and cooling our schools and office buildings.


Energy is even used to manufacture, ship and prepare a majority of the products we buy. For better or for worse, nearly everything we do requires energy and there are significant environmental and social tradeoffs to our energy consumption.


Source: Reed Saxon/AP


Cars at a standstill in both directions on Interstate 405 in Los Angeles.


On a per person basis, our consumption levels are not too much higher than what they were in the late 1960’s. Thanks to technology, our cars and appliances are more energy efficient than ever.


We are, however, using a lot more energy as a society. Energy consumption in the U.S. has nearly tripled in the last 60 years, due mainly to population growth—there are nearly 135 million more people in the U.S. today than there were in 1960.


People across the United States are also driving more than before and using more technology than earlier generations. Even though fuel efficiency standards have been bumped up twice in recent years, the number of vehicles per household increased by 66 percent between 1969 and 2009.


In the coming years, our elected officials will face important decisions regarding energy policies and the effect they have on the environment, the economy, and the lifestyles of the 320 million people living in the United States.



Energy use of major countries.


Energy Production and the Environment


How do we provide energy to a growing nation? When it comes to domestic oil production, most experts say that all of the remaining oil reserves are in remote locations, like offshore and in Alaska. Drilling for this oil will have repercussions on the health of our forests, the quality of our air and water supplies, and the safety of our wildlife.


We have seen significant pushback from environmentalists against the Keystone Pipeline in Alaska, for example. This large continental oil pipeline extension is intended to bring oil from the arctic ocean, across Canada, and into the continental United States.


Many worry that such a long pipeline could lead to an oil spill that would create permanent damage to the environments surrounding the line.


Source: DavisVanguard.org


A sample of the length and impact that an oil pipeline can have on an environment.


In addition the environmental costs of producing fuel, using coal and petroleum creates harmful greenhouse gasses as a byproduct. This unnatural release of greenhouse gasses can be linked to global warming.


About six in ten Americans don’t think global warming will have a serious impact on them during their lifetimes. Scientific consensus, however, argues that temperatures are rising and at a faster rate than ever before. Scientists believe the impacts of climate change could cause a number of problems including coastal flooding, extreme weather and drought, and the resulting social instability in many countries, especially poor ones.


Groups like the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change warn that it is no longer a question of whether world temperatures will increase as a result of global warming; it’s a matter of how much. Eleven of the 13 hottest years on record have occurred since 2001. Reducing our reliance on fossil fuels is fundamental to controlling the greenhouse gas emissions that scientists say are causing global warming.


Not everyone agrees on the extent to which each of these issues is a threat or what government in particular should do to address them. But there is a much broader consensus that the United States needs diversified, stable, and affordable sources of energy in order to protect our economy and our way of life. Some see natural gas, obtained through a process of hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, as a reliable and affordable solution.


Fracking & Natural Gas


America's Next Economic Boom Could Be Lying Underground. In recent history, oil production has been controlled by large and successful petroleum companies that drill, refine and sell oil to consumers.

"That's not good for America," says Harvard economist Michael Porter. "That's not good for America's standard of living. That's not good for our ultimate vitality as a nation."


That’s why many are excited about the deep reserves of natural gas and oil that have been made accessible by hydraulic fracturing technology, or fracking. Fracking is the process of drilling down into the earth before a high-pressure water mixture is directed at the rock to release the gas inside. Water, sand and chemicals are injected into the rock at high pressure which allows the gas to flow out to the head of the well.


Source: NapaValley.edu


An example of the science and impact of Fracking.


This process of oil and gas extraction has benefited the economy in a number of ways. Households on rural land can now sell drilling rights to oil companies. In addition, every new drill creates new spillover jobs for truckers, drill-hands, and local restaurants and hotels that serve new workers.


However, while fracking does create a positive economic impact in the short run many worry about the long run. Burning and transporting natural gas still contributes to global warming and the drilling process can pollute local water sources. Many also think that we should spend our money on researching new clean energy sources instead.


Possible Solutions


Most of our energy—83 percent—comes from fossil fuels. Fossil fuels—petroleum, natural gas and coal—not only emit carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, they are also nonrenewable sources of energy, meaning they will all run out one day.


Clean energy sources like wind and solar power, are currently much more expensive than traditional fuel sources. It will be decades before we can produce wind and solar power at reasonable prices and in enough quantities to supply the electricity we need.


One solution is to move away from fossil fuels as quickly and as safely as we can. Some think this will protect the environment and in the long run will give us cheaper and more reliable clean energy sources. Some have proposed that we do this through taxing pollution, spending government money to support green technology and limiting dangerous drilling methods.


Supporters argue that If you consider the serious costs of global warming and pollution, as well as the fact that our fossil fuels will one day in the not-too-distant future run out, there’s no question that a green economy is the best solution.


Others think that we are living in the aftermath of one of the worst financial crises our country has ever experienced, and we have a ballooning national debt. Our government simply cannot afford the huge costs involved in transitioning away from traditional energy sources.


Energy may seem complicated, but we don’t need to be experts to be able to weigh the options.  We need to know the basic facts, consider the tradeoffs in possible solutions, and always remember to turn off the lights when we leave a room!


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

fossil fuel

noun: fuel from buried combustible geologic deposits of organic materials. Fossil Fuels are decayed plants and animals that have been converted to crude oil, coal, and natural gas by exposure to heat and pressure over of millions of years.

fracking

verb: the process of drilling down into the earth before a high-pressure water mixture is directed at the rock to release the gas inside.

renewable fuels

noun: fuels produced from renewable resources such as wind or corn.

repercussions

noun: an unintended consequence occurring some time after an event or action, especially an unwelcome one.

Sources:

http://www.publicagenda.org/files/PublicAgenda_CitizensSolutionsGuide_Jobs.pdf

http://www.npr.org/2015/06/11/413395080/americas-next-economic-boom-could-be-lying-underground

title: Food
body_one:
Food helps us learn about different places. If you like green beans, fried chicken, and apple pie, you might be from the United States. If you like tortilla espanola, chorizo, and manchego cheese, you might be from Spain.


Credit: benimoto via flickr


Apple Pie is so a symbol of the United States.


When people travel and move they bring their favorite foods with them. People from all over the world live in the United States. As a result, people in the United States can enjoy many different kinds of food. Food from China, India, Mexico, Italy and the Middle East are all part of the American diet!


People buy their food from different places. Some people buy food at a grocery store. Other people buy food at a market. Some people buy their food at fast food and sit-down restaurants.


A World of Food


Food can tell us a lot about a community. When you go to a different place, whether a different country or a different town, make sure to try the food!



When people think about Italian food they think about pasta and pizza. But did you know that the tomato was not part of Italian cooking until the 1700s? Tomatoes are from the Americas. European explorers brought tomatoes to Italy. Pasta and pizza sauce can teach us about European history.


Credit: jeffreyww via flickr


Pasta is noodle made by from flour, water, and eggs.


Ethiopia is a country in Eastern Africa. Explorers from Europe would stop in Ethiopia on their way to Asia. Europeans would unload their spices and send them north. This trade route brought tasty curries and spiced meats from South Asia to East Africa.


Credit: edsel_ via flickr


Injera is a spongy bread served with ethiopian food.


In some countries, geography influences what people eat. Norway, Denmark, and Sweden are countries in Scandinavia. In Scandinavia, many ingredients come from the sea. Scandinavian meals often include fish, oysters, and mussels.


Credit: freecat via flickr


Sardines are in both the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.


Corn is a crop from the Americas. In Central America and South America, people grow and eat a lot of corn! Pupusas are made from corn. The pupusa begins with a thick corn tortilla. The tortilla is filled with cheese, meat, or beans. Pupusas are served with a cabbage, chili and vinegar coleslaw on top.



Pupusas with spicy coleslaw and fried plantains.


In the Middle East, people grow stone fruit. Stone fruits include olives, pomegranates, figs, and dates. People in the Middle East also grow rice and wheat. In the Middle East, People will eat bread or rice with almost every meal.


Credit: usembassyta via flickr


A man picks olives near Tel Aviv, Israel.


Fast Food


Fast food restaurants are popular around the world. Fast food is quick and does not cost a lot of money.


Fast food comes in different shapes and sizes. Some fast food is sold at restaurants like McDonald’s. Other fast food comes from food trucks and street vendors.


Credit: shankaronline via flickr

A hawker in Southeast Asia sells fast and affordable meals.


In Southeast Asia, hawker markets sell fast food. A hawker is a vendor of inexpensive food. Hawkers sell food in a stall or vehicle parked along busy city streets. One favorite hawker dish is satay. Satay is a meat grilled and served in sauce. Other favorite hawker dishes include biryani, laksa, and char kway teow.


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

to cook

verb: to prepare food by combining ingredients

crop

noun: a plant that is grown for food

ethnic

adjective: belonging to a particular group or subgroup

restaurant

noun: a place where people pay for prepared food

route

noun: a way to get from one place to another


Meet Your PenPal!
body_two:
Food is a great ways to explore cultures and connect with people from around the world. For example, our comfort foods tell people who we are and where we’ve come from. If after a hard day you crave macaroni and cheese, fried chicken, and a piece of pie, you are probably from the Southern United States. If, alternatively, nothing sounds better than a tapas style dish called tortilla espanola, you might be from Spain.


Credit: benimoto via flickr


Apple Pie is so associated with culture in the United States that people use the expression “As American as Apple Pie.”


The food we enjoy can also reveal where we have traveled and what cultures have migrated to our communities. People from all over the world live in the United States. As a result, people in the United States can enjoy many different types of food. Food from China, India, Mexico, Italy and the Middle East are all part of the American diet!


What we choose to eat reflects our preferences, lifestyles, and experiences. Some people buy food from a grocery store while others buy their food from a farmers’ market. Other people do not have access to groceries stories and buy food from fast food restaurants. This week, as you explore foods from around the world, think about food in your community and what foods you might like to try!


A World of Food


Whether you travel to a country on the other side of the planet or to the next town over, make sure to stop for a bite to eat! The foods that you find in different communities tell us a lot about the people who live there.



For example, when many people think about Italian food they think about delicious pasta, pizza, meats, and cheeses. But did you know that the tomato wasn’t part of Italian cooking until the 18th century? Before European exploration, tomatoes only grew in the Americas. Tomato-based pasta and pizza sauces were not present in Italian cooking until the 1700s!


Credit: jeffreyww via flickr


Pasta is noodle made from flour, water, and eggs.


Like Italian food, trade and exploration influenced food in East Africa. Ethiopia is located on the Eastern coast of Africa. European traders sailed from South Asia to Europe in the 14th and 15th centuries. Europeans would stop at East African ports where South Asian spices were unloaded and sent North to the Mediterranean Sea. This trade route brought tasty curries and spiced meats from south Asia to East Africa.


Credit: edsel_ via flickr


Injera is a spongy bread served with ethiopian food.


In some nations, cuisine is less influenced by trade and exploration. Instead, the geography of the community has an impact on the cuisine.


In Scandinavian countries like Norway, Denmark, and Sweden, many ingredients come from the sea. Scandinavian meals often include fish, oysters and mussels. Root vegetables, berries, and grains are also common in Scandinavian cuisine. Unlike cuisine across South Asia and Africa, spices are missing from Scandinavian cuisine. Instead of spicy peppers, Scandinavian dishes include dill, mustard, and nutmeg.


Credit: freecat via flickr


Norway began exporting sardines in 1880.


Ukraine is a country located in Eastern Europe. Ukraine has some of the most fertile land in the world. In Ukraine, the topography is like the Midwestern United States. Ukrainian cuisine includes grains, fruits, and vegetables that grow across the country. Common vegetables featured in Ukrainian dishes include potatoes, cabbage, and beets. Borscht, a cabbage based soup, is popular not just in Ukraine, but in countries across the region.


In Central America and South America, corn is king! Pupusas are are one of many corn-based dishes enjoyed across the region. The pupusa begins with a thick, handmade corn tortilla. The tortilla is then filled with either cheese, cooked and seasoned meat, or refried beans. Pupusas are often served with a cabbage, chili and vinegar coleslaw on top.



Pupusas with spicy coleslaw and fried plantains.


Tamales are yet another corn based dish found across Latin America. Tamales are made from masa, a starchy corn based dough, that is then steamed inside a corn husk or leaf wrapper. Like the pupusa tamales can be stuffed with different of ingredients. From seasoned and cooked meats to beans and cheese, there is no shortage of tasty tamale fillings. If you try a tamale, make sure to remove the leaf wrapper before eating!



Tamales are steamed in a corn husk or leaf.


In Middle Eastern nations like Turkey and Lebanon people enjoy locally grown stone fruit. Stone fruits include olives, pomegranates, figs, and dates. Cereal crops such as rice and wheat also make up a large part of most Middle Eastern diet. People will eat bread or rice with almost every meal.


Credit: usembassyta via flickr


A man picks olives near Tel Aviv, Israel.


The Rise of Fast Food


Fast food restaurants are on the rise around the world. Fast food comes in different shapes and sizes. From large corporations like McDonald’s and Domino's to food trucks and street vendors, fast food allows people to eat quick and easy meals at affordable prices.



Across Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, and Riau Islands, one can find hawker markets. A hawker is a vendor of inexpensive food usually sold from a stall or vehicle parked along busy city streets. One favorite hawker dish is satay, a spiced skewered meat grilled and served in sauce. Other favorites include biryani, laksa, and char kway teow.


Credit: shankaronline via flickr


A hawker in Southeast Asia sells fast and affordable meals.


In Finland, residents enjoy Kotipizza, the largest pizza chain in Scandinavia. Goody’s is Greece’s most popular fast food chain with tens of thousands of visitors every day. South Africa has domestic fast food chains like Chicken Lickers and Nando’s.


Reflect on this week’s article and learn about the foods popular in your PenPals’ communities. What foods do you like to eat at home, school and in your community? What does the food the you eat say about you?


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

to crave

verb: to really want something

diet

noun: the foods that a person eats regularly

influence

verb: to have an effect on something

port

noun: a location where ships load and unload their cargo
body_three:
Food can be one of the best ways to explore cultures and connect with people from around the world. For example, our comfort foods reveal who we are and where we’ve come from. If after a hard day you were to treat yourself to macaroni and cheese, fried chicken, and a piece of pie, you might very well be from the Southern United States. If, alternatively, nothing sounds better than a tapas style dish called tortilla espanola, you might be from Spain.


Credit: benimoto via flickr


Apple Pie is so associated with culture in the United States that people use the expression “As American as Apple Pie.”


The food we enjoy can also reveal where we have traveled and what cultures have migrated to our communities. People from all over the world live in the United States. As a result, people in the United States can enjoy many different types of food. Food from China, India, Mexico, Italy and the Middle East are all part of the American diet!


Whether we purchase foods from a grocery store, farmers’ market, or a fast food restaurant, our eating habits reveal a lot about our culture and socio-economic status. This week, as you explore and learn about foods from around the world, reflect on the foods that are popular in your community, where you purchase the food that you eat, and what foods you might like to try!


A World of Food


Whether you travel to a country on the other side of the planet or to the next town over make sure to stop for a bite to eat! The foods that you find in different communities tell us a lot about the people who live there.



Many people associate Italian food with delicious pasta, pizza, meats, and cheeses. But did you know that the tomato wasn’t part of Italian cooking until the 18th century? Prior to European exploration, tomatoes only grew in the Americas. The classic tomato-based pasta and pizza sauces we know today were not present in Italian cooking until the 1700s!


Credit: jeffreyww via flickr


Pasta is noodle made by combining flour, water, and eggs.


Like Italian food, trade and cultural contact has also influenced food in the East African nation of Ethiopia. Ethiopia is located on the Eastern coast of Africa. As European traders sailed from South Asia to Europe, they would often stop at East African ports where South Asian spices were unloaded and sent along to the Mediterranean Sea and European nations to the north. This trade route is partially responsible for the tasty curries and spiced meats served across the region today.


Credit: edsel_ via flickr

Injera is a spongy bread served with ethiopian food.


Cuisine in other nations is less dependent on trade and exploration than on the geography of the community. In the Scandinavian countries of Norway, Denmark, Sweden and Finland, many ingredients come from the sea. Scandinavian meals often include fish, oysters and mussels. Root vegetables, berries, and grains are also common in Scandinavian cuisine. Unlike cuisine across South Asia and Africa, spices are noticeably missing from Scandinavian cuisine. Rather than spicy peppers, Northern European dishes often call for flavors like dill, mustard, and nutmeg.


Credit: freecat via flickr


Norway began exporting sardines in 1880.


Ukraine, located in Eastern Europe, has some of the most fertile land in the world and is similar in topography to the Midwestern United States. Ukrainian cuisine includes grains, fruits, and vegetables that grow across the country. Common vegetables featured in Ukrainian dishes include potatoes, cabbage, and beets. Borscht, a cabbage based soup, is popular not just in Ukraine, but in countries across the region.



Pupusas with spicy coleslaw and fried plantains.


In Central America and South America, corn is king! Pupusas are are one of many corn-based dishes enjoyed across the region. The pupusa begins with a thick, handmade corn tortilla. The tortilla is then filled with either cheese, cooked and seasoned meat, or refried beans. Pupusas are often served with a cabbage, chili and vinegar coleslaw on top.



Tamales are yet another corn based dish found across Latin America. Tamales are made from masa, a starchy corn based dough, that is then steamed inside a corn husk or leaf wrapper. Like the pupusa, tamales can be stuffed with a variety of ingredients. From seasoned and cooked meats to beans and cheese, there is no shortage of tasty tamale fillings. If you try a tamale, make sure to remove the leaf wrapper before eating!



Tamales are steamed in a corn husk or leaf.


Turkey, Lebanon, and other Middle Eastern nations are known for stone fruits like olives, pomegranates, figs, and dates. Cereal crops such as rice and wheat also make up a large part of most Middle Eastern diet. People in the Middle East will eat bread or rice with almost every meal. Since the teachings of Islam prohibit eating pork, other meats such as lamb and mutton are commonly eaten.


Credit: usembassyta via flickr

A man picks olives near Tel Aviv, Israel.


The Rise of Fast Food


Fast food culture is on the rise around the world. From the United States to Northern Europe and the South Pacific, fast food comes in many shapes and sizes. From multinational corporations like McDonald’s and Domino's to less formal food trucks and street vendors, fast food allows people to eat quick and convenient meals at affordable prices. But is the rise of fast food a good thing for our health and for our planet?


Fast foods tend to have more fat, sugar, and salt than freshly prepared food. This means that when eating fast food, people are more at risk of weight gain and chronic disease.


Many of the foods served in fast food restaurants come from large factory farms that produce tremendous quantities of food at all hours of the day. The waste and environmental impact of these types of farming operations can be detrimental to the environment and communities where they are located.


But while there are many reasons people may choose to avoid fast food, these quick and convenient establishments are popping up all over the world. McDonald’s, Kentucky Fried Chicken (KFC) and Pizza Hut are US restaurant chains with locations around the globe.



Across Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, and Riau Islands, one can find hawker markets. A hawker is a vendor of inexpensive food usually sold from a stall or vehicle parked along busy city streets. One favorite hawker dish is satay, a skewered meat that is then grilled and served in sauce. Other favorite hawker dishes include biryani, laksa, and char kway teow.


Credit: shankaronline via flickr


A hawker in Southeast Asia sells fast and affordable meals.


In Finland, residents enjoy Kotipizza, the largest pizza chain in Scandinavia. Goody’s is Greece’s most popular fast food chain with tens of thousands of visitors every day. South Africa has domestic fast food chains like Chicken Lickers and Nando’s.


As you reflect on this week’s topic and learn about the foods popular in your PenPals’ communities, reflect on the foods that you like to eat at home, school and in your community. What does the food the you eat say about you?


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

convenient

adjective: characteristic of something that required little effort or trouble

fertile

adjective: capable of producing an abundance of crops

port

noun: a location where ships load and unload their cargo

title: Compare Your Culture with that of Your PenPal
Introduction to Argument Writing
body_one:
Understanding how to craft a piece of argument writing is an important skill. During this course, you and your pen pal will learn about what makes an effective piece of argument writing. You will learn how to make a claim and support that claim through clear reasons and evidence. You will learn how writers use evidence to support a claim as you write a piece of argument writing. You will work with your pen pal to identify credible sources. And you will craft your own argument paragraph!


Lesson Objectives:

  • Watch a short video about argument writing and working with pen pals

  • Meet your pen pal

  • Explore the differences between opinions and claims

  • Identify strengths and weaknesses in argument writing samples



Many people like to argue! In fact, over 40% of young people say that arguments happen around them every day. So, what is an argument? What are people arguing about? Who are they arguing with? And how are spoken arguments similar to argument writing?


Over the next seven weeks, you and your pen pal will explore what it takes to craft an argument. You will discover that an argument is more than just countering that “something isn’t so.” In fact, the goal of an argument has surprisingly little to do with the people arguing.


Believe it or not, the goal of an argument is all about convincing your audience. When two individuals argue, they try to use reasons to support their claim. If those reasons are strong and convincing, then the audience is more likely to listen and agree! Convince your audience and win the argument!


So let’s take a look at arguments. Let’s think about arguments you’ve had at school or at home. You and your pen pal will work together to explore what made these arguments effective or ineffective.


Let’s take a look at an argument between two students:



Complete the Questions for Part 1 before moving on to Part 2!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)



Have you ever heard someone say something in an argument or debate that you just didn’t think was true? That person likely used an opinion rather than a claim.


In this section, you and your pen pal will learn about opinions and claims. First you will explore these two different ideas. Then you will work together to distinguish opinions from claims!


Understanding the difference between an opinion and a claim is one of the key pieces to making an effective argument. An opinion tells how someone feels about a topic or an issue, and may not be supported by evidence. A claim is a position someone takes on an issue or topic and is important to making an effective argument. Unlike an opinion, in argument writing, a claim is supported by facts and evidence.


Let’s look at some examples!


Claim: Starting School later would improve academic success.


This is claim because it explains why starting school later is a good idea.


Opinion: School starts too early.


This is an opinion because it does not explain why the writer thinks school starts too early.


Supporting claims with EITHER-OR:


Sometimes, identifying opinions and claims can be pretty tough. Luckily, there is a trick! The words EITHER and OR can be used as a mnemonic device to remember strategies for supporting claims. Each letter in EITHER-OR stands for one way that claims can be supported. Use the chart below to better understand these eight ways to support the following claim: all rock climbers should wear helmets.



Complete the Questions for Part 2 before moving on to Part 3!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)



Now, that you have learned to identify opinions and claims, let’s take a look at some examples of argument writing. Effective writing has many common characteristics. These characteristics can be grouped into organization, ideas and content, language/style, and conventions.


Directions: Review the checklist below. Then read the two sample paragraphs. Use the checklist to evaluate both argument paragraphs. If you are unsure about one of the items on the checklist, ask your pen pal for help! Once you have finished evaluating your paragraph, talk with your pen pal about his or her evaluation.


Traits of Effective Argument Writing


Traits of Effective

Argument Writing

 Yes or No?

Organization

Introduction states claim.


Reasons and evidence are organized logically.


Conclusion supports claim.


Ideas and Content

Reasons are sufficient, relevant, and based on facts.


Sources used are accurate/credible.  


Opposing claim is addressed.


Language/Style

Sentences are complete and interesting.


Wording is clear and precise.


A formal style is maintained.


Conventions (CUPS)

Capitalization correct


Usage (grammar) correct


Punctuation correct


Spelling correct




Paragraph 1:


Should We Send Astronauts to Mars?


       Some people think astronauts should fly to Mars and explore the planet, but I think this is a bad idea. First, the astronauts will be exposed to a lot of radiation and other dangers; if something happens, they will be too far away for anyone to rescue them. Second, a Mars mission would be very expensive, and we have a lot of problems here on Earth which will take money to fix. Third, sending robot probes, like we are already doing, is less expensive and safer. That is why I think a human mission to Mars is foolish.


Paragraph 2:


Should We Send Astronauts to Mars?


       Space exploration is exciting, and many people hope that humans will soon set foot on Mars. However, there are multiple reasons why we should reconsider this goal. A round-trip voyage to Mars will be long and difficult. Space flight experts estimate it would take 400-450 days; compare that with the Apollo moon-landing missions that took a little more than a week. On such a long mission, the astronauts would be exposed to cosmic rays that could sicken or kill them; and if something did go wrong, any kind of rescue would be impossible. Then there is the question of cost. Some analysts estimate a single mission could cost as much as $450 billion. When we have so much poverty and other problems here on Earth, spending that much for a single space missions seem irresponsible. Some scientists argue that landing astronauts on Mars is an important step for science. Many view this landing as a way to establish human colonies beyond earth. Instead, we can continue to explore the Red Planet in other ways and wait until the benefits outway the costs. In fact, we are already exploring Mars with robotic space probes like the Curiosity rover and the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter. We can send fleets of these probes to orbit and land on Mars for a fraction of the cost of a manned mission without risking human lives. The capability of these robots are proving quickly and may soon be a match for human exploration. A human mission to Mars would capture the world’s imagination, but there are cheaper and safer ways to explore our solar system.


Complete the questions located at the bottom of this page! After answering each of your questions, read and respond to your pen pal’s answers!



Word

Definition

argument writing

(noun) a type of writing that makes a claim and supports it with evidence, examples, and explanation

audience

(noun) the target group of people for a text

claim

(noun) a position a writer takes on a particular issue. A claim is supported by factual evidence

evidence

(noun) factual information used to support a claim

logical

(adj) having the characteristics of a clear and well sequenced thought

opinion

(noun) a personal view held by an individual on a particular subject that could be debated

state

(verb) to say or write something in a clear and concise way

usage

(noun) using language correctly

In this section, you and your pen pal will learn about opinions and claims. First you will explore these two different ideas. Then you will work together to distinguish opinions from claims!


Understanding the difference between an opinion and a claim is one of the key pieces to making an effective argument. An opinion tells how someone feels about a topic or an issue, and may not be supported by evidence. A claim is a position someone takes on an issue or topic and is important to making an effective argument. Unlike an opinion, in argument writing, a claim is supported by facts and evidence.


Let’s look at some examples!


Claim: Starting School later would improve academic success.


This is claim because it explains why starting school later is a good idea.


Opinion: School starts too early.


This is an opinion because it does not explain why the writer thinks school starts too early.


Supporting claims with EITHER-OR:


Sometimes, identifying opinions and claims can be pretty tough. Luckily, there is a trick! The words EITHER and OR can be used as a mnemonic device to remember strategies for supporting claims. Each letter in EITHER-OR stands for one way that claims can be supported. Use the chart below to better understand these eight ways to support the following claim: all rock climbers should wear helmets.



Complete the Questions for Part 2 before moving on to Part 3!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)



Now, that you have learned to identify opinions and claims, let’s take a look at some examples of argument writing. Effective writing has many common characteristics. These characteristics can be grouped into organization, ideas and content, language/style, and conventions.


Directions: Review the checklist below. Then read the two sample paragraphs. Use the checklist to evaluate both argument paragraphs. If you are unsure about one of the items on the checklist, ask your pen pal for help! Once you have finished evaluating your paragraph, talk with your pen pal about his or her evaluation.


Traits of Effective Argument Writing


Traits of Effective

Argument Writing

 Yes or No?

Organization

Introduction states claim.


Reasons and evidence are organized logically.


Conclusion supports claim.


Ideas and Content

Reasons are sufficient, relevant, and based on facts.


Sources used are accurate/credible.  


Opposing claim is addressed.


Language/Style

Sentences are complete and interesting.


Wording is clear and precise.


A formal style is maintained.


Conventions (CUPS)

Capitalization correct


Usage (grammar) correct


Punctuation correct


Spelling correct




Paragraph 1:


Should We Send Astronauts to Mars?


       Some people think astronauts should fly to Mars and explore the planet, but I think this is a bad idea. First, the astronauts will be exposed to a lot of radiation and other dangers; if something happens, they will be too far away for anyone to rescue them. Second, a Mars mission would be very expensive, and we have a lot of problems here on Earth which will take money to fix. Third, sending robot probes, like we are already doing, is less expensive and safer. That is why I think a human mission to Mars is foolish.


Paragraph 2:


Should We Send Astronauts to Mars?


       Space exploration is exciting, and many people hope that humans will soon set foot on Mars. However, there are multiple reasons why we should reconsider this goal. A round-trip voyage to Mars will be long and difficult. Space flight experts estimate it would take 400-450 days; compare that with the Apollo moon-landing missions that took a little more than a week. On such a long mission, the astronauts would be exposed to cosmic rays that could sicken or kill them; and if something did go wrong, any kind of rescue would be impossible. Then there is the question of cost. Some analysts estimate a single mission could cost as much as $450 billion. When we have so much poverty and other problems here on Earth, spending that much for a single space missions seem irresponsible. Some scientists argue that landing astronauts on Mars is an important step for science. Many view this landing as a way to establish human colonies beyond earth. Instead, we can continue to explore the Red Planet in other ways and wait until the benefits outway the costs. In fact, we are already exploring Mars with robotic space probes like the Curiosity rover and the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter. We can send fleets of these probes to orbit and land on Mars for a fraction of the cost of a manned mission without risking human lives. The capability of these robots are proving quickly and may soon be a match for human exploration. A human mission to Mars would capture the world’s imagination, but there are cheaper and safer ways to explore our solar system.


Complete the questions located at the bottom of this page! After answering each of your questions, read and respond to your pen pal’s answers!



Word

Definition

argument writing

(noun) a type of writing that makes a claim and supports it with evidence, examples, and explanation

audience

(noun) the target group of people for a text

claim

(noun) a position a writer takes on a particular issue. A claim is supported by factual evidence

evidence

(noun) factual information used to support a claim

logical

(adj) having the characteristics of a clear and well sequenced thought

opinion

(noun) a personal view held by an individual on a particular subject that could be debated

state

(verb) to say or write something in a clear and concise way

usage

(noun) using language correctly

title: Colorful Foods Around the World
body_one:
Part 1: Meet Your PenPal


What are your favorite foods? What do your friends and family like to eat? Do people in your community all like the same things?


Daily diets vary considerably around the world! With many supermarkets, farmers markets and personal gardens, most people have access to a variety of fruits, vegetables, and ingredients from all over the world.


Over the next six weeks, you and your pen pal will work together to study the foods we eat. Each week, you will explore a different theme. After watching an exciting video, you will explore a different (and often times mouth-watering) topic! Answer each week’s questions to get the conversation started and check back often to see what your pen pal has to say.


Have fun learning with your pen pal! Ask questions. Share stories. And most importantly, HAVE FUN!



Part 2: A Rainbow of Color


Tomatoes are red. Berries are blue. Taro is white and purple too!


Did you know that people around the world eat colorful foods? Red apples grow in countries all around the world. The first apples were native to Central Asia. Juicy, round, and brightly colored, berries are also eaten worldwide! Many people eat berries by themselves while other prefer perries in jellies, jams, cakes, and pies. Taro is a vegetable native to Southern India and SouthEast Asia! Both the purple and white varieties of taro contain an abundance of vitamins and minerals!



It’s important that we eat a variety of fruits and vegetables to support a healthy body. Each color on our plate gives us important vitamins and nutrients to support our health. Eating healthy is simple when you know what the colors of vegetables indicate about their nutritional value.



Red and orange fruits and vegetables contain lots of vitamin C. Green foods like peas, collard greens, and lima beans, are great sources of iron. The blue compound that makes blueberries blue is a powerful antioxidant called anthocyanin that may protect against cancer and heart disease.


A food diary is a great way to observe the colorful foods you eat. It’s also a great way to share the foods you eat with your pen pal! Use the Food Diary below to record the different kinds of food you eat this week.



Part 3: Recipe of the Week


When we put these healthy and colorful foods together, the result is a tasty and nutritious dish! A recipe is a set of instructions that help you prepare a particular dish. A great recipe will share the ingredients, give step by step instructions, and even provide nutritional information.


What colorful recipes do people love to prepare in your community? Take a look at one of our favorites below! A Caprese Salad is a colorful dish full of flavor and nutrition. This salad is easy to prepare and sure to please the taste buds!
