title: Immigration
body_one:
More immigrants are coming to the United States than ever before.


The United States is a nation of immigrants. Immigration may be one of America’s oldest public issues. In 1620, a group of 100 people called Pilgrims came to the land that would become the United States. The Pilgrims came to escape religious persecution.  


Credit: Chris via Flickr


Immigrants arriving at Ellis Island in 1922


Since the Pilgrims, many groups of immigrants have come to the United States. As the United States grew, more immigrants made the trip to live in America.  


Who is Coming To America?


There are two groups at the center of the immigration debate: legal immigrants and illegal immigrants.


Immigrants enter the country legally for many reasons. Some legal immigrants enter the United States to be with family members. Other legal immigrants come to escape fighting in their home country.


A lottery system is used to choose which immigrants can come to the United States.


In 2014, Abdi Nor, a refugee from Somalia, got lucky. He won a lottery that allowed him to come to the United States.


“When I realized I won.” said Abdi, “I walked out with my friends all shouting, holding my hands, and shaking me. My heart was bumping.”


Abdi’s was excited because he loved America. His friends even gave him the nickname “Abdi the American” because he spent so much time practicing English and studying American movies.


Source: afrikareporter.com


A citizen from a foreign country must obtain a visa before they may enter the United States.


Abdi’s story is different from many other immigrants who come to the United States. Many people enter the country illegally. Some illegal immigrants come to the United States by land, boat, or plane, while others stay after their visas expire.


Benefits and Costs to Immigration


Immigrants do many great things for the United States. For example, immigrants often start new businesses. Immigrants helped start Yahoo!, Google and eBay. Immigrants help enrich food, clothing, and American art.


Other experts think that immigration is not good for the economy.  Sometimes the government has to support immigrants. The government might pay to help immigrants find a house and get an education.


Immigration and the Election


Some politicians are worried that terrorists and criminals might come to the United States as immigrants. These politicians think that making it harder for immigrants to come to the United States would make the United States a safer place.


These politicians want to make laws more strict. They want to give more resources to law-enforcement. They also think that sending immigrants back to their home country might also stop immigrants from coming to the United States.


Other politicians fear that harder laws might lead to discrimination.


Most immigrants come to the United States because they are looking for a better life.


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

illegal

verb: something that is prohibited by law

discrimination

noun:  treating someone unfairly based on race, religion, or political beliefs

immigrant

noun: a person who comes from a foreign country to live in a new country

legal

verb: something that is permitted by law

refugee

noun: a person who was forced to leave his or her country to escape violence or war

persecution

verb: hostility towards people based on race, religion, or political beliefs

Sources :

http://www.publicagenda.org/pages/csg-immigration

http://www.history.com/topics/u-s-immigration-before-1965

http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/560/transcript

https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/mark-zuckerberg-immigrants-are-the-key-to-a-knowledge-economy/2013/04/10/aba05554-a20b-11e2-82bc-511538ae90a4_story.html
body_two:
More immigrants are coming to the United States than at any point in its history.


The United States of America has always been a nation of immigrants. As a result, Immigration may be one of America’s oldest public issues. In 1620, long before the United States was a country, a group of 100 people called Pilgrims came to the land that would become the United States to escape religious persecution. These pilgrims established a colony in current day Massachusetts.


Credit: Chris via Flickr


Immigrants arriving at Ellis Island in 1922


Since the Pilgrims, many groups of immigrants have come to the United States. These people come to find jobs and economic opportunities.  


As the United States grew, more immigrants made the trip to live in America. In the years 1880 and 1920, the United States received more than 20 million immigrants from eastern, central and southern Europe.


Who is Coming To America?


When we talk about immigration, we need to recognize that there are at least two sub-groups within the immigrant population - legal immigrants and illegal immigrants.


Immigrants enter the country legally for many reasons. A large number of legal immigrants enter the United States to reunite with family members. Other immigrants enter as refugees escaping conflict in their home country.


A common theme across the many types of people who immigrate to the United States is a desire to experience American culture. An international lottery system is in place for immigrants seeking citizenship, temporary work, or student visas.


On April 17th, 2014, Abdi Nor, a Somali refugee living in Kenya, got the luckiest break of his life when he won a lottery that put him on a short list for a visa.


“When I realized I won.” said Abdi, “I walked out with these friends all shouting behind me, in front of me, holding my hands, shaking me. My heart was bumping.”


Source: afrikareporter.com


A citizen from a foreign country must obtain a visa before they may enter the United States.


Abdi’s excitement came from a love for American culture. His friends even gave him the nickname “Abdi the American” because he spent so much time practicing English and studying American news and movies.


Abdi’s story is different from many other immigrants who come to the United States. Almost 11.5 million people have entered the country illegally or stayed longer than they were legally allowed. People illegally immigrate to the United States in many different ways. Some cross the United States border by land, boat, or plane, while others overstay temporary visas


Illegal immigrants come from various backgrounds. Because of their illegal status, many illegal immigrants tend to work jobs that other people do not want. Some undocumented immigrants make the journey to escape poverty. Others flee from war and conflict. And others just want to see family who immigrated to the United States long ago.


Benefits and Costs to Immigration


Immigrants do many great things for the United States. For example, immigrants are more likely than native-born Americans to start a new business. Immigrants helped start companies like Yahoo!, Google and eBay.


Many experts think that immigration is not good for the economy. The government must sometimes support immigrants by paying for housing and education. States like like California and Texas have large immigrant populations and often pay more to support these communities.


Immigration and the Election


Some politicians worry that terrorists and criminals might take advantage of easy access to the United States. These politicians think that more strict immigration policies may make the US a safer place. They want to strengthening current laws and enhance law-enforcement. Improving these systems might stop immigrants from entering the United States illegally. They also think that deporting immigrants could also slow or stop immigrant groups from wanting to come to the United States.


Other politicians fear that stricter immigration requirements could lead to racial profiling. They believe amnesty should be given to certain groups of illegal immigrants, allowing them to stay and work in the United States indefinitely.


The vast majority of immigrants enter the United States to improve their lives. They see America as a land of opportunity, and endure dangerous journeys to be here.  


So where do you stand on immigration?  What role should both local and federal government play in managing the millions of immigrants, US citizens, and the families affected by this complex issue?


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

amnesty

noun: an official pardon given to someone who breaks the law

deport

verb: expel or send away from a country

illegal

verb: something that is prohibited by law

persecution

verb: hostility towards people based on race, religion, or political beliefs

refugee

noun: a person who has been forced to leave his or her country because of war and conflict

Sources:

http://www.publicagenda.org/pages/csg-immigration

http://www.history.com/topics/u-s-immigration-before-1965

http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/560/transcript

https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/mark-zuckerberg-immigrants-are-the-key-to-a-knowledge-economy/2013/04/10/aba05554-a20b-11e2-82bc-511538ae90a4_story.html
body_three:
From its earliest days, America has been a nation of immigrants. As a result, immigration may be one of America’s oldest public issues.  In 1620, long before the United States was a country, a group of roughly 100 people known as the Pilgrims fled religious persecution in Europe and arrived at present-day Plymouth, Massachusetts.


Since the Pilgrims, many groups of immigrants have come to the United States seeking jobs and economic opportunities. As the nation developed, more immigrants made the trip to live in America. During times of rapid industrialization and urbanization more immigrants tend to arrive in the United States. For example, from 1880 to 1920, the United States received more than 20 million immigrants from eastern, central and southern Europe. These workers contributed to a booming economy through work across industries.


Credit: Chris via Flickr


Immigrants arriving at Ellis Island in 1922


Today, the United States is experiencing one of the biggest waves of immigration in its history.  While most Americans think that welcoming immigrants is a good thing, this particular wave is creating a debate over how the United States should handle immigration in the years to come.


Who is Coming To America?


When we talk about immigration, we need to recognize that there are at least two sub-groups within the immigrant population - legal immigrants and illegal immigrants.


Immigrants enter the country legally for a variety of reasons. A large percent of legal immigrants enter the United States to reunite with family members. Other immigrants enter as political refugees escaping conflict in their home country. United States businesses will also sponsor immigrants who have valuable skills not commonly found in the United States.  


An international lottery system is in place for immigrants seeking citizenship, temporary work, or student visas. On April 17th, 2014, Abdi Nor, a Somali refugee living in Kenya, got the luckiest break of  his life when he won a lottery that put him on a short list for a visa.


“When I realized I won.” said Abdi, “I walked out with these friends all shouting behind me, in front of me, holding my hands, shaking me. My heart was bumping.”


For immigrants like Abdi, securing an American visa is normally the first step to entering the United States and becoming a citizen. Abdi’s excitement came from a love for American culture. His friends even gave him the nickname “Abdi the American” because he spent so much time practicing English and studying American news and movies.


Source: afrikareporter.com


A citizen from a foreign country must obtain a visa before they may enter the United States.


Abdi’s experience is not characteristic of many other immigrants who come to the United States.


Approximately 11.5 million individuals have either entered the country illegally or overstayed legal temporary visas. This illegal immigration is accomplished in various ways including crossing the US border by land, boat, or plane, or by overstaying temporary visas


Illegal immigrants come from various backgrounds and have various motives for entering the United States. Because of their immigration status and lack of official documentation, most illegal immigrants tend to work in jobs that others do not want. These jobs often require minimal education and formal training.


Many illegal immigrants come to the United states for the same reason immigrants come legally. Some make the journey in order to escape poverty in their home country. Others flee war and conflict, and even others simply want to reconnect with family who immigrated to the United States long ago.


Benefits and Costs to Immigration


Immigrants provide a number of benefits to the economy and American culture. For example, immigrants are 30 percent more likely than native-born Americans to form a new business.  Immigrants are also three times more likely to file a patent. High-skilled immigrants helped launch Yahoo!, Google and eBay. In fact, in 1997, the National Research Council found that immigrants add up to $10 billion to the economy every year!  


While many experts argue that immigration is a boon to the economy, others argue to the contrary. Both state and federal government must incur costs for housing and education as they help new immigrants establish themselves in the United States. These budgetary costs are not equal across states and local governments. Some states with concentrated high immigration, such as the US-Mexico border states of California, New Mexico, Arizona and Texas bear a heavier economic burden than others.


Immigration and the Election


Some politicians believe our current immigration system should raise some questions about national security. They worry that terrorists and criminals might take advantage of easy access to the United States. These politicians believe that a more strict immigration policy may make the United States a safer place.


These politicians believe that strengthening current laws and enhancing law-enforcement might dissuade migrants from attempting to enter the United States illegally. Others think that  deporting immigrants who are currently residing illegally in the United States could be an effective deterrent to malicious immigrant groups.


Other politicians are concerned that an overemphasis on immigration and stricter immigration requirements could lead to racial profiling; profiling that may take away people’s civil liberties. This group of politicians believe that amnesty should be given to certain groups of illegal immigrants allowing them to stay and work in the United States indefinitely.


The vast majority of immigrant enter the United States to improve their lives. They see America as a land of opportunity, and endure dangerous journeys to get here.  


So where do you stand on immigration? What role should both local and federal government play in managing the millions of immigrants, US citizens, and families affected by this complex issue?  


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

amnesty

noun: an official pardon given to someone who breaks the law

boon

noun: a thing that is helpful and beneficial

persecution

verb: hostility towards people based on race, religion, or political beliefs

Sources:

http://www.publicagenda.org/pages/csg-immigration

http://www.history.com/topics/u-s-immigration-before-1965

http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/560/transcript

https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/mark-zuckerberg-immigrants-are-the-key-to-a-knowledge-economy/2013/04/10/aba05554-a20b-11e2-82bc-511538ae90a4_story.html

title: History
body_one:
Credit: ideonexus via flickr


Australopithecus is an extinct ancestor of humans.


Humans began farming 10,000 years ago. Humans began to farm crops and herd animals in the Fertile Crescent. Rivers made the Fertile Crescent a good place for farming. Farming allowed humans to build permanent villages.




A map of the Fertile Crescent.


The Ancient Egyptians were a civilization in the Fertile Crescent. Thanks to the waters of the Nile River, Ancient Egyptians were able to farm crops. The Egyptians were one of the first civilizations to use farming tools like the plow.


The Egyptians made buildings, statues, and roads. The Egyptians also had a written language, calendars, the sundial, and ships.

Credit: arch_sam via flickr


The great Pyramids of Giza and the Sphinx were built in 2500 BCE.


From 11th through 15th Centuries CE a civilization grew in South Africa. More than 18,000 people lived in the Kingdom of Zimbabwe. Skilled builders used local granite to build large buildings and walls in the Kingdom’s capital.

Credit: rosshuggett via flickr


Great Zimbabwe was a palace complex for local monarchs.


The environment helped the Kingdom of Great Zimbabwe grow. Access to granite and rich farming soil supported the cities of Great Zimbabwe.


But a change in climate made it hard for people in Great Zimbabwe to farm. Today, people can move food around the world to help those in need. When the climate changed in the 15th Century CE, it became hard to grow food. Without access to food, the Kingdom of Zimbabwe could not feed its people and the Kingdom came to an end.



In Oceania, the Pacific Ocean shaped early civilizations. Southeast Asian sailors explored the South Pacific. These explorers traveled from one island to another. These explorers used canoes to explore the thousands of islands in the region.


Citation: london via flickr


An outrigger canoe like the ones used by early Oceanic explorers.


The Maori are an indigenous group of people who live in East Polynesia. The Maori traveled across the islands of Oceania. The Maori made their home on the islands of New Zealand in the 13th century. The Maori had an impact on the environment in New Zealand. The Maori cut down forests and cleared land for farming.


Credit: kcmmc via flickr


365-day calendars were used by civilizations in Mesoamerica.


Between 2,000 and 300 BCE, the Olmec, Maya, and Toltec built cities. The Olmec, Maya, and Toltec lived in the Western Hemisphere. They built cities between North and South America. They shared tools and resources with other communities.


The Olmec, Maya, and Toltec lived in the land that is today called Central America. People moved between South and North America through Central America. As people moved across this route, they shared ideas and  inventions.


Making Law and Order


History is made every day. When people invent things they make history. Many important inventions influence life today.


Credit: cvalette via flickr


Hammurabi's Code was one of the first set of laws ever made.


Hammurabi was a Babylonian king. Hammurabi lived in ancient Mesopotamia. Hammurabi made one the first list of laws. The laws had guidelines for behavior and punishments. We know some of Hammurabi's rules today. One of his rules said “an eye for an eye.” Hammurabi wrote 282 laws. He wrote his rules in a language called cuneiform. The laws are carved into a 7 foot tall stele. Today, the stele can be seen in the Louvre museum in Paris, France.


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

crop

noun: a plant that is grown for food

law

noun: a rule made by a government or community

indigenous

adjective: being naturally from a place; originating in a place

to invent

verb: to make something new

permanent

adjective: a thing that will last for a long time


Meet Your PenPal
body_two:
Credit: ideonexus via flickr


Australopithecus is an extinct ancestor of humans.


Humans began farming and herding around 10,000 years ago. Humans began to farm crops and herd animals in the Fertile Crescent. Rivers and nourishing soil made the Fertile Crescent a perfect place for farming. Farming allowed humans to quit their nomadic lifestyle and settle into permanent villages. The earliest civilizations in human history emerged in the Fertile Crescent.




A map of the Fertile Crescent.


The Ancient Egyptians were a civilization in the Fertile Crescent. Thanks to the nourishing waters of the Nile River, Ancient Egyptians were able to farm crops. In fact, the Egyptians were among the first civilizations to use farming tools like the plow.


Having a reliable food source allowed the Egyptians to create cities. During the Egyptian dynasties, pharaohs built massive buildings, statues, and infrastructure projects. The Egyptians also created a written language, calendars, the sundial, and  ships.

Credit: arch_sam via flickr


The great Pyramids of Giza and the Sphinx were built in 2500 BCE.


Located in the South African nation of Zimbabwe, from 11th through 15th Centuries CE, the Kingdom of Zimbabwe flourished. More than 18,000 people lived in the Kingdom of Zimbabwe. Skilled builders and craftsmen used local granite to build large buildings and walls in the Kingdom’s capital.

Credit: rosshuggett via flickr


Great Zimbabwe is believed to have been a palace complex for local monarchs.


The environment helped the Kingdom of Great Zimbabwe flourish. Access to granite and rich soil supported the cities of Great Zimbabwe. But an eventual climate change created farming challenges. Today, people can move food around the world to help those in need. When the climate changed in the 15th Century CE, it became hard to grow food. Without access to food, the Kingdom of Zimbabwe could not feed its people and the Kingdom came to an end.


Across the world in Oceania, the Pacific Ocean shaped early civilizations. Polynesian culture developed as Southeast Asian sailors explored the South Pacific. These explorers traveling from one island to the another. Early Polynesian peoples developed canoes and navigation techniques that allowed them to explore the thousands of islands in the region.



Citation: london via flickr


An outrigger canoe similar to those used by early Oceanic explorers.


The Maori are an indigenous group of people native to East Polynesia. The Maori traveled across the islands of Oceania and found their way to the islands of New Zealand in the 13th century CE. The Maori had an impact on the environment in New Zealand. The Maori cut down forests largely through controlled fires and cleared land for agriculture.


Credit: kcmmc via flickr


365-day calendars like the one above were used by the Aztecs and other pre-columbian civilizations across Mesoamerica.


Between 2,000 and 300 BCE, the Olmec, Maya, and Toltec built complex cities in the Western Hemisphere. They built their cities along a trading route between North and South America. Mesoamerican civilizations developed  agricultural tools, studied astronomy, and created a unique system of writing.


Thanks to the location on and around the land that is today known as Central America, these indigenous peoples had contact with traders and travellers moving between South and North America. As people moved across Mesoamerica they shared language, architecture,and inventions.


Democracy and Independence


The 15th to 18th Centuries CE are often called the Age of Discovery. During this time, explorers from European nations traveled around the world. European monarchs supported these explorers and began to claim the lands and territories. The British, French, Dutch, and Portuguese monarchies all claimed regions of the world. These nations used both peaceful and military tactics to control their new territories.



Europeans spread disease and war across indigenous communities. Disease and violence caused a decline in population. The Portuguese had colonies in current day Brazil. The Spanish had colonies in many of the other nations across the Western Hemisphere.



A map of Colonial Africa.


In 1776 CE, American colonists were unhappy with their status as colonies under English rule. The Founding Fathers led the American Patriots to victory in the Revolutionary War. With a victory in 1783, the United States became an independent country. American leaders created a democracy. In a democracy, instead of obeying a King, people vote for laws and leaders. George Washington was elected as the first President of the United States in 1788-9.


Following the example of countries like the United States and France, many revolutions began in Latin America. From 1819-1831 Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador, Panama, and Peru became independent countries. Mexico became an independent nation following the war for Mexican independence in 1821. Brazil signed its formal independence from Portugal in 1825.



A map of Gran Colombia before it was divided in 1931.


The countries across the Caribbean did not achieve independence until much later. Both the United States and European powers wanted control over these smaller territories.


The 20th century experienced a series of wars and unrest across Latin America. Colonial leaders and political elite did not support the indigenous populations and lower-income families. As a result, long conflicts occurred from Central America through South America.


European nations colonized much of South and Southeast Asia through the 19th and 20th centuries. The French colonized Vietnam, Cambodia, and Laos. The British colonized countries like Malaysia, India, Pakistan, and Myanmar. After World War II nearly all of the South and Southeast Asian nations gained their independence.



The Invention of Law


History is made every day by brilliant individuals all around the world. Many important inventions influence life today.


Credit: cvalette via flickr


Hammurabi's Code was one of the first codified legal systems ever created.


Hammurabi was a Babylonian king in ancient Mesopotamia. Hammurabi outlined one of the first known legal codes in human history. The laws established guidelines for behavior and corresponding punishments. Some of the rules are still well known today, such as “an eye for an eye”. The 282 laws of Hammurabi’s Code were written using a writing system called cuneiform and carved into a 7 foot tall stele. Today, the stele can be seen in the Louvre museum in Paris, France.


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

colony

noun: a territory under control of a distant leader or government

dynasty

noun: a line of  people from the same family who rule a country or community

indigenous

adjective: being naturally from a place; originating in a place

infrastructure

noun: systems needed to build a city

monarch

noun: a head of state such as a kind, queen, or emperor

nomad

noun: people who have no permanent land and travel from place to place, usually following animals
body_three:
Credit: ideonexus via flickr


Australopithecus, an extinct ancestor of humans, evolved in Africa over 2 million years ago.


Humans first began farming and herding in the Fertile Crescent around 8,000 BCE, or approximately 10,000 years ago. This change from hunting and gathering allowed humans to quit their nomadic lifestyle and settle into permanent villages. Some of the earliest civilizations in human history, notably the Ancient Egyptians, Sumerians, and Babylonians, emerged in the Fertile Crescent.



A map of the Fertile Crescent.


The history of people is often related to the environment and geography of their community. Thanks to its proximity to the nourishing waters of the Nile River, Ancient Egyptians were able to create and sustain a sophisticated culture for thousands of years.


Ancient Egyptians had a complex written language, built sophisticated ships, and were among the first civilizations to use farming tools like the plow. Egyptians used these tools to cultivate the banks of the Nile River which flooded annually and deposited rich soil for farming. During the various Egyptian dynasties, pharaohs constructed massive buildings, statues, and infrastructure like roads and markets.


Credit: arch_sam via flickr


The great Pyramids of Giza and the Sphinx were built in 2500 BC.


Located in the South African nation of Zimbabwe. From 11th through 15th Centuries CE, the Kingdom of Zimbabwe flourished and sustained as many as 18,000 people! Skilled stone masons and craftsmen took advantage of an abundance of local granite to construct large buildings and walls in the Kingdom’s capital, Great Zimbabwe. The Kingdom of Zimbabwe extended across the region until it fell to the Kingdom of Mutapa, a group from what is current day South Africa.

Credit: rosshuggett via flickr


Great Zimbabwe is believed to have been a palace complex for local monarchs.


While the environment helped the Kingdom of Great Zimbabwe flourish, an eventual change in climate lead to farming challenges. Unlike today, where food is transported around the world, during the 15th century CE, without reliable access to food, large and permanent civilizations like the Kingdom of Zimbabwe could no longer sustain their populations.


Across the world in Oceania, early civilizations were shaped by the Pacific Ocean. Polynesian culture, for example, developed as Southeast Asian indigenous sailors explored the South Pacific traveling from one island to the another. Early Polynesian peoples developed canoes and navigation techniques that allowed them to explore the thousands of islands in the region.


Citation: london via flickr


An outrigger canoe similar to those used by early Oceanic explorers.


The Maori are an indigenous group of people native to East Polynesia. The Maori traveled across the islands of Oceania and eventually found their way to the islands of New Zealand in the 13th Century CE. The Maori had a significant impact on New Zealand’s forests and fauna as they reduced New Zealand’s forest by about half, largely through controlled fires used to clear land for agriculture.


Credit: kcmmc via flickr


365-day calendars like the one above were used by the Aztecs and other pre-columbian civilizations across Mesoamerica.


In the Western Hemisphere, between 2,000 and 300 BCE, the Olmec, Maya, and Toltec occupied complex cities along the trading corridor between North and South America. These civilizations developed advanced agricultural techniques, mathematics, astronomy, medicine, and even a system of writing.


Thanks to the location of Mesoamerican civilizations on and around the land that is today known as Central America, these groups of indigenous peoples benefitted from contact with traders and travellers moving between the continents of South and North America. The movement of people across Mesoamerica supported the exchange of language, architecture, and agricultural techniques.


The Age of Democracy and Independence


As explorers from European nations traveled around the world, the European monarchs who financially supported these explorers began to claim the lands and territories that were “discovered.” Throughout the 18th, 19th, and 20th Centuries CE, British, French, Dutch, and Portuguese monarchies all claimed regions of the world through both peaceful and military occupations.



Europeans spread disease and war across indigenous communities and caused a massive declines in population. The Portuguese built their colonial empire in current day Brazil while the Spanish controlled many of the other nations across the region.



A map of Colonial Africa.


In 1776 CE, American colonists were unhappy with their status as colonies under British rule. George Washington and other Founding Fathers led the American Patriots to victory in the Revolutionary War. With a victory in 1783, the United States became an independent country. American leaders created a democracy where instead of obeying a King from England, American people now voted for laws and leadership. George Washington was elected as the first President of the United States in 1788-9.


Following a precedent set by revolutions and wars for independence in countries like the United States and France, as well as instability among the European empires, a series of revolutions and independent states emerged across Latin America.



A map of Gran Colombia before it was divided in 1931.


From 1819-1831 CE, the region known as Gran Colombia was divided into modern day Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador, Panama, and Peru. Mexico became an independent nation following the war for Mexican independence which ended in 1821. Brazil signed its formal independence from Portugal in 1825. The countries across the Caribbean did not achieve independence until quite later as both the United States and European powers sought to maintain control over the smaller, more conveniently located territories.


The 20th century continued to see a series of civil wars and political unrest across Latin America. Colonial leaders and political elite did not support the indigenous populations and lower-income families. As a result, lengthy conflicts occurred from Central America through South America - the results of which can still be felt today.


European nations colonized much of Southeast Asia during the first half of the twentieth century. The French colonized Vietnam, Cambodia, and Laos while the British colonized countries like Malaysia and Myanmar. During and immediately after World War II, between 1945 and 1957, nearly all of Southeast Asian nations gained their independence.



The Invention of Law and Order


History is made every day by brilliant individuals all around the world. Many important inventions and innovations continue to influence daily life in communities all around the world.


Credit: cvalette via flickr


Hammurabi's Code was one of the first codified legal systems ever created.


Hammurabi was a Babylonian king in ancient Mesopotamia. Hammurabi outlined one of the first known legal codes in human history. The laws established guidelines for behavior and corresponding punishments. Some of the rules are still well known today, such as “an eye for an eye”. The 282 laws of Hammurabi’s Code were written using a writing system called cuneiform and carved into a 7 foot tall stele. Today, the stele can be seen in the Louvre museum in Paris, France.


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

colony

noun: a territory under control of a distant leader or government

cultivate

verb: to prepare land for growing food

dynasty

noun: a succession of people from the same family who rule a country or community

indigenous

adjective: being naturally from a place; originating in a place

monarch

noun: a head of state such as a kind, queen, or emperor

nomad

noun: people who have no permanent land and travel from place to place, usually following animals

unrest

noun: a situation in which there is trouble, turmoil, or chaos

title: Diversity and Discrimination
body_one:
Introduction to Discrimination




What is Discrimination?


There are more than 7 billion people alive on Earth. These people speak different languages. They live in different countries. They have different skin colours. They speak different religions. The world is diverse and full of people who are different from you.


Acceptance of cultural diversity is becoming more and more commonplace.


Many people celebrate diversity. But some people discriminate against people who are not like them. Discrimination is when a person treats another person in a cruel way because the other person is different.


People discriminate against other people for many reasons. You and your pen pal will learn about discrimination based on race, religion, gender and wealth.


The History of Discrimination in South Africa



Discrimination in South Africa started long ago. When explorers from Europe came to southern Africa in the 1600s they met people who lived there. The explorers made many African people into slaves and treated others with cruelty.


These native African people were called the Khoisan. The Khoisan lived along the coasts and in the deserts of South Africa.


Europeans discriminated against the Khoisan based on their skin colour. This racism lasted for hundreds of years into the 21st century.  


The History of Discrimination in the United States



When the first colonists arrived in North America they met the Native Americans. The European colonists did not understand the many languages used by the Native American. Europeans and Natives Americans fought over land.


Like in South Africa, European colonists discriminated against Native Americans because they were different. Europeans captured and killed many Native Americans.


The colonists also discriminated against Native Americans because they had different religions.


Walking to Freedom


In the coming weeks, you and your PenPal will learn about leaders who stood up against racism and discrimination in South Africa and the United States.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

cruel

(adj) causing pain on purpose

colonist

(noun) a person who tries to start a community some place new

discriminate

(verb) to unfairly treat a person or group differently from other people or groups

diverse

(adj) showing a variety; many different things

racism

(noun) prejudice and ill-treatment directed to someone who looks different

slave

(noun) a person who is the property of another person
body_two:
Introduction to Discrimination




What is Discrimination?


There are more than 7 billion people alive on Earth today. These people speak different languages, live in different countries, have different skin colours, and follow different religions. The world is diverse and full of people who are different from you.


Acceptance of cultural diversity is becoming more and more commonplace.


While many people celebrate diversity, there are still many who discriminate against those who are not like them. Discrimination is when someone treats someone else unfairly just because they are different.


People discriminate against others for many different reasons. In this course, you and your pen pal are going to specifically look at discrimination based on race, religion, gender and class.


The History of Discrimination in South Africa



South Africa has a long history of discrimination. During the 1900s, South Africa was famous for a system called apartheid. Apartheid discriminated against people who were labeled as ‘non-white’. The apartheid laws segregated people.  People who were labeled ‘non-white’ were refused many basic human rights.


But discrimination in South Africa started long before apartheid. When European explorers first came to southern Africa in the 1600s, they forced the African residents to become slaves. Explorers robbed and murdered the natives of the country.


These natives were called the Khoisan people. The Khoisan were hunter-gatherers who lived along the coasts and inland deserts of South Africa.


Europeans discriminated against the Khoisan based on their skin colour. This racism took hold quickly, and was built upon by the European colonists into modern times. This early racism is the origin of the apartheid system in South Africa.


The History of Discrimination in the United States of America



When the first settlers arrived in North America (before the United States even existed) they encountered the Native Americans. The European settlers did not understand the many languages of Native American tribes, and frequently fought them for land and resources.


As in South Africa, the European settlers discriminated against Native Americans simply because they were different. This eventually led to many of the Native Americans being killed and captured.


Another reason for the colonisers’ discrimination against the Native Americans was religion. The Europeans who arrived in America were mostly Christians, while most Native Americans followed a pagan, ancestor-based religion.


Walking to Freedom


In the coming weeks, you and your PenPal will learn about leaders who stood up against racism and discrimination in South Africa, the United States, and countries around the world. You will learn about people who fought discrimination throughout history and people who fight discrimination today.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

discriminate

(verb) to unfairly treat a person or group differently from other people or groups

diverse

(adj) showing a variety; many different things

persecution

(noun) oppressive treatment, especially because of racial, religious or gender differences

racism

(noun) prejudice and ill-treatment directed to someone of a different race

resources

(noun) material or money that people use to make things and conduct business

segregation

(noun) keeping apart
body_three:
Introduction to Discrimination




What is Discrimination?


There are more than 7 billion people alive on Earth today. These people speak different languages, live in different countries, have different skin colours, and follow different religions. The world is diverse and full of people who are different from you.


Acceptance of cultural diversity is becoming more and more commonplace.


While many people embrace the differences of others, there are still many who discriminate against those who are not like them. Discrimination is when someone treats someone else unfairly, and sometimes cruelly, just because they are different.


When people in a group are similar to each other, we say they are homogeneous. When a group of people are different from each other, we say they are heterogeneous. Discrimination generally happens in a group of heterogeneous people.


Discrimination takes different forms. People discriminate against others based on many different things. In this course, you and your pen pal are going to specifically look at discrimination based on race, religion, gender, and class.


During this course, you and your pen pal will look at how discrimination has taken root across the world over the course of history. You will pay specific attention to discrimination in South Africa and the United States of America, using these countries as examples.


You will also learn about civil rights activists who fought against persecution in these countries.


The History of Discrimination in South Africa



South Africa has a long history of discrimination. During the mid to late 1900s, South Africa became notorious for its cruel apartheid system, which discriminated harshly against people who were labeled as ‘non-white’. The apartheid laws mandated segregation, where blacks were refused even the most basic of human rights.


But discrimination in South Africa started long before apartheid. When European explorers and settlers first arrived in southern Africa in the 1600s, they enslaved, robbed and murdered the natives of the country.


These natives were called the Khoisan people - nomadic hunter-gatherers who lived along the coasts and inland deserts of South Africa.


The Europeans discriminated against the Khoisan based on their skin colour. This racism took hold quickly, and was built upon by the European colonisers into modern times. It is the origin of the apartheid system in South Africa.


South Africa’s battle with discrimination is an old one. But with the unending support of politicians, civic leaders, ordinary citizens, and many other activists, South Africa has overcome many of its greatest challenges.


The History of Discrimination in the United States of America



When the first settlers arrived in North America (before the United States even existed) they encountered the Native Americans. The European settlers did not understand the many languages of Native American tribes, and frequently fought them for land and resources.


As in South Africa, the European settlers discriminated against Native Americans simply because they were different. This eventually led to many of the Native Americans being killed and captured.


Another reason for the colonisers’ discrimination against the Native Americans was religion. The Europeans who arrived in America were mostly Christians, while most Native Americans followed a pagan, ancestor-based religion.


Fortunately there were also many people in America who opposed this kind of discrimination. They played a fundamental role in helping the United States become the free country it is today.


Walking to Freedom


Through the years, there have been many civic leaders who opposed racism and segregation, as well as discrimination in a broader sense. Over the course of the next six weeks you will learn about people who fought discrimination throughout history and people who fight discrimination today.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

discriminate

(verb) to unfairly treat a person or group differently from other people or groups

heterogeneous

(noun) diverse

homogeneous

(noun) the same kind; alike

persecution

(noun) oppressive treatment, especially because of racial, religious or gender differences

racism

(noun) prejudice and ill-treatment directed to someone of a different race

segregation

(noun) keeping apart

title: Elements of Argument Writing
body_one:
Organization is a necessary part of argument writing! All writers plan, whether they are students or published authors. In this section, you will learn about the elements of argument writing. Then, you will learn about an organization strategy that will help you plan to write your own piece of argument writing. You will also identify and discuss these strategies as you evaluate examples of argument writing. The chance to identify and discuss the elements of argument writing in real writing samples will help you prepare to reflect on your own writing in the coming lessons!


Lesson Objectives:

  • Watch a short video to explore vocabulary related to argument writing

  • Discuss the elements of argument writing with your pen pal

  • Use a color coding system to identify important parts of argument writing

  • Evaluate two argument paragraphs



Whether an argument is a single paragraph or several pages long, the overall structure of argument writing is the same. In this lesson, you and your pen pal will explore the elements that make a piece of argument writing so effective and enjoyable. You will learn how to identify a topic sentence, claims supported by evidence, effective transitions, and strong conclusions.


The purpose of argument writing is to make a claim and support a claim with reasons and evidence. Whether an argument is a single paragraph or a multi-paragraph essay, the elements are generally the same.


Directions: Study the chart to unpack elements of argument writing. Then, talk with your pen pal to better understand these key elements.



Complete the Questions for Part 1 before moving on to Part 2!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)




What do the elements of argument writing have to do with a traffic light? Quite a bit more than you might expect! In this section, you and your pen pal will use three different colors to explore the elements of argument writing. Just like a traffic light, this section will help you learn when it’s time to speed up, slow down, and stop to provide evidence and details as you write your own argument paragraph.


Directions: Read the chart below to learn what each color represents in the traffic-light color system. Then, read the paragraph titled “Turn Classrooms into Gyms!” to see the traffic light colors in action! Finally, work with your pen pal to color-code an argument writing paragraph!



Turn Classrooms into Gyms!


I have the perfect solution to the obesity epidemic: install stationary bikes and treadmills in classrooms. We would all be healthier. School would become a health club where kids get to stay in shape as they learn. In addition, we would be better students. Many articles indicate that exercise makes the brain work work better because of increased blood flow. Exercising would also fend off boredom and would prevent students from getting sleepy in class. Some teachers and parents say that exercise equipment in the classroom would be distracting. It would be easy, however, to limit equipment use to lectures, reading periods, and study halls. When kid have to write or type, they can have their hands free. But it is no problem to listen to a lecture or read a book while cycling or walking. Building exercise into every classroom’s routine is a creative way to make healthier, better students and to make some headway against the obesity epidemic.


Complete the Questions for Part 2 before moving on to Part 3!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)




Now that you have seen the traffic light model in action, it’s time for you and your pen pal to try your hand at color-coding and evaluating two paragraphs.


Read the sample argument writing paragraph. Then, answer Part 3 discussion questions to better understand how to use the traffic light colors to highlight a paragraph.


Social Media Benefits Kids


Children under 16 should not be banned from social media. Social media provides a great way for kids to make valuable connections. Social networking sites make it easier for kids to reach out to other kids and form new friendships. For example, my 13-year-old cousin Mei is smart talented and very funny. However, she is also very shy. She finds it hard to make friends in school and in her neighborhood. After she signed up on a social networking site, she started making online friends who share her interests. She discovered that one of them lived 15 minutes away from Mei and plays chess. Mei’s favorite hobby. Now they play chess together on weekends and are planning to enter local chess competitions. Connecting with other kids is important to young people. A study conducted by an international Corporation found that 90% of kids between the age of 11 and 18 use social media sites. Connecting with others is also a key part of a healthy social development. The earlier that kids learn how to do this, the more likely that they will have stronger social skills when they are older. Social media is here to stay, and it would be a disadvantage to kids to deny them from using it.


Traits of Effective Argument Writing


Traits of Effective

Argument Writing

 Yes or No?

Organization

Introduction states claim.


Reasons and evidence are organized logically.


Conclusion supports claim.


Ideas and Content

Reasons are sufficient, relevant, and based on facts.


Sources used are accurate/credible.  


Opposing claim is addressed.


Language/Style

Sentences are complete and interesting.


Wording is clear and precise.


A formal style is maintained.


Conventions (CUPS)

Capitalization correct


Usage (grammar) correct


Punctuation correct


Spelling correct



Complete the questions located at the bottom of this page! After answering each of your questions, read and respond to your pen pal’s answers!


Word

Definition

accurate

(adj) information that is correct

claim

(noun) a position a writer takes on a particular issue. A claim is supported by factual evidence

conclusion

(noun) a statement that ties all of the parts of an argument together and reminds the reader of the claim

evidence

(noun) factual information used to support a claim

support

(verb) to help or give assistance to something

thesis statement

(noun) a type of topic sentence used in argument writing in which the writer takes a position, makes an argument, or states the main idea for the entire essay or report

transition

(noun) a word or phrase that lets the reader know the writer is moving from one main idea or reason to another
