Complete the Questions for Part 1 before moving on to Part 2!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)




What do the elements of argument writing have to do with a traffic light? Quite a bit more than you might expect! In this section, you and your pen pal will use three different colors to explore the elements of argument writing. Just like a traffic light, this section will help you learn when it’s time to speed up, slow down, and stop to provide evidence and details as you write your own argument paragraph.


Directions: Read the chart below to learn what each color represents in the traffic-light color system. Then, read the paragraph titled “Turn Classrooms into Gyms!” to see the traffic light colors in action! Finally, work with your pen pal to color-code an argument writing paragraph!



Turn Classrooms into Gyms!


I have the perfect solution to the obesity epidemic: install stationary bikes and treadmills in classrooms. We would all be healthier. School would become a health club where kids get to stay in shape as they learn. In addition, we would be better students. Many articles indicate that exercise makes the brain work work better because of increased blood flow. Exercising would also fend off boredom and would prevent students from getting sleepy in class. Some teachers and parents say that exercise equipment in the classroom would be distracting. It would be easy, however, to limit equipment use to lectures, reading periods, and study halls. When kid have to write or type, they can have their hands free. But it is no problem to listen to a lecture or read a book while cycling or walking. Building exercise into every classroom’s routine is a creative way to make healthier, better students and to make some headway against the obesity epidemic.


Complete the Questions for Part 2 before moving on to Part 3!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)




Now that you have seen the traffic light model in action, it’s time for you and your pen pal to try your hand at color-coding and evaluating two paragraphs.


Read the sample argument writing paragraph. Then, answer Part 3 discussion questions to better understand how to use the traffic light colors to highlight a paragraph.


Social Media Benefits Kids


Children under 16 should not be banned from social media. Social media provides a great way for kids to make valuable connections. Social networking sites make it easier for kids to reach out to other kids and form new friendships. For example, my 13-year-old cousin Mei is smart talented and very funny. However, she is also very shy. She finds it hard to make friends in school and in her neighborhood. After she signed up on a social networking site, she started making online friends who share her interests. She discovered that one of them lived 15 minutes away from Mei and plays chess. Mei’s favorite hobby. Now they play chess together on weekends and are planning to enter local chess competitions. Connecting with other kids is important to young people. A study conducted by an international Corporation found that 90% of kids between the age of 11 and 18 use social media sites. Connecting with others is also a key part of a healthy social development. The earlier that kids learn how to do this, the more likely that they will have stronger social skills when they are older. Social media is here to stay, and it would be a disadvantage to kids to deny them from using it.


Traits of Effective Argument Writing


Traits of Effective

Argument Writing

 Yes or No?

Organization

Introduction states claim.


Reasons and evidence are organized logically.


Conclusion supports claim.


Ideas and Content

Reasons are sufficient, relevant, and based on facts.


Sources used are accurate/credible.  


Opposing claim is addressed.


Language/Style

Sentences are complete and interesting.


Wording is clear and precise.


A formal style is maintained.


Conventions (CUPS)

Capitalization correct


Usage (grammar) correct


Punctuation correct


Spelling correct



Complete the questions located at the bottom of this page! After answering each of your questions, read and respond to your pen pal’s answers!


Word

Definition

accurate

(adj) information that is correct

claim

(noun) a position a writer takes on a particular issue. A claim is supported by factual evidence

conclusion

(noun) a statement that ties all of the parts of an argument together and reminds the reader of the claim

evidence

(noun) factual information used to support a claim

support

(verb) to help or give assistance to something

thesis statement

(noun) a type of topic sentence used in argument writing in which the writer takes a position, makes an argument, or states the main idea for the entire essay or report

transition

(noun) a word or phrase that lets the reader know the writer is moving from one main idea or reason to another

title: Popular Culture
body_one:
Popular culture is made up of the things we love to talk about. Maybe you and your friends talk about movies. Maybe you talk about tv shows. Or maybe you talk about your favorite songs, computer games, and sports teams. These are the things that make pop culture!


Movies and Television


People around the world love movies and television shows. Movies take us to different places. Movies can make us laugh and cry. Movies can help us think about the world we live in. Your favorite movies and tv shows say something about you and your community!


Credit: minnemom via flickr


Hollywood is home to the United States film industry.


From Los Angeles, USA to Mumbai, India, people love watching movie stars. Bollywood refers to movies made in the Hindi language. Actors, actresses, and directors from around the world work on Bollywood movies. Almost one thousand Bollywood movies are made every year!


Credit: adam_jones via flickr


Bollywood films are extremely popular in India and around the world.


Many moves are made in Africa. Like India and the United States, Nigeria has a film industry. The Nigerian film industry is called Nollywood. Almost 50 movies are made every week in Nigeria!



Nollywood is the film industry in Nigeria.


Television shows are also popular all around the world. Many people watch their favorite shows on a television. Many other people watch television shows on their computer or phone.


Music


Many musicians are famous people. Musicians can be famous for their voices and catchy songs. Musicians can also become famous for their fashion (Nicki Minaj). Musicians can be famous for their politics (Beyonce/Bob Marley/Bruce Springsteen). And musicians can be famous for getting in trouble (Justin Bieber).


The Beatles and the Rolling Stones are two British bands. These two bands are among the most successful bands in music history. The Beatles and the Rolling Stones are still popular today!


Credit: beatlesmaniac11 via flickr


The Beatles have sold over 65 million albums.


Canada is another country with famous musicians and bands! Celine Dion, Drake, Michael Buble, and Justin Bieber are some of Canada's famous musicians.



The Canadian musician Justin Bieber has been nominated for three Grammy Awards and has won once.


Celebrities


People can become famous in many different ways! Malala Yousafzai, is famous for helping others. Yousafzai works to help young women around the world go to school. She is the youngest person to ever win the Nobel Peace Prize.


Credit: statsministerenskontor via flickr


Malala Yousafzai advocates for equal access to education for young women.




Another popular person is Pope Francis. Pope Francis has talked with presidents and prisoners. He has walked with rich and poor people. Pope Francis will often take “selfies” with his fans and followers.


Athletics and Sports Heroes


People can become celebrities through sports. In the United States, baseball players can be famous. Derek Jeter, Miguel Cabrera, and Albert Pujols are famous.

Credit: m01229 via flickr


Baseball is America’s unofficial pastime.


Baseball is also a popular sport in South Korea. Excellent baseball players from around the world compete in the Korean league. Today, many Korean ballplayers play in the United States. Some Korean baseball players include Hyun-jin Ryu and Jung ho Kang.


Credit: kozumel via flickr


Santiago Bernabéu Stadium is a stadium in Madrid, Spain.


Soccer is one of the world’s most popular sports! Football, Futbol, or Soccer is the most popular sport in Europe and in many other parts of the world. Famous soccer players include Lionel Messi from Argentina, Cristiano Ronaldo from Portugal, and Abby Wambach from the United States.


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

band

noun: a group of musicians who perform together

celebrity

noun: a famous person

famous

adjective: known by many people

fashion

noun: a popular trend (specifically in clothing)

popular

adjective: liked by many people


Meet Your PenPal!
body_two:
The ideas, perspectives, and trends that we see around us make up popular culture. Another way to think about popular culture is to think about all the things we love to talk about!


Turn on the television and you might see famous people getting into trouble. Log-in to Facebook and you might hear about a new song that has over a million views on YouTube! Walk to a park or mall and you might see young people playing their favorite cell phone game. These are the things that make our popular culture!


Movies and Television


People around the world love movies and television shows. Movies can take us to different places like the fantastic worlds of The Lord of the Rings and Jurassic Park. Sometimes movies send us to different planets like in the popular Star Trek and Star Wars films. Movies can also make us laugh, cry, and think about the world around us.


Credit: minnemom via flickr


Hollywood is home to the United States film industry.


Movies are part of popular culture around the world. From Los Angeles to Mumbai, India, people love watching their favorite stars. Bollywood is the Hindi language film industry. Actors, actresses, and directors from around the world work on Bollywood movies.


Bollywood films often include songs and dances. Bollywood films include a variety of dance styles from classical Indian dances to  modern and western styles of dancing. As many as one thousand Bollywood films are released every year.


Credit: adam_jones via flickr


Bollywood films are extremely popular in India and around the world.


The film industry in Africa dates back to the 1920s. Like India and the United States, Nigeria bustling film industry. Often called “Nollywood,” nearly 50 movies are made every week in Nigeria. African movies often have social and political themes like those in the 1992 Nollywood film Living in Bondage.



Nollywood is the film industry in Nigeria.


Like movies, television is popular all around the world. While many people still enjoy their favorite television programs on a traditional television, streaming and online television is becoming more and more popular.

One of the most famous Spanish language sitcoms is El Chavo del Ocho. The Mexican sitcom had seven seasons with almost 300 total episodes. The show reached a record breaking audience of 350 million viewers per episode! By comparison, the 2014 Super Bowl in the United States had only 114 million viewers. The main character of the sitcom is a boy named El Chavo. El Chavo lives in a working class neighborhood with his close friends. He is a poor and hungry boy who is often mistreated by the members of his community.



The title character from the popular TV show El Chavo.


Music


Some of the most famous celebrities around the world are musicians! Musicians are often recognized for their voices, their fashion (Nicki Minaj), their politics (Beyonce/Bob Marley/Bruce Springsteen), and for getting in trouble (Justin Bieber).


The Beatles and the Rolling Stones are two British bands. These two bands are among the most successful bands in music history. The Beatles’ combination of catchy songs and rock and roll sound made them one of the most popular bands of the 1960s. The Beatles and the Rolling Stones are still popular today!



Credit: beatlesmaniac11 via flickr


The Beatles have sold over 65 million albums.


In the Middle East, music fans enjoy a variety of music from classical to rock and roll and hip-hop. Thanks to satellite television and the internet, musicians can explore different bands and styles. In Iran, for example, singers like Tupac Shakur and Eminem influence young hip-hop artists.


Canada is another country with many popular musicians and bands! Celine Dion, Drake, Michael Buble, and Justin Bieber are some of Canada's famous musicians.



The Canadian musician Justin Bieber has been nominated for three Grammy Awards and has won once.


Celebrities


While many people become famous through movies, television, and music, there are other ways people become famous. Malala Yousafzai, for example, became famous for doing humanitarian work. Yousafzai survived an assassination attempt after standing up for her right to attend school in Pakistan. She is the youngest person to ever receive the Nobel Peace Prize.


Credit: statsministerenskontor via flickr


Malala Yousafzai advocates for equal access to education for young women.


Perhaps the most famous Europeans are the British Monarchs. Queen Elizabeth II, Princes William, Prince Harry, and Kate Middleton are celebrities. People around the world love talking about their lives. As a result, the British Monarchs are often featured in tabloids and online magazines.


Credit: huckool via flickr


The British Royal Family are seen in magazines and newspapers across Europe.


Another popular person is Pope Francis. Pope Francis is a celebrity because of his position as Pope, but also because of the ideas he shares. Born Jorge Mario Bergoglio, Pope Francis is from Buenos Aires, Argentina. When Pope Francis visited South America in the summer of 2015 he made history.



The Pope has talked with presidents and prisoners. He has met with the wealthy and the poor. While traveling, Pope Francis will often take “selfies” with his fans and followers.


Athletics and Sports Heroes


People also become pop culture icons and celebrities through sports and athletics. In the United States, athletes like baseball’s Derek Jeter, Miguel Cabrera, and Albert Pujols are famous. Once famous, athletes often begin relationships with famous musicians, models, and movie stars.


Credit: m01229 via flickr


Baseball is America’s unofficial pastime.


Baseball is also a popular sport in South Korea. In the 1980s, South Korean baseball teams joined together to form the Korean Baseball Organization. Excellent baseball players from around the world compete in the Korean league.


Today, many Korean ballplayers play in Major League Baseball in the United States. Some Korean Baseball Organization alumni include Hyun-jin Ryu, pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodges, and Jung ho Kang, infielder for the Pittsburgh Pirates.


Credit: kozumel via flickr


Santiago Bernabéu Stadium is a stadium in Madrid, Spain.


Football, Futbol, or Soccer is the most popular sport in Europe and in many other parts of the world. In Europe, The Champions League hosts an annual football tournament. More than 360 million people tune in to watch The Champions League. Some of the world’s most famous soccer players include Lionel Messi from Argentina, Cristiano Ronaldo from Portugal, and Abby Wambach from the United States.


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

celebrity

noun: a famous person

humanitarian

noun: a person who works to help others

influence

verb: to have an effect on something; to change something

sitcom

noun: a show that is on television regularly and features the same characters in funny situations

trend

noun: a direction or pattern in the way something is changing

viewer

noun: a person who looks at or watching something
body_three:
Popular culture consists of the ideas, perspectives, trends, and images that are mainstream in a culture. The things that make up popular culture are the things we love to talk about!


Turn on the television and you might see stories about famous people causing trouble or advancing in their careers. Log-in to your Facebook account and you might hear all about the newest song that has over a million views on YouTube! Or walk to a park or mall where you might see hundreds of young people walking around playing their favorite cell phone game. These are the things that comprise popular culture!


Movies and Television


People around the world love movies and television shows. Sometimes movies transport us to another place like the fantastic worlds of The Lord of the Rings and Jurassic Park. Sometimes they send us to different planets like in the popular Star Trek and Star Wars films. Other times movies can make us laugh, cry, and think critically about the world around us.


Credit: minnemom via flickr


Hollywood is home to the United States film industry.


Movies are a central piece of popular culture. From Los Angeles to Mumbai, India, people love watching their favorite stars. Bollywood is the Hindi language film industry based in Mumbai, India. Like the US Hollywood, Bollywood employs thousands of people and attracts actors, actresses, and directors from around the world.


Bollywood films often incorporate elaborate songs and dances. Bollywood dancing is inspired by classical Indian dance styles but has begun to incorporate modern and western styles of dancing as well. As many as one thousand Bollywood films are released every year, compared with the over five hundred films created by Hollywood in the USA.


Credit: adam_jones via flickr


Bollywood films are extremely popular in India and around the world.


The film industry in Africa dates back to the 1920s when movies were captured and presented on large film reels. Like India and the United States, Nigeria has a thriving film industry which produces hundreds of films every year! Often called “Nollywood,” nearly 50 movies are produced every week in Nigeria. African movies often have social and political themes as seen in the 1992 Nollywood film Living in Bondage.



Nollywood is the film industry in Nigeria.


While Europeans enjoy watching movies from The United States and other countries, Europeans have long been at the forefront of the film industry. Europeans pioneered many film techniques and hosted many of the most influential movements in film history. The European Film Awards are an annual award ceremony, similar to the Academy Awards in the United States. During the European Film Awards, Europeans celebrate the film achievements of the European continent.  


Like movies, television is extremely popular all over the world. In fact, in the twenty countries that comprise Latin America, there are more than 60 million television sets!  And while many people still enjoy their favorite television programs on a traditional television, streaming and online television is becoming more and more popular.


One of the most famous Spanish language sitcoms is called El Chavo del Ocho. The Mexican sitcom had seven seasons with a total of almost 300 episodes. The show reached a record breaking audience of 350 million viewers per episode! By comparison, the 2014 Super Bowl in the United States had only 114 million viewers. The main character of the sitcom is a boy named El Chavo. El Chavo lives in a working class neighborhood with his close friends. He is a poor and hungry boy who is often mistreated by the members of his community.



The title character from the popular TV show El Chavo.


Music


Some of the most famous celebrities around the world are musicians! Musicians are often recognized by their powerful voices, their fashion lines (Nicki Minaj), their political opinions (Beyonce/Bob Marley/Bruce Springsteen), and simply for getting in trouble (Justin Bieber).


The Beatles and the Rolling Stones are two British bands and among the most successful bands in all of music history. The Beatles’ catchy songs, good looks, and unique rock and roll sound made them one of the most popular bands of the 1960s. Many of the band’s songs are still popular today!


While European music has been heavily influenced by American rock over the past decades, now, European music is creating an identify of its own with genres like electronic, techno, and dance. Cities around Europe host electronic and techno music festivals every year.


Credit: beatlesmaniac11 via flickr


The Beatles have sold over 65 million albums.


In Middle Eastern cities like Beirut and Cairo, music fans enjoy a variety of genres ranging from classical to rock and roll and hip-hop. Thanks to satellite television and the internet, musicians in the Middle East are exploring a variety of genres.


In Iran, for example, hip-hop artists have been influenced by singers like Tupac Shakur and Eminem. In Jordan, a new-age group called RUM became famous for performing music for television dramas and has gained fans around the world.


Canada is another country with many popular musicians and bands!  Celine Dion, Drake, Michael Buble, and Justin Bieber are among many of the famous Canadian musicians.



The Canadian musician Justin Bieber has been nominated for three Grammy Awards and has won once.


Celebrities


While many people become famous through their participation in the performance arts, many other people become famous for entirely different reasons. In Sri Lanka, for example, members of the national cricket team are incredibly famous!


Malala Yousafzai is a famous Pakistani student who survived an assassination attempt after standing up for her right to attend school. She is the youngest person to ever receive the Nobel Peace Prize. Muhammad Yunus is a Nobel Prize-winning economist from Bangladesh.


Credit: statsministerenskontor via flickr


Malala Yousafzai advocates for equal access to education for young women.


Perhaps among the most famous Europeans are the British Monarchs. Queen Elizabeth II, Princes William, Prince Harry, and Kate Middleton can often be spotted in tabloids and online magazines.


Credit: huckool via flickr


The British Royal Family are seen in magazines and newspapers across Europe.


Another very popular person is a celebrity not only thanks to his position but thanks to the ideas he shares and the ways he communicated them. Born Jorge Mario Bergoglio, Pope Francis is from Buenos Aires, Argentina. When Pope Francis visited South America in the summer of 2015 he made history.



The Pope spoke with presidents and prisoners, the wealthy and the established as well as the poor and disenfranchised. He took “selfies” with millions of people across the continent and visited a Burger King in Bolivia! The Pope even apologized for the many sins committed by Christians against the continent's indigenous peoples.


Athletics and Sports Heroes


Sports and athletics also produce celebrities and popular culture icons. In the United States, athletes like baseball’s Derek Jeter, Miguel Cabrera, Albert Pujols, and Clayton Kershaw are all household names. Athletes often use their sport to gain fame and often times begin relationships with famous musicians, models, and movie stars.


Credit: m01229 via flickr


Baseball is America’s unofficial pastime.


Baseball is also a popular sport in South Korea! In the 1980s, a number of South Korean professional baseball teams joined together to form the Korean Baseball Organization. Excellent baseball players compete in the Korean league and today, many Korean ballplayers make their way to Major League Baseball in the United States. Some Korean Baseball Organization alumni include Hyun-jin Ryu, pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodges, and Jung ho Kang, infielder for the Pittsburgh Pirates.


Soccer, Rugby, and cricket are among the most popular sports in Oceania. The New Zealand All Blacks have won over 75% of their Rugby matches and are considered one of the best teams in the world.


Any mention of athletics and sports heroes would not be complete without mentioning one of the world’s most popular sports: football! Football, Futbol, or Soccer is by far the most popular sport in Europe and many other parts of the world.


In Europe, The Champions League hosts an annual football competition that regularly draws more than 360 million television viewers! Some of the world’s most famous soccer players include Lionel Messi from Argentina, the Portuguese star Cristiano Ronaldo, Abby Wambach from the United States, and the German star goalkeeper Nadine Angerer.


Credit: kozumel via flickr


Santiago Bernabéu Stadium is a stadium in Madrid, Spain.


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

genre

noun: a category in music or literature

influence

verb: to have an effect on something; to change something

sitcom

noun: a show that is on television regularly and features the same characters in funny situations

trend

noun: a direction or pattern in the way something is changing

title: Displaced But Not Defeated
body_one:
Watch the film DISPLACED BUT NOT DEFEATED to learn about María Ceballos Paz. María is a teenager in Colombia. María introduces us to her family, her friends, her teacher, and her community. As you explore María’s story, share your thoughts with your PenPals and talk about home, the importance of family, and the treatment of displaced people around the world.




María Ceballos Paz is a 16-year-old Colombian girl. María has been living in displacement for the past nine years. María and her family had to leave their home because of fighting in their town between the army, guerrilla groups and drug cartels. Over 4 million Colombians have had to leave their homes for the same reasons.


María and her family fled their farm after her father was killed. Now María lives in the slums of Cali.





Colombia is bordered by Panama, Venezuela, Brazil, Peru, and Ecuador. The Andes Mountain Range crosses the country. Half of Colombia is a low jungle fed by the Amazon and the Orinoco Rivers.




Population

46,736,728

Languages

Spanish

Life Expectancy

75 years

Major Industries

Energy, Mining, Manufacturing, Agriculture, Construction

*age 15+ who can read & write




Colombia has more internally displaced people than any other country in the world. Most of these people come from rural areas where fighting is common.  



Many displaced people in Colombia move to big cities. In cities, these people look for safety that they can not find in their home towns.




Word

Definition

displace

(verb) to compel to leave; to move to a different place

guerrilla

(adj, noun) an irregular soldier or military group who uses surprise tactics
body_two:
Watch the film DISPLACED BUT NOT DEFEATED to learn about María Ceballos Paz. María is a teenager in Colombia. María introduces us to her family, her friends, her teacher, and her community. As you explore María’s story, share your thoughts with your PenPals. Talk about home, family, and the treatment of displaced people around the world.




María Ceballos Paz is a 16-year-old Colombian girl. María has been living in displacement for the past nine years as a result of Colombia's civil war. Decades of fighting between the army, paramilitary, guerrilla groups and drug cartels has forced over 4 million Colombians from their homes. Colombia has the largest internally displaced population in the world.


After her father was killed by guerrillas, María and her family fled their farm. Now living in the slums of Cali, María shows us her family, friends and community as they rebuild their lives.





Colombia is bordered on the northwest by Panama, on the east by Venezuela and Brazil, and on the southwest by Peru and Ecuador. The Andes Mountain Range runs across the western half of the country. The eastern half of Colombia is a low, jungle covered region fed by the Amazon and the Orinoco Rivers.


Colombia is a diverse place! Many Colombians descend from the original native inhabitants, Spanish colonists, Africans brought to the country as slaves, and 20th century immigrants from Europe and the Middle East. As a result of Colombia’s diverse peoples, the country has a rich and varied cultural heritage.




Population

46,736,728

Languages

Spanish

Age Structure

0-14 years: 25%

15-24 years: 18%

25-52 years: 42&

55-64 years: 6,5 %

65+ years: 7%

Life Expectancy

75 years

Literacy Rate*

95%

Major Industries

Energy, Mining, Manufacturing, Agriculture, Construction

*age 15+ who can read & write




Countries with high rates of internally displaced persons often struggle with civil war. In Colombia, most displacements take place in remote rural areas where armed conflicts are common.  



Approximately 80 percent of internally displaced people in Colombia migrate to big cities. In cities, these people look for safety and public services that they can not find in their home towns.


The Colombian government has not been able to do much to help the internally displaced peoples. While peace talks continue between Colombia’s armed militant groups, an end to fighting is not in sight.




  1. Share your ideas on how policymakers can enact legislation and create change that protects the rights of refugees and internally displaced people athttp://refugeesinternational.org/blog/have-your-say-contribute-ri-blog

  2. Host a fundraiser and donate to the UN Refugee Agency to send kitchen sets, bedding, stoves, and tents to displaced Colombians at http://donate.unhcr.org/1family. Select "Colombia" under "Give through your national office."




Word

Definition

displace

(verb) to compel to leave; to move to a different place

guerrilla

(adj, noun) an irregular soldier or military group who uses surprise tactics

remote

(adj) far apart, distanced, secluded

upheaval

(noun) strong and violent change
body_three:
Watch the film DISPLACED BUT NOT DEFEATED to learn about María Ceballos Paz, a Colombian teenager. María introduces us to her family, her friends, her teacher, and other displaced people living in her community. We learn the role of family and the power of perseverance in the face of violence and conflict. As you explore María’s story, share your reactions with your PenPals and talk about home, the importance of family, and the treatment of populations displaced by armed conflict around the world.




María Ceballos Paz, a 16-year-old Colombian girl, has been living in displacement for the past nine years as a result of Colombia's civil war. Decades of fighting between the army, paramilitary, guerrilla groups and drug cartels has forced approximately 4 million Colombians from their homes, creating the largest internally displaced population in the world.


After her father was killed by guerrillas, María and her family fled their farm. Now living in the slums of Cali, María shows us her family, friends and community as they rebuild their lives.



María directed, filmed and narrated this award-winning documentary that puts a human face on the statistics of displacement. Her story is like those of millions of people facing similar upheaval, not only in Colombia, but in other war-torn countries around the world.


Susan Hoenig is María's BYkids Film Mentor. Among Hollywood's top TV producers, Susan has produced shows for Discovery, National Geographic, Fox, ABC, NBC and CBS. She received an Emmy nomination for Undercover Boss.




Colombia is bordered on the northwest by Panama, on the east by Venezuela and Brazil, and on the southwest by Peru and Ecuador. The Andes Mountain Range runs across the western half of the country. The eastern half of Colombia is a low, jungle covered region fed by the Amazon and the Orinoco Rivers.


Colombia is a diverse place! Many Colombians descend from the original native inhabitants, Spanish colonists, Africans brought to the country as slaves, and 20th century immigrants from Europe and the Middle East. As a result of Colombia’s diverse peoples, the country has a rich and varied cultural heritage.




Population

46,736,728

Languages

Spanish

Age Structure

0-14 years: 25%

15-24 years: 18%

25-52 years: 42&

55-64 years: 6,5 %

65+ years: 7%

Life Expectancy

75 years

Literacy Rate*

95%

Major Industries

Energy, Mining, Manufacturing, Agriculture, Construction

Gross Domestic Product (GDP)

$683 billion

*age 15+ who can read & write




Countries with high rates of internally displaced persons often struggle with civil war and armed conflict, and Colombia is no exception. Internal conflict between the government, armed guerilla groups, and armed groups within the drug industry are widely recognized as the main reason behind Colombia’s large population of displaced people. In Colombia, most displacements take place in remote rural areas where armed conflicts are common.  



Approximately 80 percent of internally displaced people in Colombia migrate to big cities. In cities, these migrants are looking for security from militants, and access to public services that are inaccessible in their home towns.


Unfortunately, as growing numbers of displaced peoples migrate into Colombia’s cities, violence follows. As cities are unable to support the influx of people, the poor often become poorer. The average displaced family is able to earn approximately $63 US per month, a majority of which goes to purchasing food. Women and children are particularly vulnerable. They endure violence, sexual exploitation, and malnutrition. Many adolescents are forced into gangs in order to survive.


The Colombian government's response to the crisis of internally displaced peoples has been limited. Attempts by the government to provide services to displaced peoples have encountered administrative problems and have failed to result in their intended outcomes. While promising peace talks continue to occur between Colombia’s armed militant groups, an end to fighting is not yet in sight.



  1. Share your ideas on how policymakers can enact legislation and create change that protects the rights of refugees and internally displaced people athttp://refugeesinternational.org/blog/have-your-say-contribute-ri-blog

  2. Host a fundraiser and donate to the UN Refugee Agency to send kitchen sets, bedding, stoves, and tents to displaced Colombians at http://donate.unhcr.org/1family. Select "Colombia" under "Give through your national office."




Word

Definition

displace

(verb) to compel to leave; to move to a different place

guerrilla

(adj, noun) an irregular soldier or military group who uses surprise tactics

migrate

(verb) to go from one country or region to another

remote

(adj) far apart, distanced, secluded

upheaval

(noun) strong and violent change

title: Fire In Our Hearts
body_one:
Watch the film FIRE IN OUR HEARTS. Learn about Jayshree Janu Kharpade, a sixteen-year-old girl from the Warli tribe in the Maharashtra State, India. Jayshree introduces us to her friends, family and community members. As you explore Jayshree’s story, talk with your PenPals about home, family, and education.




Jayshree Janu Kharpade had to leave school when she was 7 years old. She had to help raise her four younger brothers and work with her parents. Jayshree hoped her parents would let her return to school.


Jayshree’s parents finally let her return to school and soon she became one of the best students in her class. Now, 16 years old, Jayshree shows us the importance of educating girls in the developing world.



Jayshree's film mentor is Joyce Chopra. Joyce, and a second camerawoman, Cat Papadimitriou, went to India in January 2011.





India is a country in South Asia. It has the seventh-largest area out of all the countries in the world! India also has the second-largest number of people in the world! Over a billion people live in India today!


India is home to people who speak many different languages and practice many different customs and religions.




Population

1,251,695,584

Languages

Hindi (41%), English (10%), Bengali (8.1%), Telugu (7.2%), Others (30%)

Life Expectancy

68 years

Major Industries

Services (information technology, telecommunications), Industry (chemicals, pharmaceuticals, engineering, textiles), Agriculture




In the year 2000, most of the unenrolled school-age children were young girls. Today, there are more than 60 million girls out of school around the world.


Investing in women and girls makes a huge difference. Countries around the world are losing billions of dollars every year by not letting girls go to school.


Girls are more likely to have to stay home in order to take care of household chores and younger family members. In the developing world, 1 in 3 girls are forced into marriage before the age of 18.



Organizations around the world are working to help end discrimination towards girls at school.




Word

Definition

custom

(noun) a traditional way of doing something

developing world

(noun) nations of the world which have less money and less advanced technology

discrimination

(noun) treating someone differently based on race, age, or gender

mentor

(noun) an experienced or trusted advisor
body_two:
Watch the film FIRE IN OUR HEARTS to learn about Jayshree Janu Kharpade. Jayshree is a sixteen-year-old girl from the Warli tribe in the Maharashtra State, India. Jayshree introduces us to her friends, family and community members. As you explore Jayshree’s story, talk with your PenPals about home, community, and the importance of education.




Jayshree Janu Kharpade of India had to leave school when she was 7 years old so that she could raise her four younger brothers and help her parents work at the brick site. Jayshree pleaded for years with her parents to let her return to school.


Jayshree’s parents finally agreed to let her return to school and soon Jayshree became one of the most successful students in her class. Now 16 years old, Jayshree shows us the importance of educating girls in the developing world.



Jayshree's film mentor is the renowned Joyce Chopra. Joyce, and a second camerawoman, Cat Papadimitriou, went to India in January 2011.



About India



India is a country in South Asia. It is the seventh-largest country in the world by area and has the second-largest population! In fact, over a billion people live in India today!


The country is home to people who speak many different languages and practice many different customs and religions. India’s indigenous and tribal groups makes up about 8.5 percent of India’s population and account for over 100 million people!





Population

1,251,695,584

Languages

Hindi (41%), English (10%), Bengali (8.1%), Telugu (7.2%), Others (30%)

Age Structure

0-14 years (28%)

15-24 years (18 %)

25-54 years (41%)

55-64 years (7 %)

65 years and over (6%)

Life Expectancy

68 years

Literacy Rate*

71%

Major Industries

Services (information technology, telecommunications), Industry (chemicals, pharmaceuticals, engineering, textiles), Agriculture

*age 15+ who can read & write




In the year 2000, nearly two thirds of the school-age children unenrolled in school were young girls. Today, there are more than 60 million girls out of school around the world.


Investing in women and girls makes a huge difference. Countries around the world are losing billions of dollars every year by not educating girls to the levels they do with young boys. Every extra year of education is estimated to increase a girl’s earning power by 10 to 20 percent.


Girls are more likely to have to stay home in order to take care of household chores and younger family members. In the developing world, 1 in 3 girls are forced into marriage before the age of 18.



Organizations around the world are working to increase awareness about the benefits to allowing girls access to the same educational opportunities as boys. Through both government, private, and nonprofit initiatives, projects are now in place to help end discrimination towards girls at school.



  1. Blog about how the universal right to an education is an international and domestic human rights issue at www.actionaid.org/what-we-do/education.

  2. Sign a petition or start one of your own to raise awareness about the inequality surrounding educational access at: http://www.change.org/topics/education.




Word

Definition

earning power

(noun) the ability to make money

indigenous

(adj) naturally occurring in a particular place, native

plead

(verb) to ask for something in an emotional way
body_three:
Watch the film FIRE IN OUR HEARTS to learn about Jayshree Janu Kharpade, a sixteen-year-old girl from the Warli tribe in the Maharashtra State, India. Jayshree introduces us to her friends, family and community members. As you explore her story, share your reactions with your PenPals and talk about home, community, and the importance of education to young people around the world.




Jayshree Janu Kharpade of India was taken out of school at 7 years old so that she could raise her four younger brothers and contribute to her parents' labor at a brick kiln site. Exceptionally bright and motivated, Jayshree pleaded for years with her parents to let her return to school. Jayshree’s parents finally agreed, and soon Jayshree rose to the top of her school. Now aged 16, she illuminates the immense social and economic potential of educating girls in the developing world.



Jayshree's film mentor is the renowned Joyce Chopra, a pioneer of documentary cinema whose numerous titles include That Our Children Will Not Die, about primary health care in Nigeria, and the autobiographical Joyce at 34, which is in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art. Joyce, and a second camerawoman, Cat Papadimitriou, went to India in January 2011.






India is a country in South Asia. It is the seventh-largest country in the world by area and has the second-largest population in the world! In fact, over a billion people live in India today! India is a federal constitutional republic and is the world’s largest democracy. The country is home to people who speak many different languages and practice many different customs and religions.


India’s indigenous and tribal groups makes up about 8.5 percent of India’s population and account for over 100 million people!




Population

1,251,695,584

Languages

Hindi (41%), English (10%), Bengali (8.1%), Telugu (7.2%), Others (30%)

Age Structure

0-14 years (28%)

15-24 years (18 %)

25-54 years (41%)

55-64 years (7 %)

65 years and over (6%)

Life Expectancy

68 years

Literacy Rate*

71%

Major Industries

Services (information technology, telecommunications), Industry (chemicals, pharmaceuticals, engineering, textiles), Agriculture

*age 15+ who can read & write




In the year 2000, young girls accounted for nearly two thirds of the school-age children who remained unenrolled in school. Today, there are more than 60 million girls out of school around the world. Even though girls are more often marginalized than young boys, investing in women and girls makes a huge difference.


It is estimated that countries around the world are losing billions of dollars every year by not educating girls to the levels they do with young boys. Every extra year of education is estimated to increase a girl’s earning power by 10 to 20 percent.


Girls are more likely to have to stay home in order to take care of household chores and younger family members. In the developing world, 1 in 3 girls are forced into marriage before the age of 18. Girls who have completed seven years of education will marry on average five years later than girls who are less educated.



Organizations around the world are working to promote awareness about the advantages to allowing girls access to the same educational opportunities as boys. Through both government, private, and nonprofit initiatives, projects are now in place to help end discrimination towards girls at school.


  1. Blog about how the universal right to an education is an international and domestic human rights issue at www.actionaid.org/what-we-do/education.

  2. Sign a petition or start one of your own to raise awareness about the inequality surrounding educational access at: http://www.change.org/topics/education.




Word

Definition

earning power

(noun) the ability to make money

indigenous

(adj) naturally occurring in a particular place, native

marginalize

(verb) treat as a less significant part of a group

plead

(verb) to ask for something in an emotional way

potential

(adj) having the capacity to develop into something

republic

(noun) a government where the leaders are elected representatives of the people

title: Reflection
body_one:
It’s time to reflect on the past five weeks! What facts did you learn? Where would you like to visit? What activities would you like to try? Which new foods would you like to eat?


This week, build a project that shares what you learned. Here are a few ideas for a reflective project!


Option 1: Make a Padlet


Padlet is an easy way to share ideas from your PenPal exchange! You can share pictures of interesting places. You can share recipes for interesting foods. You can even share video links!



Visit padlet.com to get started!


With your teacher’s permission, visit www.padlet.com. Here’s a sample Padlet that can help give you and your classmates some ideas!


Option 2: Quiz Your PenPals


Making a quiz is a fun way to reflect on what you learn! Look through your exchange to find fun facts. Look at each of your PenPals’ messages. Make a list of fun and interesting facts and turn these facts into questions!



Visit getkahoot.com to get started!


With your teacher’s permission, make a Kahoot! Go to www.getkahoot.com. Share a link to your finished quiz with your PenPals, friends, and classmates. Here’s a sample Kahoot that can give you some ideas!


Option 3: Make a Collaborative Drawing


A flag made by the PenPal Schools team!


With your teacher’s permission, visit www.awwapp.com to make a drawing that represents your PenPal exchange. Share your drawing with your PenPals.
body_two:
It’s time for you and your PenPals to reflect on your experience! This week, build a project that shares what you learned. Here are a few ideas and resources you can use!


Option 1: Make A Collaborative Padlet


Padlet is an easy way to share highlights from your PenPal exchanges. You can share images that highlight interesting places that you and your PenPals explored. You can post photos and the recipes for new and interesting favorite foods. You can even share links to videos or music from Youtube or Vimeo!



Visit padlet.com to get started!


With your teacher’s permission, visit www.padlet.com to begin building a Padlet. Then, share the Padlet with your PenPals by pasting your Padlet’s url into your PenPal exchange. Here’s a sample Padlet that can help give you some ideas!


Option 2: Quiz Your PenPals


A quiz is a fun way to review the things you learned during the World Explorer course. Look back through your exchange to find interesting facts. Be sure to look through each of the weekly articles and your PenPals’ messages. After you have made a list of fun and interesting facts, turn these facts into questions that you can ask in a Kahoot! quiz!




Visit getkahoot.com to get started!


With your teacher’s permission, navigate to www.getkahoot.com. Share a link to your finished quiz with your PenPals, friends, and classmates. Here’s a sample Kahoot! that can help give you some ideas!


Option 3: Design a Flag or Collaborative Drawing


Flags help people show pride in their communities! Work with your PenPals to design a flag. The flag should highlights similarities between you and your PenPals!




A flag made by the PenPal Schools team!


With your teacher’s permission, visit www.awwapp.com to make a flag or drawing that represents your PenPal exchange.


Explore Other Project Ideas


There are many other ways to reflect on and share your PenPal exchange. You may want to make a slideshow, a website, or a short video. Share the final product with your PenPals, classmates, and members of the community.
body_three:
It’s time for you and your PenPals to reflect on your experience! This week, build a project that shares what you learned. Consider a project that will best share your learning and your unique perspective. Here are a few ideas and resources you can use for your project.


Option 1: Make A Collaborative Padlet


Padlet is an easy way to share highlights from your PenPal exchanges. You can share images that highlight interesting places that you and your PenPals explored. You can post photos and the recipes for your favorite foods. You can even link to videos and music from Youtube or Vimeo!



Visit padlet.com to get started!


With your teacher’s permission, visit www.padlet.com to begin building a Padlet. Then, share the Padlet with your PenPals by pasting your Padlet’s url into your PenPal exchange. You can also share a special link to your Padlet that will let your PenPals work with you and collaborate on this project. Here’s a sample Padlet that can help give you some ideas!


Option 2: Quiz Your PenPals


Making a quiz can be a fun way for both you and your PenPals to review all the things you learned  during the World Explorer course. Before you start building your quiz, look back through your exchange to find interesting facts. Be sure to look through each of the weekly articles and all of your PenPals’ messages. After you have made a list of fun and interesting facts, turn these facts into questions that you can ask in a quiz!




Visit getkahoot.com to get started!


With your teacher’s permission, navigate to www.getkahoot.com. Once you have finished creating your Kahoot!, share a link to your finished quiz with your PenPals, friends, and classmates. Here’s a sample Kahoot! that can help give you some ideas!


Option 3: Design a Flag or a Collaborative Drawing


Flags help people show pride in their communities. Work with your PenPals to design a flag that highlights similarities between you and your PenPals. Your drawings might include the foods, activities, and famous people that make your PenPals communities interesting places.


A flag made by members of the PenPal Schools team!


With your teacher’s permission, visit www.awwapp.com to make a flag or drawing that represents your PenPal exchange.


Explore Other Project Ideas


There are many other ways to reflect on and share your PenPal exchange! In addition to the ideas above, you and your PenPals might want to build a website using Google Sites. When building a website, you may want to include an “About Us” section. You might also want to link to different pages that detail your favorite foods, embed videos to your favorite songs, and even include screenshots from your PenPal exchange!


Alternatively, showcase your creativity by writing a song or creating a short video. Work with your PenPals to draft a script before shooting and producing a video on WeVideo, Animoto, or iMovie. Try making a slideshow using Google Slides, Prezi, or Creaza. Then, share the final product with your PenPals, classmates, and members of the community!

title: The Writing Process
body_one:
In this lesson, you and your pen pal focus on the big picture! You will explore the Writing Process and begin to understand how writers move from an idea to a finished, well written, piece of writing. After exploring the Writing Process, you and your pen pal will learn how to gather evidence from sources using a note taking tool. You will finish this lesson evaluating the sources themselves and deciding what makes a source reliable or not-reliable.


Lesson Objectives:

  • Watch a short video to explore vocabulary related to argument writing

  • Identify and discuss the eight steps of the Writing Process for Step Up to Writing

  • Use four-column notes to gather evidence and details to support claims

  • Explore digital resources and assess their accuracy, reliability, and bias



The Writing Process is a valuable tool for writers of all ages and abilities! The Writing Process includes specific steps that guide writers from general ideas to a finished, well written piece of writing. Writers use the steps in the Writing Process for both long or short writing. Writers will also use the Writing Process in informative writing, argument writing, and narrative writing. Whether you are writing an e-mail or a school report, the writing process will help you be the best writer you can be!



  1. Prewrite: Prewriting includes the different activities that help you think and learn about a topic. Sometimes, you will only have a few minutes to think about the topic. At other times you are able to research, discuss, analyze, compare, and think deeply about the topic before you begin writing.


  1. Plan: Planning means taking steps to organize your thoughts or ideas. Planning should include an informal outline. Planning saves you time and frustration and helps you visualize the paragraph or essay that you want to write. Remember, good writers will add, delete, or change parts of their plan as they begin writing.


  1. Draft:  Most writers create several drafts of a piece of writing before they have a final, published copy. Sometimes, however, your first attempt will be the only draft you make. At other times, you will have many chances to make multiple drafts before you have a finished version.


  1. Revise: Revising a draft means changing the order of words, sentences, and paragraphs. When you revise, you ask yourself some important questions: Does this text make sense? Is my information accurate? Will the reader understand what I have written? Do the words and sentences flow? You may also have classmates, teachers, or your pen pal read a draft and give you feedback.


  1. Edit: When you edit, your job is to check for mistakes in Capitalization, Usage, Punctuation, and Spelling.


  1. Write a Final Copy: When you create your final copy, remember that this is your time to shine! Be neat. Use your best handwriting or a word processor.


  1. Proofread: Proofreading means reviewing your final copy carefully for errors that you made as you rewrote the text.


  1. Share and Publish: Look for ways to share your writing with a real-life audience. Consider sharing your writing with your classmates, the school newspaper, or an online blog.


You might notice the circular arrow in the middle of the Writing Process. Writing is a process and good writers often write and rewrite the same paragraph over and over again until it is just right. This circle reminds writers to work on improving their writing rather than trying to finish as quickly as possible.


The Writing Process in Action



Complete the Questions for Part 1 before moving on to Part 2!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)



Unsupported claims are not very convincing! In Lesson 1, you and your pen pal explored the importance of making claims supported by evidence and examples. In this section, we will explore how to gather information from a source. A note taking template, like the one below, will help you during the prewrite and planning steps of the Writing Process.


A four-column notes tool can be used to record and research evidence that supports a claim.


In the first column, “Reasons and Opposing Claim(s),” write the main reasons that support a claim.


In the second column, “Evidence/Details,” write relevant information and facts that support the reasons or address an opposing claim.


In the third column, “Questions, Concerns, Insights, Connections,” record notes about how the information will be used in writing.


In the final column, “Sources,” identify the source. Include author; title of article, book, and/or website; date published and or/accessed online.


Study and discuss the completed four-column notes below with your pen pal.



Now that you have seen an example of four-column notes, work with your pen pal to answer questions using sources.


Hint: use the EITHER-OR strategy from Lesson 1 to think of different types of evidence that can support your claims!


Complete the Questions for Part 2 before moving on to Part 3!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)



Not all sources are created equal! While many internet searches result in tens of thousands of “hits,” many of these sources may not actually be reliable. Anyone can post anything on the Internet. A site might appear to be true or accurate, but it could contain errors or bias, or it could be completely false! Information on the internet can also be old and outdated, just as information in print.  


Five main types of extensions found in web addresses are: .com (commercial), .edu (education), .gov (government), .net (network), and .org (organization). You should generally use .edu, .gov, or .org sites as sources when conducting research.


Writers will also use check-lists like the one below to assess digital sources.



Complete the questions located at the bottom of this page! After answering each of your questions, read and respond to your pen pal’s answers!



Word

Definition

draft

(noun) a preliminary or early version of a piece of writing that is not final

research

(verb) to investigate

source

(noun) a place, person, or thing where information can be found

topic

(noun) the main idea of a report or paragraph

word processor

(noun) a computer program used for writing a text

research

(verb) to investigate

source

(noun) a place, person, or thing where information can be found

topic

(noun) the main idea of a report or paragraph

word processor

(noun) a computer program used for writing a text
