title: Rock the Vote
body_one:
Rock the Vote


The right to vote is very important. When you vote, you help make important decisions about the future of our country.


Many people think that the process voting can be confusing. In fact, less than 40% of voters decided to participate in the 2014 election.


So let’s learn about voting! Who can vote? What can you vote for? How can you make sure your voice is heard?



A voter is:

  • 18 years or older

  • A United States citizen and resident of the state where they are voting

  • Has voter Identification such as:

    • Drivers License

    • State-issued ID card

    • Passport

    • Credit or debit card

    • Student ID

    • Military ID


People can vote on a many important issue. Voters can pick a candidate such as the president, a governor, or a member of the school board. Voters can also vote for a ballot measure. A ballot measure is a piece of proposed law or rule.


Voters can vote on the following topics and positions:

Federal

State*

Municipal*


  • President of the United States

  • United States Senator

  • United States Representative

  • Governor

  • Lieutenant Governor

  • Attorney General

  • Comptroller of Public Accounts

  • Judge (supreme court)

  • Judge (court of appeals)

  • State Representative

  • State Senator

  • Amendments to state constitution

  • Mayor

  • Council members

  • Propositions and amendments to the city’s charter

  • School Board members

  • Comptroller

  • Clerks

  • Bonds

  • Sheriff

*state and municipal positions and ballot measures often differ by state, county, and city


A sample ballot from the 2012 General Election


Be a Volunteer


In an election, every vote matters. But what other ways can people make a difference in our democracy?


Martin Luther King Jr. influenced our democracy by organizing peaceful protests. These protests influenced voters and lawmakers to support equal rights for African Americans.


One way that you can participate in the democratic processes is as a volunteer. Young people volunteer to promote Voter Registration. Voter Registration volunteers help people register to vote. The simple act of making sure that people are eligible to vote can make a huge difference.


There are many different ways that people can register to vote


Another way you can help is by volunteering with a campaign. Campaigns support politicians, ballot measures, and a variety of causes. Campaigns welcome volunteers. Volunteers help campaigns share information with voters and help voters complete their registration forms.


Meet 2016 Presidential Candidates


Republican Candidate

Donald Trump

Experience: Businessman, author, and television personality.


Key Policies:

  • Opposes Common Core education standards

  • Does not believes in climate change

  • Wants to build a wall to protect border with Mexico


Quotation: “I try to learn from the past, but I plan for the future by focusing exclusively on the present. That's where the fun is.”


Democratic Candidate

Hillary Clinton

Experience: First Lady to President Bill Clinton, Senator from New York (2001-2009), Secretary of State to President Obama (2009-2013)


Key Policies:

  • Supports Common Core standards

  • Supports climate change research and environmental regulation

  • Proposes creating clean energy jobs

  • Supports comprehensive immigration reform


Quotation: “What we have to do... is to find a way to celebrate our diversity and debate our differences without fracturing our communities.”
body_two:
Rock the Vote


The right to vote is an important part of our democracy. When a person votes, they are helping to make important decisions about the future of our country.


While voting is very important, many people think that the process can sometimes be confusing. In fact, less than 40% of eligible voters voted in the 2014 election.


So let’s learn how we can become thoughtful voters. Who can vote? What kinds of things can a person vote for? And how can you, as a young person, make sure your voice is heard?



In order to vote, a voter must meet the following requirements:

  • 18 years of age or older

  • A United States citizen and resident of the state where they are voting

  • Voter Identification-many states have different requirements for voter identification while some states do not require voters to present any identification, others require one of the following documents:

    • Drivers License

    • State-issued ID card

    • Passport

    • Credit or debit card

    • Student ID

    • Military ID


When people enter a voting booth they can vote on a many important issue. By electing a candidate at the federal, state, or municipal level voters hope that the person they vote for will make decisions that they agree with once in office.


Voters can also choose individual ballot measures. A ballot measure is a piece of proposed legislation to be approved or rejected by eligible voters. Sometimes known as "propositions" or "questions", ballot measures allow people to influence democracy directly.


Voters can vote on the following issues and positions:

Federal

State*

Municipal*


  • President of the United States

  • United States Senator

  • United States Representative

  • Governor

  • Lieutenant Governor

  • Attorney General

  • Comptroller of Public Accounts

  • Judge (supreme court)

  • Judge (court of appeals)

  • State Representative

  • State Senator

  • Amendments to state constitution

  • Mayor

  • Council members

  • Propositions and amendments to the city’s charter

  • School Board members

  • Comptroller

  • Clerks

  • Bonds

  • Sheriff

*state and municipal positions and ballot measures often differ by state, county, and city


A sample ballot from the 2012 General Election


Support Your Cause - Be a Volunteer


Every vote counts in an election, but what other ways can people make a difference in our democracy?


Martin Luther King Jr. influenced the political system by using peaceful protests to influence voters and lawmakers to support equal rights for African Americans.


Former Vice Presidential Candidate Al Gore uses websites to help voters learn about important environment and climate change.


One way that you can help the democratic processes is through volunteering.  Young people volunteer to promote Voter Registration. Voter Registration volunteers pass-out Voter Registration applications and help people to complete these short forms. The simple act of making sure that people are eligible to vote can make a huge difference.


There are many different ways that people can register to vote


Another way you can help is by volunteering with a campaign. Working for a campaign is a way for an individual to directly support politicians, ballot measures, and a variety of causes. Campaigns welcome volunteers. Volunteers help campaigns share information with voters about issues, candidates, and the voter registration process.


Meet the 2016 Presidential Candidates


Republican Candidates

Donald Trump

Experience: Businessman, author, and television personality


Key Policies:

  • Supports local control of education initiatives and opposes Common Core standards

  • Does not believe in climate change

  • Wants to build a wall to protect border with Mexico

  • Plans to legalize drugs and use tax revenue on education


Quotation: “I try to learn from the past, but I plan for the future by focusing exclusively on the present. That's where the fun is.”

Mike Pence

(VP Candidate)

Experience: Governor of Indiana (2013-present), US House of Representatives (2001-2013)


Key Policies:

  • Opposes federal involvement in education policy and Common Core standards

  • Supports expanding charter schools and voucher programs

  • Does not believe in climate change

  • Supports building a fence along border with Mexico and ending birthright citizenship for immigrants

  • Supports more funding to fight war on drugs


Quotation: “In my home state of Indiana we prove every day that you can build a growing economy on balanced budgets and low taxes.”


Democratic Candidates

Hillary Clinton

Experience: First Lady to President Bill Clinton, Senator from New York (2001-2009), Secretary of State to President Barack Obama (2009-2013)


Key Policies:

  • Supports Common Core standards

  • Supports climate change research and environmental regulation

  • Proposes creating clean energy jobs

  • Supports comprehensive immigration reform


Quotation: “What we have to do... is to find a way to celebrate our diversity and debate our differences without fracturing our communities.”

Tim Kaine

(VP Candidate)

Experience: Senator from Virginia (2013-present), Governor of Virginia (2006-2010), Mayor of Richmond, Virginia (1998-2001)


Key Policies:

  • Support Common Core standards, free community college, and early childhood education

  • Acknowledges climate change and support sea level resilience planning

  • Supports an immigration system that attracts and retains talented workers


Quotation: “We have got to advance opportunity for everybody, no matter where you come from, how much money you have, what you look like, how you worship or who you love.”
body_three:
Rock the Vote


The right to vote is a cornerstone of our society.  Many people, however, have pointed out that the requirements and process can sometimes be confusing and overwhelming. Who can vote? What kinds of things can a person vote for? How can you, as a young person, make sure your voice is heard?



When people enter a voting booth they can often make a decision that will affect the political system in two different ways. By electing a candidate at the federal, state, or municipal level voters hope that the person they vote for will make decisions that they agree with once in office.


Most candidates fight hard for their party's nomination. Today, many politicians make this their life's work as they move from city, to state, to national office.


Another way to vote is by voting on individual ballot measures. A ballot measure is a piece of proposed legislation to be approved or rejected by eligible voters. Sometimes known as "propositions" or "questions", ballot measures allow people to influence democracy directly. Ballot measures differ from most legislation passed by representative democracies; ordinarily, an elected legislature develops and passes laws.


In order to vote, a voter must meet the following requirements:

  • 18 years of age or older

  • A United States citizen and resident of the state where they are voting

  • Voter Identification-many states have different requirements for voter identification while some states do not require voters to present any identification, others require one of the following documents:

    • Drivers License

    • State-issued ID card

    • Passport

    • Credit or debit card

    • Student ID

    • Military ID


Voters can vote on the following issues and positions:

Federal

State*

Municipal*


  • President of the United States

  • United States Senator

  • United States Representative

  • Governor

  • Lieutenant Governor

  • Attorney General

  • Comptroller of Public Accounts

  • Judge (supreme court)

  • Judge (court of appeals)

  • State Representative

  • State Senator

  • Amendments to state constitution

  • Mayor

  • Council members

  • Propositions and amendments to the city’s charter

  • School Board members

  • Comptroller

  • Clerks

  • Bonds

  • Sheriff

*state and municipal positions and ballot measures often differ by state, county, and city


A sample ballot from the 2012 General Election


Support Your Cause - Be a Volunteer


Every vote counts in an election, but what other ways can people influence the political process? While voting is an important part of influencing the democratic system in the United States, there are many ways that people participate in the democratic process.


Martin Luther King Jr. influenced the political system by using peaceful civil disobedience and public protests to influence voters and lawmakers to support equal rights for African Americans.


Former Vice Presidential Candidate Al Gore uses websites to notify voters about important election topics regarding the environment and climate change.


One way that you can help the democratic processes is through volunteering.  Many young people volunteer to promote Voter Registration. Voter Registration distributors distribute Voter Registration applications and assist people in completing the voter registration process. The simple act of making sure that people are eligible to vote can make a huge difference.


There are many different ways that people can register to vote


Another way to get involved is by volunteering to help a candidate's campaign. Working for a campaign is a way for an individual to directly support politicians, ballot measures, and a variety of causes. Campaigns welcome volunteers. Volunteers help campaigns informing voters about specific issues, candidates, and the voter registration process.


Real Life Example


Teresa Cheng, now 26, first became involved in labor rights activism at the University of Southern California, where she led an anti-sweatshop campaign that culminated in the occupation of the university president’s office.


As a national organizer for United Students Against Sweatshops (USAS), she trained and coordinated a network of student labor organizations across the country that waged several successful campaigns in solidarity with unions to demand that global corporations respect workers’ rights.


One of Cheng’s first efforts was to mobilize a national campaign to pressure Russell Athletics, which produces college-licensed apparel, to rehire 1,200 Honduran workers who it had fired after they voted to unionize. USAS also picketed the National Basketball Association (NBA) finals in Orlando, Fla., and Los Angeles to protest the NBA’s licensing agreement with Russell.


Young people across the country take action to support causes they support


In addition, students distributed leaflets inside Sports Authority stores and sent Twitter messages to customers of the Dick’s Sporting Goods chain, urging them to boycott Russell products. Cheng helped arrange a letter, signed by 65 members of Congress, that voiced “grave concern about reports of severe violations” of workers’ rights at Russell. Russell agreed to rehire the workers and open a new plant in Honduras as a unionized factory and also pledged not to fight efforts by workers to unionize at the company’s seven other factories in the country.


Working through USAS, Cheng helped mobilize student activists on about 100 campuses to persuade their universities to sever licensing agreements with Russell.


Meet the 2016 Presidential Candidates


Republican Candidates

Donald Trump

Experience: Businessman, author, and television personality


Key Policies:

  • Supports local control of education initiatives and opposes Common Core standards

  • Does not believe in climate change

  • Wants to build a wall to protect border with Mexico

  • Plans to legalize drugs and use tax revenue on education


Quotation: “I try to learn from the past, but I plan for the future by focusing exclusively on the present. That's where the fun is.”

Mike Pence

(VP Candidate)

Experience: Governor of Indiana (2013-present), US House of Representatives (2001-2013)


Key Policies:

  • Opposes federal involvement in education policy and Common Core standards

  • Supports expanding charter schools and voucher programs

  • Does not believe in climate change

  • Supports building a fence along border with Mexico and ending birthright citizenship for immigrants

  • Supports more funding to fight war on drugs


Quotation: “In my home state of Indiana we prove every day that you can build a growing economy on balanced budgets and low taxes.”


Democratic Candidates

Hillary Clinton

Experience: First Lady to President Bill Clinton, Senator from New York (2001-2009), Secretary of State to President Barack Obama (2009-2013)


Key Policies:

  • Supports Common Core standards

  • Supports climate change research and environmental regulation

  • Proposes creating clean energy jobs

  • Supports comprehensive immigration reform


Quotation: “What we have to do... is to find a way to celebrate our diversity and debate our differences without fracturing our communities.”

Tim Kaine

(VP Candidate)

Experience: Senator from Virginia (2013-present), Governor of Virginia (2006-2010), Mayor of Richmond, Virginia (1998-2001)


Key Policies:

  • Support Common Core standards, free community college, and early childhood education

  • Acknowledges climate change and support sea level resilience planning

  • Supports an immigration system that attracts and retains talented workers


Quotation: “We have got to advance opportunity for everybody, no matter where you come from, how much money you have, what you look like, how you worship or who you love.”


Third Party Candidates

Jill Stein

Party: Green Party


Experience: Doctor and graduate from Harvard School of Medicine, Presidential candidate (2012)


Key Policies:

  • Supports federal economic stimulus and baking regulation

  • Supports single-payer public health system

  • Opposes Common Core and Charter Schools

  • Supports environmental restoration

  • Proposes extending the DREAM Act and paths towards legal immigration


Quotation: “Social movements working together with independent political parties have always made history together.”

Gary Johnson

Party: Libertarian Party


Experience: Businessman, Governor of New Mexico (1995-2003), Presidential candidate (2012)


Key Policies:

  • Opposes bailout of banks and financial institutions

  • Proposes cutting federal budget by 43%

  • Supports education reform including vouchers for students

  • Supports clean energy

  • Supports grace period for undocumented immigrants to get visas


Quotation: “Everything that I did as Governor, and everything that I think needs to occur right now in the Federal Government, needs to be a cost-benefit analysis. What are we spending our money on, and what are we getting for what we're spending?”

title: Art and Literature
body_one:
Art is all around you. Art is on the street. Art is in museums. Art is even in your own home! Paintings and murals are great examples of art. Buildings and house are also examples of art. Art is everywhere and tells the story of the people who make it.


Credit: kenwalton via flickr


You can find art in many different places!


Why do people create art? Art helps some people share their feelings. Art helps other people share information and opinions. In Mexico, the muralist Diego Rivera used art to talk about politics and life.



Art & Architecture


The Middle East has many famous artists and works of art. Many of the most well-known buildings in the Middle East have a religious significance. Many of these buildings are churches, mosques, and temples.


The Hagia Sophia in Turkey was built in 587 CE as a church. The building was then used as mosque. Now, the Hagia Sophia is a museum. The Hagia Sophia has a massive dome and four tall towers. The changing story of the Hagia Sophia reflects changes in Turkish culture.


A brand new building in the Middle East is the Burj Khalifa. The Burj Khalifa is in the city of Dubai. Built from 2004 to 2009 CE, the Burj Khalifa has over two hundred floors. The Burj Khalifa is the tallest building in the world. When designing the Burj Khalifa, architects wanted to create a symbol for the modern city.


Credit: tipsfortravellers via flickr


The Burj Khalifa in Dubai is the tallest building in the world at 2,722 feet.


The Taj Mahal is a famous building in South Asia. The Taj Mahal is a white marble mausoleum built from 1632-1653 CE. The Taj Mahal was designed by an emperor. The tall towers and ornamental domes took over twenty thousand workers and one thousand elephants to build. Over three million people visit the Taj Mahal every year.


Credit: archer10 via flickr


The Taj Mahal in Uttar Pradesh, India.


Credit: lfphotos via flickr


Across the Middle East, Europe, and Asia, mosaics are found in religions buildings.


In Europe, cathedrals are beautiful examples of architecture. Cathedrals have tall ceilings, colorful glass windows, and ornate sculptures.


Credit: celso via flickr


Notre Dame is a famous French cathedral built in the Gothic style.


Painting and Sculpture


Some of the most famous writers and artists over the past two hundred years were born in the United States. In the 1700 and 1800s CE, artists traveled across the United States and painted landscapes. These artists would travel to the Grand Canyon and the Rocky Mountains. They would paint nature and share their paintings with people across the country.



Paintings like ‘Among the Sierra Nevada Mountains, California’ were made by a group of American Painters called the Hudson River School.


Andy Warhol (1928-1987 CE) created paintings, prints and videos. Warhol's art became known as Pop Art. Warhol used objects from advertisements in his prints.


Credit: Warhol Museum


Andy Warhol turned everyday objects into prints.


The Ghanaian sculptor El Anatsui is a famous artist. El Anatsui creates large mosaics from used bottle tops, printing plates, and roofing sheets. El Anatsui wants viewers to think about the things we buy, the things we waste, and the environment.


Credit: seeminglee via flickr


El Anatsui makes sculptures using aluminium bottle tops sewn together with copper wire.


Written and Performance Art


Artists tell beautiful stories. These stories share important messages. The Mahabharata is an ancient Sanskrit story that tells the tales of ancient India. The oldest parts of the story are almost 2,500 years old!


Credit: wikimediacommons via flickr


This picture shows a battle between mongoose and serpent armies from a Mahabharata story.


Music and dance are important types art. Many Latin American dances are popular in around the world. Shakira and Juanes are famous Latin American musicians from Colombia. Celia Cruz is a famous musician from Cuba. Celia Cruz is the Queen of Salsa!



Celia Cruz won eight Grammy Awards throughout her career.


Dance is a part of life for many people. The Bachata and Merengue are dances from the Dominican Republic. The Cha Cha and Mambo are popular dances from Cuba. Exploring Latin American dance is not only a fun activity but a great way to exercise!


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

mausoleum

noun: a building or burial chamber used to store tombs

mosaic

noun: a picture made from smaller pieces

mural

noun: a painting made directly on a wall

opinion

noun: a view about a topic that may not be a fact

to reflect

verb: to represent something


Meet Your PenPal!
body_two:
When you walk down the street or drive across town, you have many chances to see art. Art surrounds us and is not limited to what you might find in a museum. Paintings and murals are great examples of art. But so are the buildings that house the paintings. Art is everywhere and reflective of the people who make it.


Credit: kenwalton via flickr


Art can be found in many different places and in many different forms.


So why do people create art? For many people, art helps them to express their feelings in a healthy and creative way. For others, art is a way to share information and opinions. In Mexico, the muralist Diego Rivera used art to talk about politics and the economy.


Art & Architecture


In the Middle East, artists have a tradition of creating objects that represent their culture. Many of the most well-known buildings in the Middle East have a religious significance. Many of these buildings are churches, mosques, and temples.


The Hagia Sophia in Turkey, for example, was built in 587 CE as a church. The building was then converted into a mosque, and is now a museum. The Hagia Sophia has a massive dome and towering minarets. The changing story of the Hagia Sophia reflects changes in Turkish culture and politics.


A brand new building found in the Middle East is the Burj Khalifa located in the city of Dubai. Built from 2004 to 2009 CE, the Burj Khalifa has over two hundred floors and is the tallest building in the world. In designing the Burj Khalifa, architects wanted to create a symbol that represents national pride and the modern city.


Credit: tipsfortravellers via flickr


The Burj Khalifa in Dubai, United Arab Emirates is the tallest building in the world at 2,722 feet.


Few works of art in South Asia are as recognizable as the architectural marvels of India. The Taj Mahal, is a white marble mausoleum built from 1632-1653 CE. The building was designed by an emperor to house the tomb of his favorite wife. The soaring towers and ornamental domes took over twenty thousand workers and a thousand elephants to build. Over three million people visit the Taj Mahal every year.


Credit: archer10 via flickr


The Taj Mahal in Uttar Pradesh, India is an outstanding example of South Asian architecture.


Credit: lfphotos via flickr


Across the Middle East, Europe, and Asia, mosaics like the one above from the Sheikh Loftollah Mosque in Isfahan, Iran are common features in religions buildings.


In Europe, cathedrals are impressive examples of architecture. Cathedrals have tall ceilings, colorful glass windows, and ornate sculptures. Architects design cathedrals to make their visitors feel awe and humility.


Credit: celso via flickr


Notre Dame is a famous French cathedral built in the Gothic style.


Painting and Sculpture


Some of the most famous writers and artists over the last two hundred years were born in the United States. In the 1700 and 1800s CE, artists traveled the United States and painted landscapes. These artists would travel to the Grand Canyon and the Rocky Mountains. They would paint these subjects and share them with people across the country.



Paintings like ‘Among the Sierra Nevada Mountains, California’ were made by a group of American Painters called the Hudson River School.


Some of the most famous artists from the United States lived in the 20th century.  Jackson Pollock (1912-1956 CE) was an abstract expressionist. Pollock painted with action, dribbling colors and splashing paint across the canvas. Through his work, Pollock hoped to show nature, movement and complex emotions.


Andy Warhol (1928-1987 CE) created paintings, prints, videos, and art installations. Warhol's art became known as Pop Art because he often used images and objects found in advertisements in his prints and paintings.


Credit: Warhol Museum


Andy Warhol turned everyday objects into prints.


Countries across the African continent also have many important Contemporary artists. African art is featured in museums around the world. One particularly famous African artist is the Ghanaian sculptor El Anatsui. El Anatsui creates large mosaics from used bottle tops, printing plates, and roofing sheets. His works help viewers reflect on consumption, waste, and the environment.


Credit: seeminglee via flickr


El Anatsui makes sculptures using aluminium bottle tops sewn together with copper wire.


Written and Performance Art


Artists use their words to tell beautiful stories. These stories share important messages. The Mahabharata is an ancient Sanskrit epic that tells the tales of ancient India. The oldest parts of the text are almost 2,500 years old! The Mahabharata combines written and visual art into a beautifully illustrated epic.


Credit: wikimediacommons via flickr


This picture shows a battle between mongoose and serpent armies from a Mahabharata story.


The author Isabel Allende is a famous writer from Chile. Her novels include ‘The House of Spirits’ and the ‘City of the Beasts.’ Allende won the Chilean National Prize for Literature as well as the Presidential Medal of Freedom from Barack Obama.



Music and dance are important types of performance art across Latin America. In fact, many Latin American forms of dance are popular in countries around the world. Famous Latin American musicians include Colombian born musicians like Shakira and Juanes. Celia Cruz is a famous musician from Cuba. Many people consider Cruz as the undisputed queen of salsa.



Celia Cruz won eight Grammy Awards throughout her career.


Dance is also a part of life for many people around the world. In Latin America, popular dance styles include Bachata and Merengue from the Dominican Republic, the Cha Cha and Mambo from Cuba, and the Brazilian Samba. Exploring Latin American dance styles is not only a fun activity but a great way to exercise!


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

convert

verb: to change something from one thing to something else

epic

noun: a long poem or story

mausoleum

noun: a building or burial chamber used to store tombs

minaret

noun: a tall tower

mural

noun: a painting made directly on a wall

ornamental

adjective: when something is used for decoration
body_three:
When you walk down the street or drive across town, you may not realize it but there are countless opportunities to observe and study art. Art surrounds us and certainly is not limited to what you might find in a museum. From paintings and murals, to the buildings themselves, art is everywhere and reflective of the people who make it.


Credit: kenwalton via flickr


Art can be found in many different places and in many different forms.


So why do people create art? For many people, art helps them to express their thoughts and feelings in a healthy and creative way. For others, art is a way to share information and opinions. In Mexico, the muralist Diego Rivera used art to comment on the political and economic conditions of his time.


Art & Architecture


Art is the expression of creative skill and imagination into a visual or physical form. Around the world, many of the most interesting pieces of art are buildings, monuments and structures.


In the Middle East, for example, artists have a long and rich tradition of creating objects that represent their culture. Many of the most well-known buildings across the Middle East have religious significance. These buildings take the form of churches, mosques and temples.


The Hagia Sophia in Turkey, for example, was built in 587 CE as a church. The building was then converted into a mosque, and is now a museum. It is distinguished by its massive dome and towering minarets. The story of the Hagia Sophia reflects changes in Turkish culture and politics.


A brand new building in the Middle East is the The Burj Khalifa located in the city of Dubai. Built from 2004 to 2009 CE, the Burj Khalifa has over two hundred floors and is currently the tallest building in the world. In designing the Burj Khalifa, architects wanted to create a symbol that represents national pride and the modern city.


Credit: tipsfortravellers via flickr


The Burj Khalifa in Dubai, United Arab Emirates is the tallest building in the world at 2,722 feet.


Few works of art in South Asia are as recognizable as the architectural marvels of India. The Taj Mahal, is a white marble mausoleum built from 1632-1653 CE. The building was designed by an emperor to house the tomb of his favorite wife. The soaring towers and ornamental domes took over twenty thousand workers and a thousand elephants to build. Over three million people visit the Taj Mahal every year.


Credit: archer10 via flickr


The Taj Mahal in Uttar Pradesh, India is an outstanding example of South Asian architecture.


Credit: lfphotos via flickr


Across the Middle East, Europe, and Asia, mosaics like the one above from the Sheikh Loftollah Mosque in Isfahan, Iran are common features in religions buildings.


In Europe, cathedrals are among the region’s most impressive forms of architecture. From London’s St. Paul's Basilica and Westminster Abbey to St. Basil’s Cathedral in Moscow, Russia, cathedrals are breathtaking works of art. Their soaring ceilings, colorful stained glass, and ornate facades inspire awe in anyone who visits. In designing and constructing these significant buildings, architects hoped that visitors feel in the presence of God; both in awe of and humbled.


Credit: celso via flickr


Notre Dame is a famous French cathedral built in the Gothic style.


Painting and Sculpture


Some of the most famous writers and artists over the last two hundred years either worked in the United States or were born there. Across the young United States, early artists would travel the country and paint landscapes on large canvases. These artists would travel to the Grand Canyon of the American South West or visit the Native American tribes of the Great Plains. They would paint these subjects and share them with people across the country.



Paintings like ‘Among the Sierra Nevada Mountains, California’ were made by a group of American Painters called the Hudson River School.


Some of the most famous artists from the United States lived in the 20th century. These artists would be part of what became known as the Modern and Contemporary movements.


Jackson Pollock (1912-1956 CE) was an abstract expressionist who painted with action, dribbling colors and splashing paint across the canvas. Through his work, Pollock hoped to convey nature, movement and complex emotions.


Andy Warhol (1928-1987 CE) was an artist who worker across mediums. Warhol created paintings, prints, videos, and art installations. His style was to become known as Pop Art as he often used images and objects found in famous advertisements in his prints and paintings.


Credit: Warhol Museum


Andy Warhol turned everyday objects into thought-provoking prints.


Like the United States, countries across the African continent also have a vibrant Contemporary art scene. African art can be found in museums around the world. One particularly famous African artist, Ghanaian El Anatsui, creates large cloth-like mosaics from used bottle tops, printing plates, and roofing sheets. El Anatsui’s work has been featured in museums around the world from New York to Beijing.


Credit: seeminglee via flickr


El Anatsui makes sculptures using aluminium bottle tops sewn together with copper wire. His works help viewers reflect on consumption, waste, and the environment.


Written and Performance Art


Since the invention of oral language, artists have used their words to tell beautiful stories, share important messages, and create inspiring music. The Mahabharata, for example, is an ancient Sanskrit epic that tells the tales of ancient India. The oldest parts of the text are almost 2,500 years old! The Mahabharata itself combines written and visual art into a beautifully illustrated epic. The Mahabharata tells the tale of ancient rulers and heroes, epic wars, and how the Hindu deities shaped the world.


Credit: wikimediacommons via flickr


This picture depicts a battle between mongoose and serpent armies from a Mahabharata story.


The Argentine storyteller, author, essayist, and translator, Jorge Luis Borges, is perhaps one of the most important people in the history of Spanish Language Literature. Among his best known books are Ficciones (Fictions) and Aleph. In his works, Borges used fascinating and complex stories to explore topics from the political structure of Argentina to mathematics, philosophy, and religion.



The works of Chilean born author Isabel Allende contain elements of the magic realist tradition. Her most famous novels include ‘The House of Spirits’ and the ‘City of the Beasts.’ Allende won both the Chilean National Prize for Literature as well as the Presidential Medal of Freedom from Barack Obama in 2014.



Across South Asia, music, dance, theatre, and puppetry are very popular types of performance art. A common form of puppetry practiced in northern Afghanistan is called buz-bazi. Buz-bazi is a performance in which puppets dance to the accompaniment of the dambora, a long string instrument similar to a guitar.


In Nepal, theatre incorporates folk traditions, classic oral stories, and religious festivals. Today, the Nepali government sponsors and supports theatre and recently established the National Cultural Corporation and Academy of Dance and Drama.


Credit: kabulpublicdiplomacy via flickr


Traditional Afghan instruments like the damboora often accompany theatrical performances.


Music and dance are important types of performance art found across Latin America. In fact, many Latin American forms of dance are popular in countries around the world. Famous Latin American musicians include Colombian born musicians like Shakira and Juanes, Celia Cruz, the undisputed queen of salsa, and Gustavo Cerati, frontman of the Argentine pop-rock group Soda Stereo.



Celia Cruz won eight Grammy Awards throughout her career.


Dance is also a part of life for many people around the world. In Latin America, popular dance styles include Bachata and Merengue from the Dominican Republic, the Cha Cha and Mambo from Cuba, and the Brazilian Samba. Exploring Latin American dance styles is not only a fun activity but a great way to exercise!


Vocabulary


Word

Definition

to accompany

verb: to go with something else

canvas

noun: a strong cloth used for sails, tents, and painting

deity

noun: a god or goddess

facade

noun: the face or front of a building

installation

noun: a piece of art that takes up a large space

mausoleum

noun: a building or burial chamber used to store tombs

minaret

noun: a tall tower

mural

noun: a painting made directly on a wall

title: Discrimination Long Ago
body_one:
The Age of Discovery

Almost six hundred years ago European explorers went to different parts of the world.  These explorers looked for places where they could make money and build settlements. This was the Age of Discovery.


Dutch ships in Table Bay in the Cape Colony in the 18th century


In 1652 indigenous groups of people called the San and the Khoi lived in the southern Africa in a place called the Cape. The San and the Khoi were two groups of people who lived in southern Africa for a long time.


This map shows where the San and the Khoi lived


Dutch Settlements at the Cape

In 1651 Dutch explorers wanted to build a settlement at the Cape. On 6 April 1652, Jan van Riebeeck, a Dutch explorer, came to the Cape of Good Hope.

The Dutch took land from the Khoi and San people without permission.  The Dutch built their own farms and houses.  

When the Dutch needed help with work at the Cape, they tried to work with the Khoi people. The Khoi people did not want to work with the Dutch.  

When the Khoi disagreed with the Dutch, the Dutch people tried to turn the Khoi into slaves. From 1656 to 1673 the two groups fought in three Dutch–Khoi wars.


Soon after the Dutch arrived at the Cape, they began to take the Khoi people’s land.

Source: http://www.griquas.com


Discrimination in the Americas


Before the Age of Discovery, Europeans did not know that the Americas existed!

In October 1492, Christopher Columbus landed on an island in the Americas. Columbus thought that he was in a country called India. Columbus said the land now belonged to the King and Queen of Spain and the Catholic Faith.

On October 12 1492 Columbus first met the indigenous people called the Arawak. Because Columbus thought he was in India, he called the indigenous people Indians.

Columbus thought the indigenous people would be good servants.  Columbus decided to take six Arawak people 3 000 miles back to Spain for the King and Queen.

Columbus did not build a settlement in the Americas. In February 1495, Columbus captured 500 Arawak and took them back to Spain as slaves.

In 1493 the Arawak population was about 100,000 people; in 1570, 300 Arawak people survived.

Discrimination in Australia

In 1788, Europeans began to build settlements in Australia in a place called Botany Bay.

About 162 000 prisoners were sent from England and Ireland to Australia. Many of the prisoners were skilled workers and farmers. These prisoners were forced to spend seven years in Australia.

The first governor of this new colony was Captain Arthur Phillip. Phillip wanted to be friendly with the indigenous people called the Australian Aborigines.  Most of the prisoners treated the indigenous people cruelly and took their land.  

When the British first came to Australia, there were almost one million indigenous people living there. The Europeans brought diseases and fighting. In the early 21st century there were about 400 000 Aboriginal Australians left.

Vocabulary

Word

Definition

aboriginal

(adjective) indigenous


(noun) a local inhabitant of a place

indigenous people

(noun) people who have lived in an area from the time before that area was colonised

population

(noun) all the people who live in a town or area

servent

(noun) a person who works for another person

settlement

(noun) a place where people build a community
body_two:
South Africa in the 17th and 18th Centuries

From about 1450 to 1700 many European countries sent ships to different parts of the world.  These explorers were looking for places where they could trade, find resources, and build settlements. This period in history is called the Age of Discovery.

Dutch ships in Table Bay in the Cape Colony in the 18th century


Before the Dutch arrival to the Cape in 1652, indigenous groups of people called the San and the Khoi lived in the Cape. The San had lived in southern Africa for a long time.  Some historians think the San had lived in south Africa for almost 20 000 years. The Khoi arrived about 2 000 years before the Dutch.

This map shows where the San lived at the end of the 17th century and the possible routes the Khoi followed into southern Africa and the Cape


Dutch Settlements at the Cape

In 1651 the VOC (Dutch East India Company, in English) decided to build a permanent settlement at the Cape. On 6 April 1652, Jan van Riebeeck arrived at the Cape of Good Hope.

Because the Khoi and the San people could not prove they owned the land in the Cape (they had no written title deeds), the Dutch took parts of the land at the Cape without permission.  The Dutch built their own farms and houses.

When the Dutch needed extra labour at the Cape, they tried to employ the Khoi people. Very few of the Khoi people wanted to become labourers or workers for the Dutch. The Khoi resisted the Dutch as they tried to turn the Khoi into slaves. From 1656 to 1673 the two groups fought in three Dutch–Khoi wars.


Soon after the Dutch arrived at the Cape, they began to take the Khoi people’s land.

Source: http://www.griquas.com


Discrimination in the Americas

Before the Age of Discovery, Europeans did not know that there was a continent to the west. These Europeans had no idea that the Americas existed!

In October 1492, Christopher Columbus landed on an island in what would be known as the Caribbean Islands. Columbus thought that he had reached the coast of India. He claimed the island for the King and Queen of Spain and for the Catholic Faith.

On October 12 1492 Columbus had first met the indigenous people called the Arawak. Because Columbus thought he was in India, he called the indigenous people Indians. Columbus wrote in his journal that he thought the indigenous people would be good servants.  Columbus decided to take six Arawak people back to Spain for the King and Queen.

Columbus made four voyages to the Caribbean, but did not build a settlement. In February 1495, Columbus captured 500 Arawak and took them back to Spain. By 1496 Columbus had taken over the island of Hispaniola by force, and encouraged Spanish colonists to capture the indigenous people and make them slaves.

From the beginning, the Columbian legacy took its toll on the New World.  In 1493 the Arawak population had been approximately 100,000; in 1570, 300 Arawak people survived.

Discrimination in Australia

Although European sailors and explorers had been exploring Australia’s coastline since the early 1600s, colonisation only began in 1788. The First Fleet from Britain arrived in a place called Botany Bay on 26 January 1788.  These explored created the first British colony of New South Wales.

About 162 000 prisoners were sent from England and Ireland to Australia. Many of them were skilled workers and farmers. These prisoners were forced to spend seven years in Australia.  

The first governor of this new colony was Captain Arthur Phillip. Phillip planned to be friendly to the indigenous people, the Australian Aborigines.  Most settlers, however, regarded the indigenous people of Australia as less than human and treated them with cruelty.

During the first 140 years of Australian colonial history, settlers took the land occupied by Aboriginal Australians.  The British colonial leaders even declared Australia terra nullius – unoccupied territory.

When the British arrived on the Australian continent, the total indigenous population was between 750 000 and 1 million Aboriginal Australians.  The Europeans brought diseases and conflict. The white settlers were interested in taking more and more land from the indigenous people. In the early 21st century, Aboriginal Australians were estimated to number around 400 000.

These young boys were removed from their families because they  were ‘mixed-race’.

Source: Mapoon boys, Church parade, c.1900, John Oxley Library, State Library of Queensland


From 1905-1969, the Australian government took ‘mixed-race’ children from their families and put them into institutions or foster homes. The government argued that these children were not safe with their families.  The government forced these children to learn about ‘white Australian society’. The children on this programme became known as ‘the Stolen Generation’.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

aboriginal

(adjective) indigenous


(noun) a local inhabitant of a place

claim

(verb) to say something is a fact (often) without having proof

colonisation

(noun) when outsiders from another country settle among the indigenous people and create political and economic control

conflict

(noun) a disagreement or clash between people or groups

employ

(verb) to provide or offer a job

indigenous people

(noun) people who have lived in an area from the time before that area was colonised

resist

(verb) to withstand something; to not accept a change

settlement

(noun) a place where people build a community
body_three:
South Africa in the 17th and 18th Centuries: Discrimination in the Cape

From about 1450 to 1700 many European countries sent ships to different parts of the world in order to find places where they could trade, get raw materials, and build settlements. This period in history is called the Age of Discovery.

Dutch ships in Table Bay in the Cape Colony in the 18th century


Before the Dutch arrival to the Cape in 1652, indigenous groups of people called the San and the Khoi lived a semi-nomadic lifestyle in the Cape. The San had already been living in southern Africa for a long time, possibly longer than 20 000 years. The Khoi arrived about 2 000 years before the Dutch.

This map shows where the San lived at the end of the 17th century and the possible routes the Khoi followed into southern Africa and the Cape.


The San people had survived since the Stone Age. The lifestyle of the San hunter-gatherers remained undisturbed for thousands of years  The Khoi prospered at the Cape until the arrival of the Dutch in 1652.

Permanent Dutch Settlement at the Cape

In 1651 the VOC (Dutch East India Company, in English) issued instructions that a Dutch outpost must be established at the Cape. On 6 April 1652, Jan van Riebeeck arrived at the Cape of Good Hope to establish a VOC outpost.

Because the Khoi and the San people could not prove they owned the land in the Cape (they had no written title deeds), the Dutch started appropriating parts of the land at the Cape to start their own farms and build their own houses.

When the Dutch needed extra labour at the Cape, they tried to employ the Khoi people. Very few of the Khoi people, however, were willing to become labourers because the Khoi were economically independent. The Khoi strongly resisted Dutch attempts to turn them into slaves and appropriate their land.  From 1656 to 1673 there were three Dutch–Khoi wars.

This conflict led to the beginning of the Khoi resistance against the Dutch invasion and theft of their land.  The Khoi resistance continued until the Khoi War of Independence (1799–1803) when the Khoi were finally defeated.

Soon after the Dutch arrived at the Cape, they began to take the Khoi people’s land.

Source: http://www.griquas.com


Discrimination in the Americas

Although Europeans had some knowledge of Africa during the Age of Discovery – they did not know that there was a continent to the west. They had no idea that the Americas existed!

In October 1492 Christopher Columbus landed on an island, one of those today known as the Caribbean Islands, that he named San Salvador. He believed that he had reached the coast of India. He ordered his men to ‘bear witness’ that he was taking possession of the island for the King and Queen of Spain and for the Catholic Faith.

On October 12 1492 Columbus had his first encounter with the indigenous people, the Arawak. Because he thought he had reached India, Columbus called them Indians. He wrote in his journal that he thought they would be good servants and that he would take six back to Spain for the King and Queen. He also noted how friendly and generous they were to the Spanish who had landed on their island.

Columbus made four voyages to the Caribbean, but did not establish a lasting colony. He also did not find the wealth that he had hoped for. Disappointed, he planned to capture the Arawak and ship them to Spain as slaves to try to make money that way. The Queen refused permission, but in spite of that, in February 1495, Columbus captured some 500 Arawak and took them back to Spain. By 1496 Columbus had taken over the island of Hispaniola by force, and encouraged Spanish colonists to carry out slaving raids.

From the beginning, the Columbian legacy took its toll on the New World.  Forced labour, disease, and starvation rapidly killed off the indigenous people of Hispaniola (modern Haiti).

In 1493 the Arawak population had been approximately 100 000; in 1570, 300 people survived.

Discrimination in Australia

Although European sailors and explorers had been exploring Australia’s coastline since the early 1600s, colonisation only began in 1788 when the First Fleet from Britain arrived in Botany Bay on 26 January 1788, marking the foundation of the British colony of New South Wales. About 162 000 male and female convicts were sent from England and Ireland to Australia. Many of them were skilled tradesmen or farmers who had been convicted for minor crimes and sentenced to seven years transportation, the period of time needed to establish a colony.

The first governor of the new colony was Captain Arthur Phillip. His plan was to establish friendly relations with the Australian Aborigines and to try to reform as well as discipline the convicts transported to the colony. However, whatever Captain Phillip’s intentions had been towards the Aboriginal Australians, they were never carried out. The vast majority of the settlers regarded the indigenous people of Australia as less than human and treated them accordingly.

The first 140 years of Australian colonial history was marked by conflict and dispossession. Settlers took the land occupied by Aboriginal Australians and, in spite of the presence of indigenous people, the British colonial authorities declared Australia terra nullius – unoccupied territory.

When the British arrived on the Australian continent, the total indigenous population is believed to have been between 750 000 and 1 million Aboriginal Australians, but they were devastated by introduced diseases and by the conflicts that occurred as white settlers claimed more and more land. In the early 21st century, Aboriginal Australians were estimated to number around 400 000.

These young boys were removed from their families with the intention of assimilating them into white society

Source: Mapoon boys, Church parade, c.1900, John Oxley Library, State Library of Queensland


Discriminatory policies included the forced removal of ‘mixed-race’ children from their families and putting them into institutions or foster homes. The purpose was to assimilate these individuals into white Australian society. ‘Extermination’ was seen to be ‘breeding out’ aboriginal blood and creating a white population over several generations. The children on this programme became known as ‘the stolen generation’.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

aboriginal

(adjective) indigenous


(noun) a local inhabitant of a place. It is believed that the aboriginal inhabitants of Australia migrated from the African continent around 70 000 years ago, and arrived in Australia around 50 000 years ago.

colonisation

(noun) when outsiders from another country settle among the indigenous people of a country and establish political and economic control over them.

indigenous people

(noun) people who have lived in an area from the time before that area was colonised

title: My Country Is Tibet
body_one:
Watch the film MY COUNTRY IS TIBET to learn about the teenage king of Tibet. Trichen helps us meet his friends, family, and community. Trichen is fighting to save their way of life and identity. Talk with your PenPals about home and the importance of family history. Explore how refugees are treated around the world.



Trichen is the 17 year old boy who tells the story in My Country Is Tibet. Trichen is the exiled, teenage King of Tibet. Trichen introduces us to his friends, family and community members living in exile in India. They struggle to save their culture, their language, and their freedom to choose where they live and work.



Trichen is the descendant of the great Kings of Tibet. Trichen is a young Tibetans caught today between the peaceful traditions of Tibetan Buddhism and a desperate desire to fight for freedom.




Tibet is on a high plateau between China and India. It is nicknamed "the Roof of the World!” Tibet is located in the Himalayan mountains. Many of Asia’s important rivers start in tibet.



The Dalai Lama, who is the Buddhist religious leader, also used to rule Tibet. In 1951 the Chinese Army entered Tibet and took control. In 1959, Tibet became a dangerous place for the Dalai Lama and he fled to India.  Today, many Tibetan refugees live in India.






In 1950, China’s army entered Tibet. Over the next decade, China fought Tibetan opposition. Fearing capture, the Dalai Lama fled the country to India.


In 1965, the area of Tibet that had previously been under the control of the Dalai Lama became called the Tibet Autonomous Region (TAR). Tibet is now controlled by the Chinese Communist Party.



In 1959, after the Dalai Lama left Tibet for India, the Indian government agreed to accept Tibetan refugees. The Dalai Lama and the Tibetan government-in-exile are now based in Dharamsala, India.


Today, the Chinese government does not let Tibetans practice their religion. Tibetans can not even have pictures of the Dalai Lama. Tibetan refugees who are exiled in other countries want to learn the Tibetan religion and language, which were banned in their native country by China.


There are an estimated 150,000 Tibetans living in exile.




Word

Definition

conflict

(noun) a disagreement that often results in violence

descendent

(adj) the children of a particular ancestor

exile

(noun, verb) the state of kicked out from and not allowed to return to one’s native country

refugee

(noun) a person who flees for safety
body_two:
Watch the film MY COUNTRY IS TIBET to learn about Namgyal Wangchuk Trichen Lhagyari, the teenage king of Tibet. Trichen (pronounced ‘TREE-chen’) introduces us to his friends, family, and community. They are fighting to save their way of life and identity. As you explore Trichen’s story, talk with your PenPals about home and the importance of family history. Then work with your PenPals to explore how refugees are treated around the world.



Namgyal Wangchuk Trichen Lhagyari is the 17 year old narrator of My Country Is Tibet. My Country is Tibet tells Trichen’s story. He is the exiled, teenage King of Tibet. Trichen (pronounced ‘TREE-chen’) introduces us to his friends, family and community members living in exile in India. They struggle to save their culture, their languages, and their freedom to choose where they live and work.



Trichen is the direct descendant of the great Kings of Tibet. As a teenager, Trichen belongs to a new generation of young Tibetans caught today between the peaceful traditions of Tibetan Buddhism and a desperate desire to fight for their freedom and cultural identity.




Tibet is on a high plateau between China and India. It is nicknamed "the Roof of the World” because Tibet is located among the Himalayan mountains. Many of Asia’s important rivers begin in tibet including the Yellow River, the Yangtze River, and the Indus River.



Traditionally, the Buddhist religious leader, the Dalai Lama, was the leader of Tibet. But conflict between Tibet and China is part of the history of the region. In 1951 the Chinese Army claimed control of Tibet. In 1959, the Dalai Lama fled from Tibet to India, where many Tibetan refugees now live.  The Tibetan government-in-exile is located in India.




Population

Tibetan (2.5 million) Han Chinese (160 thousand)

Languages

Tibetan, Mandarin, English, Nepali, Hindi

Literacy Rate*

Tibetan (50%)

Major Industries

Agriculture (85%), Manufacture (3%), Geological prospecting (1%)

*age 6+ who can read & write




In 1950, China’s People’s Liberation Army entered Tibet. Over the next decade, China fought Tibetan opposition. Fearing capture, the Dalai Lama fled the country to India.


In 1965, the area of Tibet that had previously been under the control of the Dalai Lama became called the Tibet Autonomous Region (TAR). Tibet is now controlled by the Chinese Communist Party.



In 1959, after the Dalai Lama left Tibet for India, the Indian government agreed to accept Tibetan refugees. The Dalai Lama and the Tibetan government-in-exile are now based in Dharamsala, India.


Today, the Chinese government denies Tibetans space to practice their religion. Tibetans are not allowed to study their religion. They can’t even have pictures of their spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama. Many Tibetan refugees are people seeking a Tibetan education.


There are an estimated 150,000 Tibetans living in exile with the largest communities living in India, Nepal, and Bhutan.



  1. Host a debate party. Ask guests to share what they know about political refugees. What refugees are you aware of? How did you learn about them? What rights do refugees have? What rights do refugees not have? Who are the refugees in your local community? What can individuals/communities do to help?


Hand out half-page flyers with information about the UN Refugee Agency (www.unhcr.org) so that they can get involved in the issues you've discussed together.




Word

Definition

conflict

(noun) a disagreement that often results in violence

descendant

(adj) the children of a particular ancestor

exile

(noun, verb) the state of kicked out from and not allowed to return to one’s native country

refugee

(noun) a person who flees for safety
body_three:
Watch the film MY COUNTRY IS TIBET to learn about Namgyal Wangchuk Trichen Lhagyari, the teenage king of Tibet. Trichen (pronounced ‘TREE-chen’) introduces us to his friends, family and community members living in exile in India. We see their efforts to overcome the obliteration of their very identity – their culture, their languages, their freedom to choose where they live and work. As you explore his story, talk with your PenPals about home, the importance of family history. Then work with your PenPals to explore the treatment of refugees both in your community and around the world.



Filmed, directed and narrated by 17-year-old Namgyal Wangchuk Trichen Lhagyari, My Country Is Tibet is the personal, rare and timely story of the exiled, teenage King of Tibet. Trichen (pronounced ‘TREE-chen’) introduces us to his friends, family and community members living in exile in India. We see their efforts to overcome the obliteration of their very identity – their culture, their languages, their freedom to choose where they live and work.



Trichen is the direct descendant of the great Kings of Tibet. Coronated by His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama, Trichen carries the unique responsibility of representing Tibet’s unbroken history and cultural heritage. Yet, as a teenager, he belongs to a new generation of young Tibetans caught today between the peaceful traditions of Tibetan Buddhism and a desperate desire to fight for their freedom and cultural identity.


Trichen was taught the art of filmmaking from BYkids Film Mentor, Dirk Simon, to make this award-winning documentary.




Tibet’s history is ancient, as is its spiritual tradition of Buddhism. Tibet lies on a high plateau between China and India. It is nicknamed "the Roof of the World” as Tibet is situated among the Himalayan mountains. Tibet is also the source of many of Asia’s important rivers including the Yellow River, the Mekong River, the Yangtze River, and the Indus River.



Traditionally, the Buddhist religious leader, the Dalai Lama, was also the political head of Tibet. But conflict between Tibet and China is part of the history of the region, and the Chinese Army claimed sovereignty over Tibet in 1951. In 1959, the Dalai Lama fled from Tibet to India, where many Tibetan refugees now live and where the Tibetan government-in-exile is based.




Population

Tibetan (2.5 million) Han Chinese (160 thousand)

Languages

Tibetan, Mandarin, English, Nepali, Hindi

Literacy Rate*

Tibetan (50%)

Major Industries

Agriculture (85%), Manufacture (3%), Geological prospecting (1%)

*age 6+ who can read & write




In 1950, China’s People’s Liberation Army entered an area of Tibet called Chamdo. Over the following decade, China defeated Tibetan opposition on multiple occasions. In 1959, China’s military attacked those who resisted the Chinese presence in Tibet. Fearing capture, the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibet, fled the country to India.


In 1965, the area of Tibet that had previously been under the control of the Dalai Lama became known as the Tibet Autonomous Region (TAR). As an Autonomous Region of China, Tibet is governed by the Chinese Communist Party. The role of Tibetans remains limited in the Chinese government.



In 1959, following the Dalai Lama’s flight to India, the Indian government agreed to accept Tibetan refugees. The Dalai Lama and the Tibetan government-in-exile are now based in Dharamsala, India.


Today, the Chinese government denies Tibetans space to develop and express their cultural and religious identities. Tibetans cannot study their religion or possess pictures of their spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama. Tibetans living in the TAR are not allowed to study the Tibetan language. Many Tibetan refugees are individuals who are seeking a Tibetan education.


There are an estimated 150,000 Tibetans living in exile with the largest communities living in India, Nepal, and Bhutan.



  1. Host a debate party and ask guests to share their thoughts about the topic of political refugees. What refugees are you aware of and how did you learn about them? What are the various political or social dynamics that have created large refugee populations around the globe? What rights do refugees have, what rights are they denied? Who are the refugees in your local community? What can individuals/communities do to help? As guests leave, hand out half-page flyers with information about the UN Refugee Agency (www.unhcr.org) so that they can get involved in the issues you've discussed together.


  1. Sign a petition or start your own to raise awareness about the plight of refugees around the world.  Visit: www.change.org/petitions (and search for "refugee")




Word

Definition

descendent

(adj) the children of a particular ancestor

exile

(noun, verb) the state of kicked out from and not allowed to return to one’s native country

heritage

(noun) someone that comes or belongs to one by birth, inherited

motherland

(noun) one’s native land

refugee

(noun) a person who flees for safety

sovereignty

(noun) have power of authority over something

title: Poet Against Prejudice
body_one:
Watch the film POET AGAINST PREJUDICE to learn about Faiza Almontaser. Faiza is a 17-year old immigrant from New York City. Faiza tells her story of courage, perseverance, and her fight to overcome prejudice. Explore Faiza’s story and talk with your PenPals about the importance of diversity.




Faiza Almontaser immigrated with her family to the United States from Yemen. Faize enrolled in a middle school in New York City. Faiza faced bullying because she was new and different.



Faiza explains what it means for a family to immigrate to the United States. Faiza shows us how it looks to live between two cultures and to deal with intense prejudice. Faiza’s film helps us think about religious tolerance, bias, immigration, activism and social change.


Mentored by Albert Maysles, Faiza shows us her courageous and inspiring journey from victim to activist.




Yemen is a country in West Asia. Yemen is bordered by Saudi Arabia, the Red Sea, the Gulf of Aden, the Arabian Sea, and Oman.


Yemen formed in 1990 when North Yemen and South Yemen joined to become the Republic of Yemen.



The population in Yemen is growing quickly. Because Yemen’s population is growing, the government is struggling to provide imortant educational and health services, drinking water and jobs.





The United States is a country in North America. The United States is bordered by Canada, Mexico, the Atlantic Ocean, and the Pacific Ocean.



Immigrants have lived in the United States for hundreds of year. During the colonial period,1600-1800, immigrants came to the United States from England and Western Europe. From 1830-1915, immigrants came to the United States from Europe and East Asia. The twentieth century saw immigrants from Eastern Europe. Today, many immigrants come to the United States from Latin America, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia.




Word

Definition

activist

(noun) a person who campaigns for a social change

bias

(noun) having a judgement about a group of people that is not fact based

immigrant

(noun) a person who comes to live permanently in a foreign country

immigrate

(verb) to move to a foreign country permanently

prejudice

(noun) having an idea about someone that is not based in reason
body_two:
Watch the film POET AGAINST PREJUDICE to learn about Faiza Almontaser. Faiza is a 17-year old immigrant from New York City. At age 10, Faiza enrolled in the sixth grade as the only Muslim in her school. In POET AGAINST PREJUDICE, Faiza tells her story of courage, perseverance, and her fight to overcome prejudice. As you explore her story, share your reactions with your PenPals and talk about the importance of diversity.




Faiza Almontaser immigrated with her family to the United States from Yemen. Faize enrolled in a middle school in New York City. Faiza faced bullying because of her Islamic identity and “otherness”.



Through the eyes of Faiza we learn what it means for a family to immigrate to America. Faiza shows us how it looks to navigate living in two cultures and to deal with intense Islamophobia. Faiza’s film helps us think about religious tolerance, bias, immigration, activism and social change.


Mentored by Albert Maysles, Faiza shows us her courageous and inspiring journey from victim to activist.





Yemen is a country in West Asia on the Arabian Peninsula. Yemen is bordered by Saudi Arabia to the north, the Red Sea to the west, the Gulf of Aden and the Arabian Sea to the south, and Oman to the East.


The current day country of Yemen formed in 1990 when North Yemen and South Yemen formed the Republic of Yemen. In 1994, the country of Yemen experienced a short civil war.



Yemen is one of the poorest countries in the Arab region. In Yemen there is high unemployment, particularly among young people and women.


The population in Yemen is expected to double in 20 years to around 40 million people. Because Yemen’s population is growing, the government is struggling to provide important educational and health services, drinking water and employment opportunities.



Population

26,737,317

Languages

Arabic

Age Structure

0-14 years: 41.09%

15-24 years: 21.12%

25-54 years: 31.33%

55-64 years: 3.79%

65 years and over: 2.67%

Life Expectancy

65 years

Literacy Rate*

70%

Major Industries

Oil, textiles, leather goods, food processing, cement, commercial ship repair

*age 15+ who can read & write





The United States is a country located in North America. The United States is bordered by Canada to the north and Mexico to the south. The United States borders the Atlantic Ocean to the east and the Pacific Ocean to the west.


The United States became an official country in 1776 after American colonists broke from British control. Among the most formative experiences in the history of the United States were the Civil War (1861-1865) and the Great Depression of the 1930s. During the civil war, the northern Union states defeated a secessionist movement by 11 southern slave states. The Great Depression was a time when a quarter or people in the United States lost their jobs. Today, the United States remains one of the most powerful nations in the world.



Immigrants have lived in the United States for hundreds of year. During the colonial period,1600-1800, hundreds of thousands of immigrants came to the United States from England and Western Europe. From 1830-1915, over 30 million immigrants came to the United States from Europe and East Asia. The twentieth century saw immigrants from Eastern Europe. Today, many immigrants come to the United States from Latin America, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia.



Population

321,368,864

Languages

English, Spanish, Chinese

Age Structure

0-14 years: 18.99%

15-24 years: 13.64%

25-54 years: 39.76%

55-64 years: 12.73%

65 years and over: 14.88%

Life Expectancy

79 years

Literacy Rate*

85%

Major Industries

Technology, petroleum, steel, motor vehicles, aerospace, chemicals, etc

*age 15+ who can read & write




  1. Do you see intolerance happening in your community? Get your school designated as a "No Place for Hate" school and help promote a culture of respect and dignity for your classmates, just like Faiza does in the film. See: www.adl.org/npfh/




Word

Definition

activist

(noun) a person who campaigns for a social change

bias

(noun) having a judgement about a group of people that is not fact based

formative

(adj) having a lasting impact on the development of something or someone

immigrant

(noun) a person who comes to live permanently in a foreign country

immigrate

(verb) to move to a foreign country permanently
body_three:
Watch the film POET AGAINST PREJUDICE to learn about Faiza Almontaser, a 17-year old immigrant from New York City.  At age 10, Faiza enrolled in the sixth grade as the only Muslim in her school. She had high hopes for her new education, but was soon discouraged by her minimal understanding of English and the anti-Islamic fervor she encountered among her classmates. As you explore her story, share your reactions with your PenPals and talk about the importance of diversity and the ways discrimination, xenophobia, impact people in your community.




Faiza Almontaser, a 17-year-old from New York City, immigrated with her family to the United States from Yemen when she was in middle school. Faiza faced vicious bullying because of her Islamic identity and “otherness”. Mentored by the legendary pioneer of direct cinema, Albert Maysles, Faiza shows us her courageous and inspiring journey from victim to activist.



Through the eyes of Faiza we learn what it means for a family to immigrate to America, to navigate living in two cultures and to deal with intense Islamophobia. Faiza’s film personally illuminates issues of religious tolerance, bias, immigration, activism and social change.




Yemen is a country in West Asia on the Arabian Peninsula. Yemen is bordered by Saudi Arabia to the north, the Red Sea to the west, the Gulf of Aden and the Arabian Sea to the south, and Oman to the East.


The current day country of Yemen formed in 1990 when North Yemen and South Yemen formed the Republic of Yemen. In 1994, the country of Yemen experienced a short civil war.



Yemen is one of the poorest countries in the Arab region. The Yemeni economy is caught in a jobless slow growth cycle leading to stagnant per capita incomes and rising levels of unemployment, particularly amongst the youth and women.


Yemen has one of the highest population growth rates globally, with a population expected to double in 23 years to around 40 million. The growth in Yemen’s population has lead to increases in the demand for educational and health services, drinking water and employment opportunities. Yemen faces a severe water shortage, with available ground water being depleted at an alarming rate due to the growing population.

26,737,317

Languages

Arabic

*age 15+ who can read & write





The United States is a country located in North America. The United States is bordered by Canada to the north and Mexico to the south. The United States borders the Atlantic Ocean to the east and the Pacific Ocean to the west.


The United States became a recognized nation in 1776 after American colonists broke from British control. Among the most formative experiences in the history of the United States were the Civil War (1861-1865) and the Great Depression of the 1930s. During the civil war, the northern Union states defeated a secessionist movement by 11 southern slave states. The Great Depression was a period when a quarter or people in the United States lost their jobs. Today, the United States remains one of the most powerful nations in the world.



Immigrants have been arriving in the United States for hundreds of year. During the colonial period,1600-1800, hundreds of thousands of immigrants came to the United States from England and Western Europe. From 1830-1915, over 30 million immigrants continued to come to the US from Europe and East Asia. The twentieth century saw a boom in immigrants from war-torn Eastern Europe. Today, many immigrants continue to come to the United States from Latin America, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia.

  2. Sign a petition or start one of your own to raise awareness about:
