title: PreWrite, Plan, and Peer Review
body_one:
Good writing always starts with a plan! In this lesson, you and your pen pal will start writing your own argument paragraph, and the process will start with a great plan! First, you and your pen pal will study an informal outline and the resulting argument paragraph. Then you and your pen pal will select an argument writing topic and begin your own informal outline. Finally, you and your pen pal will share outlines and give each other feedback.


Lesson Objectives:

  • Watch a short video to explore vocabulary related to argument writing

  • Discuss how an informal outline prepares a student to write an argument paragraph

  • Select an argument topic and complete an informal outline

  • Review your pen pal’s work and share your feedback



An informal outline is a great way to organize your ideas before writing! Identifying your topic early in the Writing Process will help you make the best argument. Below you will find an informal outline completed by a student. You will also find the paragraph this student wrote using the informal outline.


As you read the sample outline and paragraph, pay attention to the elements of argument writing. Where does this student make his or her claim? What evidence does this student use to support his or her claims? Does this student use the same information from the outline in the argument paragraph? What role do transitions words play in making this paragraph enjoyable to read?


Study the outline below and read the resulting paragraph. Then, talk with your pen pal to explore how the outline and paragraph are related.




Sports Drinks: Not Worth the $$$


       TV commercials for sports drinks try to make the viewer think that using the products will turn ordinary people into superheroes. Sports drinks are, in fact, an expensive and unnecessary sideshow. First of all, food provides the energy the body needs for exercise: energy which is stored as glucose in our cells. Glucose is mostly formed from carbohydrates that we get from food and drink. If we have a healthy diet, our bodies should already have enough glucose stored for ninety minutes of exercise. Most sports drinks contain a little salt and carbohydrates in the form of sugar—pretty normal ingredients. Also, sports drinks are expensive. Why are people willing to hand over a couple of dollars for a sports drink? Maybe because friends drink it, or ads give them hope the drink will give them an edge. It won’t. Some experts argue that sports drinks can be helpful for endurance athletes. The drinks taste good, so a long-distance runner may drink more and stay better hydrated, for example. However, these athletes could stay equally hydrated with water. Athletes who exercise hard for more than 90 minutes can restore some energy they have burned by consuming a sports drink. These competitors could also restore energy by eating a banana or some other healthy snack. Besides, most people aren’t endurance athletes. The truth is, sports drinks exist so people can make money by selling what is basically colored sugar water. For most people out for a bike ride or neighborhood pickup game, drinking free tap water and eating a healthy diet will give them everything they need plus a little more money in their pockets.


Complete the Questions for Part 1 before moving on to Part 2!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)



After studying the informal outline and argument paragraphs in Part 1, it’s now your turn to begin your informal outline.


Argument Writing Topics



Now that you have explored and selected a topic, answer the questions below to help you complete an informal outline.



Complete the Questions for Part 2 before moving on to Part 3!

(Questions are located at the bottom of this page)



Peer Review is an important part of the Writing Process. When writers work together, excellent writing happens! When you share your ideas with a friend, parent, teacher, or pen pal, you will be able to think about new ideas and better understand your current ideas. When other writers read your work, they will also help you find hard-to-catch mistakes.


Remember that the goal of argument writing is to convince an audience of your position. By letting a peer give you feedback and ask questions during the writing process, you will be better prepared to convince an audience.


Directions: Review the roles of a peer reviewer. Then, study your pen pal’s informal outline. Celebrate your pen pal’s great ideas! Ask questions about the ideas you find confusing. Last, thank your pen pal for the feedback he or she shares on your own writing!



Complete the questions located at the bottom of this page! After answering each of your questions, read and respond to your pen pal’s answers!



Word

Definition

convince

(verb) to make someone firmly agree with or believe something

current

(adj) the quality of something happening in the present or right now

feedback

(noun) a respectful response to someone else’s work

informal

(adj) unofficial

peer

(noun) a person of similar age and ability

title: Mahatma Gandhi: The Great One
body_one:
Gandhi’s Early Years in South Africa


Mahatma Gandhi was born in India in 1869. Gandhi studied law in London, England. In 1893, when he was 24 years old, he came to South Africa to help Indians fight discrimination.


People recognize Mahatma Gandhi around the world


How Did Gandhi Fight Discrimination in South Africa?


Gandhi helped to start the Natal Indian Congress (NIC). The NIC was a group of people who fought for equality in South Africa. Indians in South Africa formed the largest Indian community outside of India.


Unfortunately, Indians faced discrimination from the Dutch and British.  Indians were forced to carry passes. They were limited in their right to vote. Indians were also not allowed to work in certain jobs.


Gandhi as a young lawyer in South Africa, 1906


The NIC fought for Indian rights through passive resistance.  This means they resisted through peace instead of violence.


In 1908, the government discriminated against South African Indians.  The government passed a law that forced the colony’s Indian population to carry passes.


Gandhi helped South African Indians protest the new law in many ways.  Gandhi organized protests where people refused to sign-up for passes.  He also helped people burn their passes and use other non-violent resistance.


This is how Gandhi described a pass-burning protest:



A pass burning protest in South Africa


Gandhi was arrested many times in South Africa, for his role in passive resistance to discrimination.


Gandhi’s work in South Africa was an important example for future fights against discrimination.  Groups of people around the world follow Gandhi's example and use non-violent resistance to fight discrimination.


Gandhi helped many people through non-violence protest


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

equality

(noun) when people are equal and have the same rights

law

(noun) the system of rules that tell people how a government should work

passes

(noun) internal passport documents required by ‘non-white’ South Africans from 1797 onwards, restricting their movement around South Africa

resistance

(noun) to refuse something with actions

right

(noun) a moral and legal ability or status that applies to everyone
body_two:
Gandhi’s Early Years in South Africa


Mahatma Gandhi was born in India in 1869. Gandhi studied law in London, England. In 1893, when he was 24 years old, he came to South Africa to help Indians resist discrimination.


When Gandhi traveled to South Africa, he experienced the discrimination directed at Indians and at black people. These experiences led him to become a social activist. Gandhi spent the next 21 years of his life fighting discrimination in South Africa before going back to India.


Mahatma Gandhi is recognised by many people around the world. He is seen here with a spinning wheel, which for him, was a symbol of freedom


How Did Gandhi Fight Discrimination in South Africa?


The Natal Indian Congress (NIC) was an important group of people who fought for racial equality in South Africa. Gandhi was one of the founders of the NIC. Under his leadership, the NIC organised many protests. The NIC formed in 1894 to gather Indians who opposed racial discrimination in the South African.


Many Indian people were living in South Africa had been brought to South Africa from 1860 onwards as indentured labour. These indentured Indians, together with other Indians who came to South Africa freely, formed the largest Indian community outside of India.


Indians were forced to carry passes. They were limited in their right to vote, and Indians were prohibited from working in certain jobs.


Gandhi as a young lawyer in South Africa, 1906


The NIC campaigned for Indian rights. The passive resistance campaigns of Gandhi and the NIC persuaded the government that Indians did not have to carry passes in Natal.


In 1908, the Transvaal government once again discriminated against South African Indians.  The government passed laws that forced the colony’s Indian population to register for passes. Gandhi called on Indians living in South Africa to protest the new law in many ways.  Gandhi organized protests where people refused to register, burned their passes and used non-violent resistance.


At a mass protest meeting held in Johannesburg on 11 September 1908, hundreds of Indians gathered outside a mosque to protest against a law that forced Indians to carry passes.

This is how Gandhi described the pass-burning protest:



A pass burning protest in South Africa


Gandhi was arrested on numerous occasions in South Africa, for his role in passive resistance to discrimination.


Gandhi’s presence in South Africa between 1893 and 1914 had an important influence on the country, especially in terms of using non-violent resistance to fight discrimination. As President Mandela said in 1996, “When we adopted passive resistance that was a direct result of what Gandhi had done.”


Gandhi successfully transformed the ethic of non-violence into a powerful political instrument


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

activist

(noun) a person who actively works for a fair and just world

campaign

(noun) work organized to result in a shared goal

equality

(noun) having equal rights and access to opportunities

founder

(noun) a person who establishes or starts something

indentured labour

(noun) contracted to work for no pay, in exchange for transport to a new country

passes

(noun) internal passport documents required by ‘non-white’ South Africans from 1797 onwards, restricting their movement around South Africa
body_three:
Gandhi’s Formative Years in South Africa


Mahatma Gandhi was born in India in 1869. He studied law in London. In 1893, when he was 24 years old, he came to South Africa to help Indians resist the anti-Indian legislation that was rife at the time. He experienced the discrimination directed at Indians in particular and at black people generally. These experiences led him to become a social activist, fighting for the rights of the oppressed in South Africa. He spent the next 21 years of his life fighting discrimination in South Africa before going back to India.


Mahatma Gandhi is possibly the most recognised political icon of all time. He is seen here with a spinning wheel, which for him was a symbol of freedom.


How Did Gandhi Fight Discrimination in South Africa?


The Natal Indian Congress (NIC) was an important influence in the development of a non-racial African nationalism in South Africa. It was formed in 1894 to mobilise Indian opposition to the racial discrimination in the colony. Indians were forced to carry passes that restricted their movement around the country. Indians were limited in their right to vote, and were also prohibited from working in certain industries.


Gandhi was one of the founders of the NIC. Under his leadership, the NIC organised many protests. Many Indian people were living in South Africa at the time, as they had been brought to South Africa from 1860 onwards as indentured labour, to work on the sugar cane plantations. These indentured Indians, together with other Indians who came to South Africa freely, formed the foundation of what would become the largest Indian community outside of India.


Gandhi as a young lawyer in South Africa, 1906


The NIC campaigned for Indian rights. The passive resistance campaigns of Gandhi and the NIC succeeded in Indians not having to carry passes in Natal, but failed to win them full citizenship rights.


Gandhi founded the Transvaal Indian Congress (TIC) in 1903. The TIC was involved in the Gandhi Passive Resistance Campaigns of 1908 and 1913.


The Transvaal government passed the Asiatic Registration Act in 1908, forcing the colony’s Indian population to register. Gandhi called on Indians living in South Africa to defy the new law through strikes, refusing to register, burning their registration cards and other forms of non-violent resistance.


At a mass protest meeting held in Johannesburg on 11 September 1908, hundreds of Indians gathered outside a mosque to protest against a law that forced Indians to carry passes. Gandhi said they should suffer the punishment for doing these non-violent things, rather than resist through violent means. In this way, Gandhi laid the foundations for early forms of black resistance to segregation and apartheid, which were largely non-violent.

This is how Gandhi described the pass-burning protest against Ordinance 29:



A pass burning protest in South Africa


Gandhi led the Satyagraha Campaign of 1913–1914. A satyagrahi is a person who has dedicated him- or herself to truth. The Satyagraha Campaign was a campaign of passive political resistance aimed to resist the unjust Acts against Indian South Africans.
Gandhi was arrested on numerous occasions in South Africa, for his role in passive resistance to discrimination.


Gandhi’s presence in South Africa between 1893 and 1914 had an important influence on the country, especially in terms of using non-violent resistance to fight discrimination against Indians. As President Mandela said in 1996, “When we adopted passive resistance that was a direct result of what Gandhi had done.”


Gandhi successfully transformed the ethic of non-violence into a powerful political instrument


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

activist

(noun) a person who actively works for a fair and just world

indentured labour

(noun) contracted to work for no pay, in exchange for transport to a new country

legislation

(noun) laws; legal systems

mobilise

(verb) to give movement to; to prepare an army for action

passes

(noun) internal passport documents required by ‘non-white’ South Africans from 1797 onwards, restricting their movement around South Africa

title: A World of News
body_one:
A World of News


People get the news in different ways! Some people read the newspaper every morning. Others get the news from television or radio.


Today, more and more people read the news online. Some people even get their news from social media platforms like facebook and twitter.


People around the world get their news in different ways

Credit: (Mick Baker)rooster via flickr


Over the past five weeks, you and your pen pal explored stories from around the world. You learned about the environment, poverty, technology, conflict, and government. You shared stories from your own communities.


This week, you and your pen pal will create a news story of your own!


Let’s Tell a Story


Use the chart to learn about some of the pieces the make a great story!

Headline

Headlines should make your reader feel excited! A headline tells your audience what the story is about.

Images

Most news stories use pictures and text to tell a story. A good picture can help tell a story by showing vocabulary or people from the story.

Story

A good story is something that your audience finds interesting and important. A news story shares information and tells a story.

Sources

and

Evidence

A credible source is someone who has first-hand experience with the story.

Call to Action

The call to action explains why you told the story. The call to action helps your audience care about the topic.


Read this story about Ruby Bridges and look for each piece of a news story.

A Simple Act of Courage: The Story of Ruby Bridges


  


November 14, 1960


New Orleans, United States - The people of New Orleans face a challenge. An African-American person is allowed to go to an all-white school. The girl is named Ruby Bridges.  Ruby is six years old.  Her first day of school at William Frantz Elementary School is today.


The community in New Orleans is split in two.  Some people think that African-Americans should not be allowed to go to school with white kids. However, there are some who insist that race should play no part in education, and that this kind of discrimination is not welcome in the United States.


Ruby Bridges may not be the biggest or most experienced champion of civil rights, but she will rely on the support of her community and family during this challenging time.
body_two:
A World of News


People around the world get the news in different ways! Some people read the newspaper every morning. Others get the news from television or radio. Today, more and more people read the news online from publications, and blogs. Some people even get their news from social media platforms like snapchat, facebook, and twitter.


No matter how people in your community get their news, the news plays an important role in our daily lives.  Through news we learn about the world. We discover events that impact people around the world. We learn about arts, literature, and the entertainment industry.


People around the world get their news in different ways

Credit: (Mick Baker)rooster via flickr


Over the past five weeks, you and your pen pal have explored stories from all around the world. You learned about the environment, poverty, technology, conflict, and government. You have shared stories from your own communities.


This week, you and your pen pal will create a news story of your own! First, you will study the pieces that make a news story. Then, you will share your story with your pen pal!


Let’s Tell a Story


News happens all around you. Use the chart to learn about some of the pieces the make a great story! Remember, you can always find examples of these concepts in the articles from this course!

Headline

Headlines are very important. Your headline should be unique and specific. It should make your reader feel a sense of urgency, and tell your audience what the story is about.

Images

Most news stories use pictures and text to tell a story. A good picture can brighten a page and make your reader want to learn more about the story. The picture itself can help tell the story by showing important vocabulary or people from the story.

Story

A good story will be something that your audience finds interesting and important. A great news article combines relevant information and a relatable story. Great news does more than just describe the story, it makes the audience care about the topic.

Credible Sources

and

Evidence

A credible source is someone who has first-hand experience with the story. If the source did not experience the event first hand, he or she may be an expert who has studied the topic.

Call to Action

A call to action is more than just a conclusion. The call to action should highlight your reason for telling the story. The call to action should also motivate your audience to care about the topic.


Read this story about Ruby Bridges and look for each piece of a news story.

A Simple Act of Courage: The Story of Ruby Bridges


  


November 14, 1960


New Orleans, United States - The people of New Orleans face a challenge. An African-American person is allowed to go to an all-white school. The girl is named Ruby Bridges.  Ruby is six years old.  Her first day of school at William Frantz Elementary School is today.


The community in New Orleans is split in two.  Some people think that African-Americans should not be allowed to go to school with white kids. However, there are some who insist that race should play no part in education, and that this kind of discrimination is not welcome in the United States.


Ruby Bridges may not be the biggest or most experienced champion of civil rights, but she will rely on the support of her community and family during this challenging time.

title: The World Through My Eyes
body_one:
You and your PenPals have explored the lives of five inspiring kids from around the world! Now, it’s your turn to share their message! This week, you and your PenPals will make a plan to share one of the BYkids films your community!




Pick the BYkids film that you will show to members of your community. Why do you want to show this BYkids film to the members of your community? What themes or lessons from the video do you want to emphasize?


Who is your audience? Will you share this BYkids story with students from another class? Members of your family? A club, youth group or religious organization? Why should this audience watch the BYkids film you chose?


Now, let’s think about how to introduce the film to your audience. Some students might want to make a poster. Others might create a flyer, podcast, radio announcement, or even a video. Remember, you can find previews of all five BYkids films on the BYkids website!


Last, it is time for your event! As you share the BYkids film. What questions will you ask before and after the screening? What challenges do you think might come up?


After the BYkids film screening, reflect on the event with your pen pal. How did it go? What did you learn? Was your audience interested in the movie? What might you do differently next time?
body_two:
You and your PenPals have explored the lives of five inspiring kids from around the world! You watched five videos created by inspiring young people. You learned about different communities around the world and the struggles people face every day. Now, it’s your turn to share their message! This week, you and your PenPals will make a plan to share one of the BYkids films your community!




First, pick the film that you will share with members of your community. Consider why  you want to show this BYkids film to the members of your community? What themes or lessons from the video do you want to emphasize?


Who is your audience? Will you share this BYkids story with students from another classroom or school? Members of your family? A club, youth group, sports team or religious organization?



Now, let’s think about how to introduce the film to your audience. Some students might want to make a poster. Others might create a flyer, podcast, radio announcement, or even a video. Remember, you can find previews of all five BYkids films on the BYkids website!


You may want to create a blog post to introduce the BYkids film you chose to share. Include information about the BYkids director, the film itself, and key themes or issues addressed in the film. Include links to advocacy groups that can help your audience take action.



It is time for your event! As you share the BYkids film, what questions will you ask before and after the screening? What challenges do you think might come up?



After the BYkids film screening, reflect on the event with your pen pal. How did it go? What did you learn? Was your audience interested in the movie? What might you do differently next time?

title: A Pollinator Problem
body_one:
A new report warns that animals responsible for pollinating plants are in danger. That could mean big problems for the world’s food supply.


By Heather Price-Wright, with AP reporting

March 14, 2016


There are about 20,000 species of pollinators on Earth. They include bees, butterflies, moths, bats, and birds. They are important to the world’s food supply. Pollinators help fertilize more than 75% of the world’s edible crops. But a new report from the United Nations says these vital critters are in trouble.


ANTHONY MERCIECA—GETTY IMAGES


A broad-billed hummingbird flits near a flower in Arizona.


The report draws from about 3,000 scientific studies. It concludes that two-fifths of invertebrate pollinators are in danger of becoming extinct. These include bees and butterflies. One out of every six vertebrate pollinators, like bats and birds, is also facing extinction.


GETTY IMAGES


Vertebrate pollinators, like this lesser bare-backed fruit bat, are important to the world’s food supply.


The scientists who wrote the U.N. report offer many reasons for pollinators’ dire situation. Changing agricultural practices play a role. Pesticide use is also a factor. So are habitat loss, disease, and climate change. In the U.S., large-scale growth of single crops is a main culprit. Too much land is given over to just one crop. Pollinators that rely on wild plants and require biodiversity in their diets suffer.


KERSTIN KLAASSEN—GETTY IMAGES


Bees and other pollinators are threatened by a variety of forces, including habitat loss, disease, and global warming.


Global warming can hurt pollinators in several ways. One problem is that a change in climate can affect when flowers bloom. They may bloom too early. Their timing can then get out of sync with pollinators’ habits. This threatens the survival of both plant and animal.


Pesticides, too, hurt pollinators. Insecticides can harm or kill bees and other insects. it can also limit their ability to reproduce. And herbicides can wipe out the wild plants many pollinators rely on for food.


Solutions Close to Home


Researchers say there is some good news. People can help protect these creatures. Some problems, like global warming, require cooperation between nations. But local groups and even individuals can make a difference for pollinators. For example, residents of some parts of Britain are being encouraged to grow wildflowers in their yards. This is intended to lure bees back. “There are relatively simple … [ways to turn] the trend around for native pollinators,” says David Inouye of the University of Maryland. He worked on the U.N. report.


The study recommends relying more on sustainable indigenous farming practices. “These practices include traditional farming systems [and] maintenance of diverse landscapes and gardens,” the report states. Rather than planting the same crop on the same land every season, farmers can rotate them. Dividing large pieces of land into smaller plots of different crops could also help.


JACKY PARKER—GETTY IMAGES


A swallowtail butterfly pauses on a flower.


Averting a Crisis


People around the world must step in soon to help pollinators. If they don't, the consequences could be extreme. Without these creatures, much of our food would become difficult or impossible to grow. “Everything falls apart if you take pollinators out of the game,” says Dennis vanEngelsdorp. He is a University of Maryland bee expert.


Whole Foods created this photo to show how much produce would disappear from regular supermarkets if pollinators went extinct.


COURTESY WHOLE FOODS MARKET


Whole Foods created this photo to show how much produce would disappear from regular supermarkets if pollinators went extinct.


“There are going to be increasing consequences,” agrees the report’s lead author, Simon Potts. He is the director of the Centre for Agri-Environmental Research at the University of Reading, in England.


The problem is also an economic one. Crops that rely on pollinators account for between $235 billion and $577 billion in revenue, globally. And those numbers are only going to get bigger. The report notes that in the last 50 years, the amount of agricultural production that depends on pollinators has increased 300%. Most people on Earth rely on some pollinator-supported crop for food. “If we want to say we can feed the world in 2050, pollinators are going to be part of that,” vanEngelsdorp says.


Vocabulary

Word

Definition

biodiversity

noun: the existence of many different species of plants and animals in an environment

extinct

adjective: when all members in an animal group have died

indigenous

adjective: produced or occurring naturally in, or native to, a particular place

invertebrate

adjective: lacking a backbone

pollinator

noun: an animal that helps plants reproduce by moving pollen from one plant to another

revenue

noun: money made by businesses

If people around the world don’t step in soon to help pollinators, the consequences could be extreme. Without these creatures, much of our food would become difficult or impossible to grow. “Everything falls apart if you take pollinators out of the game,” says Dennis vanEngelsdorp. He is a University of Maryland bee expert.

The problem is an economic one, as well. Crops that rely on pollinators account for between $235 billion and $577 billion in revenue, globally. And those numbers are only going to get bigger. The report notes that in the last 50 years, the amount of agricultural production that depends on pollinators has increased 300%. Most people on Earth rely on some pollinator-supported crop for food. “If we want to say we can feed the world in 2050, pollinators are going to be part of that,” vanEngelsdorp says.

Definition

noun: the existence of many different species of plants and animals in an environment

indigenous

adjective: produced or occurring naturally in, or native to, a particular place

invertebrate

adjective: lacking a backbone
